text_human: Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two at home and two away, with the exception of two teams each year who play a fifth game, the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition games, most of which are held in the month of August, are played for the purpose of helping coaches narrow down the roster from the offseason limit of 90 players to the regular-season limit of 53 players. While the scheduling formula is not as rigid for preseason games as they are for the regular season, there are numerous restrictions and traditions that limit the choices of preseason opponents; teams are also restricted on what days and times they can play these games. Split-squad games, a practice common in baseball and hockey, where a team that is scheduled to play two games on the same day splits their team into two squads, are prohibited. The NFL has played exhibition games in Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia (including the American Bowl in 1999) and Mexico to spread the league's popularity (a game of this type was proposed for China but, due to financial and logistical problems, was eventually canceled). The league has tacitly forbidden the playing of non-league opponents, with the last interleague game having come in 1972 and the last game against a team other than an NFL team (the all-NFL rookie College All-Stars) was held in 1976. Exhibition games are quite unpopular with many fans, who resent having to pay regular-season prices for two home exhibition games as part of a season-ticket package. Numerous lawsuits have been brought by fans and classes of fans against the NFL or its member teams regarding this practice, but none have been successful in halting it.[citation needed] The Pro Bowl, traditionally played after the end of the NFL season (since 2011 is played the week prior to the Super Bowl), is also considered an exhibition game.
text_ai_base: Compared to other team sports, the National Football League (NFL) preseason is highly structured. Each NFL team typically plays four preseason exhibition games: two at home and two away. However, two teams play a fifth game in the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition matches, mostly held in August, help coaches reduce the roster from 90 offseason players to the regular-season limit of 53. Although the scheduling for preseason games is less rigid than the regular season, there are many restrictions and traditions that influence opponent selection and game timing. Unlike baseball and hockey, where split-squad games are common, the NFL prohibits teams from splitting their roster to play two games in one day. The NFL has hosted exhibition games in locations such as Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico to expand the league's global reach. A game was once proposed for China but was canceled due to financial and logistical difficulties. Playing against non-league teams is largely forbidden since the last such game occurred in 1972, and the last non-NFL opponent was the College All-Stars in 1976. Many fans dislike exhibition games, as they are required to pay regular-season prices for them within season-ticket packages, leading to numerous, albeit unsuccessful, lawsuits against the NFL. The Pro Bowl, considered an exhibition game, traditionally occurs after the season ends, though since 2011, it has been played the week before the Super Bowl.
text_ai_humanized: The National Football League preseason is highly structured in comparison to Major League Baseball, with the 32 teams each playing 4 games, 2 each home and away, with two of the teams each playing a fifth game, the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. The games are contested in August, with the training camp in the 4–5 weeks before that, to determine the rosters for the regular season. Each team is allowed to have 90 players on its roster at the start of training camp. By the end of preseason, teams must reduce their rosters to 53 players for the regular season. Though the games' lack of local or national relevance lends some latitude in scheduling, there remain many longstanding restrictions and traditions concerning when, where and against whom a given team will play. Unlike professional baseball and basketball, where teams regularly play exhibition games against non-league teams (and in the case of baseball, allow outside teams to host the major league team as part of a larger event), non-league games in the NFL are exceptionally rare; since a last-ever game against an independent team in 1972, the last non-NFL opposition of any kind came in 1976, and the last time an NFL team was ever the guest even was in 1974 (all but one such case have come in the preseason). Also, unlike baseball and basketball games (but similar to professional hockey), teams will not use split squad games to try out more players, instead the entire team being limited in the number of exhibition games they may play.[3] Games have been played in locations such as Europe, Japan, and Canada as an effort to promote the league worldwide, as well as Mexico and Australia; China was once proposed (and a game was scheduled), but a prospective game there eventually was canceled due to financial and logistical difficulties. Since the debut of the International Series, all games in the series have been regular-season games. Playing time in the preseason is allotted more equally to allow coaches to evaluate the entire roster, especially the second- and third-string players. Star and veteran players typically play sparingly if at all in preseason games, while rookies may play most of the game and typically see more playing time during the preseason than they would in the regular season. Many fans object to exhibition games, as players have suffered injuries in them and season ticket holders are required to purchase them as part of their ticket package, while under most circumstances, fans who buy individual tickets to those games are required to pay the full regular-season price.[4] Numerous lawsuits have been filed against the NFL over the matter, but to date, none have been successful. Alongside preseason exhibition, another exhibition game of sorts is the Pro Bowl. Since 1970 the Pro Bowl has been played at the conclusion of the season (now referred to as an "exhibition game" though the league awarded a now-meaningless "conference championship" to the winning team through the 2009 Pro Bowl). Since 2011, the Pro Bowl has been played the week prior to the Super Bowl.

text_human: The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 m2 (830,000 sq ft) of floorspace. The floor area is smaller than the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, or the Forbidden City. There are 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The principal rooms are contained on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade at the rear of the palace. The centre of this ornate suite of state rooms is the Music Room, its large bow the dominant feature of the façade. Flanking the Music Room are the Blue and the White Drawing Rooms. At the centre of the suite, serving as a corridor to link the state rooms, is the Picture Gallery, which is top-lit and 55 yards (50 m) long. The Gallery is hung with numerous works including some by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens and Vermeer; other rooms leading from the Picture Gallery are the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room. The Green Drawing Room serves as a huge anteroom to the Throne Room, and is part of the ceremonial route to the throne from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase. The Guard Room contains white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, in Roman costume, set in a tribune lined with tapestries. These very formal rooms are used only for ceremonial and official entertaining, but are open to the public every summer.

text_human: As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. The other, al-Azhar, did acquire this status in name and essence only in the course of numerous reforms during the 19th and 20th century, notably the one of 1961 which introduced non-religious subjects to its curriculum, such as economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture. It should also be noted that many medieval universities were run for centuries as Christian cathedral schools or monastic schools prior to their formal establishment as universitas scholarium; evidence of these immediate forerunners of the university dates back to the 6th century AD, thus well preceding the earliest madaris. George Makdisi, who has published most extensively on the topic concludes in his comparison between the two institutions:

This designation allowed donors and their descendants to retain control, leading to a boom in establishing madrasas during the 11th and 12th centuries. Conversely, in Western Islamic areas, the Maliki school's prohibition on donor control over endowments made madrasas less prevalent. Unlike Western educational institutions with corporate status, the waqf model often excluded non-orthodox subjects like philosophy and natural sciences from madrasa curricula. The Madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two remaining madrasas predating the earliest medieval universities, has been recognized as an official university only since 1947. The other, al-Azhar, achieved university status through reforms in the 19th and 20th centuries, specifically in 1961, when it included secular subjects like economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture in its curriculum. Historically, many medieval universities functioned for centuries as Christian cathedral or monastic schools before formally becoming universitas scholarium, with their origins traceable to the 6th century AD, predating even the earliest madrasas. Scholar George Makdisi, who has extensively studied this topic, concludes in his comparison between these two types of educational institutions:

text_human: The '98 season would begin on a somber note with the death of legendary broadcaster Harry Caray. After the retirement of Sandberg and the trade of Dunston, the Cubs had holes to fill and the signing of Henry Rodríguez, known affectionately as "H-Rod" to bat cleanup provided protection for Sammy Sosa in the lineup, as Rodriguez slugged 31 round-trippers in his first season in Chicago. Kevin Tapani led the club with a career high 19 wins, Rod Beck anchored a strong bullpen and Mark Grace turned in one of his best seasons. The Cubs were swamped by media attention in 1998, and the team's two biggest headliners were Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood. Wood's signature performance was one-hitting the Houston Astros, a game in which he tied the major league record of 20 strikeouts in nine innings. His torrid strikeout numbers earned Wood the nickname "Kid K," and ultimately earned him the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs in the month, and his home run race with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire transformed the pair into international superstars in a matter of weeks. McGwire finished the season with a new major league record of 70 home runs, but Sosa's .308 average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award. After a down-to-the-wire Wild Card chase with the San Francisco Giants, Chicago and San Francisco ended the regular season tied, and thus squared off in a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field in which third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the eventual game winning homer. The win propelled the Cubs into the postseason once again with a 90–73 regular season tally. Unfortunately, the bats went cold in October, as manager Jim Riggleman's club batted .183 and scored only four runs en route to being swept by Atlanta. On a positive note, the home run chase between Sosa, McGwire and Ken Griffey, Jr. helped professional baseball to bring in a new crop of fans as well as bringing back some fans who had been disillusioned by the 1994 strike. The Cubs retained many players who experienced career years in '98, and after a fast start in 1999, they collapsed again (starting with being swept at the hands of the cross-town White Sox in mid-June) and finished in the bottom of the division for the next two seasons.

text_human: Despite efforts to revive Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, knowledge of the language is not commonly possessed by Jews worldwide and English has emerged as the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora. Although many Jews once had sufficient knowledge of Hebrew to study the classic literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were commonly used as recently as the early 20th century, most Jews lack such knowledge today and English has by and large superseded most Jewish vernaculars. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today are Hebrew, English, and Russian. Some Romance languages, particularly French and Spanish, are also widely used. Yiddish has been spoken by more Jews in history than any other language, but it is far less used today following the Holocaust and the adoption of Modern Hebrew by the Zionist movement and the State of Israel. In some places, the mother language of the Jewish community differs from that of the general population or the dominant group. For example, in Quebec, the Ashkenazic majority has adopted English, while the Sephardic minority uses French as its primary language. Similarly, South African Jews adopted English rather than Afrikaans. Due to both Czarist and Soviet policies, Russian has superseded Yiddish as the language of Russian Jews, but these policies have also affected neighboring communities. Today, Russian is the first language for many Jewish communities in a number of Post-Soviet states, such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan, as well as for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Although communities in North Africa today are small and dwindling, Jews there had shifted from a multilingual group to a monolingual one (or nearly so), speaking French in Algeria, Morocco, and the city of Tunis, while most North Africans continue to use Arabic as their mother tongue.[citation needed]

Currently, the top languages spoken by Jews are Hebrew, English, and Russian, with French and Spanish also widely used among some Jewish communities. Historically, more Jews have spoken Yiddish than any other language, but its usage has declined significantly post-Holocaust, with Modern Hebrew’s adoption by the Zionist movement and Israel. In some regions, the Jewish community's predominant language differs from that of the wider population. In Russia, both Czarist and Soviet policies shifted Jew's language from Yiddish to Russian, influencing neighboring communities as well. Today, Russian is the primary language for many Jewish communities in post-Soviet areas like Ukraine, Uzbekistan, and for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Though North African Jewish communities are currently small and shrinking, they transitioned from multilingualism to speaking predominantly French in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, whereas most North Africans continued using Arabic as their native language.

text_human: Terry Eastland, the author who wrote From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice states, "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity". Eastland believes that the founders of affirmative action did not anticipate how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it, mostly middle class minorities. Additionally, she argues that affirmative action carries with it a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities. Eastland believes that affirmative action is a great risk that only sometimes pays off, and that without it we would be able to compete more freely with one another. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell identified what he says are negative results of affirmative action in his book, Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study. Sowell writes that affirmative action policies encourage non-preferred groups to designate themselves as members of preferred groups [i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action] to take advantage of group preference policies; that they tend to benefit primarily the most fortunate among the preferred group (e.g., upper and middle class blacks), often to the detriment of the least fortunate among the non-preferred groups (e.g., poor white or Asian); that they reduce the incentives of both the preferred and non-preferred to perform at their best – the former because doing so is unnecessary and the latter because it can prove futile – thereby resulting in net losses for society as a whole; and that they engender animosity toward preferred groups as well.:115–147
text_ai_base: In "Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," Terry Eastland discusses the primary justifications for affirmative action: correcting past discrimination and promoting diversity. Eastland argues that affirmative action’s founders did not foresee how its benefits would predominantly aid those who do not truly need it, namely middle-class minorities. She also believes that affirmative action perpetuates a stigma, fostering feelings of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities. According to Eastland, these measures pose considerable risks and only occasionally yield positive outcomes. She suggests that removing affirmative action would enable more open competition. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell echoes similar concerns in "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," where he highlights negative consequences of affirmative action. Sowell claims such policies prompt non-preferred groups to identify themselves as members of preferred groups to benefit from preferential treatment. He notes that affirmative action largely benefits the privileged members of preferred groups, like upper and middle-class blacks, while neglecting less fortunate individuals from non-preferred groups, such as impoverished whites or Asians. Furthermore, Sowell argues that these policies decrease the incentives for both preferred and non-preferred groups to strive for excellence; the former because it’s unnecessary, and the latter because it seems pointless. Ultimately, this leads to societal losses and breeds animosity towards preferred groups.

She contends, however, that this was not the intended form of AA, The architects of affirmative action did not realize that its benefits would flow chiefly to precisely those individuals who did not need them-the middle-class minority. She also maintains that AA affixes a label of stigma, entitlement and self-doubt for these minorities. Eastland concludes with her belief that AA has posed significant risks with occasional rewards, She implies that if AA is ended, competition will become fairer. The libertarian economist Thomas Sowell has suggested another potential harm within AA in his book, Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study. Sowell argues that AA has prompted non-preferred groups (like whites and Asians) to self-identify as preferred groups and that the latter is the most beneficial from AA. He also argues that due to privilege gained by AA, this policy has succeeded in benefiting the most privileged (upper and middle-classed blacks) of the preferred group whereas the non-preferred group (poor whites or Asians) has not had this luxury. Sowell continues with the impact of AA and its impacted groups. He believes that AA has minimized the motives to succeed for both groups: the former because they don't need to and the latter because they feel that there is no point. These combined effects minimized the possible gains of society and causes resentment of preferred groups.

text_human: Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not diplomatic delegations at all, that Tibetan areas were ruled by the Ming since Tibetan leaders were granted positions as Ming officials, that horses were collected from Tibet as a mandatory "corvée" tax, and therefore Tibetans were "undertaking domestic affairs, not foreign diplomacy". Sperling writes that the Ming simultaneously bought horses in the Kham region while fighting Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing. He also argues that the embassies of Tibetan lamas visiting the Ming court were for the most part efforts to promote commercial transactions between the lamas' large, wealthy entourage and Ming Chinese merchants and officials. Kolmaš writes that while the Ming maintained a laissez-faire policy towards Tibet and limited the numbers of the Tibetan retinues, the Tibetans sought to maintain a tributary relationship with the Ming because imperial patronage provided them with wealth and power. Laird writes that Tibetans eagerly sought Ming court invitations since the gifts the Tibetans received for bringing tribute were much greater in value than the latter. As for the Yongle Emperor's gifts to his Tibetan and Nepalese vassals such as silver wares, Buddha relics, utensils for Buddhist temples and religious ceremonies, and gowns and robes for monks, Tsai writes "in his effort to draw neighboring states to the Ming orbit so that he could bask in glory, the Yongle Emperor was quite willing to pay a small price". The Information Office of the State Council of the PRC lists the Tibetan tribute items as oxen, horses, camels, sheep, fur products, medical herbs, Tibetan incenses, thangkas (painted scrolls), and handicrafts; while the Ming awarded Tibetan tribute-bearers an equal value of gold, silver, satin and brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves. Silk workshops during the Ming also catered specifically to the Tibetan market with silk clothes and furnishings featuring Tibetan Buddhist iconography.

Ming silk workshops also catered to the Tibetan market with silk garments and furnishings adorned with Tibetan Buddhist designs.

text_human: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values. In addition to the dollar the coinage act officially established monetary units of mill or one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥), cent or one-hundredth of a dollar (symbol ¢), dime or one-tenth of a dollar, and eagle or ten dollars, with prescribed weights and composition of gold, silver, or copper for each. It was proposed in the mid-1800s that one hundred dollars be known as a union, but no union coins were ever struck and only patterns for the $50 half union exist. However, only cents are in everyday use as divisions of the dollar; "dime" is used solely as the name of the coin with the value of 10¢, while "eagle" and "mill" are largely unknown to the general public, though mills are sometimes used in matters of tax levies, and gasoline prices are usually in the form of $X.XX9 per gallon, e.g., $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10. When currently issued in circulating form, denominations equal to or less than a dollar are emitted as U.S. coins while denominations equal to or greater than a dollar are emitted as Federal Reserve notes (with the exception of gold, silver and platinum coins valued up to $100 as legal tender, but worth far more as bullion). Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, although the note form is significantly more common. In the past, "paper money" was occasionally issued in denominations less than a dollar (fractional currency) and gold coins were issued for circulation up to the value of $20 (known as the "double eagle", discontinued in the 1930s). The term eagle was used in the Coinage Act of 1792 for the denomination of ten dollars, and subsequently was used in naming gold coins. Paper currency less than one dollar in denomination, known as "fractional currency", was also sometimes pejoratively referred to as "shinplasters". In 1854, James Guthrie, then Secretary of the Treasury, proposed creating $100, $50 and $25 gold coins, which were referred to as a "Union", "Half Union", and "Quarter Union", thus implying a denomination of 1 Union = $100.
text_ai_base: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar, the U.S. dollar is structured on a decimal system. The Coinage Act not only introduced the dollar but also established other monetary units: the mill, which is one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥); the cent, or one-hundredth of a dollar (symbol ¢); the dime, or one-tenth of a dollar; and the eagle, or ten dollars. Each had specific weights and compositions of gold, silver, or copper. In the mid-1800s, there was a proposal to name a hundred-dollar coin the "union," but no such coins were minted. Patterns for the $50 "half union" do exist. Today, only the cent is commonly used as a subdivision of the dollar. The term "dime" refers specifically to the 10¢ coin. "Eagle" and "mill" are largely unfamiliar, though mills are occasionally used in tax calculations, and fuel prices are often noted as $X.XX9 per gallon, such as $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10. Currently, denominations less than a dollar are issued as U.S. coins, while those equal to or greater than a dollar are typically Federal Reserve notes, except for gold, silver, and platinum coins valued up to $100 as legal tender, though their bullion worth is much higher. Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, with notes being more common. Historically, "paper money" included denominations under a dollar (fractional currency), and gold coins were circulated with values up to $20 (the "double eagle"), discontinued in the 1930s. The Coinage Act of 1792 introduced "eagle" as the term for a ten-dollar denomination, also used for naming gold coins. Fractional currency was sometimes derogatorily called "shinplasters". In 1854, James Guthrie, the Secretary of the Treasury, suggested minting $100, $50, and $25 gold coins referred to as a "Union," "Half Union," and "Quarter Union," thereby suggesting a value of 1 Union = $100.
text_ai_humanized: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values. The Coinage Act introduced the mill ($0.001), the cent ($0.01), the dime ($0.10) and the eagle ($10) as subdivisions of the dollar, with prescribed weights and composition of gold, silver, or copper for each. The value of the coin has not been changed. However, only cents are in everyday use as divisions of the dollar; "dime" is used solely as the name of the 10¢ coin; "eagle" and "mill" are largely unknown to the general public, though mills are sometimes used in matters of tax levies , and gasoline prices are usually in the form of a decimal number of dollars per gallon, e.g. $3.599, as of June 2024, is a typical gas price in the United States. When written, the price is usually written as $3.599/10, because there is no unicode symbol for the mill. In the United States, the dime is a coin, the dollar is a coin or bill, and amounts of money under one dollar are written as ¢/c (not ¤/¤) or as a decimal part of the U.S. dollar. 1853 US Assay Office $20 gold coin Until 1857 an ordinary English-style d was used, but $ was widely used and ultimately prevented d becoming widespread in the United States. The decimal point is used with money, and is called the "decimal point" or "point" (period) - never "dot". (This is different from many parts of the world, where a middle dot or comma is used for the decimal, and a full stop or space is used as a thousands separator.) Division by thousand is written as, usually in taxes: $3.65 6¾ mills or: $3.65.6 mills or: $3.65⅔ or: . Any coin or bill equal to or less than a dollar is a U.S. Coin, while any bill above a dollar is in principle a Federal Reserve note, although gold, silver, and platinum coins valued up to $100 as a legal tender are produced, but have value in bullion far in excess of their monetary value. Minting of a $100 coin has been authorized, but not produced. Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, although the note form is significantly more common. Notes above $100 have been discontinued, and are therefore exceedingly rare, although notes as high as $10, 000 were at one time produced. At one time "paper money" was produced in denominations of 50c, 25c, and so forth. Gold coinage was produced and circulated in the form of at least $10, $20, and $100 coins, and exempted from some forms of currency regulation; this was discontinued, however, in the 1930s. The Coinage Act of 1792, Section 9, defined "eagle" to mean a denomination of ten dollars, and subsequently came to be used to mean a gold coin of such denomination. "Shinplasters" is a derogatory term that came to be associated with fractional currency. In 1854, Secretary of the Treasury, James Guthrie, proposed a $100 gold coin, which he called a Union. Additionally, he proposed a $50 coin, which he called a Half Union, and a $25 coin, which he called a Quarter Union. Thus 1 Union = $100.

text_human: In 2012, Abigail Fisher, an undergraduate student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, filed a lawsuit to challenge the University of Texas admissions policy, asserting it had a "race-conscious policy" that "violated their civil and constitutional rights". The University of Texas employs the "Top Ten Percent Law", under which admission to any public college or university in Texas is guaranteed to high school students who graduate in the top ten percent of their high school class. Fisher has brought the admissions policy to court because she believes that she was denied acceptance to the University of Texas based on her race, and thus, her right to equal protection according to the 14th Amendment was violated. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments in Fisher on October 10, 2012, and rendered an ambiguous ruling in 2013 that sent the case back to the lower court, stipulating only that the University must demonstrate that it could not achieve diversity through other, non-race sensitive means. In July 2014, the US Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit concluded that U of T maintained a "holistic" approach in its application of affirmative action, and could continue the practice. On February 10, 2015, lawyers for Fisher filed a new case in the Supreme Court. It is a renewed complaint that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit got the issue wrong — on the second try as well as on the first. The Supreme Court agreed in June 2015 to hear the case a second time. It will likely be decided by June 2016.
text_ai_base: In 2012, Abigail Fisher, a student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, filed a lawsuit against the University of Texas, challenging its admissions policy. They claimed the policy was "race-conscious" and violated their civil and constitutional rights. Texas's "Top Ten Percent Law" guarantees admission to any state public college or university for high school students graduating in the top ten percent of their class. Fisher argued that her rejection from the University of Texas was based on her race, violating her 14th Amendment right to equal protection. The Supreme Court heard the case on October 10, 2012, and issued a vague ruling in 2013, instructing the lower court to reconsider, asking the University to prove that achieving diversity couldn't be done through race-neutral means. In July 2014, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit decided that the University of Texas could continue its "holistic" affirmative action approach. On February 10, 2015, Fisher's lawyers brought the case back to the Supreme Court, contending that the Fifth Circuit was wrong both times. The Supreme Court agreed in June 2015 to review the case again, with a decision expected by June 2016.
text_ai_humanized: In 2012, two white women, LSU undergrad Abigail Fisher and Southern Methodist University law student Rachel Multer Michalewicz, sued the University of Texas over its "race-conscious" admissions policy, which is designed to comply with state law. (Students who graduate in the top 10 percent of their high school classes are guaranteed spots at any public college or university in Texas under what's known as the "Top Ten Percent Law.") Fisher alleged that the University of Texas denied her admission on the basis of race, infringing upon her 14th Amendment constitutional right to equal protection under the law. The Supreme Court heard the case, academically dubbed Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, on Oct. 10, 2012, and handed down a nebulous decision on June 24, 2013, postponing judgment and kicking the case back down to the lower court, asking the University to demonstrate that a suitably diverse student body could not be assembled without the use of racial classification. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled in July 2014 that the University of Texas could proceed with its "holistic" affirmative action program, and on Feb. 10, 2015, Fisher's lawyers again petitioned the Supreme Court, arguing that the Fifth Circuit erred again. In June 2015, the Supreme Court agreed to rehear the case and is expected to rule by the end of its term in June 2016.

text_human: Athanasius recounts being a student, as well as being educated by the Martyrs of the Great (tenth) and last persecution of Christianity by pagan Rome.[citation needed] This persecution was most severe in the East, particularly in Egypt and Palestine. Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop of Alexandria, was martyred in 311 in the closing days of that persecution, and may have been one of those teachers. His successor as bishop of Alexandria, Alexander of Alexandria (312–328) was an Origenist as well as a documented mentor of Athanasius. According to Sozomen, Bishop Alexander "invited Athanasius to be his commensal and secretary. He had been well educated, and was versed in grammar and rhetoric, and had already, while still a young man, and before reaching the episcopate, given proof to those who dwelt with him of his wisdom and acumen". Athanasius's earliest work, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (written before 319), bears traces of Origenist Alexandrian thought (such as repeatedly quoting Plato and used a definition from Aristotle's Organon) but in an orthodox way. Athanasius was also familiar with the theories of various philosophical schools, and in particular with the developments of Neo-Platonism. Ultimately, Athanasius would modify the philosophical thought of the School of Alexandria away from the Origenist principles such as the "entirely allegorical interpretation of the text". Still, in later works, Athanasius quotes Homer more than once (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29). In his letter to Emperor Constantius, he presents a defense of himself bearing unmistakable traces of a study of Demosthenes de Corona.
text_ai_base: Athanasius shares his experience as a student under the tutelage of the Martyrs from the Great (tenth) and final persecution of Christians by pagan Rome.[citation needed] This persecution was especially brutal in the East, notably in Egypt and Palestine. Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop there, was martyred in 311 as the persecution came to an end and might have been among his teachers. Peter's successor, Alexander of Alexandria (312–328), was an Origenist and documented mentor of Athanasius. As noted by Sozomen, Bishop Alexander "invited Athanasius to be his companion and secretary. Athanasius was well-educated, proficient in grammar and rhetoric, and had already shown his wisdom and intelligence to those around him, even before rising to the episcopate." Athanasius's earliest work, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (written before 319), reflects Origenist Alexandrian ideas, such as frequent references to Plato and using Aristotle's Organon definitions, albeit in an orthodox manner. He was versed in various philosophical schools, particularly Neo-Platonism. Ultimately, Athanasius adjusted the School of Alexandria's philosophical stance away from purely allegorical interpretations characteristic of Origenist thought. Yet, he continued to cite Homer in later works (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29). In his letter to Emperor Constantius, he defends himself with clear elements of Demosthenes' study, De Corona.
text_ai_humanized: Athanasius was a Christian theologian, a leader of the fourth century. In a letter to Epictetus of Corinth,[49] he relates how he derived support from the Martyrs who fell under Maximian in the Great (tenth) and last persecution , that of Christians by the gentiles. He accompanied his uncle, the martyr, to synaxes, a term which refers to both Christian or philosophical gatherings. The Synaxes of the God-Fearers, or Phobou Theou, were assemblies of Christians and Pious Polytheist Philosophers, suggesting that Athanasius may have received some of his education from such syncretistic philosophers.[50] It was reported that he spoke with the martyrs before their deaths, and even the last words of the 98-year-old virgin martyr, Flora, during the first years of the tenth persecution.[citation needed] The tenth and last persecution of Christians by the pagan Romàn was sporadic but more violently lasted in the East, especially in Egypt and Palestine (Euseb. Martyr. Pal. Hieron. Epist). Alexandria, in which Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop of Alexandria, was martyred in 311, during the late period of that persecution. He is among the people Athanasius mentions as his educators. Peter's successor as Bishop of Alexandria was also among his teachers: Alexander of Alexandria (312–328) was an Origenist and is the first known mentor of Athanasius.[51] Sozomen reports that "Saint Anthony [the Great] delivered him (Athanasius) to Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, and that the latter cherished him as a son, and taught him the doctrines and mysterious truths of the Christian religion. It is likely that he had not yet accepted baptism. He subsequently became a priest, and was bestowed with the care of the church".[52] Bishop Alexander "attends the council of Nicaea subject of Athanasisus and tells about the initiation of Athanasius as his book-holder". Historian Sozomen writes: "Alexandros, the archbishop assembled everyone besides him and he ordered the children to act without leaving anything out. Athanasius acted out the bishop and those who were with him the clerics of the church".[53] In his first work as a young cleric, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (before 319), he used many references to Plato and Aristotle's Organon, which is characteristic of Origenist Alexandrine thought (like Origen he had small anterior knowledge of Aristotle).[54] In his later writings he ceases these characteristic Platonic Orthodox references,[55][56] as he recognized, adopting the Aristotelian Dios, The Proparizomenos Theos, as his dialytic organ.[57] He had knowledge of Letter V[58] (albeit more as later [Pseudo-] Plato), and we recognize some echoes of Aristotle's De Interpretatione. Like Origen, and Theodore of Mopsuestia, his writing style is Socratic. He also was knowledgeable about other philosophical movements such as Neo-Platonism.[59] In general, he modified the School of Alexandria's position in philosophy from an allegorist Philosopher type, like those of the past, such as Philo, Clement of Alexandria, Plotinus, and Origen. On Homer's epic poems as Plato on his dialogues, both are on a level with the Hellē رتia. In his later texts he was also using Homer (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29),[60] as quoted during his defence to emperor Constantius, he used a clarity of the study of Demosthenis (De Corona).

text_human: From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas of the Deccan. The Sena dynasty would later assume control of the Pala Empire, and the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various states. These were the first of the Rajput states. The first recorded Rajput kingdoms emerged in Rajasthan in the 6th century, and small Rajput dynasties later ruled much of northern India. One Gurjar Rajput of the Chauhan clan, Prithvi Raj Chauhan, was known for bloody conflicts against the advancing Turkic sultanates. The Chola empire emerged as a major power during the reign of Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I who successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka in the 11th century. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724 CE–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri Karkoṭa dynasty, which exercised influence in northwestern India from 625 CE until 1003, and was followed by Lohara dynasty. He is known primarily for his successful battles against the Muslim and Tibetan advances into Kashmiri-dominated regions. Kalhana in his Rajatarangini credits king Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign in Northern India and Central Asia. He broke into the Uttarapatha and defeated the rebellious tribes of the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks in Turkmenistan and Tocharians in Badakhshan), Bhautas (Tibetans in Baltistan and Tibet) and Daradas (Dards). His campaign then led him to subjugate the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya and the Uttarakurus. The Shahi dynasty ruled portions of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century.
text_ai_base: From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties vied for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas of the Deccan. Eventually, the Sena dynasty took over the Pala Empire, while the Gurjara Pratiharas disintegrated into several Rajput states. These Rajput kingdoms first appeared in Rajasthan in the 6th century, leading to small Rajput dynasties governing much of northern India. Notably, a Gurjar Rajput from the Chauhan clan, Prithvi Raj Chauhan, became famous for his fierce battles against the advancing Turkic sultanates. The Chola empire rose to prominence under Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I, who successfully invaded regions of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka in the 11th century. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri Karkoṭa dynasty, which influenced northwestern India from 625 to 1003 CE and was succeeded by the Lohara dynasty. He is renowned for his victories against Muslim and Tibetan expansions into regions controlled by Kashmir. The historian Kalhana, in his *Rajatarangini*, credits Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign across Northern India and Central Asia. He advanced into the Uttarapatha, defeating tribes such as the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks in Turkmenistan and Tocharians in Badakhshan), Bhautas (Tibetans in Baltistan and Tibet), and Daradas (Dards). His conquests continued as he subjugated the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya, and the Uttarakurus. Meanwhile, the Shahi dynasty ruled parts of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th to early 11th centuries.
text_ai_humanized: The three dynasties that contested for control of northern India from the 8th to the 10th century were the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and Rashtrakutas of the Deccan. The Pala Empire was eventually assimilated by the Sena dynasty, while the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various Rajput states. The Rajput kingdoms, Saptarishi, that arose in Rajasthan in the sixth century led to the formation of various small kingdoms in Northern India. Some of those Rajput kingdoms are Chauhans of Ajmer, Paramaras of Malwa, Chandelas of Bundelkhand, Solankis of Gujarat. A Gurjar Rajput, Chauhan Prithvi Raj Chauhan, was known for bloody resistance from revolutionary Turk Sultanates. The Chola empire eventually declined in the 13th century, but it is regarded as the most significant Hindu empire to exist in contemporary history. The Chola dynasty reached its peak under the rule of Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I in the 11th century. Rajendra Chola I successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724 –760 CE) was an emperor of Kashmir belonging to the region's Karkoṭa dynasty. The Karkoṭa Empire was a powerful Hindu empire, referenced in Kalhana's Rajatarangini and other chronicles that once dominated over south and central Asia from 625 to 1003 or 1101 CE, and at its height encompassed much of South and Central Asia. It was the precursor to the Lohara dynasty. Lalitaditya (Muktapida) is remembered as the conqueror of both Muslims and Tibetans, who were trying to expand into the regions controlled by Kashmir. The Kashmirian historian Kalhana, author of the Rajatarangini, describes him as the ruler of all of Northern India and Central Asia, and as far as Eastern Iran. He marched through the Uttarapatha into Eastern Afghanistan, subjected the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks of Turkistan or Turkmens of Badakhshan: the Tukhara of Swat–Gilgit–Dardistan and the Tukhara of Badakshan), the Bhauttas (Tibetians of Baltistan, Ladakh, Purang, Guge, Tsaparang and Tibet) and Daradas (Dards of the Chilas, Gurez & the Hunzas, Gilgit, Puian, etc.). Then he marched north to subjugate the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya (Kamarupa) and Uttarakuru. The Shahi (Devanagari: शाही), Sahi, also called Shahiya (Devanagari: शाहीय), dynasties ruled portions of the Kabul Valley (eastern Afghanistan), Gandhara (modern-day Pakistan), and present-day northwestern India (from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century).

text_human: Regardless, the Luftwaffe could still inflict huge damage. With the German occupation of Western Europe, the intensification of submarine and air attack on Britain's sea communications was feared by the British. Such an event would have serious consequences on the future course of the war, should the Germans succeed. Liverpool and its port became an important destination for convoys heading through the Western Approaches from North America, bringing supplies and materials. The considerable rail network distributed to the rest of the country. Operations against Liverpool in the Liverpool Blitz were successful. Air attacks sank 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping, with another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) damaged. Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison was also worried morale was breaking, noting the defeatism expressed by civilians. Other sources point to half of the port's 144 berths rendered unusable, while cargo unloading capability was reduced by 75%. Roads and railways were blocked and ships could not leave harbour. On 8 May 1941, 57 ships were destroyed, sunk or damaged amounting to 80,000 long tons (81,000 t). Around 66,000 houses were destroyed, 77,000 people made homeless, and 1,900 people killed and 1,450 seriously hurt on one night. Operations against London up until May 1941 could also have a severe impact on morale. The populace of the port of Hull became 'trekkers', people who underwent a mass exodus from cities before, during, and after attacks. However, the attacks failed to knock out or damage railways, or port facilities for long, even in the Port of London, a target of many attacks. The Port of London in particular was an important target, bringing in one-third of overseas trade.
text_ai_base: Despite setbacks, the Luftwaffe was still capable of causing significant damage. With Germany occupying Western Europe, Britain feared intensified submarine and air assaults on its sea routes. Such an escalation could have grave implications for the war's outcome if the Germans prevailed. Liverpool and its port became vital destinations for convoys from North America, carrying supplies and materials. From there, a robust rail network distributed the goods across the country. The Liverpool Blitz proved successful for the attackers; air assaults sank 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping and damaged another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t). Herbert Morrison, the Minister of Home Security, worried about a drop in morale, as civilians expressed defeatist attitudes. Reports suggested that half of the port's 144 berths were unusable, and cargo unloading capabilities fell by 75%. Roads and railways were blocked, and ships couldn't leave the harbor. On May 8, 1941, 57 ships were either destroyed, sunk, or damaged amounting to 80,000 long tons (81,000 t). Approximately 66,000 homes were destroyed, leaving 77,000 people homeless, with 1,900 killed and 1,450 seriously injured in just one night. Operations against London up until May 1941 threatened to impact morale severely. In Hull, residents became "trekkers," fleeing the city before, during, and after attacks. However, the bombardments failed to disable railways or port facilities for long, even in the frequently targeted Port of London, which handled one-third of overseas trade.
text_ai_humanized: Nevertheless, the Luftwaffe kept coming. With the Germans occupying Western Europe, the British expected an air onslaught and a renewed submarine offensive against shipping to cripple the British economy. Both the Germans and the British realised the war would be won or lost through the production of material. Liverpool and its port became the main targets for raids on Britain, receiving 68 raids in the war. The heaviest losses were felt by the merchants. An estimated 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping was sunk with a further 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) damaged.[91] MORI, the Ministry of Home Security, suspected a collapse in morale. It reported that civilians criticised firemen's efforts and wild rumours were widespread. Some 500 people had to be rescued from collapsed buildings. One report read "Indiscriminate action against offenders unlikely. Morale on the whole unimpaired and everybody busy but Emergency Service Personnel and nucleus of Hostels Staff near breaking point. Serious delay in ambulance attendance owing to roads blocked. Large scale temporary emigration." Half the 144 cargo berths were made unserviceable; 75 per cent of cargo space was also unavailable and several major junctions of the railways were forced to close.[92] London, the principal port, and Hull, on the east coast and a conduit to the Atlantic convoys, were also attacked. Of the 57 ships damaged, sunk or destroyed during the Blitz 80,000 long tons (81,000 t) was lost; 66,000 houses were destroyed and 77,000 people made homeless, 1,900 dead and 1,450 seriously hurt on one night alone.[93] Attacks against London up to May 1941 made it clear that the morale, material and food crisis could impact the British war effort. In the northeast, the Hull Blitz devastated the city. Some 92 raids fell soon after. People of Humber became "trekkers", arriving in towns each evening. They came and left each morning. Striking railway workers complained that "trent trekkers" were emergent. Targeted because of its ports and industries, the percentage of destroyed houses soared from 5 per cent to 15 per cent; three-times worse than London. Panic spread in the capital, but despite the port being a major element in the supply chain (it handled one third of overseas trade), the attacks failed to disrupt rail, road and port facilities for long.[94]

text_human: After its release, Evita garnered critical appreciation. Zach Conner from Time magazine commented, "It's a relief to say that Evita is pretty damn fine, well cast and handsomely visualized. Madonna once again confounds our expectations. She plays Evita with a poignant weariness and has more than just a bit of star quality. Love or hate Madonna-Eva, she is a magnet for all eyes." Madonna won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for the role. She released three singles from the Evita soundtrack album, including "You Must Love Me" (which won an Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1997) and "Don't Cry for Me Argentina". Madonna was later presented with the Artist Achievement Award by Tony Bennett at the 1996 Billboard Music Awards. On October 14, 1996, Madonna gave birth to Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, her daughter with Leon. Biographer Mary Cross writes that although Madonna was often ill during the filming and worried that her pregnancy would harm the film, she reached some important personal goals: "Now 38 years old, Madonna had at last triumphed on screen and achieved her dream of having a child, both in the same year. She had reached another turning point in her career, reinventing herself and her image with the public." Her relationship with Carlos Leon ended in May 1997; she declared that they were "better off as best friends." After Lourdes' birth, Madonna became involved in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah. She was introduced to Jewish mysticism by actress Sandra Bernhard in 1997.
text_ai_base: After its release, *Evita* received critical acclaim. Zach Conner from *Time* magazine remarked, "It's a relief to say that *Evita* is impressive, well cast, and visually stunning. Madonna surprises us once more. She portrays Evita with a touching weariness and undeniably possesses star quality. Whether you love or hate Madonna-Eva, she draws everyone's attention." For her role, Madonna won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture Musical or Comedy. She released three singles from the *Evita* soundtrack, including "You Must Love Me," which won the Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1997, and "Don't Cry for Me Argentina." Later, at the 1996 Billboard Music Awards, Tony Bennett presented Madonna with the Artist Achievement Award. On October 14, 1996, Madonna gave birth to her daughter, Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, with Carlos Leon. Biographer Mary Cross notes that although Madonna was often ill during filming and worried about her pregnancy affecting the film, she achieved significant personal milestones: "Now 38 years old, Madonna had finally succeeded on screen and realized her dream of having a child in the same year. She reached a career turning point, reinventing herself and her public image." Her relationship with Leon concluded in May 1997, with her stating they were "better off as best friends." After Lourdes' birth, Madonna became interested in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah, introduced to Jewish mysticism by actress Sandra Bernhard in 1997.
text_ai_humanized: Evita was released to positive reviews from critics; Zach Conner from Time described it as a "glorious, sensuous, [and] fantastic" film and wrote, "You can forget about Madonna the self-important celebrity, because to our surprise, she's a talented, affecting actress. And, what's equally surprising, Evita is a pretty good movie...In short, it is a relief to report that Evita is something to see, something to laud. It has boldness, great casting and memorable songs. Once again Madonna confounds expectations. She plays Evita with a poignancy to match her power, and finally proves herself an actress. She makes Evita alive, desperately alive, full of ambitions, hope, audacity, and as the years pass, something scars. Madonna offers a brittle, soft-spoken Evita, with flashing eyes, hesitant with fury...Yes, Madonna finally knows how to work on screen. She has developed enough technique that we see the rage behind the fading smile. 'She had her moments,' sings the grieving Che, 'She had some style.' Madonna has it too. Love her or hate her, she has focus, vision, and unmistakable star quality. Everybody wants Madonna-Eva, and everyone is watching."[110] Madonna was presented with her ninth Golden Globe Award, for Best Actress in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy, for her portrayal of Eva Perón. She released three singles from the Evita soundtrack album, including "You Must Love Me" (which won the Best Original Song Oscar), "Don't Cry for Me Argentina", and "Another Suitcase in Another Hall". At the 1996 Billboard Music Awards, she received the Artist Achievement Award, presented to her by Tony Bennett.[111] On October 14, 1996, she gave birth to her daughter, Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, fathered by her personal trainer Carlos Leon,[112] Biographer Mary Cross writes that although Madonna often worried that her pregnancy would harm Evita by postponing its filming, she reached some important personal goals the year the film was released, becoming a mother and finally starring in a film for which she could earn critical acclaim. "Now 38 years old, Madonna had at last triumphed on the screen. She had at last claimed her daughter, and she had at last become a competent actress. In the same year she carried both accomplishments off with homages to Eva Perón (adopting an Argentina baby, mimicking her appearance in style and fashion, and testing the acting skills to portray her character in a movie and musical). She had already reached another, perhaps more significant, turning point in her career: her relationship with Carlos Leon. She had reinvented herself and her image in the public eye with the public acknowledgment of her second successful relationship and the birth of her new daughter. Life imitated art. Art imitated life."[113] Madonna and Carlos later ended their relationship; she declared that they were "better off as best friends."[114] Following the birth of Lourdes, Madonna became more engaged in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah, as she was introduced to Jewish mysticism in 1997 by actress Sandra Bernhard.[115]

text_human: The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and the Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue began to appear in the chronicles and records written during the Spring and Autumn Period. According to the chronicles, the kingdom of Yue was located in northern Zhejiang. Shiji claims that its leaders were descended from the Shang founder Yu the Great. Evidence suggests that Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue possessed their own culture and history that are different from those kingdoms in north and central China, whose cultures and histories were carefully recorded in chronicles and histories during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty. The Song of the Yue Boatman (Chinese: 越人歌, p Yuèrén Gē, lit. "Song of the man of Yue") was transliterated into Chinese and recorded by authors in north China or inland China of Hebei and Henan around 528 BC. The song shows that the Yue people spoke a language that was mutually unintelligible with the dialects spoken in north and inland China. The Yue peoples seem to have had their own written script. The Sword of Goujian bears bird-worm seal script. Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ; Wade–Giles: Yüeh-nü; literally: "the Lady of Yue") was a swordswoman from the state of Yue. In order to check the growth of the kingdom of Wu, Chu pursued a policy of strengthening Yue. Under King Goujian, Yue recovered from its early reverses and fully annexed the lands of its rival in 473 BC. The Yue kings then moved their capital center from their original home around Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to the former Wu capital at present-day Suzhou. With no southern power to turn against Yue, Chu opposed it directly and, in 333 BC, succeeded in destroying it. Yue's former lands were annexed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and organized into a commandery named for Kuaiji in Zhejiang but initially headquartered in Wu in Jiangsu.
text_ai_base: During the second millennium BC, the area now known as Zhejiang was not heavily influenced by the Shang civilization. It was inhabited by groups collectively called the Hundred Yue, including tribes like the Dongyue and Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue first appeared in written records during the Spring and Autumn Period, with these chronicles placing it in northern Zhejiang. The Shiji asserts that Yue's rulers were descendants of Shang's founder, Yu the Great. Evidence indicates that the Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue had distinctive cultures and histories compared to those in northern and central China, whose pasts were well-documented during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty. One remarkable artifact from this era is "The Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, pinyin: Yuèrén Gē, meaning "Song of the Man of Yue"), which was transliterated into Chinese around 528 BC by authors from Hebei and Henan. This song reveals that the Yue people spoke a language unintelligible to those in northern China. It appears the Yue also had their own written script, as evidenced by the Sword of Goujian inscribed with bird-worm seal script. A notable figure from Yue was Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ, meaning "the Lady of Yue"), a renowned swordswoman. The state of Chu supported Yue to curb the expansion of the kingdom of Wu. Under King Goujian, Yue rebounded from its early setbacks and fully annexed Wu's territories in 473 BC. Subsequently, the Yue changed their capital from the area near Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to Wu's former capital in present-day Suzhou. With no southern adversaries remaining, Chu directly confronted Yue and successfully destroyed it in 333 BC. Yue's former territories were absorbed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and formed into a commandery named Kuaiji in Zhejiang, with its initial headquarters located in Wu in Jiangsu.
text_ai_humanized: The purported territories of the Ouyue, considered the predecessor of the kingdom of Yue, are shown in green. In the second millennium BC, the area of modern-day Zhejiang was described as being within the sphere of influence of the mostly contemporaneous Erligang and later Shang civilizations. The records of the Shang and early Zhou dynasties' histories are based on transmitted texts compiled many centuries later. The area of what is now southern Zhejiang was inhabited by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue (Baiyue), such as the Dongyue (東越), Ouyue (歐越), and the Shan Yue. The kingdom of Yue began to appear in Chinese historic records during the Spring and Autumn Period, and these sources placed Yue within the northern part of modern Zhejiang. The "Song of the Yue Boatman" records an ancient Yue language The exact origin of the kingdom of Yue is unclear but the Yues are believed to have descended from the ancient Baiyue. The founders of Yue had surnames (Si and later Ying), different from the royal family of Chu in the west, suggesting a possible, albeit distant, relationship between the two. According to the Zuo Zhuan, Yue was a relatively insignificant state before its rise in the late 6th century BC, and was originally a vassal state of Chu. Shiji claims that the rulers of Yue were descended from the mythical Yu the Great of Xia dynasty. However, the Yue were first recorded to have fought in wars in northern China during the Spring and Autumn period. From various historiographical evidence in ancient China, the Baiyue, and the Ouyue kingdom, appear to have been very different from other cultures in early and classical Chinese history. Their level of leadership and martial advancement in comparison to the Wu is unclear. One of the most significant, and perhaps the only known evidences, was The Song of the Yue Boatman (Chinese: 越人歌; pinyin: Yuèréngē; lit. 'Song of the Man of Yue') that was transcribed phonetically into Chinese, apparently sometime around 528 BC by people from the region of Hebei and Henan. The "song" indicates a language that is otherwise unintelligible to not only speakers of Chinese, but also today's students of Chinese philology. Other than Yue's language, it is also believed that the Yue possessed their own script. As the Yue prepared to invade Wu, King Goujian's sword, one of the few artifacts that have survived from the period, was apparently made close or within Wucheng, with bird-worm seal script inscriptions that include scripts introduced to the Wu as well. A number of notable personal names in Chinese history were associated with the Yue before its annexation by Chu and then by Qin. Among them were Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ; lit. 'the Lady of Yue'), a famous swordswoman who taught the art of the sword, including a special brand of fencing that originated from the Yue. King Goujian of Yue was also famous for his perseverance during hard times. If the contents of Yugong in the Book of Documents and Rites of Zhou can be taken to be factual, Dong'ou would be part of Yu province and Yue would be part of Yang province. To check the rise of the kingdom of Wu, Chu helped strengthen the Yue. Under King Goujian, Yue fully recovered from its previous humiliation and annexed the lands of Wu (except for the two small states of Zhongwu and Zhou) in 473 BC. Afterward, the Yue moved their capital to the former Wu capital in present-day Suzhou. However, after Wu was eliminated, Yue didn't have any competitors in the south anymore. Chu no longer needed Yue as an ally and relations between two states deteriorated. Eventually, Chu destroyed Yue in 333 BC. After the fall of Yue, its ruling clan moved south and created the Minyue kingdom in Fujian. The Yue territories would eventually be known as Kuaiji Commandery under the Qin dynasty. Another kingdom made up of the Baiyue, known as Nanyue, was established in Guangdong early in the Han dynasty. The destruction of Yue was documented in Chinese history in Shiji, and the Yue ethnic group were gradually merged into the Han Chinese or displaced. Later on, the people of Wu and Yue became the ancestral ethnic group of modern Hangzhou and Shanghai. In 222 BC, former Yue lands were annexed by the Qin Empire and its people would be included in Kuaiji Commandery in modern Zhejiang, initially with its headquarters in Wu in modern Jiangsu.

text_human: Romantic relationships tend to increase in prevalence throughout adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have had a romantic relationship that lasted at least one month over the course of the previous 18 months. In a 2008 study conducted by YouGov for Channel 4, 20% of 14−17-year-olds surveyed revealed that they had their first sexual experience at 13 or under in the United Kingdom. A 2002 American study found that those aged 15–44 reported that the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females. The typical duration of relationships increases throughout the teenage years as well. This constant increase in the likelihood of a long-term relationship can be explained by sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills necessary to maintain a romantic bond (e.g. caregiving, appropriate attachment), although these skills are not strongly developed until late adolescence. Long-term relationships allow adolescents to gain the skills necessary for high-quality relationships later in life and develop feelings of self-worth. Overall, positive romantic relationships among adolescents can result in long-term benefits. High-quality romantic relationships are associated with higher commitment in early adulthood and are positively associated with self-esteem, self-confidence, and social competence. For example, an adolescent with positive self-confidence is likely to consider themselves a more successful partner, whereas negative experiences may lead to low confidence as a romantic partner. Adolescents often date within their demographic in regards to race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical attractiveness. However, there are traits in which certain individuals, particularly adolescent girls, seek diversity. While most adolescents date people approximately their own age, boys typically date partners the same age or younger; girls typically date partners the same age or older.

According to a 2002 American study, the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females aged 15–44. As teens mature, the duration of their relationships tends to increase as well. This trend can be attributed to sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills needed to maintain romantic bonds, such as caregiving and attachment, although these skills are not fully developed until late adolescence. Long-term relationships help adolescents cultivate the skills they need for high-quality relationships later on and foster a sense of self-worth. Overall, positive adolescent romantic relationships can have long-term benefits. High-quality romantic relationships are linked to greater commitment in early adulthood and positively impact self-esteem, self-confidence, and social competence. For instance, adolescents with positive self-confidence often view themselves as successful partners, while negative experiences might lead to low confidence. Adolescents generally date within their demographic based on factors like race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical attractiveness. However, some traits, especially among girls, encourage seeking diversity. While most adolescents date peers close to their own age, boys usually date partners who are the same age or younger, whereas girls tend to date partners who are the same age or older.

For instance, romantically involved adolescence having positive self-confidence tend to have higher role conceptions such as a good partner; whereas, a negative experience in engaging in romantic relationships could be felt as low confidence. Adolescents tend to form romantic relationships with people who are similar to them or within their demography usage of phrase unclearin terms of race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical appearance; however, some adolescents may have a trait to value diversity, which is more likely to be encouraged by girls. Furthermore, adolescents who dated for first or second time are more likely to find a partner of same age. Also, boys tend to date to same age or younger, while girls tend to date to same age or older.

text_human: Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A sample taken from potentially diseased tissue or fluid is then tested for the presence of an infectious agent able to grow within that medium. Most pathogenic bacteria are easily grown on nutrient agar, a form of solid medium that supplies carbohydrates and proteins necessary for growth of a bacterium, along with copious amounts of water. A single bacterium will grow into a visible mound on the surface of the plate called a colony, which may be separated from other colonies or melded together into a "lawn". The size, color, shape and form of a colony is characteristic of the bacterial species, its specific genetic makeup (its strain), and the environment that supports its growth. Other ingredients are often added to the plate to aid in identification. Plates may contain substances that permit the growth of some bacteria and not others, or that change color in response to certain bacteria and not others. Bacteriological plates such as these are commonly used in the clinical identification of infectious bacterium. Microbial culture may also be used in the identification of viruses: the medium in this case being cells grown in culture that the virus can infect, and then alter or kill. In the case of viral identification, a region of dead cells results from viral growth, and is called a "plaque". Eukaryotic parasites may also be grown in culture as a means of identifying a particular agent.

text_human: Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. The hydrographic network includes several of the largest bodies of freshwater in Central and Western Europe, among which are included Lake Geneva (also called le Lac Léman in French), Lake Constance (known as Bodensee in German) and Lake Maggiore. Switzerland has more than 1500 lakes, and contains 6% of Europe's stock of fresh water. Lakes and glaciers cover about 6% of the national territory. The largest lake is Lake Geneva, in western Switzerland shared with France. The Rhône is both the main source and outflow of Lake Geneva. Lake Constance is the second largest Swiss lake and, like the Lake Geneva, an intermediate step by the Rhine at the border to Austria and Germany. While the Rhône flows into the Mediterranean Sea at the French Camarque region and the Rhine flows into the North Sea at Rotterdam in the Netherlands, about 1000 km apart, both springs are only about 22 km apart from each other in the Swiss Alps.

text_human: On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States. The album formally introduces Beyoncé's alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single "Crazy in Love", selling 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting atop the Billboard 200, and giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US. The album featured the number-one song "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and the top-five songs "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo". Achieving the accomplishment of becoming her longest-running Hot 100 single in her career, "Halo"'s success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top-ten singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s. It also included the successful "Sweet Dreams", and singles "Diva", "Ego", "Broken-Hearted Girl" and "Video Phone". The music video for "Single Ladies" has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. The video has won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year. Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American country pop singer Taylor Swift's "You Belong with Me", led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance speech. In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5 million.

In March 2009, Beyoncé launched the I Am... World Tour, her second solo global tour, comprising 108 shows and grossing $119.5 million.

text_human: Many ground crew at the airport work at the aircraft. A tow tractor pulls the aircraft to one of the airbridges, The ground power unit is plugged in. It keeps the electricity running in the plane when it stands at the terminal. The engines are not working, therefore they do not generate the electricity, as they do in flight. The passengers disembark using the airbridge. Mobile stairs can give the ground crew more access to the aircraft's cabin. There is a cleaning service to clean the aircraft after the aircraft lands. Flight catering provides the food and drinks on flights. A toilet waste truck removes the human waste from the tank which holds the waste from the toilets in the aircraft. A water truck fills the water tanks of the aircraft. A fuel transfer vehicle transfers aviation fuel from fuel tanks underground, to the aircraft tanks. A tractor and its dollies bring in luggage from the terminal to the aircraft. They also carry luggage to the terminal if the aircraft has landed, and is being unloaded. Hi-loaders lift the heavy luggage containers to the gate of the cargo hold. The ground crew push the luggage containers into the hold. If it has landed, they rise, the ground crew push the luggage container on the hi-loader, which carries it down. The luggage container is then pushed on one of the tractors dollies. The conveyor, which is a conveyor belt on a truck, brings in the awkwardly shaped, or late luggage. The airbridge is used again by the new passengers to embark the aircraft. The tow tractor pushes the aircraft away from the terminal to a taxi area. The aircraft should be off of the airport and in the air in 90 minutes. The airport charges the airline for the time the aircraft spends at the airport.

After landing, a cleaning service tidies the aircraft, and flight catering supplies food and beverages for the next flight. The airport charges the airline for the time the aircraft spends there.
