text_human: Hidalgo is hailed as the Father of the Nation even though it was Agustin de Iturbide and not Hidalgo who achieved Mexican Independence in 1821. Shortly after gaining independence, the day to celebrate it varied between September 16, the day of Hidalgo's Grito, and September 27, the day Iturbide rode into Mexico City to end the war. Later, political movements would favor the more liberal Hidalgo over the conservative Iturbide, so that eventually September 16, 1810 became the officially recognized day of Mexican independence. The reason for this is that Hidalgo is considered to be "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the (Mexican War of) Independence." Hidalgo has become an icon for Mexicans who resist tyranny in the country. Diego Rivera painted Hidalgo's image in half a dozen murals. José Clemente Orozco depicted him with a flaming torch of liberty and considered the painting among his best work. David Alfaro Siqueiros was commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to paint a mural for a celebration commemorating the 200th anniversary of Hidalgo's birth. The town of his parish was renamed Dolores Hidalgo in his honor and the state of Hidalgo was created in 1869. Every year on the night of 15–16 September, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the balcony of the National Palace. This scene is repeated by the heads of cities and towns all over Mexico. The remains of Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla lie in the column of the Angel of Independence in Mexico City. Next to it is a lamp lit to represent the sacrifice of those who gave their lives for Mexican Independence.

Over time, political movements leaned towards the liberal Hidalgo rather than the conservative Iturbide, leading to September 16, 1810, being officially recognized as Mexican Independence Day. Hidalgo is regarded as the "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the Mexican War of Independence," symbolizing resistance against tyranny in Mexico. His image appears in half a dozen murals by Diego Rivera and was portrayed with a flaming torch of liberty by José Clemente Orozco, who considered it among his finest works. David Alfaro Siqueiros was commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to create a mural for the 200th anniversary of Hidalgo's birth. The town of his parish was renamed Dolores Hidalgo to honor him, and the state of Hidalgo was established in 1869. Annually, on the night of September 15–16, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the National Palace balcony, a scene replicated by leaders across the country. Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla's remains rest in the Angel of Independence column in Mexico City, alongside a lamp lit to symbolize the sacrifice of those who fought for Mexican Independence.
text_ai_humanized: Hidalgo is venerated as the Father of the Nation even though it was Agustin de Iturbide who brought about Mexican Independence in 1821. After independence, the question of which day to mark independence was debated between the day the war started, on 16 September, and the day it ended, on 27 September, when Iturbide entered Mexico City. Political movements of the 19th century tended to prefer the Hidalgo revolt and have credited him with leading to the eventual independence of Mexico. In the end, political forces chose to emphasize the liberal, anti-Spanish Hidalgo and not the conservative, pro Spanish Iturbide.[54] Ultimately the day on which Hidalgo declared the end of bad government, 16 September 1810, was chosen, and the day is now celebrated as Mexican Independence Day. Hidalgo has become iconized in Mexico's history to the point where he has become more of a symbol than a person. Some of these icons are designed to portray Hidalgo as a martyr of injustice since his approach to Mexican independence was as one who did not like the way his people were treated. Modern-day Mexico's image of Hidalgo is of a powerful symbol who was responsible for ending Spanish rule in Mexico. He is viewed as the "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the country."[54] Hidalgo's state in Mexico and the city of Dolores Hidalgo are both named after him. His name and image can be seen extensively in Mexican politics and culture. Half a dozen of Diego Rivera's murals, Hidalgo's image in a flaming torch of liberty done by José Clemente Orozco, a mural by David Alfaro Siqueiros were commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to honor Hidalgo. In his own hometown of Dolores (Hidalgo), the town name was changed to Dolores Hidalgo in his honor. In 1869, the new state of Hidalgo was created. He has appeared on Mexican currency, and the largest denomination bill, the 1000 peso note, issued in 2008, bears Hidalgo's image.[55][56][57][58][59] Every year, at midnight on 15–16 September, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the balcony of the National Palace in Mexico City, with the ringing of the same bell Hidalgo used in 1810. This scene, known as El Grito de Dolores, is repeated in cities and towns all over Mexico.[6] Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla`s remains, with those of three other insurgents, José María Morelos, Vicente Guerrero, and Ignacio Allende, rest in the Angel of Independence column in Mexico City. There is also a lamp lit to honor the murdered priests and sacrificed people who gave their lives for Mexican Independence.[60]

text_human: Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a "communion table," usually on the same level as the congregation. There may be a rail between the communion table and the "Chancel" behind it, which may contain a more decorative altar-type table, choir loft, or choir stalls, lectern and clergy area. The altar is called the communion table and the altar area is called the Chancel by Presbyterians. In a Presbyterian (Reformed Church) there may be an altar cross, either on the communion table or on a table in the chancel. By using the "empty" cross, or cross of the resurrection, Presbyterians emphasize the resurrection and that Christ is not continually dying, but died once and is alive for all eternity. Some Presbyterian church buildings are often decorated with a cross that has a circle around the center, or Celtic cross. This not only emphasized the resurrection, but also acknowledges historical aspects of Presbyterianism. A baptismal font will be located either at the entrance or near the chancel area. Presbyterian architecture generally makes significant use of symbolism. You may also find decorative and ornate stained glass windows depicting scenes from the bible. Some Presbyterian churches will also have ornate statues of Christ or Graven Scenes from the Last Supper located behind the Chancel. St. Giles Cathedral ( Church Of Scotland- The Mother Church of Presbyterians) does have a Crucifix next to one of the Pulpits that hangs alongside. The image of Christ is more of faint image and more modern design.

text_human: Of the 80 torch-bearers in London, Sir Steve Redgrave, who started the relay, mentioned to the media that he had received e-mailed pleas to boycott the event and could "see why they would like to make an issue" of it. Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan refused to carry the torch, while Konnie Huq decided to carry it and also speak out against China. The pro-Tibetan Member of Parliament Norman Baker asked all bearers to reconsider. Amid pressure from both directions, Prime Minister Gordon Brown welcomed the torch outside 10 Downing Street without holding or touching it. The London relay saw the torch surrounded by what the BBC described as "a mobile protective ring." Protests began as soon as Redgrave started the event, leading to at least thirty-five arrests. In Ladbroke Grove a demonstrator attempted to snatch the torch from Konnie Huq in a momentary struggle, and in a separate incident, a fire extinguisher was set off near the torch. The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through Chinatown after an unpublicized change to the route amid security concerns. The torch made an unscheduled move onto a bus along Fleet Street amid security concerns and efforts to evade the protesters. In an effort to counter the pro-Tibet protesters and show their support for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, more than 2,000 Chinese also gathered on the torch route and demonstrated with signs, banners and Chinese flags. A large number of supporters were concentrated in Trafalgar Square, displaying the Olympic slogan "One World, One Dream".

text_human: The album also featured the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody", which was number one in the UK for nine weeks. Mercury's close friend and advisor, Capital London radio DJ Kenny Everett, played a pivotal role in giving the single exposure. It is the third-best-selling single of all time in the UK, surpassed only by Band Aid's "Do They Know It's Christmas?" and Elton John's "Candle in the Wind 1997", and is the best-selling commercial single in the UK. It also reached number nine in the United States (a 1992 re-release reached number two on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks). It is the only single ever to sell a million copies on two separate occasions, and became the Christmas number one twice in the UK, the only single ever to do so. "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been voted numerous times the greatest song of all time. The band decided to make a video to help go with the single and hired Trilion, a subsidiary of the former management company Trident Studios, using new technology to create the video; the result is generally considered to have been the first "true" music video ever produced, and popularised the medium. The album's first track "Death on Two Legs" is said to be written by Mercury about Norman Sheffield and the former management at Trident who helped make the video so popular. Although other bands, including the Beatles, had made short promotional films or videos of songs prior to this, generally, those were specifically made to be aired on specific television shows. On the impact of "Bohemian Rhapsody", Rolling Stone states: "Its influence cannot be overstated, practically inventing the music video seven years before MTV went on the air." The second single from the album, "You're My Best Friend", the second song composed by John Deacon, and his first single, peaked at number sixteen in the United States and went on to become a worldwide Top Ten hit. The band's A Night at the Opera Tour began in November 1975, and covered Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia.

The band embarked on the A Night at the Opera Tour in November 1975, covering Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia.
text_ai_humanized: The album also featured the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody", which became the band's first UK number one. It held the top position in the UK for nine weeks, and is Britain's third-best-selling single of all time, surpassed only by Band Aid's "Do They Know It's Christmas?" and Elton John's "Candle in the Wind 1997", and is the biggest selling commercial single in UK history. It also reached number nine in the US in 1976, while a re-release in 1992, following its use in the film Wayne's World, hit number two on the Billboard Hot 100 (and number one on the Modern Rock Tracks chart). The band decided to make a video to go with the song; directed by Bruce Gowers, it was based on their Queen II album cover. The B-side of "Bohemian Rhapsody" was "I'm in Love with My Car" and these two songs, together with "Death on Two Legs" and "You're My Best Friend" from the same album, all are featured in the 2018 film, Bohemian Rhapsody. Bohemian Rhapsody is the only song in history ever to have sold a million copies (from their Greatest Hits album) on two separate occasions[97] and became their most recognisable hit. This, coupled with the A Night at the Opera track "Love of My Life", led to the song and album often being hailed as Queen's finest work; "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been voted, several times, as the greatest song of all time.[98] The band embarked on the worldwide A Night at the Opera Tour in November 1975, which covered Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia. Mercury's best friend and advisor, Capital London radio DJ Kenny Everett, played a huge part in giving the single and the band publicity by teasing fans with airs of the song before its release.[99] They hired one of the best and most expensive studios of that era, Trilion, which updated their equipment and technology just to keep up with the state-of-the-art equipment Queen demanded for the video.[100] They hired Trilion, which they were familiar with because it was a subsidiary of their ex-management company Trident,[101] who were, coincidentally, also creative and financial influences in helping Bohemian Rhapsody become popular.[99][100] Although other bands had 'made videos' before, to air on specific TV shows,[102] Queen were the first band to create an accompanying 'promotional video' of a song for an album release.[103] Rolling Stone stated: "Its influence cannot be overstated, practically inventing the music video seven years before MTV went on the air."[104] The second single from the album, John Deacon's "You're My Best Friend", became a Top Ten worldwide hit, peaking at number sixteen in the United States. This was Deacon's first single. The opening track, "Death on Two Legs", was reportedly written by Mercury about Norman Sheffield, and the ex-management at Trident were also blamed by Mercury for much of the neglect of this period.[ citation needed ]

text_human: As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). Phytochemicals (Section Below) and their subgroup, polyphenols, make up the majority of antioxidants; about 4,000 are known. Different antioxidants are now known to function in a cooperative network. For example, Vitamin C can reactivate free radical-containing glutathione or Vitamin E by accepting the free radical itself. Some antioxidants are more effective than others at neutralizing different free radicals. Some cannot neutralize certain free radicals. Some cannot be present in certain areas of free radical development (Vitamin A is fat-soluble and protects fat areas, Vitamin C is water-soluble and protects those areas). When interacting with a free radical, some antioxidants produce a different free radical compound that is less dangerous or more dangerous than the previous compound. Having a variety of antioxidants allows any byproducts to be safely dealt with by more efficient antioxidants in neutralizing a free radical's butterfly effect.
text_ai_base: Cellular metabolism and energy production rely on oxygen, but this can lead to the formation of potentially harmful compounds known as free radicals, which can cause mutations. Most of these radicals are oxidizers that strongly react by accepting electrons. For normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, it is essential to neutralize these free radicals with antioxidants. Recently, some researchers proposed an intriguing theory about the evolution of dietary antioxidants. The human body produces some antioxidants like glutathione and Vitamin C but requires others through diet, such as Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, and Vitamin K. Some antioxidants can be synthesized by the body from other substances, like Beta-carotene, which is converted into Vitamin A, and Vitamin D, which is made from cholesterol through sunlight exposure. Phytochemicals and their subset, polyphenols, form the majority of known antioxidants, totaling about 4,000. These antioxidants work in a cooperative network, with some like Vitamin C reactivating free radical-containing compounds like glutathione or Vitamin E by taking on the radical itself. Each antioxidant varies in its effectiveness against different free radicals, with some unable to neutralize certain types or function in specific areas—Vitamin A, being fat-soluble, protects fat regions, while Vitamin C, being water-soluble, guards watery areas. When antioxidants interact with free radicals, they may produce new radical compounds that can be less or more harmful than the original. A diverse array of antioxidants ensures that any resultant byproducts are efficiently handled, neutralizing the potential cascading effects of free radicals.
text_ai_humanized: Cells require oxygen to maintain metabolism and produce energy. But, they can react to produce different, possibly mutagenic compounds. Collectively these compounds are called free radicals —which most are forms of oxidizers— or compounds that in general react strongly with other compounds by taking their electrons. It’s necessary to neutralize these radicals with antioxidants to avoid interfering with regular cellular maintenance, development and proliferation. Basically, you want to avoid oxidizers so your cells can do what they do on a day-to-day basis. Recently, some researchers came up with a interesting hypothesis on how consuming antioxidants evolved. Some antioxidants, like glutathione and Vitamin C the body can create on it’s own, while others it needs to get- like with humans and Vitamin C and others like Vitamin A or K. In addition, some antioxidants, like Beta-carotene the body can convert into antioxidants, with Beta-carotene into Vitamin A. Another example is that Vitamin D, which is created from cholesterol with sunlight. In addition, the vast majority of antioxidants are phytochemicals and a subclass of phytochemicals, polyphenols. These are collectively all the known antioxidants (about 4,000). Antioxidants create a synergistic network to combat free radicals, with some antioxidants taking free radical containing compounds, like glutathione or Vitamin E, and then reactivate them by taking the free radical, itself. All the antioxidants vary on how well they take on different types of free radicals, they can’t possibly take on every radical, and how they function within certain environments (Vitamin A targets fatty regions, because it’s a fat-soluble antioxidant, while Vitamin C targets aqueous regions, being a water soluble antioxidant). These antioxidants can neutralize free radicals, but can then carry new radical compounds that can be comparatively less or more dangerous than the original, but having all these antioxidants means they can make use of the new byproducts, preventing, or limit, the domino effect free radicals do.

text_human: Zhejiang's main manufacturing sectors are electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. In recent years Zhejiang has followed its own development model, dubbed the "Zhejiang model", which is based on prioritizing and encouraging entrepreneurship, an emphasis on small businesses responsive to the whims of the market, large public investments into infrastructure, and the production of low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic consumption and export. As a result, Zhejiang has made itself one of the richest provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" has become something of a legend within China. However, some economists now worry that this model is not sustainable, in that it is inefficient and places unreasonable demands on raw materials and public utilities, and also a dead end, in that the myriad small businesses in Zhejiang producing cheap goods in bulk are unable to move to more sophisticated or technologically more advanced industries. The economic heart of Zhejiang is moving from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, southeastward to the region centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou. The per capita disposable income of urbanites in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) in 2009, an annual real growth of 8.3%. The per capita pure income of rural residents stood at 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a real growth of 8.1% year-on-year. Zhejiang's nominal GDP for 2011 was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, Zhejiang's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were worth 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively.

text_ai_humanized: Zhejiang manufacturing is concentrated in electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. Zhejiang has followed an export-oriented development path and has pioneered the establishment of the "Zhejiang model," characterized as "encouraging entrepreneurship, moving from small to bigger and better, responding quickly to changes in the market, prioritizing infrastructure, and producing in bulk at low cost both for the domestic and international markets". As a result, Zhejiang has grown into one of the relatively wealthy regions in China and has the reputation of a province with the strongest private economy in China. The "Zhejiang spirit" is celebrated throughout China. However, some economists (particularly those in China) worry that the "Zhejiang model" is not sustainable, since it is not efficient and largely dependent on public utilities like raw materials and energy, and the plethora of small businesses producing similar products have limited potential in moving into more advanced industries. The province is increasingly concentrating on the high-tech and service industries. There is a clear economic shift towards the geographic center of the province, with the economic importance of the north (centered on Hangzhou) gradually declining and that of the southeast (centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou) rapidly rising. The per capita disposable income of urbanites was 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) and rural residents 10,007 yuan (US$1,465). The Engel's coefficient was 35.8% and 38.4%, respectively. The per capita net income of rural households was 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a year-on-year real growth of 8.1%. In 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with an annual growth rate of 9.0%. Per capita GDP reached 44,335 yuan (US$6,490).[8] The primary, secondary and tertiary industries' value-added output was 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion) and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively.

text_human: A central teaching of Jehovah's Witnesses is that the current world era, or "system of things", entered the "last days" in 1914 and faces imminent destruction through intervention by God and Jesus Christ, leading to deliverance for those who worship God acceptably. They consider all other present-day religions to be false, identifying them with "Babylon the Great", or the "harlot", of Revelation 17, and believe that they will soon be destroyed by the United Nations, which they believe is represented in scripture by the scarlet-colored wild beast of Revelation chapter 17. This development will mark the beginning of the "great tribulation". Satan will subsequently attack Jehovah's Witnesses, an action that will prompt God to begin the war of Armageddon, during which all forms of government and all people not counted as Christ's "sheep", or true followers, will be destroyed. After Armageddon, God will extend his heavenly kingdom to include earth, which will be transformed into a paradise similar to the Garden of Eden. After Armageddon, most of those who had died before God's intervention will gradually be resurrected during "judgment day" lasting for one thousand years. This judgment will be based on their actions after resurrection rather than past deeds. At the end of the thousand years, Christ will hand all authority back to God. Then a final test will take place when Satan is released to mislead perfect mankind. Those who fail will be destroyed, along with Satan and his demons. The end result will be a fully tested, glorified human race.
text_ai_base: Jehovah's Witnesses teach that the current era, referred to as the "system of things," entered the "last days" in 1914 and is soon to be destroyed through divine intervention by God and Jesus Christ, ensuring deliverance for true worshippers. They view other contemporary religions as false, labeling them "Babylon the Great" or the "harlot" from Revelation 17, and believe these will be annihilated by the United Nations, the scarlet-colored wild beast of Revelation 17. This event will signal the start of the "great tribulation." Afterward, Satan will assault Jehovah's Witnesses, triggering God's initiation of Armageddon, during which all governments and all individuals not identified as Christ's "sheep," or genuine followers, will be eliminated. Following Armageddon, God's heavenly kingdom will encompass the earth, transforming it into a paradise akin to the Garden of Eden. Most deceased individuals will be resurrected during a "judgment day" lasting one thousand years, judged by actions after resurrection rather than prior deeds. After this period, Christ will return authority to God. A final test will occur when Satan is released to deceive perfect mankind; those who fail will be destroyed alongside Satan and his demons, culminating in a thoroughly tested and glorified humanity.
text_ai_humanized: Jehovah's Witnesses believe that the present world order, or "system of things", which comprises non-Witness religions, governments, and businesses, is about to be replaced by God's new order under the messianic Kingdom of God. [97][98] The current world order is regarded as being under Satan's control, and is characterized by crime, immorality, war, disease, and death. [99][100] They believe that a final confrontation between the forces of good (as represented by Jehovah's Witnesses) and evil will shortly take place at Armageddon, after which all wickedness and suffering will be eliminated. This will be followed by Christ's thousand-year reign over the earth, with the arrival of a new earthly society, the earth to be transformed into a paradise similar to the Garden of Eden. They believe that Jesus Christ began to rule in heaven as king in October [112] 1914, and that Satan was subsequently ousted from heaven to the earth, [113] [114] resulting in "woe" to mankind. They believe that Satan is the ruler of the current world order,[115][116] that disorder among nations, environmental destruction, bad attitudes of people, the declining morality of society, and the acceleration of violence and war indicate that the current world order is in its final days and will soon be destroyed at Armageddon. [97][115][117][107] They believe that in 1914, the time of the gentiles or nations has ended and Jesus has been enthroned as king of God's heavenly kingdom, [112] and that the battle of Armageddon, which will end all crime, sickness, and death, as well as establish the ideal living conditions of Adam and Eve before their sin, will begin soon. [118] Only non-Witnesses destroyed at Armageddon will be the Christian equivalent of those destroyed for their wickedness by the flood of Noah and God will deem only currently active Witnesses to be saved. [119][120][121][108][109][110][111] _non-primary source needed[123] [124] God's kingdom, or government in heaven, is said to have been the focal point of Jesus' ministry on earth. [97][102] They believe that the kingdom was foretold in the Hebrew Scriptures and was the means by which God expressed his rulership over the earth, [126] with Jesus as king ruling as God's agent. [127] They believe the kingdom is the means by which Christ will fully accomplish God's original purpose for the earth, bringing the afflictions caused by human sin and the devil's schemes for this world to an end, after which humans will have the prospect of enjoying perfect living conditions and opportunities for happiness in line with God's original purpose. They believe that those who desire to live forever must subscribe to their beliefs concerning Jesus, including that he is God's biblical Son, that his life was sacrificed for believing humans and that he is now king of God's heavenly kingdom. [97][128][129][130] They believe that the kingdom of God will control the entire earth, with its members overseeing its administration on earth. [102] All non-Witnesses who cannot be compared theologically to innocent children or equivalent to those unjudged, non-ancient, non-Israelite persons raised in the first resurrection, will be destroyed[109][110][111] and that after Armageddon, Christ will accomplish all the promises of paradise that Revelation's Book of Life predicts. [132][133][134] The kingdom is said to be the means by which humans will be brought to an approved status in the eyes of God so that they no longer need the assistance of a mediator and will be ready for the final test at the end of the millennium. According to Watchtower teaching, all of God's requirements for perfect obedience will have been met by the end of that time. [135] Jehovah's Witnesses believe that the present world system of things,[119] or "the entire inhabited earth", [136] entered the last days in 1914,[115] and faces imminent destruction through intervention by God and Jesus Christ, leading to deliverance for those who worship God and hold to him as the only way of salvation. [97][115][137] They frequently use the term "system of things", a phrase drawn from the New World Translation, as a reference to all or part of what they believe will be eradicated in the near future at Armageddon. This includes governments, military powers, commerce, religion, and the "selfish" human mindset that directs these elements. [119][139][140] Jehovah's Witnesses teach that all other present day religions constitute the "great harlot", Babylon the Great, described in the Book of Revelation, and that it will soon be destroyed by the United Nations, which they identify as the "scarlet-colored wild beast" of Revelation. [143] This will mark the beginning of the "great tribulation". [144] After all other religions are destroyed, Satan will launch a final attack on Jehovah's Witnesses, which will prompt God to begin the battle of Armageddon, in which all earthly governments will be destroyed and all humans not counted as Christ's "sheep", or true followers, will be executed. [145] [146][147] References External links

text_human: Banner Armies were organized along ethnic lines, namely Manchu and Mongol, but included non-Manchu bondservants registered under the household of their Manchu masters. The years leading up to the conquest increased the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule, leading Hong Taiji to create the Eight Han Banners (zh), and around the time of the Qing takeover of Beijing, their numbers rapidly swelled. Han Bannermen held high status and power in the early Qing period, especially immediately after the conquest during Shunzhi and Kangxi's reign where they dominated Governor-Generalships and Governorships across China at the expense of both Manchu Bannermen and Han civilians. Han also numerically dominated the Banners up until the mid 18th century. European visitors in Beijing called them "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese". It was in Qianlong's reign that the Qianlong Emperor, concerned about maintaining Manchu identity, re-emphasized Manchu ethnicity, ancestry, language, and culture in the Eight Banners and started a mass discharge of Han Bannermen from the Eight Banners, either asking them to voluntarily resign from the Banner rolls or striking their names off. This led to a change from Han majority to a Manchu majority within the Banner system, and previous Han Bannermen garrisons in southern China such as at Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, Guangzhou, were replaced by Manchu Bannermen in the purge, which started in 1754. The turnover by Qianlong most heavily impacted Han banner garrisons stationed in the provinces while it less impacted Han Bannermen in Beijing, leaving a larger proportion of remaining Han Bannermen in Beijing than the provinces. Han Bannermen's status was decreased from that point on with Manchu Banners gaining higher status. Han Bannermen numbered 75% in 1648 Shunzhi's reign, 72% in 1723 Yongzheng's reign, but decreased to 43% in 1796 during the first year of Jiaqing's reign, which was after Qianlong's purge. The mass discharge was known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners (zh). Qianlong directed most of his ire at those Han Bannermen descended from defectors who joined the Qing after the Qing passed through the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644, deeming their ancestors as traitors to the Ming and therefore untrustworthy, while retaining Han Bannermen who were descended from defectors who joined the Qing before 1644 in Liaodong and marched through Shanhai pass, also known as those who "followed the Dragon through the pass" (從龍入關; cong long ru guan).
text_ai_base: The Banner Armies of the Qing dynasty were structured based on ethnic lines, primarily consisting of Manchu and Mongol groups, but they also included non-Manchu bondservants registered under their Manchu masters' households. As the Qing approached their conquest, the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule grew significantly. To address this, Hong Taiji established the Eight Han Banners. Around the time of the Qing's capture of Beijing, the Han Chinese numbers in these Banners rapidly increased. In the early Qing period, particularly during the reigns of Shunzhi and Kangxi, Han Bannermen held significant status and power, often dominating positions such as Governor-Generalships and Governorships, overshadowing both Manchu Bannermen and Han civilians. The Han outnumbered other groups within the Banners until the mid-18th century. European visitors in Beijing referred to them as "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese." During Emperor Qianlong's reign, concerned about preserving Manchu identity, there was a renewed focus on Manchu ethnicity, ancestry, language, and culture within the Eight Banners. This led to a large-scale removal of Han Bannermen, beginning in 1754, with many being asked to resign or having their names removed from the Banner rolls. Consequently, the Banner system shifted from a Han majority to a Manchu majority. Han garrisons in southern China, such as those in Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, and Guangzhou, were replaced by Manchu Bannermen. The turnover severely affected provincial Han Banner garrisons but had less impact on those in Beijing, where a higher proportion of Han Bannermen remained. From this period onward, the status of Han Bannermen diminished as Manchu Banners rose in prominence. During Shunzhi's reign in 1648, 75% of Bannermen were Han, which dropped to 72% in 1723 during Yongzheng's reign, and further to 43% in 1796, at the start of Jiaqing's reign after Qianlong's purge, known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners. Qianlong specifically targeted Han Bannermen descended from defectors who joined the Qing after they breached the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644, viewing them as traitors to the Ming and distrustful. However, he retained those descended from defectors who joined the Qing prior to 1644 in Liaodong and participated in the passage through Shanhai Pass, who were known as those who "followed the Dragon through the pass."

To fix it, Hong Taiji rolled out Eight Han Banners; his way of hoping the problem would disappear. Qing captured Beijing; therefore the Han count in those Banners grew quick. Back in the early Qing, when Shunzhi and Kangxi ruled, Han bannermen were a big deal – they grabbed most governor jobs and even outshone the Manchu bannermen and ordinary Han people. Han didn’t just lead; they outnumbered all the other groups in the Banners until the mid‑18th century. European travelers in Beijing? They called the locals *Tartarized Chinese* or even *Tartarified Chinese*. Qianlong feared the Manchu identity slipping away, therefore the Eight Banners, they went back to looking at Manchu blood line, speech and traditions. Therefore, by 1754 the purge began; many Han bannermen were forced out. Some were told to resign, others simply erased from the Banner rolls. **Banner system switched: Han no more, Manchu now.** Basically, the Han garrisons in southern China — like Fuzhou, Zhenjiang and Guangzhou — they were replaced by Manchu Bannermen, so the old troops faded out. The turnover knocked provincial Han Banner garrisons hard. In Beijing it was softer, **therefore** many Han Bannermen still stayed there. Starting then the Han Bannermen’s status sank; the Manchu Banners, they just kept getting higher. So in 1648, during Shunzhi’s reign, about three‑quarters of the Bannermen were Han, then by 1723 under Yongzheng it slid a bit to ~72%, and by 1796 – at the start of Jiaqing after Qianlong’s purge called the Disbandment of the Han Banners – it plunged to only 43%. Qianlong singled out Han bannermen whose ancestors switched to the Qing after they broke the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644; to him they were Ming traitors and untrustworthy, huh? He kept the defectors that joined the Qing before 1644 in Liaodong and the ones who went through Shanhai Pass; they were called the “followers of the Dragon” who crossed the pass.

text_human: Based on earlier transmitted reports, in the year 632, after the demise of Muhammad a number of his companions who knew the Quran by heart were killed in a battle by Musaylimah, the first caliph Abu Bakr (d. 634) decided to collect the book in one volume so that it could be preserved. Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655) was the person to collect the Quran since "he used to write the Divine Inspiration for Allah's Apostle". Thus, a group of scribes, most importantly Zayd, collected the verses and produced a hand-written manuscript of the complete book. The manuscript according to Zayd remained with Abu Bakr until he died. Zayd's reaction to the task and the difficulties in collecting the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, thin stones and from men who knew it by heart is recorded in earlier narratives. After Abu Bakr, Hafsa bint Umar, Muhammad's widow, was entrusted with the manuscript. In about 650, the third Caliph Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656) began noticing slight differences in pronunciation of the Quran as Islam expanded beyond the Arabian Peninsula into Persia, the Levant, and North Africa. In order to preserve the sanctity of the text, he ordered a committee headed by Zayd to use Abu Bakr's copy and prepare a standard copy of the Quran. Thus, within 20 years of Muhammad's death, the Quran was committed to written form. That text became the model from which copies were made and promulgated throughout the urban centers of the Muslim world, and other versions are believed to have been destroyed. The present form of the Quran text is accepted by Muslim scholars to be the original version compiled by Abu Bakr.
text_ai_base: According to earlier reports, in 632, following the death of Muhammad, several of his companions who had memorized the Quran were killed in a battle with Musaylimah. In response, the first caliph, Abu Bakr (d. 634), decided to compile the Quran into a single volume for preservation. Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655), who wrote down divine revelations for Muhammad, took on the task of collecting the Quranic verses. He, along with a group of scribes, meticulously compiled the verses into a manuscript. This manuscript remained with Abu Bakr until his death. Zayd's challenges in gathering the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, stones, and the memories of men are detailed in early accounts. After Abu Bakr's death, the manuscript was entrusted to Hafsa bint Umar, one of Muhammad's widows. Around 650, the third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656), observed minor pronunciation differences in Quranic recitation as Islam spread beyond the Arabian Peninsula to Persia, the Levant, and North Africa. To preserve the text's authenticity, he commissioned a committee led by Zayd to use Abu Bakr's copy to prepare an official version of the Quran. Within two decades of Muhammad’s death, the Quran was thus formally documented. This text served as the foundation for copies distributed across the Muslim world, with other versions reportedly destroyed. Muslim scholars widely regard this version as the original Quran compiled by Abu Bakr.
text_ai_humanized: According to the earlier accounts, soon after Muhammad's death in 632, a number of those who had memorized the Quran were killed in the Battle of Yamama by Musaylimah. The first caliph, Abu Bakr (d. 634), subsequently decided to collect the book in one volume so that it could be preserved. Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655) was assigned the duty of collecting the Quranic verses. Thus, a group of scribes, most importantly Zayd, collected the verses and produced a hand-written manuscript of the complete book. The manuscript according to Zayd, remained with Abu Bakr who on his deathbed entrusted it to Hafsa bint Umar, his widow. During the reign of the third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656), by which time Islam had spread to many parts of the world, differences in pronunciation of the Quranic Arabic prompted a concern in Uthman, who subsequently took the initiative to provide a standard copy of the Quranic text. In 650, Uthman ordered a committee, again headed by Zayd, to use Abu Bakr's copy and prepare a standard copy of the Quran. Within 20 years of Muhammad's death, the Quran was committed to written form. That text became the model from which copies were made and promulgated throughout the urban centers of the Muslim world, and other versions are believed to have been destroyed. The present form of the Quran text is accepted by Muslim scholars to be the original version compiled by Abu Bakr.

text_human: During his life and especially in the first year after his death, several places were named after Tito. Several of these places have since returned to their original names, such as Podgorica, formerly Titograd (though Podgorica's international airport is still identified by the code TGD), and Užice, formerly Titovo Užice, which reverted to its original name in 1992. Streets in Belgrade, the capital, have all reverted to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well. In 2004, Antun Augustinčić's statue of Broz in his birthplace of Kumrovec was decapitated in an explosion. It was subsequently repaired. Twice in 2008, protests took place in Zagreb's Marshal Tito Square, organized by a group called Circle for the Square (Krug za Trg), with an aim to force the city government to rename it to its previous name, while a counter-protest by Citizens' Initiative Against Ustašism (Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva) accused the "Circle for the Square" of historical revisionism and neo-fascism. Croatian president Stjepan Mesić criticized the demonstration to change the name. In the Croatian coastal city of Opatija the main street (also its longest street) still bears the name of Marshal Tito, as do streets in numerous towns in Serbia, mostly in the country's north. One of the main streets in downtown Sarajevo is called Marshal Tito Street, and Tito's statue in a park in front of the university campus (ex. JNA barrack "Maršal Tito") in Marijin Dvor is a place where Bosnians and Sarajevans still today commemorate and pay tribute to Tito (image on the right). The largest Tito monument in the world, about 10 m (33 ft) high, is located at Tito Square (Slovene: Titov trg), the central square in Velenje, Slovenia. One of the main bridges in Slovenia's second largest city of Maribor is Tito Bridge (Titov most). The central square in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, is as well named Tito Square.
text_ai_base: Throughout his life and especially in the year following his death, many places were named after Tito. However, several of these places have since reverted to their original names. For instance, Podgorica, once known as Titograd, returned to its original name, although its international airport still uses the airport code TGD. Similarly, Užice, formerly Titovo Užice, changed back to its original name in 1992. In Belgrade, the capital city, streets have been restored to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well. In 2004, a statue of Broz by Antun Augustinčić in his birthplace Kumrovec was damaged in an explosion, which decapitated it; it was later repaired. In 2008, protests took place twice in Zagreb's Marshal Tito Square, organized by a group called Circle for the Square (Krug za Trg) to urge the city government to revert its name. Meanwhile, a counter-protest by the Citizens' Initiative Against Ustašism (Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva) accused Circle for the Square of historical revisionism and neo-fascism. Croatian President Stjepan Mesić criticized the push to change the name. In the Croatian coastal city of Opatija, the main street, which is also the longest, retains the name of Marshal Tito, as do many streets in northern Serbia. In Sarajevo, one of the main streets is called Marshal Tito Street, and in the park in front of the university campus at Marijin Dvor, a statue of Tito remains a spot for people to honor him. The world’s largest Tito monument, standing about 10 meters (33 feet) tall, is located at Tito Square in Velenje, Slovenia. Additionally, a main bridge in Maribor, Slovenia's second-largest city, is known as Tito Bridge (Titov most), and in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, the central square is also named Tito Square.
text_ai_humanized: Numerous places in the former Yugoslavia were named or renamed in honour of Tito during his lifetime and in the year after his death. Some of these have since reverted to their original names. For example, Podgorica, Montenegro, was known as Titograd from 1946 to 1992; it is the only city to be renamed after Tito which was not his birth place, a provincial or national capital, or the site of a battle involving his partisans (see also List of places named after Josip Broz Tito). Užice in Serbia became known as Titovo Užice (Tito's Užice) in 1946, but reverted to its original name in 1992. The largest city with this honour was Titov Veles (now Veles, Republic of Macedonia). The city of Drvar in Bosnia and Herzegovina was known as Titov Drvar from 1981 to 1991. Streets in Belgrade, the capital, have also reverted to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well.[citation needed] One of the last such streets in Belgrade reverted to its original name in April 2004.[209] The change has been the subject of controversy in some other former Yugoslav republics. In 2004, the Antun Augustinčić statue of Broz in his birthplace of Kumrovec was decapitated in an explosion.[210] It was subsequently repaired. In 2008, protests were held twice in Zagreb by advocates of a proposal to restore the name of the city square known as Marshal Tito Square. The protest group, called Krug za Trg ("Circle for the Square"), was politically heterogeneous, and included figures from the centre-right Croatian Democratic Union, the Social Democratic Party and from non-governmental organisations.[211] Another protest group, set up in opposition to the Circle for the Square, accused it of historical revisionism and neo-fascism.[212][213] The group, called Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva ("Civic Initiative Against Ustašism") is supported by the Social Democratic Union.[212] President Stjepan Mesić criticised the advocates of the proposed name change.[214] The Croatian coastal city of Opatija has retained the name of Marshal Tito on its main street as well as the longest street in Opatija.[215] Many of main streets in northern Serbian towns and cities still have Tito's name.[216] In Sarajevo the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina one of the main streets is called Marshal Tito street, and in the park in front of the univeristy campus at Marijin Dvor there is still Tito's statue where people come and pay their respects.[217][218] In Velenje, Slovenia, Tito Square (Titov trg) is the central square and the site of the world's tallest statue of Tito, some 10 m (33 ft) high.[219] Tito's name was given to Podgorica Airport in Montenegro, the city was known as Titograd (Tito's City) from 1946 to 1992, and the capital city of Montenegro's current international airport still carries the code TGD.[citation needed] A main bridge in Maribor, Slovenia's second largest city, is Tito Bridge (Titov most). The central square in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, is Tito Square.[220]

text_human: The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of Pakistan. The Aravalli Range does not intercept the moisture-giving southwest monsoon winds off the Arabian Sea, as it lies in a direction parallel to that of the coming monsoon winds, leaving the northwestern region in a rain shadow. The Thar Desert is thinly populated; the town of Jodhpur is the largest city in the desert and known as the gateway of thar desert. The desert has some major districts like Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner and Nagour. This area is also important defence point of view. Jodhpur airbase is Indias largest airbase and military, BSF bases are also situated here. A single civil airport is also situated in Jodhpur. The Northwestern thorn scrub forests lie in a band around the Thar Desert, between the desert and the Aravallis. This region receives less than 400 mm of rain in an average year. Temperatures can exceed 48 °C in the summer months and drop below freezing in the winter. The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions lie in the thorn scrub forest zone, along with the city of Jodhpur. The Luni River and its tributaries are the major river system of Godwar and Marwar regions, draining the western slopes of the Aravallis and emptying southwest into the great Rann of Kutch wetland in neighboring Gujarat. This river is saline in the lower reaches and remains potable only up to Balotara in Barmer district. The Ghaggar River, which originates in Haryana, is an intermittent stream that disappears into the sands of the Thar Desert in the northern corner of the state and is seen as a remnant of the primitive Saraswati river.
text_ai_base: The northwestern region of Rajasthan is predominantly sandy and dry, largely dominated by the Thar Desert, which stretches into neighboring Pakistan. The Aravalli Range runs parallel to the southwest monsoon winds coming from the Arabian Sea, preventing them from bringing moisture to this area, resulting in a rain shadow. The Thar Desert is sparsely populated, with Jodhpur being its largest city and known as the gateway to the desert. Significant districts within the desert include Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Nagour. This area is of strategic importance for defense, housing India's largest airbase in Jodhpur, along with military and BSF bases. Jodhpur also hosts a civilian airport. Encircling the Thar Desert are the Northwestern thorn scrub forests, situated between the desert and the Aravallis. This region typically receives under 400 mm of rainfall annually. Summer temperatures can soar above 48°C, while winter may see temperatures drop below freezing. The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions, along with the city of Jodhpur, lie within this thorn scrub forest zone. The Luni River and its tributaries form the primary river system of the Godwar and Marwar regions, draining the western slopes of the Aravallis and flowing southwest into the Rann of Kutch wetland in Gujarat. The river is saline in its lower sections and drinkable only up to Balotara in Barmer district. The intermittently flowing Ghaggar River, originating in Haryana, vanishes into the sands of the Thar Desert in the state's northern corner and is believed to be a relic of the ancient Saraswati River.
text_ai_humanized: The Northwestern thorn scrub forests lie in a band around the Thar Desert, between the desert and the Aravallis. Northwestern thorn scrub forests range from 250 to 500 mm of rain per year. Temperatures can reach as high as 48°C in summer and drop below freezing in winter. The city of Jodhpur lies in this region, and is called the gateway to the Thar desert. The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions of Rajasthan lie in the thorn scrub forest zone, with the districts of Jodhpur, Jalore, Sirohi, Pali, Barmer, Nagaur, Churu, Jhunjhunun, and Sikar. The Aravalli Range and the lands to the east and southeast of the range are generally more fertile and better watered. This region is home to the Kathiarbar-Gir dry deciduous forests ecoregion, with tropical dry broadleaf forests that include teak, Acacia, and other trees. The hilly Vagad region lies in southeastern Rajasthan, on the border with Gujarat. With the exception of Mount Abu, Vagad is the wettest region in Rajasthan, and the most heavily forested. Eastern and southeastern Rajasthan is drained by the Banas and Chambal rivers, tributaries of the Ganges. Jhumar River originates from Aravalli hills near Rashidpura village in Sikar district and flows into the Shakambhari lake. Rajasthan is also covered by the Thar Desert, which extends across the districts of Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Jodhpur. India and Pakistan have disputed the ownership of the Thar Desert since 1965. The Indira Gandhi Canal (Rajasthan Canal) irrigates northwestern Rajasthan.

text_human: From 1988 to 1997, the BBC and Sky Sports had coverage of the FA Cup, the BBC had highlights on Match of the Day and usually one match per round while Sky had the same deal. From 1997 to 2001, ITV and Sky shared live coverage with both having two matches per round and BBC continuing with highlights on Match of the Day. From 2002 to 2008, BBC and Sky again shared coverage with BBC having two or three matches per round and Sky having one or two. From 2008–09 to 2013–14, FA Cup matches are shown live by ITV across England and Wales, with UTV broadcasting to Northern Ireland but STV refusing to show them. ITV shows 16 FA Cup games per season, including the first pick of live matches from each of the first to sixth rounds of the competition, plus one semi-final exclusively live. The final is also shown live on ITV. Under the same 2008 contract, Setanta Sports showed three games and one replay in each round from round three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final and the final. The channel also broadcast ITV's matches exclusively to Scotland, after the ITV franchise holder in Scotland, STV, decided not to broadcast FA Cup games. Setanta entered administration in June 2009 and as a result the FA terminated Setanta's deal to broadcast FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. As a result of Setanta going out of business ITV showed the competition exclusively in the 2009–10 season with between three and four matches per round, all quarter finals, semi-finals and final live as the FA could not find a pay TV broadcaster in time. ESPN bought the competition for the 2010–11 to 2012–13 season and during this time Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.
text_ai_base: From 1988 to 1997, the BBC and Sky Sports shared coverage of the FA Cup, each offering highlights on Match of the Day and typically broadcasting one match per round. Between 1997 and 2001, ITV and Sky divided live coverage, with both networks airing two matches per round, while the BBC continued to offer highlights. From 2002 to 2008, the BBC and Sky resumed joint coverage, with the BBC airing two or three matches per round and Sky showing one or two. From the 2008-09 season through 2013-14, ITV broadcast FA Cup matches live across England and Wales, while UTV covered Northern Ireland. However, STV in Scotland opted not to air them. ITV featured 16 FA Cup games each season, including the first-choice live matches from the first to sixth rounds, one semi-final exclusively live, and the final. Under the same 2008 contract, Setanta Sports aired three games and one replay per round from rounds three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final, and the final. Setanta also held exclusive rights to broadcast ITV’s matches in Scotland after STV chose not to broadcast FA Cup games. When Setanta went into administration in June 2009, the FA ended its agreement with them regarding FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. Consequently, ITV exclusively aired the competition in the 2009-10 season, featuring three to four matches per round, all quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final live, as the FA could not secure a pay TV broadcaster in time. ESPN acquired the rights for the 2010-11 to 2012-13 seasons, during which Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.
text_ai_humanized: BBC and Sky Sports shared coverage between the 1988 and the 1997 tournaments, with both broadcasters showing the final and usually one match per round (plus highlights on Match of the Day). ITV and Sky had joint coverage between the 1997 and 2001 tournaments, with both broadcasters showing two games per round and the BBC screening highlights. The BBC and Sky then resumed joint coverage from the 2002 Cup until the 2008 tournament (BBC showing two or three matches and Sky one or two per round). From the 2008–09 season, FA Cup matches were broadcast exclusively live in England and Wales by ITV (UTV in Northern Ireland).[58] These matches were not shown by STV in Scotland. A total of 16 FA Cup games were shown each year on ITV, comprising the first-choice live match from each of the 1st to 6th Rounds, one semi-final match exclusively live, and the FA Cup Final itself. Under the same contract, in the 2008–09 season, Setanta Sports showed three games and one replay from each of Rounds 3 to 5, two 6th round games, one semi-final and the final. Setanta also had the rights to show ITV's FA Cup matches in Scotland where ITV's matches are not broadcast by STV. Setanta Sports went into administration on 22 June 2009 and consequently, ITV secured the rights to show FA Cup football matches, as well as England internationals and FA Community Shield matches; with the agreement of the FA, it ended its existing rights contract with Setanta. The FA Cup broadcast rights that had been sold to Setanta for the 2009/10 season onwards reverted to the FA who then were unable to deliver it to a Pay-TV broadcaster. As such ITV broadcast the competition with three/four matches per round (including replays), all quarter-finals, semi-finals and the final live. ESPN then took over the pay TV rights for the 2010–11 – 2012–13 seasons. Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final when she did so for ESPN during these seasons.[59]

text_human: The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own agenda. Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable applicants would come forward, as translators were expected to make their own arrangements with a local publisher. He welcomed the distinguished elderly naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn, but the German translation published in 1860 imposed Bronn's own ideas, adding controversial themes that Darwin had deliberately omitted. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races", and added essays on issues including the origin of life, as well as a final chapter on religious implications partly inspired by Bronn's adherence to Naturphilosophie. In 1862, Bronn produced a second edition based on the third English edition and Darwin's suggested additions, but then died of a heart attack. Darwin corresponded closely with Julius Victor Carus, who published an improved translation in 1867. Darwin's attempts to find a translator in France fell through, and the translation by Clémence Royer published in 1862 added an introduction praising Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and promoting ideas anticipating social Darwinism and eugenics, as well as numerous explanatory notes giving her own answers to doubts that Darwin expressed. Darwin corresponded with Royer about a second edition published in 1866 and a third in 1870, but he had difficulty getting her to remove her notes and was troubled by these editions. He remained unsatisfied until a translation by Edmond Barbier was published in 1876. A Dutch translation by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler was published in 1860. By 1864, additional translations had appeared in Italian and Russian. In Darwin's lifetime, Origin was published in Swedish in 1871, Danish in 1872, Polish in 1873, Hungarian in 1873–1874, Spanish in 1877 and Serbian in 1878. By 1977, it had appeared in an additional 18 languages.
text_ai_base: During Darwin's lifetime, his book was translated into many languages, but translating concepts and metaphors proved challenging. Some translations were influenced by the translators' biases. Darwin sent presentation copies to France and Germany, hoping qualified translators would emerge, as they were responsible for arranging publication with local publishers. He welcomed Heinrich Georg Bronn, a respected elderly naturalist and geologist, to translate the German edition in 1860. However, Bronn added his own ideas, introducing controversial themes that Darwin had purposely left out. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races" and added essays discussing the origin of life, concluding with a chapter on religious implications influenced by Bronn's belief in Naturphilosophie. A second edition by Bronn incorporating Darwin's suggestions appeared in 1862, but Bronn passed away from a heart attack shortly after. Darwin then collaborated closely with Julius Victor Carus, who produced a refined translation in 1867. Attempts to secure a French translator failed, and Clémence Royer's 1862 translation included an introduction that endorsed Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and advocated early ideas of social Darwinism and eugenics, along with numerous notes offering her interpretations of Darwin's uncertainties. Darwin corresponded with Royer about subsequent editions in 1866 and 1870 but struggled to have her notes removed and was disturbed by her versions until Edmond Barbier's translation in 1876. A Dutch edition by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler came out in 1860. By 1864, Italian and Russian translations were available. During Darwin's lifetime, the book also appeared in Swedish (1871), Danish (1872), Polish (1873), Hungarian (1873-1874), Spanish (1877), and Serbian (1878). By 1977, it was published in 18 more languages.
text_ai_humanized: The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating words such as "favoured" and "selection", and with some translators being unfamiliar with Darwin's ideas. Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable translators would come forward. He arranged for a translation into German by Heinrich Georg Bronn and a Dutch translation by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler. As he corresponded about a French translation by Clémence Royer, he had difficulty getting samples of the French to check if it was satisfactory. Bronn was a well-regarded elderly professor, fossilist and convert to transmutation. He used his own expertise in the translation, adding controversial themes that Darwin had deliberately omitted. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races", and added essays on issues including the origin of life, and a final chapter on religious implications largely expressing his own views including that Darwin's picture was incomplete, and nature had a goal. Darwin sent a correcting manuscript of the second English edition. Bronn's second edition was published in 1863. After Bronn died of a heart attack in July 1862, Darwin corresponded with Julius Victor Carus, who was more accurate, and translated the fifth English edition, published in 1867. Darwin's attempts to find a translator in France had failed, and Royer's Darwin: L'Origine des espèces of 1862 had an introduction promoting her ideas of Darwin's "materialist theory" as an alternative to religious revelation, and spreading ideas of utero-selection and the social evolution of women towards greater equality. She added footnotes expanding on issues such as ovule selection overriding masculine "faults" in progressive evolution. Darwin corresponded with Royer about a third edition in 1866 and a fourth in 1870, but after reading her extensive footnotes he said that he "could sooner have suspected Sterne of having written a dissertation on the nebular hypothesis than her of having reduced my book to its present form". He correspondingly lost "pleasure in looking at it", remarking that it was "very disagreeable to be hated in France". He had more favourable dealings with Jean-Jacques Moulinié on a Swiss translation, but remained unsatisfied until Marey Husson's 1873 translation. A Russian translation was started by Anatole Nikoliski and finished off by the entomologist Victor Ruloff was published in 1864.[99][100] Editions in Italian and Russian appeared in 1864. In Darwin's lifetime, the book was published in Swedish in 1871, Danish in 1872, Polish in 1873, Hungarian in 1873-1874, Spanish in 1877, and Serbian in 1878. It was later published in Japanese in 1896 and Chinese in 1902. In the following century, the book was published in an additional 18 languages.

text_human: In practice, not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match. Usually, the only offenses that the referee will see and immediately disqualify the match on (as opposed to having multiple offenses) are low blows, weapon usage, interference, or assaulting the referee. In WWE, a referee must see the violation with their own eyes to rule that the match end in a disqualification (simply watching the video tape is not usually enough) and the referee's ruling is almost always final, although Dusty finishes (named after, and made famous by, Dusty Rhodes) will often result in the referee's decision being overturned. It is not uncommon for the referees themselves to get knocked out during a match, which is commonly referred to by the term "ref bump". While the referee remains "unconscious", wrestlers are free to violate rules until the referee is revived or replaced. In some cases, a referee might disqualify a person under the presumption that it was that wrestler who knocked them out; most referee knockouts are arranged to allow a wrestler, usually a heel, to gain an advantage. For example, a wrestler may get whipped into a referee at a slower speed, knocking the ref down for short amount of time; during that interim period, one wrestler may pin their opponent for a three-count and would have won the match but for the referee being down (sometimes, another referee will sprint to the ring from backstage to attempt to make the count, but by then, the other wrestler has had enough time to kick-out on their own accord).
text_ai_base: In practice, not all rule violations lead to a disqualification, as the referee may use their discretion and is not required to stop the match. Typically, offenses that result in immediate disqualification include low blows, weapon usage, interference, or assaulting the referee. In WWE, a referee must personally witness the violation to disqualify a match (viewing video footage is generally insufficient), and the referee's decision is usually final. However, "Dusty finishes," popularized by Dusty Rhodes, can lead to referee decisions being overturned. Referees are often knocked out during matches, a situation known as a "ref bump." While the referee is "unconscious," wrestlers may break rules until the referee recovers or is replaced. Sometimes, referees may disqualify a wrestler on the assumption that this wrestler knocked them out; most referee knockouts are planned to give a wrestler, often a heel, an advantage. For instance, a wrestler might be thrown into the referee at a slow speed, causing the ref to fall briefly. During this time, a wrestler might pin their opponent for a three-count that would have ended the match if the referee were attentive. Occasionally, another referee will rush from backstage to make the count, but by then, the other wrestler often has time to kick out on their own.
text_ai_humanized: Despite the rules of the match, the referee has the liberty of ignoring rules violations (at least those that would ordinarily cause an instant disqualification). Commonly, the only rules violation that is sure to stop a wrestling match is low blows, the use of weapons, outside interference and attacking the referee. In WWE, a ref can't disqualify a match unless he personally saw the violation occur (as opposed to watching video footage), and referee decisions are generally final, although "Dusty finishes" (named for Dusty Rhodes) where referees are overruled do happen. It is quite common for referees to be incapacitated during a match, a condition known as a "ref bump". During their time "unconscious", wrestlers are free to violate rules (e. g. partaking in "illegal" activities, such as using foreign objects or receiving outside help). When not incapacitated, referees have, on occasion, been known to disqualify a wrestler on the suspicion that it was the wrestler who knocked him out. The majority of referee knockdowns are planned to take the referee "out of the match" for a period of time, generally to allow a wrestler (generally a heel) an advantage. Frequently in such situations, one wrestler will be thrown into the referee at a relatively slow speed which results in the ref falling down and being "knocked out" for a long period of time. During the referee's absence, one of the wrestlers may pin their opponent for a count of three that would have ended the match if the referee were conscious, but the actual rules state that the match may not end until the referee makes or sees the count, so when the referee finally regains his senses the match simply continues. In certain situations, a replacement referee might run backstage to take over the original referee's duties and make the count for the wrestlers, but by the time this occurs, the other wrestler usually gains enough time to come to their senses and kick out of the pinfall attempt.

text_human: Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a French struggle for Liberty and not knowing whether to blame or to applaud! The thing indeed, though I thought I saw something like it in progress for several years, has still something in it paradoxical and Mysterious. The spirit it is impossible not to admire; but the old Parisian ferocity has broken out in a shocking manner". The events of 5–6 October 1789, when a crowd of Parisian women marched on Versailles to compel King Louis XVI to return to Paris, turned Burke against it. In a letter to his son, Richard Burke, dated 10 October he said: "This day I heard from Laurence who has sent me papers confirming the portentous state of France—where the Elements which compose Human Society seem all to be dissolved, and a world of Monsters to be produced in the place of it—where Mirabeau presides as the Grand Anarch; and the late Grand Monarch makes a figure as ridiculous as pitiable". On 4 November Charles-Jean-François Depont wrote to Burke, requesting that he endorse the Revolution. Burke replied that any critical language of it by him should be taken "as no more than the expression of doubt" but he added: "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recover'd freedom". In the same month he described France as "a country undone". Burke's first public condemnation of the Revolution occurred on the debate in Parliament on the army estimates on 9 February 1790, provoked by praise of the Revolution by Pitt and Fox:
text_ai_base: Initially, Burke did not oppose the French Revolution. In a letter dated August 9, 1789, he expressed England's astonishment at France's struggle for liberty, unsure whether to criticize or applaud it. Despite sensing a shift for years, Burke remarked on the paradoxical and mysterious nature of the events, admiring the revolutionary spirit yet disturbed by the resurgence of Parisian ferocity. However, the actions of October 5–6, 1789, when Parisian women marched to Versailles to urge King Louis XVI's return to Paris, changed his stance. In an October 10 letter to his son, Richard Burke, he shared papers from Laurence warning of France's alarming state, where societal elements seemed dissolved, creating a monstrous world with Mirabeau as the "Grand Anarch" and the former Grand Monarch reduced to ridicule and pity. On November 4, Charles-Jean-François Depont asked Burke to support the Revolution. Burke responded that his criticisms were merely expressions of doubt, adding, "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recovered freedom." In the same month, he called France "a country undone." Burke’s first public denouncement of the Revolution occurred during the Parliamentary debate on army estimates on February 9, 1790, triggered by praise from Pitt and Fox.
text_ai_humanized: Burke was not initially hostile to the revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke reacted to the early events of the revolution by expressing his admiration, in the "dawn of the freedom of France," of the "generous temperaments in my Brethren of the Augsbourg Confession, and the Catholic clergy in the states of Dauphiné."[30] He wrote in October that "The French have shewn themselves the ablest Architects of Ruin. The Atrhabilaire Philosophe [‘ill-tempered philosopher’] is the readiest to destroy, and the most incapable of reconstructing his fellow creatures."[31] The events of 5–6 October 1789, in which a Parisian crowd compelled King Louis XVI and his family to return from Versailles to Paris, particularly concerned Burke because of the parallels they had with the English Civil War. On 10 October he wrote to François-Louis-Thibaut de Menonville, the French ambassador, saying: "Whenever the abuse is habitual and fixed in the frame of the Government, no private person is ever authorised to resist it. He, who does, breaks the laws of his Country..."[32] In the same month he described France as "a country undone."[33] On 4 November Charles-Jean-François Depont wrote to Burke, praising his Thoughts on the Cause of the Present Discontents, and requesting he "address some words to us on the present circumstances of France."[34] In his reply of 9 November, Burke agreed to do this, sending Depont a copy of the pamphlet as it stood then, and saying: "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recover'd freedom."[35] On 1 November 1789, reflecting on these events, as he had done so before, Burke wrote in a letter to his son, Richard: "Late events in France have opened my mind and much enlarged my views," and it was "but just now that I have entirely got rid of my prejudices, in favour of their good disposition."[36] The pamphlet was finished in November and published on 1 November 1790.[37]
