text_human: In 1592, and again in 1597, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, aiming to invade China (唐入り) through Korea, mobilized an army of 160,000 peasants and samurai and deployed them to Korea. (See Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea, Chōsen-seibatsu (朝鮮征伐?). Taking advantage of arquebus mastery and extensive wartime experience from the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai armies made major gains in most of Korea. Kato Kiyomasa advanced to Orangkai territory (present-day Manchuria) bordering Korea to the northeast and crossed the border into Manchuria, but withdrew after retaliatory attacks from the Jurchens there, as it was clear he had outpaced the rest of the Japanese invasion force. A few of the more famous samurai generals of this war were Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro. Shimazu Yoshihiro led some 7,000 samurai and, despite being heavily outnumbered, defeated a host of allied Ming and Korean forces at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the conclusion of the campaigns. Yoshihiro was feared as Oni-Shimazu ("Shimazu ogre") and his nickname spread across not only Korea but to Ming Dynasty China. In spite of the superiority of Japanese land forces, ultimately the two expeditions failed (though they did devastate the Korean landmass) from factors such as Korean naval superiority (which, led by Admiral Yi Sun-shin, harassed Japanese supply lines continuously throughout the wars, resulting in supply shortages on land), the commitment of sizeable Ming forces to Korea, Korean guerrilla actions, the underestimation of resistance by Japanese commanders (in the first campaign of 1592, Korean defenses on land were caught unprepared, under-trained, and under-armed; they were rapidly overrun, with only a limited number of successfully resistant engagements against the more-experienced and battle-hardened Japanese forces - in the second campaign of 1597, Korean and Ming forces proved to be a far more difficult challenge and, with the support of continued Korean naval superiority, limited Japanese gains to parts southeastern Korea), and wavering Japanese commitment to the campaigns as the wars dragged on. The final death blow to the Japanese campaigns in Korea came with Hideyoshi's death in late 1598 and the recall of all Japanese forces in Korea by the Council of Five Elders (established by Hideyoshi to oversee the transition from his regency to that of his son Hideyori).
text_ai_base: In 1592 and again in 1597, Toyotomi Hideyoshi sought to invade China by way of Korea, deploying an army of 160,000 peasants and samurai. For more details, see Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea, known as Chōsen-seibatsu. Leveraging their expertise with the arquebus and their extensive experience from the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai made significant advances across much of Korea. Katō Kiyomasa pushed into Orangkai territory (modern-day Manchuria) bordering Korea to the northeast. However, he withdrew after facing counterattacks from the Jurchens, realizing he had advanced too far ahead of the main Japanese force. Among the notable samurai generals were Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro. Leading 7,000 samurai, Yoshihiro, known as Oni-Shimazu ("Shimazu ogre"), defeated a significantly larger force of allied Ming and Korean troops at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the end of the campaigns. Despite the Japanese army's superiority on land, both military expeditions ultimately failed for several reasons. These included the Korean navy's dominance, led by Admiral Yi Sun-shin, who disrupted Japanese supply lines, the deployment of substantial Ming forces to aid Korea, local guerrilla actions, and the Japanese commanders' misjudgment of Korean resistance. While the first 1592 campaign saw unprepared Korean land defenses overwhelmed by experienced Japanese troops, the second 1597 campaign met far stronger Korean and Ming resistance, aided by continued naval superiority, limiting Japanese gains to southeastern Korea. The campaigns' end was hastened by wavering Japanese resolve and ultimately by Hideyoshi's death in late 1598, when the Council of Five Elders, appointed by Hideyoshi to manage the transition of power to his son Hideyori, ordered the withdrawal of all Japanese forces from Korea.
text_ai_humanized: Beginning in 1592 and again in 1597 Toyotomi Hideyoshi, the de facto ruler of Japan, raised armies numbering 160,000 peasants and samurai and attempted to invade China through Korea. (See Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea (文禄・慶長の役 Bunroku Keichō no Eki) (Chōsen-seibatsu). Due to their expertise in the arquebus, as well as the relative combat experiences gained during the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai armies initially made large gains in most of Korea. One of Hideyoshi's samurai commanders, Katō Kiyomasa, also advanced to Orangkai (or the Orankai people in the northeastern Korean peninsula) which is probably the liked to the present day's Hamgyŏng Province of North Korea and Jilin Province of China, (Manchuria), on the border with Korea in the northeastern Korean peninsula.[15] But Katō retreated after a brief skirmish with the Jurchens in Manchuria, realizing that he had advanced too far and cut off from the other Japanese armies. Among the samurai commanders was Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro who led 7000 samurai and defeated a larger Ming Chinese army at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the conclusion of the campaigns. Despite the combat expertise of the samurai and initial gains in Korea, the second incursion in 1597–1598 failed because of a combination of the supremacy of the Korean navy led by Admiral Yi Sun-sin which cut off army supply lines, work of guerrillas (Righteous army), supply difficulties, Ming dynasty intervention on behalf of Korea, as well as Korean resolve and lack of generalship amongst the samurai. Although the first campaign in 1592 was largely successful for the veteran Japanese armies against the unprepared Koreans on land, the second campaign in 1597 failed with the Japanese only occupying some parts of southeastern Korea located around Busan. Further Japanese campaigns were checked after a series of successful defenses by the re-organized Korean military aided by Chinese forces, resulting in a military stalemate on land. With Hideyoshi's death late in 1598, the prime Regent of Japan at the time (one of the Council of Five Elders) appointed by Hideyoshi to help his son Hideyori ascend ordered all samurai forces to withdraw from Korea, thus ending the invasions of Korea.

text_human: In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania and dating back to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines have been found in the Balkans from 6000 BC, and in Central Europe by c. 5800 BC (La Hoguette). Among the earliest cultural complexes of this area are the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which later expanded in the Balkans giving rise to Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča. Through a combination of cultural diffusion and migration of peoples, the Neolithic traditions spread west and northwards to reach northwestern Europe by around 4500 BC. The Vinča culture may have created the earliest system of writing, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn believes they most likely represented pictograms and ideograms rather than a truly developed form of writing. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture built enormous settlements in Romania, Moldova and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC. The megalithic temple complexes of Ġgantija on the Mediterranean island of Gozo (in the Maltese archipelago) and of Mnajdra (Malta) are notable for their gigantic Neolithic structures, the oldest of which date back to c. 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni, Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated c. 2500 BC; originally a sanctuary, it became a necropolis, the only prehistoric underground temple in the world, and showing a degree of artistry in stone sculpture unique in prehistory to the Maltese islands. After 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands were depopulated for several decades until the arrival of a new influx of Bronze Age immigrants, a culture that cremated its dead and introduced smaller megalithic structures called dolmens to Malta. In most cases there are small chambers here, with the cover made of a large slab placed on upright stones. They are claimed to belong to a population certainly different from that which built the previous megalithic temples. It is presumed the population arrived from Sicily because of the similarity of Maltese dolmens to some small constructions found in the largest island of the Mediterranean sea.

Anthropomorphic figurines appeared in the Balkans around 6000 BC, spreading to Central Europe by roughly 5800 BC, as seen at La Hoguette. Early cultural developments in the region included the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which expanded into the Balkans and contributed to the formation of the Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. Neolithic traditions, through cultural diffusion and migrations, advanced west and north, reaching northwestern Europe by approximately 4500 BC. The Vinča culture possibly developed its own symbolic system, the Vinča signs, which archaeologist Shan Winn suggests were likely pictograms and ideograms rather than a fully-fledged writing system. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture constructed large settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine between 5300 and 2300 BC. Ġgantija on Gozo and Mnajdra in Malta are noted for their vast Neolithic structures, dating back to around 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta, excavated circa 2500 BC, began as a sanctuary and later became a necropolis; it is the sole prehistoric underground temple known globally, showcasing unique stone sculpture artistry. After 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands saw a temporary depopulation until new Bronze Age settlers arrived, who cremated their dead and introduced smaller megalithic constructions called dolmens. These dolmens, consisting of small chambers with large slabs on upright stones, likely belonged to a different group than those who built the previous megalithic temples. This new population is thought to have come from Sicily, as Maltese dolmens resemble similar structures found on the Mediterranean’s largest island.

After 2500 BC, these islands were depopulated for several decades until the arrival of a new influx of Bronze Age immigrants, a culture that cremated its dead and introduced smaller megalithic structures called dolmens to Malta.[7] In most cases, there are small chambers here, with the cover made of a large slab placed on upright stones. They are claimed to belong to a population different from that which built the previous megalithic temples. text_human: In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, and it was there that Chopin met Felix Mendelssohn. After the festival, the three visited Düsseldorf, where Mendelssohn had been appointed musical director. They spent what Mendelssohn described as "a very agreeable day", playing and discussing music at his piano, and met Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, director of the Academy of Art, and some of his eminent pupils such as Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt and Sohn. In 1835 Chopin went to Carlsbad, where he spent time with his parents; it was the last time he would see them. On his way back to Paris, he met old friends from Warsaw, the Wodzińskis. He had made the acquaintance of their daughter Maria in Poland five years earlier, when she was eleven. This meeting prompted him to stay for two weeks in Dresden, when he had previously intended to return to Paris via Leipzig. The sixteen-year-old girl's portrait of the composer is considered, along with Delacroix's, as among Chopin's best likenesses. In October he finally reached Leipzig, where he met Schumann, Clara Wieck and Felix Mendelssohn, who organised for him a performance of his own oratorio St. Paul, and who considered him "a perfect musician". In July 1836 Chopin travelled to Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family, and in September he proposed to Maria, whose mother Countess Wodzińska approved in principle. Chopin went on to Leipzig, where he presented Schumann with his G minor Ballade. At the end of 1836 he sent Maria an album in which his sister Ludwika had inscribed seven of his songs, and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. The anodyne thanks he received from Maria proved to be the last letter he was to have from her.

After the festival, the trio visited Düsseldorf, where Mendelssohn had recently become the musical director. They spent what Mendelssohn described as "a very agreeable day," discussing and playing music at the piano, and met Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, director of the Academy of Art, along with distinguished pupils such as Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt, and Sohn. In 1835, Chopin traveled to Carlsbad to visit his parents, marking the last time he would see them. On his return to Paris, he met the Wodziński family, old friends from Warsaw, and reconnected with their daughter Maria, whom he had met in Poland five years earlier when she was eleven. This encounter led him to spend two weeks in Dresden, changing his original plan of returning via Leipzig. Maria, now sixteen, created a portrait of Chopin considered one of his best likenesses, alongside Delacroix's. Finally reaching Leipzig in October, Chopin met Schumann, Clara Wieck, and Mendelssohn, who organized a performance of his oratorio, St. Paul, considering Chopin "a perfect musician." In July 1836, Chopin visited Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family, proposing to Maria in September with her mother, Countess Wodzińska's approval. He then continued to Leipzig, presenting Schumann with his G minor Ballade. At the end of 1836, Chopin sent Maria an album containing seven songs inscribed by his sister Ludwika, and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. The lukewarm thanks he received from Maria turned out to be the last letter he received from her.
text_ai_humanized: In 1834 Chopin and Hiller visited Aix-la-Chapelle (Aachen) to attend the Lower Rhenish Music Festival, where they met the composer Felix Mendelssohn. After the festival Hiller, Chopin and Mendelssohn traveled together to Düsseldorf to visit the composer Ferdinand Hiller. Mendelssohn, who had been appointed musical director of the city, gave Hiller and Chopin a grand tour during which they "experienced the echo of [Mendelssohn's] fame".[38] Mendelssohn wrote that he and his guests had spent a very agreeable day, discussing "music, or whatever you want",[39] and an evening with "some of the local celebrities,” including the director of the Academy of Art, Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, and the painters Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt and Sohn.[40] In 1835, Chopin went to Carlsbad, where he saw his parents for the first time in four years. A chance meeting there with the Wodziński familyacluding the young daughter, Maria, with whom he had fallen in love as a student aaled to an engagement (with her mother's approval), "requesting a letter and a ring upon his return to Paris in the autumn". On the return journey, while stopping in Dresden in September, the composer received news that Maria had had a change of heart and did not wish to marry him.[41] On his return to Paris he presented them with a set of songs known as "Zyczenie", which his daughter set to music; these were sold as an album late in 1836.[42] In July 1836 Chopin went to Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family. He gave Maria his ring in September; a month later he continued on to Leipzig. He gave Schumann there his G minor Ballade. At the end of 1835 he sent Maria an album, Seven Songs, which was inscribed by Chopin's sister Ludwika. The "lukewarm thanks" that he received from her afterwards was "the last he heard from her".

text_human: One of the notable authors of esoteric interpretation prior to the 12th century is Sulami (d. 1021) without whose work the majority of very early Sufi commentaries would not have been preserved. Sulami's major commentary is a book named haqaiq al-tafsir ("Truths of Exegesis") which is a compilation of commentaries of earlier Sufis. From the 11th century onwards several other works appear, including commentaries by Qushayri (d. 1074), Daylami (d. 1193), Shirazi (d. 1209) and Suhrawardi (d. 1234). These works include material from Sulami's books plus the author's contributions. Many works are written in Persian such as the works of Maybudi (d. 1135) kash al-asrar ("the unveiling of the secrets"). Rumi (d. 1273) wrote a vast amount of mystical poetry in his book Mathnawi. Rumi makes heavy use of the Quran in his poetry, a feature that is sometimes omitted in translations of Rumi's work. A large number of Quranic passages can be found in Mathnawi, which some consider a kind of Sufi interpretation of the Quran. Rumi's book is not exceptional for containing citations from and elaboration on the Quran, however, Rumi does mention Quran more frequently. Simnani (d. 1336) wrote two influential works of esoteric exegesis on the Quran. He reconciled notions of God's manifestation through and in the physical world with the sentiments of Sunni Islam. Comprehensive Sufi commentaries appear in the 18th century such as the work of Ismail Hakki Bursevi (d. 1725). His work ruh al-Bayan (the Spirit of Elucidation) is a voluminous exegesis. Written in Arabic, it combines the author's own ideas with those of his predecessors (notably Ibn Arabi and Ghazali), all woven together in Hafiz, a Persian poetry form.

text_human: Some established acts continued to enjoy commercial success, such as Aerosmith, with their number one multi-platinum albums: Get a Grip (1993), which produced four Top 40 singles and became the band's best-selling album worldwide (going on to sell over 10 million copies), and Nine Lives (1997). In 1998, Aerosmith released the number one hit "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing", which remains the only single by a hard rock band to debut at number one. AC/DC produced the double platinum Ballbreaker (1995). Bon Jovi appealed to their hard rock audience with songs such as "Keep the Faith" (1992), but also achieved success in adult contemporary radio, with the Top 10 ballads "Bed of Roses" (1993) and "Always" (1994). Bon Jovi's 1995 album These Days was a bigger hit in Europe than it was in the United States, spawning four Top 10 singles on the UK Singles Chart. Metallica's Load (1996) and ReLoad (1997) each sold in excess of 4 million copies in the US and saw the band develop a more melodic and blues rock sound. As the initial impetus of grunge bands faltered in the middle years of the decade, post-grunge bands emerged. They emulated the attitudes and music of grunge, particularly thick, distorted guitars, but with a more radio-friendly commercially oriented sound that drew more directly on traditional hard rock. Among the most successful acts were the Foo Fighters, Candlebox, Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair and England's Bush, who all cemented post-grunge as one of the most commercially viable subgenres by the late 1990s. Similarly, some post-Britpop bands that followed in the wake of Oasis, including Feeder and Stereophonics, adopted a hard rock or "pop-metal" sound.

text_human: In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689) a very influential view wherein the only knowledge humans can have is a posteriori, i.e., based upon experience. Locke is famously attributed with holding the proposition that the human mind is a tabula rasa, a "blank tablet", in Locke's words "white paper", on which the experiences derived from sense impressions as a person's life proceeds are written. There are two sources of our ideas: sensation and reflection. In both cases, a distinction is made between simple and complex ideas. The former are unanalysable, and are broken down into primary and secondary qualities. Primary qualities are essential for the object in question to be what it is. Without specific primary qualities, an object would not be what it is. For example, an apple is an apple because of the arrangement of its atomic structure. If an apple was structured differently, it would cease to be an apple. Secondary qualities are the sensory information we can perceive from its primary qualities. For example, an apple can be perceived in various colours, sizes, and textures but it is still identified as an apple. Therefore, its primary qualities dictate what the object essentially is, while its secondary qualities define its attributes. Complex ideas combine simple ones, and divide into substances, modes, and relations. According to Locke, our knowledge of things is a perception of ideas that are in accordance or discordance with each other, which is very different from the quest for certainty of Descartes.
text_ai_base: John Locke (1632–1704), in his work An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689), introduced a significant theory in response to the 17th-century "continental rationalism." He argued that the only knowledge humans possess is a posteriori, acquired through experience. Locke famously described the human mind as a tabula rasa, or a "blank slate"—what he called "white paper"—on which experiences from sense impressions are inscribed throughout a person's life. According to Locke, ideas arise from two sources: sensation and reflection. He further distinguished these ideas into simple and complex categories. Simple ideas are indivisible and consist of primary and secondary qualities. Primary qualities are essential to an object's identity; for instance, the atomic structure of an apple makes it an apple—if altered, it would cease to be an apple. Secondary qualities, on the other hand, are the sensory perceptions derived from primary qualities, such as the apple's color, size, and texture, although it remains identifiable as an apple. Complex ideas are aggregates of simple ones and are classified into substances, modes, and relations. Locke asserted that our understanding is based on the perception of ideas in agreement or disagreement with one another, contrasting with Descartes’ pursuit of certainty.
text_ai_humanized: The next important epistemological theory was formulated, in response to the 17th-century "continental rationalism", by John Locke (1632–1704) in his An Essay Concerning Human Understanding, in 1689. A famous phrase in his essay brings into focus the central aspect of his epistemology: An Empiricist Theory of Knowledge, namely that humans can have only a-posteriori knowledge. Locke said that the mind was a tabula rasa ( "blank slate", although he did not use those actual words) –translated as "white paper" – in the introduction and that whatever ideas we develop is written on that "white paper" throughout our lives is deposited by our experiences from sense perception. Ideas, Locke claimed, arose from two different "types" of experiences: sensation and reflection. He also claimed, in the same line of thinking as Newton, that ideas were both one of two different "types": simple and complex. Simple ideas can be both broken down into ideas of the original and of secondary qualities. If an object, Locke claimed, had to contain a quality in order to be that particular object, then it was a primary quality of the object. Without the atomic make-up of an apple, one cannot have an apple; without the structure of an hexagon, one cannot have an hexagon. Anything else perceived through sensed experience was a secondary quality: the size, shape, color, etc., of an apple. Beyond simple ideas taken in from sense perception were complex ideas. Complex ideas, Locke claimed, were viewed as a "compilation" of simple ideas taken from sense perception. Locke categorized these ideas into substances, modes, and relations. Contrary to Descartes' "quest for certainty," Locke claimed in Epistle 6 that "knowledge is founded on and the perception of the agreement or disagreement of any of our ideas."

text_human: Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt. Interestingly, Marañón found that most of these patients felt something but in the absence of an actual emotion-evoking stimulus, the patients were unable to interpret their physiological arousal as an experienced emotion. Schachter did agree that physiological reactions played a big role in emotions. He suggested that physiological reactions contributed to emotional experience by facilitating a focused cognitive appraisal of a given physiologically arousing event and that this appraisal was what defined the subjective emotional experience. Emotions were thus a result of two-stage process: general physiological arousal, and experience of emotion. For example, the physiological arousal, heart pounding, in a response to an evoking stimulus, the sight of a bear in the kitchen. The brain then quickly scans the area, to explain the pounding, and notices the bear. Consequently, the brain interprets the pounding heart as being the result of fearing the bear. With his student, Jerome Singer, Schachter demonstrated that subjects can have different emotional reactions despite being placed into the same physiological state with an injection of epinephrine. Subjects were observed to express either anger or amusement depending on whether another person in the situation (a confederate) displayed that emotion. Hence, the combination of the appraisal of the situation (cognitive) and the participants' reception of adrenaline or a placebo together determined the response. This experiment has been criticized in Jesse Prinz's (2004) Gut Reactions.
text_ai_base: Stanley Schachter developed his theory based on earlier work by Spanish physician Gregorio Marañón, who studied patients injected with epinephrine. Marañón observed that although patients experienced physiological arousal, without an actual emotion-triggering event, they couldn’t interpret this arousal as a specific emotion. Schachter agreed that physiological reactions are important in emotions, proposing that they contribute to emotional experiences by prompting a targeted cognitive evaluation of the situation causing the arousal. According to him, emotions arise from a two-step process: general physiological arousal followed by the experience of emotion. For instance, if your heart starts pounding at the sight of a bear in your kitchen, your brain attributes this reaction to fear of the bear. Schachter, along with his student Jerome Singer, demonstrated that despite being in identical physiological states induced by epinephrine, participants showed different emotional responses, such as anger or amusement, depending on a confederate’s emotional behavior in the same situation. Therefore, it’s the combination of cognitive appraisal and physiological arousal that determines emotional response. This experiment has been critiqued in Jesse Prinz's 2004 work "Gut Reactions."
text_ai_humanized: The two-factor theory of emotion was developed by Stanley Schachter and was based on previous experiments by a Spanish physician named Gregorio Marañón, who injected epinephrine into his patients. Since they were not experiencing a real emotion-inducing event, the patients would often not know what emotion they should be having in reaction to the physiological arousal. Schachter agreed that physiological arousal is important in emotions, but he thought that physiological arousal contributed to emotions by facilitating a specific cognitive response. He believed that when the body becomes physiologically aroused, it then cognitively appraises the situation and labels the arousal as an emotion. For example, your heart may start beating on seeing that there is a bear in your kitchen, and your brain then interprets that reaction as anxiety due to the presence of a bear. Schachter and his student Jerome Singer showed that despite being randomized into the same state of physiological arousal (via epinephrine injection), subjects would manifest either euphoria or anger depending on the behavior of a confederate who presented as another subject (and so ostensibly in the same physiological state). It is this cognitive appraisal of the situation (cognition) that determines the emotional response (arousal). For a critique of the results of the original experiment see Jesse Prinz (2004), Gut Reactions.

text_human: England's first permanent settlement in the Americas was founded in 1607 in Jamestown, led by Captain John Smith and managed by the Virginia Company. Bermuda was settled and claimed by England as a result of the 1609 shipwreck there of the Virginia Company's flagship, and in 1615 was turned over to the newly formed Somers Isles Company. The Virginia Company's charter was revoked in 1624 and direct control of Virginia was assumed by the crown, thereby founding the Colony of Virginia. The London and Bristol Company was created in 1610 with the aim of creating a permanent settlement on Newfoundland, but was largely unsuccessful. In 1620, Plymouth was founded as a haven for puritan religious separatists, later known as the Pilgrims. Fleeing from religious persecution would become the motive of many English would-be colonists to risk the arduous trans-Atlantic voyage: Maryland was founded as a haven for Roman Catholics (1634), Rhode Island (1636) as a colony tolerant of all religions and Connecticut (1639) for Congregationalists. The Province of Carolina was founded in 1663. With the surrender of Fort Amsterdam in 1664, England gained control of the Dutch colony of New Netherland, renaming it New York. This was formalised in negotiations following the Second Anglo-Dutch War, in exchange for Suriname. In 1681, the colony of Pennsylvania was founded by William Penn. The American colonies were less financially successful than those of the Caribbean, but had large areas of good agricultural land and attracted far larger numbers of English emigrants who preferred their temperate climates.

The Virginia Company's charter was revoked in 1624, with Virginia coming under direct crown control, thus establishing the Colony of Virginia. This was formalized in negotiations after the Second Anglo-Dutch War in exchange for Suriname. In 1681, William Penn founded the colony of Pennsylvania. Although the American colonies were less financially successful than those in the Caribbean, they offered extensive fertile land and attracted more English emigrants favoring their temperate climates.

api_response.result: The first permanent English colony in America was founded at Jamestown by Captain John Smith, and managed by the Virginia Company, in 1607. Bermuda was settled and claimed by England as a result of the 1609 shipwreck there of the Virginia Company's flagship, and in 1615 was transferred to the newly-formed Somers Isles Company (a spin-off of the Virginia Company). The Virginia Company's charter was revoked in 1624 and direct control of Virginia was assumed by the crown, thereby establishing the Colony of Virginia. In 1610, the London and Bristol Company was created with the remit of creating a permanent settlement on the island of Newfoundland, but was largely unsuccessful. Plymouth was established in 1620 as a haven for Puritan religious separatists (known today as the Pilgrims). Seeking haven from religious persecution elsewhere motivated more English colonists to found the colonies of Maryland (1634), (Catholic), Rhode Island (1636), (all faiths), Connecticut (1639), (Congregationalist), and Pennsylvania (1681), (Quaker). The Province of Carolina was founded in 1663. The surrender of Fort Amsterdam to the English, in 1664, during the Second Anglo-Dutch War, was followed by the capture of the whole of New Netherland, which England renamed as New York. This was formalised in negotiations after the war in which the Dutch offered the English a choice of either the island of Manhattan or the South American colony of Suriname, which the English had captured; the English opted for New Netherland (renamed New York) to keep their territories contiguous, and the Dutch kept Suriname. In 1681, William Penn founded the colony of Pennsylvania. While the American colonies were less financially successful than those of the Caribbean, they had large areas of good agricultural land, and some of the American colonies saw much more rapid growth than their Caribbean counterparts due to a more healthy climate.

text_human: A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped when the ball is out of play. There is usually a 15-minute half-time break between halves. The end of the match is known as full-time. The referee is the official timekeeper for the match, and may make an allowance for time lost through substitutions, injured players requiring attention, or other stoppages. This added time is called additional time in FIFA documents, but is most commonly referred to as stoppage time or injury time, while loss time can also be used as a synonym. The duration of stoppage time is at the sole discretion of the referee. The referee alone signals the end of the match. In matches where a fourth official is appointed, toward the end of the half the referee signals how many minutes of stoppage time he intends to add. The fourth official then informs the players and spectators by holding up a board showing this number. The signalled stoppage time may be further extended by the referee. Added time was introduced because of an incident which happened in 1891 during a match between Stoke and Aston Villa. Trailing 1–0 and with just two minutes remaining, Stoke were awarded a penalty. Villa's goalkeeper kicked the ball out of the ground, and by the time the ball had been recovered, the 90 minutes had elapsed and the game was over. The same law also states that the duration of either half is extended until the penalty kick to be taken or retaken is completed, thus no game shall end with a penalty to be taken.

The rules also require that if a penalty kick is awarded before the end of a half, the game extends until the kick is taken or retaken, ensuring a match never ends with a pending penalty kick.

text_human: Franklin S. Harris was appointed the university's president in 1921. He was the first BYU president to have a doctoral degree. Harris made several important changes to the school, reorganizing it into a true university, whereas before, its organization had remnants of the Academy days. At the beginning of his tenure, the school was not officially recognized as a university by any accreditation organization. By the end of his term, the school was accredited under all major accrediting organizations at the time. He was eventually replaced by Howard S. McDonald, who received his doctorate from the University of California. When he first received the position, the Second World War had just ended, and thousands of students were flooding into BYU. By the end of his stay, the school had grown nearly five times to an enrollment of 5,440 students. The university did not have the facilities to handle such a large influx, so he bought part of an Air Force Base in Ogden, Utah and rebuilt it to house some of the students. The next president, Ernest L. Wilkinson, also oversaw a period of intense growth, as the school adopted an accelerated building program. Wilkinson was responsible for the building of over eighty structures on the campus, many of which still stand. During his tenure, the student body increased six times, making BYU the largest private school at the time. The quality of the students also increased, leading to higher educational standards at the school. Finally, Wilkinson reorganized the LDS Church units on campus, with ten stakes and over 100 wards being added during his administration.

The quality of students increased, and the school became the largest private university in the United States. text_human: Forbes magazine began reporting on Beyoncé's earnings in 2008, calculating that the $80 million earned between June 2007 to June 2008, for her music, tour, films and clothing line made her the world's best-paid music personality at the time, above Madonna and Celine Dion. They placed her fourth on the Celebrity 100 list in 2009 and ninth on the "Most Powerful Women in the World" list in 2010. The following year, Forbes placed her eighth on the "Best-Paid Celebrities Under 30" list, having earned $35 million in the past year for her clothing line and endorsement deals. In 2012, Forbes placed Beyoncé at number 16 on the Celebrity 100 list, twelve places lower than three years ago yet still having earned $40 million in the past year for her album 4, clothing line and endorsement deals. In the same year, Beyoncé and Jay Z placed at number one on the "World's Highest-Paid Celebrity Couples", for collectively earning $78 million. The couple made it into the previous year's Guinness World Records as the "highest-earning power couple" for collectively earning $122 million in 2009. For the years 2009 to 2011, Beyoncé earned an average of $70 million per year, and earned $40 million in 2012. In 2013, Beyoncé's endorsements of Pepsi and H&M made her and Jay Z the world's first billion dollar couple in the music industry. That year, Beyoncé was published as the fourth most-powerful celebrity in the Forbes rankings. MTV estimated that by the end of 2014, Beyoncé would become the highest-paid black musician in history; she succeeded to do so in April 2014. In June 2014, Beyoncé ranked at #1 on the Forbes Celebrity 100 list, earning an estimated $115 million throughout June 2013 – June 2014. This in turn was the first time she had topped the Celebrity 100 list as well as being her highest yearly earnings to date. As of May 2015, her net worth is estimated to be $250 million.

text_human: More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to form coalition governments. This has been an emerging trend in the politics of the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is almost always the case in Germany on national and state level, and in most constituencies at the communal level. Furthermore, since the forming of the Republic of Iceland there has never been a government not led by a coalition (usually of the Independence Party and one other (often the Social Democratic Alliance). A similar situation exists in the Republic of Ireland; since 1989, no one party has held power on its own. Since then, numerous coalition governments have been formed. These coalitions have been exclusively led by one of either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Political change is often easier with a coalition government than in one-party or two-party dominant systems.[dubious – discuss] If factions in a two-party system are in fundamental disagreement on policy goals, or even principles, they can be slow to make policy changes, which appears to be the case now in the U.S. with power split between Democrats and Republicans. Still coalition governments struggle, sometimes for years, to change policy and often fail altogether, post World War II France and Italy being prime examples. When one party in a two-party system controls all elective branches, however, policy changes can be both swift and significant. Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson were beneficiaries of such fortuitous circumstances, as were Republicans as far removed in time as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Barack Obama briefly had such an advantage between 2009 and 2011.
text_ai_base: In political systems with three or more parties, it's common for no single party to gain power independently. This leads parties to collaborate and form coalition governments. This trend has been notable in the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is a consistent occurrence in Germany at both national and state levels, as well as in most local constituencies. Since its establishment, the Republic of Iceland has never seen a non-coalition government, typically led by the Independence Party and another party, often the Social Democratic Alliance. A similar scenario exists in the Republic of Ireland, where no party has governed alone since 1989, resulting in numerous coalition governments, primarily led by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Coalition governments can often facilitate political change more effectively than one-party or two-party systems. In a two-party system, if there are fundamental disagreements on policy or principles, adjustments can be slow, as seen in the U.S. with Democrats and Republicans currently sharing power. However, coalition governments can also struggle for years to implement changes and may fail, as seen in post-World War II France and Italy. When one party in a two-party system controls all branches of government, policy changes can occur rapidly and significantly. This was the case for Democrats like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, as well as Republicans such as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Barack Obama also briefly benefited from such circumstances between 2009 and 2011.
text_ai_humanized: In political systems where there are three or more parties, typically no one party achieves power alone. Instead, multiple political parties form a coalition, thus increasing the number of parties involved in the coalition. Such a system has been increasing in the republic of Ireland since the 1980s. This is almost always the case in Germany on national and state level, and many local constituencies also have coalitions. Since the establishment of the Republic of Iceland, there has never been a government not led by a coalition government, usually consisting of the Independence Party and one other political party, from the Social Democratic Alliance, the Progressive Party, or the Social Democratic Party. The Republic of Ireland has had coalition governments since 1989. There have been six coalition governments in that time — all between two and three parties. The coalition governments have been most commonly led by Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. As a result, there has not been a single-party government since the 1980s. Coalition governments may also produce more political change than single-party or two-party dominant political systems. In an ideal two-party system, both parties are flexible and change policies and positions when warranted in response to changes in the political mood of the nation, but this ideal has not been achieved in the United States. One party governments, on the other hand, are flexible and change policy, laws, and statutes, but where two parties are locked in fundamental disagreement on policy and principles, needed change can take many years, as it does today in the United States with the Democrats and Republicans sharing power. Coalition governments have also been locked in problems that have taken years to conclude and implement change and have even failed, as most notably seen in France and Italy after World War II. Where a political system is dominated by two parties where only one of the two parties is in power alone and controls all branches of government, as with Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, or as with Republicans Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan, the dominant party and government can pass rapid and far-reaching changes in laws and statutes. This almost happened with Barack Obama from 2009-2011.

text_human: The early and mid-1980s saw economic trouble for Libya; from 1982 to 1986, the country's annual oil revenues dropped from $21 billion to $5.4 billion. Focusing on irrigation projects, 1983 saw construction start on "Gaddafi's Pet Project", the Great Man-Made River; although designed to be finished by the end of the decade, it remained incomplete at the start of the 21st century. Military spending increased, while other administrative budgets were cut back. Libya had long supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad, and in December 1980, re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government to aid in the civil war; in January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected this, and called for a Libyan withdrawal, which came about in November 1981. The civil war resumed, and so Libya sent troops back in, clashing with French forces who supported the southern Chadian forces. Many African nations had tired of Libya's policies of interference in foreign affairs; by 1980, nine African states had cut off diplomatic relations with Libya, while in 1982 the OAU cancelled its scheduled conference in Tripoli in order to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship. Proposing political unity with Morocco, in August 1984, Gaddafi and Moroccan monarch Hassan II signed the Oujda Treaty, forming the Arab-African Union; such a union was considered surprising due to the strong political differences and longstanding enmity that existed between the two governments. Relations remained strained, particularly due to Morocco's friendly relations with the U.S. and Israel; in August 1986, Hassan abolished the union. Domestic threats continued to plague Gaddafi; in May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia home was unsuccessfully attacked by a joint NFSL–Muslim Brotherhood militia, and in the aftermath 5000 dissidents were arrested.
text_ai_base: During the early to mid-1980s, Libya faced significant economic challenges, with oil revenues plummeting from $21 billion in 1982 to $5.4 billion in 1986. Despite these setbacks, Libya embarked on a major irrigation initiative, beginning construction of the Great Man-Made River in 1983—often referred to as "Gaddafi's Pet Project." Though intended to be completed by the end of the decade, the project remained unfinished as the 21st century began. While military spending increased, other government budgets were reduced. Libya, having long supported the FROLINAT militia in neighboring Chad, re-invaded Chad in December 1980 upon request of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government to aid in the ongoing civil war, and in January 1981, Gaddafi proposed a political merger. This proposal was rejected by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), which demanded a Libyan withdrawal. Libya eventually complied in November 1981, but conflict reignited, leading to further military involvement where Libyan troops clashed with French forces aiding the southern Chadian forces. Many African nations grew weary of Libya's interference; by 1980, nine African states had severed diplomatic ties with Libya, and in 1982, the OAU canceled its planned conference in Tripoli to prevent Gaddafi from acquiring the chairmanship. Despite political differences and a history of rivalry, Gaddafi and Moroccan monarch Hassan II signed the Oujda Treaty in August 1984, creating the Arab-African Union. However, tensions persisted, largely due to Morocco’s friendly relations with the U.S. and Israel, and by August 1986, Hassan dissolved the union. Meanwhile, domestic threats persisted against Gaddafi; in May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia residence was attacked by a joint militia of NFSL and Muslim Brotherhood, but the assault failed, leading to the arrest of 5000 dissidents thereafter.
text_ai_humanized: Libyan economic growth slowed in the early and mid-1980s, the result of an estimated $21 billion set-back as a result of the worldwide decrease in oil prices, which dropped to approximately $5.4 billion in 1986. Nonetheless, Libya was able to develop plans for the Great Man-Made River, a massive irrigation project, the construction of which began in 1983; called "the Eighth Wonder of the World" by the Gaddafist government,[189] he considered it to be the largest Libyan national project of his lifetime.[190] Intended to be completed by the end of the decade, it remained unfinished in the 21st century. Money was also put into boosting the military, while other administrative budgets were cut back.[191][192] Adhering to their long-held support for anti-colonialist militants,[193] Libya had supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad since 1969, and in December 1980 re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-dominated GUNT government to aid them amid the Chadian Civil War. In January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger with Chad, but this was rejected by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), who demanded that Libya withdraw. They did so in November, but in June 1982 re-invaded Chad, before attacking the French forces based there. The war was unpopular in Libya and proved expensive and inconclusive, persisting into the 1990s.[194][195] Many African nations tired of Gaddafi's interference in their affairs; by 1980, nine African states had severed diplomatic relations with Libya, while in March 1982, the OAU cancelled plans to hold their conference in Tripoli to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship.[196][197] Amid the economic stagnation, a growing animosity developed between Gaddafi and many other Arab states, particularly Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, who was privately scornful of Gaddafi.[198] In August 1984, Hassan II of Morocco and Gaddafi signed the Oujda Treaty, forming the Arab-African Union; this was welcomed by the United States, who believed it would discourage Morocco from supporting the Polisario Front in Western Sahara, but relations later broke down over Hassan's moderate stance towards Israel.[199] In August 1986, Hassan disbanded the Union.[200] Gaddafi's relations with the Western world remained largely antagonistic; although in April 1984 he downplayed his revolutionary rhetoric and sought to present himself as a statesman, there was little to no improvement in relations.[201][202] In May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia home was unsuccessfully attacked by a militia of NFSL and Muslim Brotherhood members armed with guns and grenades. Following that, the government arrested many dissidents, with human rights organizations like Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch expressing concern at the treatment they received.[203] 5000 were arrested, while ten leaders of the NFSL executed.[204]

Nonetheless, Libya was able to develop plans for the Great Man-Made River, a massive irrigation project, the construction of which began in 1983; called "the Eighth Wonder of the World" by the Gaddafist government,[189] he considered it to be the largest Libyan national project of his lifetime.[190] Intended to be completed by the end of the decade, it remained unfinished in the 21st century. Money was also put into boosting the military, while other administrative budgets were cut back.[191][192] Adhering to their long-held support for anti-colonialist militants,[193] Libya had supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad since 1969, and in December 1980 re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-dominated GUNT government to aid them amid the Chadian Civil War. In January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger with Chad, but this was rejected by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), who demanded that Libya withdraw. They did so in November, but in June 1982 re-invaded Chad, before attacking the French forces based there. The war was unpopular in Libya and proved expensive and inconclusive, persisting into the 1990s.[194][195] Many African nations tired of Gaddafi's interference in their affairs; by 1980, nine African states had severed diplomatic relations with Libya, while in March 1982, the OAU cancelled plans to hold their conference in Tripoli to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship.[196][197] Amid the economic stagnation, a growing animosity developed between Gaddafi and many other Arab states, particularly Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, who was privately scornful of Gaddafi.[198] In August 1984, Hassan II of Morocco and Gaddafi signed the Oujda Treaty, forming the Arab-African Union; this was welcomed by the United States, who believed it would discourage Morocco from supporting the Polisario Front in Western Sahara, but relations later broke down over Hassan's moderate stance towards Israel.[199] In August 1986, Hassan disbanded the Union.[200] Gaddafi's relations with the Western world remained largely antagonistic; although in April 1984 he downplayed his revolutionary rhetoric and sought to present himself as a statesman, there was little to no improvement in relations.[201][202] In May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia home was unsuccessfully attacked by a militia of NFSL and Muslim Brotherhood members armed with guns and grenades. Following that, the government arrested many dissidents, with human rights organizations like Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch expressing concern at the treatment they received.[203] 5000 were arrested, while ten leaders of the NFSL executed.[204]

text_human: Since the construction of its oldest buildings, the university's physical plant has grown substantially. Over the years 29 residence halls have been built to accommodate students and each has been constructed with its own chapel. Many academic building were added together with a system of libraries, the most prominent of which is the Theodore Hesburgh Library, built in 1963 and today containing almost 4 million books. Since 2004, several buildings have been added, including the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center, the Guglielmino Complex, and the Jordan Hall of Science. Additionally, a new residence for men, Duncan Hall, was begun on March 8, 2007, and began accepting residents for the Fall 2008 semester. Ryan Hall was completed and began housing undergraduate women in the fall of 2009. A new engineering building, Stinson-Remick Hall, a new combination Center for Social Concerns/Institute for Church Life building, Geddes Hall, and a law school addition have recently been completed as well. Additionally the new hockey arena opened in the fall of 2011. The Stayer Center for Executive Education, which houses the Mendoza College of Business Executive Education Department opened in March 2013 just South of the Mendoza College of Business building. Because of its long athletic tradition, the university features also many building dedicated to sport. The most famous is Notre Dame Stadium, home of the Fighting Irish football team; it has been renovated several times and today it can hold more than 80 thousand people. Prominent venues include also the Edmund P. Joyce Center, with indoor basketball and volleyball courts, and the Compton Family Ice Arena, a two-rink facility dedicated to hockey. Also, there are many outdoor fields, as the Frank Eck Stadium for baseball.

text_ai_humanized: The campus is known for its landscape and architecture, notably the Golden Dome, the Word of Life mural (commonly known as Touchdown Jesus), and its neo-gothic buildings, including the Basilica. It also features several examples of modern architecture. The earliest buildings, including the Old College, a former orphanage, and the current main building, were built in the second French Empire style.The current Main Building replaced the previous one that burnt down in 1879. Since the construction of its earliest buildings, the university’s campus has grown. It now includes 29 residence halls, each with its own chapel; many academic buildings; each of the school’s colleges and schools; and a library system spread across the campus. The Theodore Hesburgh Library, which opened on September 18, 1963, is the center of the library system and houses nearly 4,000,000 volumes. There are also many pieces of artwork and decorations on campus. With the expansion of the campus happening in recent years, there has been a growth of new buildings on campus. From the 2004 opening of the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center on the south end of campus to the Guglielmino Complex opened in 2005; in 2009 the addition of the Jordan Hall of Science, the largest academic building on campus added more classrooms and laboratories in the Colleges of Science and Engineering.In 2010 the Stinson-Remick Hall opened its doors as well as the Strake Laboratory of Aptitude for the combination of engineering, chemistry and physics at Notre Dame. Additionally, a new consort of Ethics has formed incorporating the schools of Business, Science and Engineering. The campus also houses many athletic facilities, primarily the Edmund P. Joyce Center; the Frank Eck Stadium and Melching Field at Eck Stadium; the Guglielmino Athletics Complex; Notre Dame Stadium; the Rolfs Aquatic Center; Stinson-Remick Hall; Stepan Center; the Varsity Club; and the Loftus Sports Center. The most famous of these is Notre Dame Stadium, where the university’s football team plays home games. It is known for its mural of “Touchdown Jesus” and for the press box, where President Ronald Reagan sat when he watched the Fighting Irish defeat the USC Trojans. Colt Stadium holds the men’s soccer and lacrosse teams, and has recently been renovated to accommodate more fans. Notre Dame’s main library, the Theodore Hesburgh Library, houses the “Word of Life” mural, one of the largest on-campus murals in the world.

text_human: Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces managed to capture Vienna in November. The fall of Vienna provided the French a huge bounty as they captured 100,000 muskets, 500 cannons, and the intact bridges across the Danube. At this critical juncture, both Tsar Alexander I and Holy Roman Emperor Francis II decided to engage Napoleon in battle, despite reservations from some of their subordinates. Napoleon sent his army north in pursuit of the Allies, but then ordered his forces to retreat so that he could feign a grave weakness. Desperate to lure the Allies into battle, Napoleon gave every indication in the days preceding the engagement that the French army was in a pitiful state, even abandoning the dominant Pratzen Heights near the village of Austerlitz. At the Battle of Austerlitz, in Moravia on 2 December, he deployed the French army below the Pratzen Heights and deliberately weakened his right flank, enticing the Allies to launch a major assault there in the hopes of rolling up the whole French line. A forced march from Vienna by Marshal Davout and his III Corps plugged the gap left by Napoleon just in time. Meanwhile, the heavy Allied deployment against the French right weakened their center on the Pratzen Heights, which was viciously attacked by the IV Corps of Marshal Soult. With the Allied center demolished, the French swept through both enemy flanks and sent the Allies fleeing chaotically, capturing thousands of prisoners in the process. The battle is often seen as a tactical masterpiece because of the near-perfect execution of a calibrated but dangerous plan — of the same stature as Cannae, the celebrated triumph by Hannibal some 2000 years before.

text_ai_humanized: Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces seized Vienna in November. However, the Allies refused to negotiate, instead withdrawing further east to await reinforcements. As the Russians and Austrians massed their armies, Napoleon sent his army north in pursuit. While the French carried out their maneuvers, the Allies made the fateful decision to engage the French in battle. Some of Napoleon's subordinates had expressed doubt as to the wisdom of doing so, but ultimately Tsar Alexander I and Holy Roman Emperor Francis II decided to face Napoleon in battle. On 2 December, the Battle of Austerlitz occurred in Moravia. Subsequently known as the "Battle of the Three Emperors", the French army, under Napoleon, decisively defeated a larger Russo-Austrian army led by Alexander I and Francis II. Napoleon divided his army into three parts; one part made a forced march from Vienna to complement his forces at the battle. Napoleon deployed his army below the Pratzen Heights and deliberately weakened his right flank, enticing the Allies to launch a major assault there in the hopes of rolling up the French line. A forced march from Vienna by Marshal Davout and his III Corps plugged the gap left by Napoleon just in time. Meanwhile, the heavy Allied deployment against the French right weakened the Allied center on the Pratzen Heights, which was viciously attacked by the IV Corps of Marshal Soult. With the Allied center demolished, the French swept through both enemy flanks and sent the Allies fleeing chaotically, capturing thousands of prisoners in the process. Austerlitz is widely regarded as a tactical masterpiece, on par with other historical greats such as Cannae, due to the near-perfect execution of a calibrated but dangerous plan—identical to that deployed at Cannae 2000 years earlier–the deliberate weakening of a sector to induce the enemy to overcommit against that sector, and then attack through their lines and envelop their flanks.

text_human: Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine territory. There are survivals from the large brooches in fibula or penannular form that were a key piece of personal adornment for elites, including the Irish Tara Brooch. Highly decorated books were mostly Gospel Books and these have survived in larger numbers, including the Insular Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the imperial Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, which is one of the few to retain its "treasure binding" of gold encrusted with jewels. Charlemagne's court seems to have been responsible for the acceptance of figurative monumental sculpture in Christian art, and by the end of the period near life-sized figures such as the Gero Cross were common in important churches.
text_ai_base: Carolingian art emerged among a select group at the court and within the monasteries and churches they funded. This art sought to revive the dignity and classical style of imperial Roman and Byzantine traditions, while also incorporating elements from Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art combined the dynamic ornamentation of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles with Mediterranean formats, like the book, setting lasting trends for medieval art. Most religious artifacts from the Early Middle Ages are illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally part of metalworks that have largely been melted down. Though objects in precious metals were considered the pinnacle of artistic creation, few survive today. Notable exceptions include several crosses like the Cross of Lothair, various reliquaries, and discoveries such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo, along with hoards from Gourdon in Merovingian France, Guarrazar in Visigothic Spain, and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine areas. Among the surviving items are large brooches for elite personal adornment, such as the Irish Tara Brooch. Lavishly decorated books, mainly Gospel Books, have survived in notable numbers, including the Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, which retains its jewel-encrusted "treasure binding." Charlemagne's court played a crucial role in introducing figurative monumental sculpture to Christian art, leading to life-sized figures, like the Gero Cross, becoming common in major churches by the period's end.
text_ai_humanized: Carolingian art was produced for a small circle of figures around the Court and the monasteries and churches endowed by them. It show a revival of the style of Late Antiquity, as well as a synthesis with the many components of earlier Medieval art.[96] The classical style was to remain of great influence on medieval art, probably in part because of its incorporation into early Christian art.[97] Byzantine art had a great influence on the West, especially through monastic centres like that of Grottaferrata near Rome, founded by Greek monks.[98] The art of the barbarian peoples was characterised by a very vigorous style in both sculpture and illuminated manuscripts (of which the best examples are called Insular art), which was to merge with the classical style to produce remarkable results. Insular art is the name given to the distinct style flourishing in Britain and Ireland from about the 7th century, which was produced by the Hiberno-Scottish mission and combined Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic elements,[99] Examples include the Book of Kells and the evangelizing of the Frankish Empire. Later this style merged with the classical style when the Anglo-Saxons and Irish and Scottish Gaels converted the British and Irish Picts.[100][101] Insular art demonstrates considerable influence from Mediterranean, especially Coptic, ideas and uses a version of the late Roman book format, even in very small objects for a elite lay readership.[102] Objects in precious metals – above all in gold, and to a lesser extent silver – were the most highly regarded works of art, but Roman and barbarian works have fared badly in terms of survival,[103][104][105] firstly because of the rise of Christianity, and later Islam, but also because of the recycling that was a central part of the economic life of a precious metal object. Most ecclesiastical pieces that have survived were separated from churches and monasteries in later periods, and sometimes adapted for secular use. In the Early Middle Ages most churches and monasteries still possessed a large number of relics of Christ, the Virgin Mary[106] and the chief saints that were encased in reliquaries of very precious materials that could be fairly plain or, at the other end of the spectrum, fabulously enriched.[107] Many of these were reliquaries for major relics donated by rulers or presidents for the East and were among the most precious possessions of Rome.[108] Surviving examples include a number of crosses, including the Cross of Lothair,[109] several Gospel Books,[110] a number of figures like the Golden Madonna of Essen,[111] as well as objects like the cup donated by Eleanor of Aquitaine,[112] as well as many reliquaries and processional crosses.[113][114] The earliest large examples surviving as found objects are in the Anglo-Saxon Cullen Hoard[115] and from the burial found at Sutton Hoo.[116] Other hoards found on the Continent include the Goudron Treasure (373) from the Merovingian Gauls,[117] the Treasure of Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain,[118] and the Treasure of Nagyszentmiklós, which may well come from a people closer to Byzantine areas.[119] Other survivals, especially in Byzantine art, are in the form of the utilisable adornment of ecclesiastical or secular metalwork which was kept in some sort of regalia up until the present; a number of_geometers in the Liturgicalia Constantinopolitana, for example, have older pieces attached. Metalwork was still crucial in elite personal adornment, and a number of magnificent brooches (such as the Irish Tara Brooch) and other pieces have survived above ground from the early period, centuries before the adoption of Christian art by the Celts and Anglo-Saxons. Sumptuously illustrated books, usually Gospel Books containing the Four Gospels, but also Byrhtnoth, Psalters and other texts, were at the highest level of prestige, and many such works have survived in larger numbers than other media, including the Book of Kells, Lindisfarne Gospels and the Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram.[120] In the Book of Kells the decoration has been amalgamated with Middle Eastern and Western Oriental influences to produce a singular line,[121] most of which remains extant in its jewelled cover.[122] The Carolingian court was very important to the development of figurative monumental sculpture, beginning with Charlemagne and his son Louis the Pious. Life-size figures were common by the end of the period.[123][124][125] 넘어지무큐악 Voices[126] One of the most valuable examples of these larger sculptures is the Gero Cross in Cologne, one of a توسعهةso cross-like works.[127]

text_human: The Guangxu Emperor died on November 14, 1908, and on November 15, 1908, Cixi also died. Rumors held that she or Yuan Shikai ordered trusted eunuchs to poison the Guangxu Emperor, and an autopsy conducted nearly a century later confirmed lethal levels of arsenic in his corpse. Puyi, the oldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and nephew to the childless Guangxu Emperor, was appointed successor at the age of two, leaving Zaifeng with the regency. This was followed by the dismissal of General Yuan Shikai from his former positions of power. In April 1911 Zaifeng created a cabinet in which there were two vice-premiers. Nonetheless, this cabinet was also known by contemporaries as "The Royal Cabinet" because among the thirteen cabinet members, five were members of the imperial family or Aisin Gioro relatives. This brought a wide range of negative opinions from senior officials like Zhang Zhidong. The Wuchang Uprising of October 10, 1911, led to the creation of a new central government, the Republic of China, in Nanjing with Sun Yat-sen as its provisional head. Many provinces soon began "separating" from Qing control. Seeing a desperate situation unfold, the Qing government brought Yuan Shikai back to military power. He took control of his Beiyang Army to crush the revolution in Wuhan at the Battle of Yangxia. After taking the position of Prime Minister and creating his own cabinet, Yuan Shikai went as far as to ask for the removal of Zaifeng from the regency. This removal later proceeded with directions from Empress Dowager Longyu.
text_ai_base: The Guangxu Emperor passed away on November 14, 1908, followed by Cixi's death the next day. Rumors alleged that she or Yuan Shikai had trusted eunuchs poison the Guangxu Emperor, a suspicion confirmed nearly a century later when an autopsy detected lethal arsenic levels in his body. Puyi, the eldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and the childless Guangxu Emperor's nephew, was named successor at age two, placing Zaifeng in charge as regent. Subsequently, General Yuan Shikai was dismissed from his previous positions of influence. In April 1911, Zaifeng set up a cabinet featuring two vice-premiers, but contemporary critics dubbed it "The Royal Cabinet" due to its composition: five out of thirteen members hailed from the imperial family or were Aisin Gioro relatives. This elicited significant disapproval from senior officials like Zhang Zhidong. The Wuchang Uprising on October 10, 1911, led to the founding of the Republic of China in Nanjing, with Sun Yat-sen as its provisional leader. Many provinces soon began to break away from Qing control. Facing a worsening crisis, the Qing government restored Yuan Shikai to military command. He deployed his Beiyang Army to suppress the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. After becoming Prime Minister and forming his own cabinet, Yuan Shikai sought the removal of Zaifeng from the regency, which was eventually carried out under Empress Dowager Longyu's orders.
text_ai_humanized: The Guangxu Emperor died on 14 November 1908 and Empress Dowager Cixi died the following day. According to rumours, Cixi had ordered loyal eunuchs to murder the Guangxu Emperor via poisoning (as did Yuan Shikai), and an autopsy in 2008 showed lethal levels of arsenic in his corpse. Puyi, who was Zaifeng's first son and also Guangxu's nephew (Guangxu did not have any children of his own), was appointed as the new emperor; since he was only two years old, Zaifeng was appointed the regent.[18] Yuan Shikai was relieved of his official posts. A cabinet was set up in May 1911 with two vice premiers. On 10 October 1911, the Wuchang Uprising began in Wuhan, followed by the proclamation of the Republic of China on 1 January 1912 in Nanjing with Sun Yat-sen as the provisional president. Other provinces soon started seceding from Qing rule. In a last-ditch effort to save itself, the Qing government offered Yuan Shikai a higher position in the military and put him in charge of the Beiyang Army to crush the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. He later became the prime minister with full and exclusive powers to organise his own cabinet. Yuan forced Zaifeng to step down and appoint Empress Longyu as the regent; the regency was abolished later.

Puyi, who was Zaifeng's first son and also Guangxu's nephew (Guangxu did not have any children of his own), was appointed as the new emperor; since he was only two years old, Zaifeng was appointed the regent.[18] Yuan Shikai was relieved of his official posts. On 10 October 1911, the Wuchang Uprising began in Wuhan, followed by the proclamation of the Republic of China on 1 January 1912 in Nanjing with Sun Yat-sen as the provisional president. Other provinces soon started seceding from Qing rule. In a last-ditch effort to save itself, the Qing government offered Yuan Shikai a higher position in the military and put him in charge of the Beiyang Army to crush the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. He later became the prime minister with full and exclusive powers to organise his own cabinet. Yuan forced Zaifeng to step down and appoint Empress Longyu as the regent; the regency was abolished later.

text_human: The torch was lit at a park outside at AT&T Park at about 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), briefly held aloft by American and Chinese Olympic officials. The relay descended into confusion as the first runner in the elaborately planned relay disappeared into a warehouse on a waterfront pier where it stayed for a half-an-hour. There were clashes between thousands of pro-China demonstrators, many of whom said they were bused in by the Chinese Consulate and other pro-China groups, and both pro-Tibet and Darfur protesters. The non-Chinese demonstrators were reported to have been swamped and trailed by angry crowds. Around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch resurfaced about 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium along Van Ness Avenue, a heavily trafficked thoroughfare that was not on official route plans. Television reports showed the flame flanked by motorcycles and uniformed police officers. Two torchbearers carried the flame running slowly behind a truck and surrounded by Olympic security guards. During the torch relay, two torchbearers, Andrew Michael who uses a wheelchair and is the Vice President for Sustainable Development for the Bay Area Council and Director of Partnerships For Change, and an environmental advocate, Majora Carter, managed to display Tibetan flags in protest, resulting in their ejection from the relay. The closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was canceled due to the presence of large numbers of protesters at the site. The torch run ended with a final stretch through San Francisco's Marina district and was then moved by bus to San Francisco International Airport for a makeshift closing ceremony at the terminal, from which the free media was excluded. San Jose Mercury News described the "deceiving" event as "a game of Where's Waldo, played against the landscape of a lovely city." International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge said the San Francisco relay had "fortunately" avoided much of the disruptions that marred the legs in London and Paris, but "was, however, not the joyous party that we had wished it to be."

text_human: A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kills them. Predators may hunt actively for prey in pursuit predation, or sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill large prey and dismember or chew it prior to eating it, such as a jaguar or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as does a bottlenose dolphin swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a frog. Some animals that kill both large and small prey for their size (domestic cats and dogs are prime examples) may do either depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entails venom that subdues a prey creature before the predator ingests the prey by killing, which the box jellyfish does, or disabling it, found in the behavior of the cone shell. In some cases, the venom, as in rattlesnakes and some spiders, contributes to the digestion of the prey item even before the predator begins eating. In other cases, the prey organism may die in the mouth or digestive system of the predator. Baleen whales, for example, eat millions of microscopic plankton at once, the prey being broken down well after entering the whale. Seed predation and egg predation are other forms of true predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Predators of this classification need not eat prey entirely. For example, some predators cannot digest bones, while others can. Some may eat only part of an organism, as in grazing (see below), but still consistently cause its direct death.
text_ai_base: A true predator is commonly defined as an organism that kills and consumes another living being. While all predators harm their prey in some way, true predators are distinctive in that they kill their prey. Predators may actively pursue prey, known as pursuit predation, or they may use ambush tactics, waiting for prey to wander within reach. Some predators, like jaguars and humans, kill large prey and break it apart or chew it before consuming. Others, such as bottlenose dolphins, snakes, ducks, or storks, swallow their often smaller prey whole. Domestic cats and dogs, which hunt both large and small prey relative to their size, may consume a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Certain predators use venom to subdue prey, either killing it, as box jellyfish do, or disabling it, like cone shells. In some predators, such as rattlesnakes and certain spiders, the venom aids in digesting the prey even before they begin feeding. Additionally, some prey may die within the predator’s mouth or digestive system, such as when baleen whales consume vast quantities of plankton, breaking down the prey after ingestion. True predation also includes seed and egg predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Not all predators consume every part of their prey; for instance, some cannot digest bones, while others do. Some predators might consume only part of an organism, as in the case of grazing, yet still directly cause the organism's death.
