Some, like jaguars and humans, kill large prey and tear it to pieces or chew it up before swallowing it, whereas others, such as bottlenose dolphins, some snakes, and various birds (including ducks and storks) swallow the prey whole; typically, the prey is much smaller than the predator. text_human: In December, Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan effort by a group of 950 US mayors and others designed to influence the federal government into rethinking its gun control laws, following the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. Beyoncé became an ambassador for the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign donating her song "I Was Here" and its music video, shot in the UN, to the campaign. In 2013, it was announced that Beyoncé would work with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini on a Gucci "Chime for Change" campaign that aims to spread female empowerment. The campaign, which aired on February 28, was set to her new music. A concert for the cause took place on June 1, 2013 in London and included other acts like Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora. In advance of the concert, she appeared in a campaign video released on 15 May 2013, where she, along with Cameron Diaz, John Legend and Kylie Minogue, described inspiration from their mothers, while a number of other artists celebrated personal inspiration from other women, leading to a call for submission of photos of women of viewers' inspiration from which a selection was shown at the concert. Beyoncé said about her mother Tina Knowles that her gift was "finding the best qualities in every human being." With help of the crowdfunding platform Catapult, visitors of the concert could choose between several projects promoting education of women and girls. Beyoncé is also taking part in "Miss a Meal", a food-donation campaign, and supporting Goodwill charity through online charity auctions at Charitybuzz that support job creation throughout Europe and the U.S.

This bipartisan initiative, backed by 950 US mayors and others, seeks to persuade the federal government to reconsider gun control laws following the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. Beyoncé served as an ambassador for the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign, donating her song "I Was Here" and its UN-filmed music video to the cause. In 2013, it was announced that she would collaborate with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini on Gucci's "Chime for Change" campaign, promoting female empowerment. This campaign, set to her new music, launched on February 28. A concert supporting the cause occurred on June 1, 2013, in London, featuring performances by Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora. Ahead of the concert, Beyoncé appeared in a campaign video released on May 15, 2013, alongside Cameron Diaz, John Legend, and Kylie Minogue, sharing inspiration from their mothers. Other artists joined in, celebrating inspiration from women, culminating in a call for viewers to submit photos of inspiring women, some of which were displayed at the concert. Beyoncé spoke about her mother, Tina Knowles, praising her ability to "find the best qualities in every human being." Utilizing the crowdfunding platform Catapult, concert attendees could choose projects that promote education for women and girls. Beyoncé also participates in the "Miss a Meal" food-donation campaign and supports Goodwill charity through online auctions at Charitybuzz that aid job creation across Europe and the U.S.
text_ai_humanized: In December, Beyoncé and a number of other celebrities took part in a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan initiative from Mayors Against Illegal Guns. The campaign, involving 950 U. S. mayors as well as other victims and artists who encourage the federal government to re-evaluate their gun control laws, came in the wake of the Sandy Hook elementary school shooting in Connecticut. Beyoncé became an ambassador of the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign, where she and songwriter Diane Warren donated the video for her song "I Was Here" and its proceeds to the campaign. In 2013, it was announced that Beyoncé partnered with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini for a Gucci initiative, "Chime for Change", that aims to spread female empowerment. The campaign, which, according to Hayek, Gucci donated to and already includes a piece of Beyoncé's new music used as a backdrop, promotes "education, health and justice for girls and women". The initiative's founding committee comprises Hayek, Knowles, and Giannini as well as Arianna Huffington, an alleged victim of Roman Polanski, Julia Roberts and Jada Pinkett Smith. A concert for the cause was held at Twickenham Stadium on June 1, 2013, in London and featured Beyoncé as the headline act as well as performances from other artists including Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine and Rita Ora. Beyoncé voiced in the campaign "If you empower young women, they will change the world". Before the concert, Beyoncé appeared in a video campaign that was released on May 15, 2013, that featured herself along with the other artists including Cameron Diaz, John Legend and Kylie Minogue who all appeared at the event, talking about one woman who had made an impact on their lives and inspired them. Further artists included in the video were also Hayek, Olivia Wilde, Zoe Saldana and James Franco; all of the artists reflected on sisters, teachers and other women in their lives who they claimed changed and inspired them. The video ended with "this time, the starring woman could be the woman starring back in the mirror ... join the movement for girls and women ... Send us a photo, tag it #CHIME to Twitter or Instagram, and tell us why she inspires you ... Some of these pictures will be featured in the concert. Let's show the world the women who inspire us most". In the video, Beyoncé spoke about her mother and said "My mother's gift is finding the best qualities in every human being. I think her gift is often overlooked because she's so stylish and glamorous" and ended with "I love you, Mom". Through Catapult, the first-ever crowd-funding platform designed to advance the lives of girls and women, concert-goers can choose exactly how their money is used and which projects benefit from funding. Catapult gives to more than 70 organizations that lead education through 84 diverse projects on its site, ranging from small-scale efforts like training 10 Chinese rural, disadvantaged girls as non-profit youth leaders to large-scale ones such as funding an entire school's supplies for one year in Tanzania. Beyoncé is also contributing in the food-donation campaign "Miss a Meal", and also supports Goodwill charity through online charity auctions at Charitybuzz that support job creation throughout Europe and the U. S.

text_human: Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress during his presidency, though he did issue a Thanksgiving and Prayer proclamation as Governor of Virginia. Madison issued four religious proclamations while President, but vetoed two bills on the grounds they violated the first amendment. On the other hand, both Jefferson and Madison attended religious services at the Capitol. Years before the ratification of the Constitution, Madison contended "Because if Religion be exempt from the authority of the Society at large, still less can it be subject to that of the Legislative Body." After retiring from the presidency, Madison wrote of "total separation of the church from the state." " "Strongly guarded as is the separation between Religion & Govt in the Constitution of the United States," Madison wrote, and he declared, "practical distinction between Religion and Civil Government is essential to the purity of both, and as guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States." In a letter to Edward Livingston Madison further expanded, "We are teaching the world the great truth that Govts. do better without Kings & Nobles than with them. The merit will be doubled by the other lesson that Religion flourishes in greater purity, without than with the aid of Govt." Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights had included provisions binding the States, as well as the Federal Government, from an establishment of religion, but the House did not pass them.[citation needed]
text_ai_base: The separation of church and state as conceived by Jefferson and James Madison has been a topic of debate for many years. During his presidency, Jefferson declined to issue Thanksgiving proclamations requested by Congress, despite having issued one as Governor of Virginia. In contrast, Madison, as President, issued four religious proclamations but vetoed two bills, arguing they violated the First Amendment. Both Jefferson and Madison also attended religious services at the Capitol. Before the Constitution was ratified, Madison argued that if religion is beyond the authority of society, it should be even more so beyond that of the legislature. After his presidency, Madison advocated for a "total separation of church and state." He wrote about the strong separation between religion and government in the U.S. Constitution and stated that maintaining a practical distinction between religion and civil government is crucial to preserving the integrity of both. In a letter to Edward Livingston, Madison elaborated, "We are teaching the world that governments function better without kings and nobles. This lesson will be further enhanced by proving that religion thrives more purely without government support." Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights included provisions to prevent states, as well as the federal government, from establishing religion, but these were not passed by the House.
text_ai_humanized: Jefferson's and James Madison's conceptions of the wall of separation have been debated for over 200 years. While President, Jefferson refused to issue proclamations of thanksgiving requested by the Congress (like George Washington and John Adams had), yet issued one religious proclamation as Governor of Virginia. Madison issued four religious proclamations while President, but vetoed two bills on the grounds they violated the First Amendment.[19] Jefferson also attended religious services at the Capitol.[20] Writing after leaving the presidency, Madison stated, "Strongly guarded...[is] the separation between religion and government in the Constitution of the United States." "Every new and successful example," he wrote, "of a perfect separation between ecclesiastical and civil matters, is of importance." "Religion and government will both exist in greater purity, the less they are mixed together," Madison wrote.[19] In a letter to Edward Livingston Madison further expanded, "We are teaching the world the great truth that Governments do better without kings and nobles than with them. The merit will be doubled by the other lesson that Religion flourishes in greater purity, without than with the aid of Government."[21] Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights had included provisions to prevent the states as well as the federal government from establishing religion, though these did not pass the House.[22] Before the Constitution was written, Madison contended "If religion be not within the cognizance of Civil Government how can its legal establishment be said to be necessary to Civil Government? 'Tis the duty of every man to render to the Creator such homage...but if the right to do this be a natural and unalienable right ... it cannot be necessary to surrender it up to the State. ... This right is in its nature an inalienable right."[23] (See Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom).

text_human: John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. When this threat failed, Innocent excommunicated the king in November 1209. Although theoretically a significant blow to John's legitimacy, this did not appear to greatly worry the king. Two of John's close allies, Emperor Otto IV and Count Raymond VI of Toulouse, had already suffered the same punishment themselves, and the significance of excommunication had been somewhat devalued. John simply tightened his existing measures and accrued significant sums from the income of vacant sees and abbeys: one 1213 estimate, for example, suggested the church had lost an estimated 100,000 marks (equivalent to £66,666 at the time) to John. Official figures suggest that around 14% of annual income from the English church was being appropriated by John each year.
text_ai_base: John perceived the interdict as tantamount to a papal declaration of war. In response, he sought personal retribution against Innocent and tried to divide English clergy into factions: those who might support him and those firmly aligned with Rome. John confiscated the lands of clergy who refused to conduct services and estates associated with Innocent. He detained the concubines, which many clerics maintained, releasing them only after imposing fines. Additionally, he seized properties of church members who fled England and promised protection to clergy who remained loyal to him. Some institutions managed to negotiate terms to oversee their properties and retain their estate yields. By 1209, the deadlock persisted, prompting Innocent to threaten John's excommunication unless he accepted Langton's appointment. This threat having no effect, Innocent excommunicated John in November 1209. While theoretically a serious blow to John's legitimacy, it did not seem to trouble the king much. Close allies like Emperor Otto IV and Count Raymond VI of Toulouse had already faced excommunication, lessening its impact. John intensified his strategies, amassing substantial income from vacant sees and abbeys. In 1213, estimates suggested the church had lost around 100,000 marks (equivalent to £66,666 at the time) to John. Official records indicate that John appropriated roughly 14% of the annual income from the English church each year.
text_ai_humanized: For John, the interdict was an act of war by Innocent, and he retaliated by attacking Innocent and attempting to split the Church establishment in England between the supporters of Innocent and those of the king. John seized the lands of churchmen who were not performing church services and those of Innocent. He imprisoned a number of the clergy who continued to keep concubines, who were still permitted for the rest of John’s subjects, and released them after demanding they pay a fine. John also seized the lands of members of the Church who had left New England, and he promised to protect any clergy who remained in England and performed services as usual.[60] Some negotiated arrangements with John to manage their own estates and the revenues from the estates. 62] Bitter standoff over the interdict continued for quite some time. 62] As the standoff continued, in 1209 Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not accept Innocent’s appointment of Langton. This had no more effect on John than the interdict had, and Innocent carried out his threat in November 1209. 63] Thus far it had no great effect on John’s position, and there is no hint that it worried the king. The king’s close allies had already been excommunicated, including Emperor Otto IV, and Raymond VI, Count of Toulouse. 63] John stepped up his pressure on the church, collecting huge revenues from the vacant sees and abbeys. 63] By 1213, it was estimated that the church had lost about 100,000 marks (66,666 or roughly 128,000 in the modern day) to John. 63] Contemporary documents state that John was taking about 14 percent of the annual income of the church each year. 63]

api_response.result: For John, the interdict was an act of war by Innocent, and he retaliated by attacking Innocent and attempting to split the Church establishment in England between the supporters of Innocent and those of the king. John seized the lands of churchmen who were not performing church services and those of Innocent. He imprisoned a number of the clergy who continued to keep concubines, who were still permitted for the rest of John’s subjects, and released them after demanding they pay a fine. John also seized the lands of members of the Church who had left New England, and he promised to protect any clergy who remained in England and performed services as usual.[60] Some negotiated arrangements with John to manage their own estates and the revenues from the estates. 62] Bitter standoff over the interdict continued for quite some time. 62] As the standoff continued, in 1209 Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not accept Innocent’s appointment of Langton. This had no more effect on John than the interdict had, and Innocent carried out his threat in November 1209. 63] Thus far it had no great effect on John’s position, and there is no hint that it worried the king. The king’s close allies had already been excommunicated, including Emperor Otto IV, and Raymond VI, Count of Toulouse. 63] John stepped up his pressure on the church, collecting huge revenues from the vacant sees and abbeys. 63] By 1213, it was estimated that the church had lost about 100,000 marks (66,666 or roughly 128,000 in the modern day) to John. 63] Contemporary documents state that John was taking about 14 percent of the annual income of the church each year. 63]

text_human: Ideas for affirmative action came as early as the Reconstruction Era (1865-1877) in which a former slave population lacked the skills and resources for sustainable living. In 1865, General William Tecumseh Sherman proposed to divide the land and goods from Georgia and grant it to families of color which became the "Forty acres and a mule" policy. The proposal was never widely adopted due to strong political opposition. Nearly a century later (1950s-1960s), policies to assist classes of individuals reemerged during the Civil Rights Movement. The civil rights guarantees came through the interpretation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. The decisions came to be known as affirmative action in which mandatory, as well as voluntary programs, affirmed the civil rights of people of color. Furthermore, these affirmative action programs protected people of color from the present effects stemming from past discrimination. In 1961, President John F. Kennedy became the first to utilize the term "affirmative action" in Executive Order 10925 to ensure that government contractors "take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed, and employees are treated during employment, without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin." This executive order realized the government's intent to create equal opportunities for all qualified people. This executive order was eventually amended and superseded by Lyndon B. Johnson's Executive Order 11246 which prevented discrimination based on race, color, religion, and national origin by organizations which received federal contracts and subcontracts. In 1967, the order was amended to include sex as well. The Reagan administration was opposed to the affirmative action requirements of Executive Order 11246, but these contemplated changes[which?] faced bi-partisan opposition in Congress.
text_ai_base: Ideas for affirmative action originated during the Reconstruction Era (1865-1877), when former slaves struggled with a lack of skills and resources for sustainable living. In 1865, General William Tecumseh Sherman proposed redistributing land and goods in Georgia to families of color, resulting in the "Forty acres and a mule" concept. However, this proposal faced strong political opposition and was never widely adopted. Nearly a century later, during the Civil Rights Movement (1950s-1960s), policies to assist certain groups reemerged. Civil rights protections were supported through interpretations of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. These actions became known as affirmative action, including mandatory and voluntary programs to uphold the rights of people of color and shield them from ongoing effects of past discrimination. In 1961, President John F. Kennedy first used the term "affirmative action" in Executive Order 10925, directing government contractors to ensure employment and fair treatment regardless of race, creed, color, or national origin. This order demonstrated the government's commitment to equal opportunities for all qualified individuals. The order was later amended and replaced by Lyndon B. Johnson's Executive Order 11246, which prohibited discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, and national origin among federal contract recipients. In 1967, this order was expanded to include sex. Despite opposition from the Reagan administration, proposed changes to Executive Order 11246 encountered bipartisan resistance in Congress.

However, vehement political opposition to the plans prevented any widespread measures from happening. In the meantime, nearly 100 years later, during the Civil Rights era (1950s-1960s), legislation to favor groups of people returned. The enactment of civil rights was sustained by interpretations of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th amendment. These measures were collectively called affirmative action. These were constitutionally required and voluntary programs to safeguard persons of color and protect them against the continuing discrimination as a result of the past. Kennedy in Executive Order 10925 when he required that government contractors "take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed, and that employees are treated during employment, without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin. text_human: Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these male line ancestors appear to have been mainly Middle Eastern. For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with non-Jewish populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, Germany and the French Rhine Valley. This is consistent with Jewish traditions in placing most Jewish paternal origins in the region of the Middle East. Conversely, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, studied by looking at mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous. Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk believe this indicates that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the places where they migrated in the diaspora after fleeing ancient Israel. In contrast, Behar has found evidence that about 40% of Ashkenazi Jews originate maternally from just four female founders, who were of Middle Eastern origin. The populations of Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities "showed no evidence for a narrow founder effect." Subsequent studies carried out by Feder et al. confirmed the large portion of non-local maternal origin among Ashkenazi Jews. Reflecting on their findings related to the maternal origin of Ashkenazi Jews, the authors conclude "Clearly, the differences between Jews and non-Jews are far larger than those observed among the Jewish communities. Hence, differences between the Jewish communities can be overlooked when non-Jews are included in the comparisons."
text_ai_base: Y-chromosome DNA studies suggest that old populations had a few founding fathers who dispersed along separate migration paths. In many Jewish populations, these paternal ancestors mainly originated from the Middle East. For instance, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with non-Jewish populations in the Eastern European, German, and French Rhine Valley regions. This aligns with Jewish traditions that trace most Jewish paternal roots to the Middle East. In contrast, Jewish maternal lineages, studied via mitochondrial DNA, are generally more diverse. Scholars like Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk suggest this diversity indicates that many Jewish men took new wives from European and other local communities during their diaspora following their departure from ancient Israel. However, researcher Behar found that about 40% of Ashkenazi Jews are maternally descended from just four female ancestors of Middle Eastern origin. Meanwhile, Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities did not exhibit evidence of a narrow founder effect. Further studies by Feder et al. support the notion of a significant non-local maternal origin among Ashkenazi Jews. Reflecting on these findings, the authors note, "The differences between Jews and non-Jews are far larger than those observed among Jewish communities. Therefore, differences between Jewish communities become less significant when compared to non-Jews."
text_ai_humanized: DNA studies of the Y-chromosome in men (passed solely from father to son) imply that there were several founding patrilineages of old populations that underwent expansion and migration to separate regions. In most Jewish populations, these male founders appear to have been mainly Middle Eastern. For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, Germany and the French Rhine Valley. This is consistent with Jewish traditions which state that the male ancestors of most Jews arrived in what is now the Roman Empire after the Babylonian exile, in this case showing that they likely migrated from the Middle East.[1][4] Conversely, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, studied by looking at the mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous. According to Thomas, Prestes, Skorecki, Hammer, Ostrer, Abdelha and Goldstein, this suggests that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the regions where they migrated in the diaspora after departing from ancient Israel.[1] In addition, Behar found that at least 40% of the current Ashkenazi Jewish population is descended matrilineally from just four women, or "founder lineages", that were likely from a prehistoric Middle Eastern population, although they are "distinct from the majority of the contemporary Middle Eastern population".[1][10] However, a 2013 study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by Costa et al. seems to imply only a minority of maternal lineages have an ultimate Middle Eastern origin.[11] This is also supported by Feder et al.[12] With the exception of these few, the rest of Ashkenazi mtDNA is European.[13] Ashkenazi mtDNA, the authors think, is consistent with "a significant population conversion" to Judaism "whose male and female ancestors lived in Europe." It is estimated that the founder females lived between 1000 BCE (the time of David and Solomon) and 1000 CE (the time of the founding of Ashkenaz).[13] The mtDNA of Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities, on the other hand, closely resembles that of other Levantines and had no evidence of a bottleneck effect.[13] The authors concluded: "the differences between Jews – at least, using classical sorts of genetic analysis – are far smaller than those observed between most other communities, so the relative proportions of Israelite and non-Israelite ancestry simply fade into insignificance".

text_human: The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented. Neonates are said to be in a state of physiological immunodeficiency, because both their innate and adaptive immunological responses are greatly suppressed. Once born, a child’s immune system responds favorably to protein antigens while not as well to glycoproteins and polysaccharides. In fact, many of the infections acquired by neonates are caused by low virulence organisms like Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas. In neonates, opsonic activity and the ability to activate the complement cascade is very limited. For example, the mean level of C3 in a newborn is approximately 65% of that found in the adult. Phagocytic activity is also greatly impaired in newborns. This is due to lower opsonic activity, as well as diminished up-regulation of integrin and selectin receptors, which limit the ability of neutrophils to interact with adhesion molecules in the endothelium. Their monocytes are slow and have a reduced ATP production, which also limits the newborn's phagocytic activity. Although, the number of total lymphocytes is significantly higher than in adults, the cellular and humoral immunity is also impaired. Antigen-presenting cells in newborns have a reduced capability to activate T cells. Also, T cells of a newborn proliferate poorly and produce very small amounts of cytokines like IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-12, and IFN-g which limits their capacity to activate the humoral response as well as the phagocitic activity of macrophage. B cells develop early during gestation but are not fully active.
text_ai_base: The body's ability to respond to antigens is influenced by factors such as age, antigen type, maternal influences, and the location of antigen presentation. Newborns are considered to be in a state of physiological immunodeficiency because their innate and adaptive immune responses are significantly suppressed. After birth, a child's immune system can effectively respond to protein antigens but struggles with glycoproteins and polysaccharides. Many infections in neonates are caused by low-virulence organisms like Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas. In neonates, opsonic activity and complement cascade activation are very limited, with mean C3 levels being about 65% of adult levels. Their phagocytic activity is also greatly reduced due to lower opsonic activity and diminished up-regulation of integrin and selectin receptors, which hinders neutrophil interaction with endothelial adhesion molecules. Newborn monocytes move slowly and produce less ATP, further impairing phagocytosis. Despite having a higher total lymphocyte count than adults, the cellular and humoral immunity in newborns is impaired. Antigen-presenting cells in newborns are less capable of activating T cells. Additionally, newborn T cells proliferate poorly and produce minimal cytokines like IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-12, and IFN-g, limiting their ability to activate humoral responses and macrophage phagocytosis. Although B cells develop early in gestation, they are not fully active at birth.
text_ai_humanized: Factors such as age, nature of antigen, maternal factors and site of Ag presentation also determine the antigenic response. Neonates are in physiological state of immunodeficiency, as their innate and antigen specific immunity is profoundly suppressed to most pathogens. They can elicit competent response to proteins but not glycoprotein and polysaccharide antigens. A large number of infections in neonates are attributed to low virulent organisms such as staphylococcus and pseudomonas. Opsonic activity and complement cascade activation is very poor in neonates. The mean concentration of C3 in neonates is 65% of that in adults. Phagocytic activity is greatly depressed in neonates relative to adults, due to less efficient opsonic activity and also less potent in up-regulation of integrin and selectin surface receptors to interact with the endothelial adhesion molecules. Monocytes in newborns are sluggish and have less ATPase activity. The failure to activate oxidative metabolism retards the phagocytosis. The total lymphocyte count in newborns is higher than that in adults though the cellular and humoral arms of the neonatal immune response are depressed. APCs of newborns are less efficient to promote activation of T cells. Moreover the T cells in newborns exhibit poor proliferation and secrete little IL-2, 4 and 5, 12 and INFg, thus inadequate to enhance humoral response and to activate phagocytosis by macrophages. B cells are already functional early in gestation but are not fully functioning at birth.

text_human: Solar concentrating technologies such as parabolic dish, trough and Scheffler reflectors can provide process heat for commercial and industrial applications. The first commercial system was the Solar Total Energy Project (STEP) in Shenandoah, Georgia, USA where a field of 114 parabolic dishes provided 50% of the process heating, air conditioning and electrical requirements for a clothing factory. This grid-connected cogeneration system provided 400 kW of electricity plus thermal energy in the form of 401 kW steam and 468 kW chilled water, and had a one-hour peak load thermal storage. Evaporation ponds are shallow pools that concentrate dissolved solids through evaporation. The use of evaporation ponds to obtain salt from sea water is one of the oldest applications of solar energy. Modern uses include concentrating brine solutions used in leach mining and removing dissolved solids from waste streams. Clothes lines, clotheshorses, and clothes racks dry clothes through evaporation by wind and sunlight without consuming electricity or gas. In some states of the United States legislation protects the "right to dry" clothes. Unglazed transpired collectors (UTC) are perforated sun-facing walls used for preheating ventilation air. UTCs can raise the incoming air temperature up to 22 °C (40 °F) and deliver outlet temperatures of 45–60 °C (113–140 °F). The short payback period of transpired collectors (3 to 12 years) makes them a more cost-effective alternative than glazed collection systems. As of 2003, over 80 systems with a combined collector area of 35,000 square metres (380,000 sq ft) had been installed worldwide, including an 860 m2 (9,300 sq ft) collector in Costa Rica used for drying coffee beans and a 1,300 m2 (14,000 sq ft) collector in Coimbatore, India, used for drying marigolds.

text_human: BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. BYU has also received attention from sports networks for refusal to play games on Sunday, as well as expelling players due to honor code violations. Beginning in the 2011 season, BYU football competes in college football as an independent. In addition, most other sports now compete in the West Coast Conference. Teams in swimming and diving and indoor track and field for both men and women joined the men's volleyball program in the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation. For outdoor track and field, the Cougars became an Independent. Softball returned to the Western Athletic Conference, but spent only one season in the WAC; the team moved to the Pacific Coast Softball Conference after the 2012 season. The softball program may move again after the 2013 season; the July 2013 return of Pacific to the WCC will enable that conference to add softball as an official sport.

text_ai_humanized: BYU sponsors 21 NCAA varsity sports, with just under 20 percent of the student body participating on at least one varsity team.[346] Nineteen of these sports have teams that primarily compete in the Mountain West Conference from 1999 to 2011; the other two sports—men's volleyball and men's soccer—compete in the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation and Western Athletic Conference, respectively. Before the Mountain West Conference was formed, BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", a name that was first introduced by Eugene L. Roberts in the 1920s. Cosmo the Cougar has been the official mascot of BYU's athletic teams since 1953. BYU's athletic fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many students of both sexes delay enrollment in college for two years to serve as missionaries, BYU's athletes tend to be older on average than other schools' players. Two years of full-time missionary service is encouraged of all Mormon men who are physically and mentally capable, and is part of the Mormon religion. Young men may enter missionary service directly following high school, pending their reaching age eighteen (or 19 in pre-2012 rules); young women may begin their service at age nineteen (as of October 2012[347] or 21[348] under previous rules preceding October 2012). Serving a mission does not prevent the student athlete from participating in the full four years of athletic eligibility as the NCAA two-year eligibility period clock remains "stopped" until the athlete enrolls as a full-time student, which is typically at the conclusion of a mission.[349] This rule is considered by some to be a minor controversy,[350][351][352] although it is widely recognized by athletes, coaches and administrators that there is no competitive advantage gained as the athlete does not participate in any athletic or physical training during the mission. BYU draws a significant amount of sports media attention for two reasons. Since BYU is sponsored by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, its players are required to adhere to the church's honor code. Over the past few years, BYU has dismissed a few players (who were on athletic scholarship) from its teams for violating the honor code.[353][354] BYU's athletic program also holds the distinction of being the only NCAA program to have each athletic team receive at least one national championship title. In the 2011 season, BYU became independent in college football. The Cougars left the Mountain West Conference at the end of the 2010–11 season and have joined the West Coast Conference for most of its non-football sports as of 2011. The only exceptions to this are the aforementioned sports that already compete in other conferences, sports that the WCC does not sponsor (notably softball, which belonged to the WAC until 2012 and will move to the Pacific Coast Softball Conference afterward ),[355] and the BYU men's and women's swimming and diving teams and men's and women's indoor track and field teams, all of which also joined the MPSF alongside men's (outdoor) soccer.[356] The BYU men's and women's outdoor track and field teams became independent as well following the school's departure from the MW. Also, after spending the 2012 season in the PCSC, Cougars softball may be headed elsewhere after the 2013 season, as the conference announced in October 2012 that it will disband after that season. This became all but certain after Pacific, a charter member of the WCC, announced that it would return to that conference in July 2013. With the Tigers in the WCC fold, the conference will likely add softball, which it does not currently sponsor, in the near future.[357]

api_response.result: BYU sponsors 21 NCAA varsity sports, with just under 20 percent of the student body participating on at least one varsity team.[346] Nineteen of these sports have teams that primarily compete in the Mountain West Conference from 1999 to 2011; the other two sports—men's volleyball and men's soccer—compete in the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation and Western Athletic Conference, respectively. Before the Mountain West Conference was formed, BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", a name that was first introduced by Eugene L. Roberts in the 1920s. Cosmo the Cougar has been the official mascot of BYU's athletic teams since 1953. BYU's athletic fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many students of both sexes delay enrollment in college for two years to serve as missionaries, BYU's athletes tend to be older on average than other schools' players. Two years of full-time missionary service is encouraged of all Mormon men who are physically and mentally capable, and is part of the Mormon religion. Young men may enter missionary service directly following high school, pending their reaching age eighteen (or 19 in pre-2012 rules); young women may begin their service at age nineteen (as of October 2012[347] or 21[348] under previous rules preceding October 2012). Serving a mission does not prevent the student athlete from participating in the full four years of athletic eligibility as the NCAA two-year eligibility period clock remains "stopped" until the athlete enrolls as a full-time student, which is typically at the conclusion of a mission.[349] This rule is considered by some to be a minor controversy,[350][351][352] although it is widely recognized by athletes, coaches and administrators that there is no competitive advantage gained as the athlete does not participate in any athletic or physical training during the mission. BYU draws a significant amount of sports media attention for two reasons. Since BYU is sponsored by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, its players are required to adhere to the church's honor code. Over the past few years, BYU has dismissed a few players (who were on athletic scholarship) from its teams for violating the honor code.[353][354] BYU's athletic program also holds the distinction of being the only NCAA program to have each athletic team receive at least one national championship title. In the 2011 season, BYU became independent in college football. This became all but certain after Pacific, a charter member of the WCC, announced that it would return to that conference in July 2013. With the Tigers in the WCC fold, the conference will likely add softball, which it does not currently sponsor, in the near future.[357]

text_human: The Armenian Genocide caused widespread emigration that led to the settlement of Armenians in various countries in the world. Armenians kept to their traditions and certain diasporans rose to fame with their music. In the post-Genocide Armenian community of the United States, the so-called "kef" style Armenian dance music, using Armenian and Middle Eastern folk instruments (often electrified/amplified) and some western instruments, was popular. This style preserved the folk songs and dances of Western Armenia, and many artists also played the contemporary popular songs of Turkey and other Middle Eastern countries from which the Armenians emigrated. Richard Hagopian is perhaps the most famous artist of the traditional "kef" style and the Vosbikian Band was notable in the 40s and 50s for developing their own style of "kef music" heavily influenced by the popular American Big Band Jazz of the time. Later, stemming from the Middle Eastern Armenian diaspora and influenced by Continental European (especially French) pop music, the Armenian pop music genre grew to fame in the 60s and 70s with artists such as Adiss Harmandian and Harout Pamboukjian performing to the Armenian diaspora and Armenia. Also with artists such as Sirusho, performing pop music combined with Armenian folk music in today's entertainment industry. Other Armenian diasporans that rose to fame in classical or international music circles are world-renowned French-Armenian singer and composer Charles Aznavour, pianist Sahan Arzruni, prominent opera sopranos such as Hasmik Papian and more recently Isabel Bayrakdarian and Anna Kasyan. Certain Armenians settled to sing non-Armenian tunes such as the heavy metal band System of a Down (which nonetheless often incorporates traditional Armenian instrumentals and styling into their songs) or pop star Cher. Ruben Hakobyan (Ruben Sasuntsi) is a well recognized Armenian ethnographic and patriotic folk singer who has achieved widespread national recognition due to his devotion to Armenian folk music and exceptional talent. In the Armenian diaspora, Armenian revolutionary songs are popular with the youth.[citation needed] These songs encourage Armenian patriotism and are generally about Armenian history and national heroes.
text_ai_base: The Armenian Genocide resulted in widespread emigration, leading Armenians to settle in various countries around the world. Despite being far from their homeland, Armenians maintained their traditions, and some members of the diaspora gained fame through their music. In the United States, following the Genocide, the "kef" style of Armenian dance music emerged, characterized by the use of Armenian and Middle Eastern folk instruments—often electrified or amplified—alongside some Western instruments. This genre preserved the folk songs and dances of Western Armenia, while artists also performed popular songs from Turkey and other Middle Eastern countries where Armenians had emigrated from. Richard Hagopian stands out as a prominent "kef" style musician, and the Vosbikian Band became notable in the 1940s and 50s for blending "kef music" with the popular American Big Band Jazz of the era. As the Middle Eastern Armenian diaspora intersected with European, particularly French, pop music, Armenian pop gained popularity during the 60s and 70s. Artists like Adiss Harmandian and Harout Pamboukjian became celebrated both in the Armenian diaspora and in Armenia itself. Today, artists such as Sirusho continue to perform pop, mixing it with Armenian folk music in the global entertainment scene. Beyond pop music, Armenian diasporans have excelled in classical and international music circles. Charles Aznavour, a renowned French-Armenian singer and composer, exemplifies this success, as do pianist Sahan Arzruni and opera sopranos like Hasmik Papian and more recently Isabel Bayrakdarian and Anna Kasyan. Some Armenian artists have embraced non-Armenian genres, such as the heavy metal band System of a Down, which still incorporates traditional Armenian instrumentals, and pop star Cher. Ruben Hakobyan, known as Ruben Sasuntsi, is a celebrated Armenian ethnographic and patriotic folk singer, recognized nationally for his dedication to Armenian folk music and exceptional talent. Within the Armenian diaspora, revolutionary songs remain popular among the youth, promoting Armenian patriotism and focusing on Armenian history and national heroes.

Although living far from their homeland, Armenians kept their culture alive, and some diasporans became famous for their music. In the US, following the Armenian Genocide, the "kef" style of Armenian dance music, using Armenian and Middle Eastern folk instruments (often electrified/amplified) and some Western instruments (saxophone, electric guitar, synthesizers,) with the Armenian folk songs and dance, preserved the folk songs and dances of Western Armenia. Many artists also played the popular songs of the day from Turkey and other Middle Eastern countries that Armenians had immigrated from. One of the most famous "kef" artists is oud-player Richard Hagopian. In the 1940s and 50s, the Vosbikian Band was one of the most prominent groups to combine the "kef music" with the popular American Big Band Jazz of the time. As Middle Eastern Armenian immigration to Europe began to increase, and Middle Eastern Armenians began to fuel the American and Latin American Armenian diasporas with people, Armenian pop music began to take shape (much with similar instrumentation as the kef style music.) Armenian pop took hold throughout the Armenian Diaspora, especially in Lebanese and Syrian Armenian diaspora, European Armenian diaspora, and even the Latin American Armenian diasporas. Starting in the 60s and 70s, rock-influenced Armenian pop held a tight grip on the Lebanese and Syrian Armenian audiences. Beirut born singers Adiss Harmandian and Harout Pamboukjian, when they emigrated to Los Angeles, became popular with the Armenian-American youth of the 60s and 70s, whose style then became popular in the Armenian SSR. Present-day, artists such as Sirusho, performing pop, a genre still very famous in the Armenian Diaspora internationally, which is infused with Armenian folk music. Armenian diasporans have also found lots of success in the classical and international music arena. One of the most famous diasporan musicians in the French-Armenian singer and composer Charles Aznavour. Armenian-American pianist Sahan Arzruni, sopranos Hasmik Papian and more recent Isabel Bayrakdarian and Anna Kasyan have achieved international acclaim. Some Armenian artists have ventured and found success in genres not typically considered Armenian. For example, despite their music being mostly non-Armenian, the heavy metal band System of a Down has achieved prominence. They even incorporate a lot of traditional Armenian instrumentals in their music. Another example is pop star Cher. Ruben Hakobyan or Ruben Sasuntsi is a popular Armenian ethnographic and patriotic folk singer. He is a national singer and known for his devotion to the Armenian folk music and exceptional voice. Among the youth of the Armenian diaspora, the revolutionary songs are amongst the most popular. These songs encourage Armenian patriotism and are generally about the Armenian history and national heroes.

text_human: The Bush administration then turned its attention to Iraq, and argued the need to remove Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq had become urgent. Among the stated reasons were that Saddam's regime had tried to acquire nuclear material and had not properly accounted for biological and chemical material it was known to have previously possessed, and believed to still maintain. Both the possession of these weapons of mass destruction (WMD), and the failure to account for them, would violate the U.N. sanctions. The assertion about WMD was hotly advanced by the Bush administration from the beginning, but other major powers including China, France, Germany, and Russia remained unconvinced that Iraq was a threat and refused to allow passage of a UN Security Council resolution to authorize the use of force. Iraq permitted UN weapon inspectors in November 2002, who were continuing their work to assess the WMD claim when the Bush administration decided to proceed with war without UN authorization and told the inspectors to leave the country. The United States invaded Iraq on March 20, 2003, along with a "coalition of the willing" that consisted of additional troops from the United Kingdom, and to a lesser extent, from Australia and Poland. Within about three weeks, the invasion caused the collapse of both the Iraqi government and its armed forces, however, the U.S. and allied forces failed to find any weapon of mass destruction in Iraq. Traces of former materials and weapons labs were reported to have been located, but no "smoking guns". Nevertheless, on May 1, George W. Bush landed on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, in a Lockheed S-3 Viking, where he gave a speech announcing the end of "major combat operations" in the Iraq War. Bush's approval rating in May was at 66%, according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll. However, Bush's high approval ratings did not last. First, while the war itself was popular in the U.S., the reconstruction and attempted "democratization" of Iraq lost some support as months passed and casualty figures increased, with no decrease in violence nor progress toward stability or reconstruction. Second, as investigators combed through the country, they failed to find the predicted WMD stockpiles, which led to debate over the rationale for the war.

Additionally, the failure to find the predicted WMD stockpiles led to debate over the war's justification.
text_ai_humanized: The attention of the Bush administration turned to Iraq, where the administration trumpeted the need to depose Saddam Hussein as quickly as possible. This was alleged due to Iraq's record and capability of producing mass destruction weapons (WMD), Iraq's continuing support of terrorism, use of chemical agents in the Gulf War, alleged attempt to "purchase nuclear weapons-grade uranium from Niger " [39] and unaccounted for biological and chemical agents Iraq had produced previous to the Gulf War according to UNSCOM inspectors. [40] Both the possession and failure to account for these weapons of mass destruction (WMD) would violate standing U. N. sanctions. The grounds were initially trumpeted on by the Bush administration, but China, France, Germany, and Russia didn't feel that Iraq was a threat, and so blocked a UN Security Resolution authorizing force. Allowing UN weapon inspectors into Iraq in November 2002, Iraq was still being inspected and the claims checked when the Bush Administration abruptly made up its mind and ordered that inspectors be removed in preparation for war. The United States invaded Iraq on March 20, 2003, joined by a "coalition of the willing" including United Kingdom, and lesser component of Australian and Polish combat forces. Within three weeks, the invasion led to the defeat and collapse of the Ba'athist Iraqi government and the flight, hiding, or capture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's regime, although the rationale for the war was changed early on. No WMDs were found, though traces of materials and labs used to make such weapons were reported. Significant finds of various degradation chemical agents and warheads were also reported, but there were no discoveries made that constituted any clear evidence of WMD's , despite intensive investigation. On May 1, George W. Bush landed on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, in front of a banner labeled "Mission Accomplished" and stated that "major combat operations in Iraq have ended". [41] [42] [43] George Bush's approval rating rose to 66% in May according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll. [44] This would prove to be the short-term high-water mark. Popularity of the war itself was positive in the U. S. but eventually declined as the war dragged on. Significant casualties, both military and civilian, were sustained. Difficulty of providing administrative stability and resistance by an insurgency eventually led to a substantial reduction of support for the occupation. In addition, failure to find the predicted amount of WMD stockpiled in Iraq led to controversy.

text_human: Established bands made something of a comeback in the mid-1980s. After an 8-year separation, Deep Purple returned with the classic Machine Head line-up to produce Perfect Strangers (1984), which reached number five in the UK, hit the top five in five other countries, and was a platinum-seller in the US. After somewhat slower sales of its fourth album, Fair Warning, Van Halen rebounded with the Top 3 album Diver Down in 1982, then reached their commercial pinnacle with 1984. It reached number two on the Billboard album chart and provided the track "Jump", which reached number one on the singles chart and remained there for several weeks. Heart, after floundering during the first half of the decade, made a comeback with their eponymous ninth studio album which hit number one and contained four Top 10 singles including their first number one hit. The new medium of video channels was used with considerable success by bands formed in previous decades. Among the first were ZZ Top, who mixed hard blues rock with new wave music to produce a series of highly successful singles, beginning with "Gimme All Your Lovin'" (1983), which helped their albums Eliminator (1983) and Afterburner (1985) achieve diamond and multi-platinum status respectively. Others found renewed success in the singles charts with power ballads, including REO Speedwagon with "Keep on Loving You" (1980) and "Can't Fight This Feeling" (1984), Journey with "Don't Stop Believin'" (1981) and "Open Arms" (1982), Foreigner's "I Want to Know What Love Is", Scorpions' "Still Loving You" (both from 1984), Heart’s "What About Love" (1985) and "These Dreams" (1986), and Boston's "Amanda" (1986).

text_human: About 20% of pupils at Eton receive financial support, through a range of bursaries and scholarships. The recent Head Master, Tony Little, said that Eton is developing plans to allow any boy to attend the school whatever his parents' income and, in 2011, said that around 250 boys received "significant" financial help from the school. In early 2014, this figure had risen to 263 pupils receiving the equivalent of around 60% of school fee assistance, whilst a further 63 received their education free of charge. Little said that, in the short term, he wanted to ensure that around 320 pupils per year receive bursaries, and that 70 were educated free of charge, with the intention that the number of pupils receiving financial assistance would continue to increase. These comparatively new developments will run alongside long-established courses that Eton has provided for pupils from state schools, most of them in the summer holidays (July and August). Launched in 1982, the Universities Summer School is an intensive residential course open to boys and girls throughout the UK who attend state schools, are at the end of their first year in the Sixth Form, and are about to begin their final year of schooling. The Brent-Eton Summer School, started in 1994, offers 40-50 young people from the London Borough of Brent, an area of inner-city deprivation, an intensive one-week residential course, free of charge, designed to help bridge the gap between GCSE and A-level. In 2008, Eton helped found the Eton, Slough, Windsor and Hounslow Independent and State School Partnership (ISSP), with six local state schools. The ISSP's aims are "to raise pupil achievement, improve pupil self-esteem, raise pupil aspirations and improve professional practice across the schools". Eton also runs a number of choral and English language courses during the summer months.

text_ai_humanized: About 20% of boys at Eton receive financial support of some kind;[33] Eton has expressed a commitment to broadening access to the school through means-tested bursaries, acting Head Master Tony Little said in 2005 that Eton was prepared to raise them to fund the expansion of the school in order to "maintain Eton's position as a leading educational institution".[34] The Head Master, after finishing his first year, was quoted in The Times in 2003, stating that Eton would have to open up to students whose parents could not necessarily afford the fees: "We won't change what we do; just increase access to it." In 2011 he said the school was "committed to a generous and increasing number of scholarships for talented boys or those in need", adding that the "total of boys with any level of fee remission" was "around 250".[35] For the academic year 2013–14, the school reported that 263 boys (c 12%) received financial support amounting to two thirds or more of the full fee, and of those 63 paid no fees at all. Eton additionally allows lower-income students to take the King’s Scholarship entrance exam with more lenient pass requirements. Little has said he is "not content" with this: his ambition is for Eton to have around 320 pupils per annum receiving bursaries, and to have 70 on full fees; however, "even the current level of bursary requires money to be spent on fundraising".[36] These hopes are denominated in the context of the school’s massive financial investment in the national partnership of state boarding schools; a personal project of Little’s, which he "was instrumental in setting up" and has received very substantial funding from Eton.[37] These newer initiatives remain behind longstanding programmes to allow a wider range of state school students to experience Eton. These are mostly undertaken during the summer holidays to avoid disrupting Eton’s own students’ study time. The Universities Summer School is a residential programme for boys and girls from state schools who have just completed their first year of Sixth Form and are about to enter their second and final year. It was founded in 1982 under the title, the Eton Summer School University Programme, as a flagship access programme designed to give academically gifted students from underprivileged backgrounds the opportunity to prepare university-entrance-style study. The Brent-Eton Summer School is a programme aimed at promoting the transition between GCSE and AS-level between boys and girls in the London Borough of Brent and Eton College. It was initiated by Sir William Atkinson, Headmaster of Phoenix High School in West London, in July 1994. Since the start of the programme, an average of 40–50 students aged 15–17 have taken part in the week-long residential course that involves Eton staff. The Service to Schools Scheme is something the staff have been doing on an ad hoc basis for decades; additionally there are OSS, Choral and other courses throughout the year and summer months. In 2008, Eton co-founded the Eton, Slough, Windsor and Hounslow Independent and State School Partnership (ISSP), with six local state schools. The Department for Children, Schools and Families described it as "an unprecedented partnership" and it was driven by the then children’s secretary, Ed Balls. According to the Good Schools Guide the ISSP programme: "is widely recognised to be having a very positive impact on achievement, self-esteem and their aspirations. They also provide valuable opportunities for professional development and the exchange of good practice."[38] In 2011, Eton helped found Holyport College, a state-maintained boarding school in Berkshire. It was constructed at a cost of £15.4 million. A number of Eton staff act as governors, and sixth-form pupils from the two schools interact in a number of joint activities.[39]

api_response.result: About 20% of boys at Eton receive financial support of some kind;[33] Eton has expressed a commitment to broadening access to the school through means-tested bursaries, acting Head Master Tony Little said in 2005 that Eton was prepared to raise them to fund the expansion of the school in order to "maintain Eton's position as a leading educational institution".[34] The Head Master, after finishing his first year, was quoted in The Times in 2003, stating that Eton would have to open up to students whose parents could not necessarily afford the fees: "We won't change what we do; just increase access to it." In 2011 he said the school was "committed to a generous and increasing number of scholarships for talented boys or those in need", adding that the "total of boys with any level of fee remission" was "around 250".[35] For the academic year 2013–14, the school reported that 263 boys (c 12%) received financial support amounting to two thirds or more of the full fee, and of those 63 paid no fees at all. Little has said he is "not content" with this: his ambition is for Eton to have around 320 pupils per annum receiving bursaries, and to have 70 on full fees; however, "even the current level of bursary requires money to be spent on fundraising".[36] These hopes are denominated in the context of the school’s massive financial investment in the national partnership of state boarding schools; a personal project of Little’s, which he "was instrumental in setting up" and has received very substantial funding from Eton.[37] These newer initiatives remain behind longstanding programmes to allow a wider range of state school students to experience Eton. text_human: The title of "world's oldest airport" is disputed, but College Park Airport in Maryland, US, established in 1909 by Wilbur Wright, is generally agreed to be the world's oldest continually operating airfield, although it serves only general aviation traffic. Bisbee-Douglas International Airport in Arizona was declared "the first international airport of the Americas" by US president Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1943. Pearson Field Airport in Vancouver, Washington had a dirigible land in 1905 and planes in 1911 and is still in use. Bremen Airport opened in 1913 and remains in use, although it served as an American military field between 1945 and 1949. Amsterdam Airport Schiphol opened on September 16, 1916 as a military airfield, but only accepted civil aircraft from December 17, 1920, allowing Sydney Airport in Sydney, Australia—which started operations in January 1920—to claim to be one of the world's oldest continually operating commercial airports. Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport in Minneapolis-Saint Paul, Minnesota, opened in 1920 and has been in continuous commercial service since. It serves about 35,000,000 passengers each year and continues to expand, recently opening a new 11,000 foot (3,355 meter) runway. Of the airports constructed during this early period in aviation, it is one of the largest and busiest that is still currently operating. Rome Ciampino Airport, opened 1916, is also a contender, as well as the Don Mueang International Airport near Bangkok,Thailand, which opened in 1914. Increased aircraft traffic during World War I led to the construction of landing fields. Aircraft had to approach these from certain directions and this led to the development of aids for directing the approach and landing slope.
text_ai_base: The title of the "world's oldest airport" is debated, but College Park Airport in Maryland, USA, founded by Wilbur Wright in 1909, is widely regarded as the oldest continuously operating airfield, albeit only serving general aviation traffic. In 1943, US President Franklin D. Roosevelt dubbed Bisbee-Douglas International Airport in Arizona as "the first international airport of the Americas." Pearson Field Airport in Vancouver, Washington, has been active since a dirigible landed there in 1905, with airplanes following suit in 1911. Bremen Airport, which opened in 1913, is still operational, though it was used as an American military field from 1945 to 1949. Amsterdam Airport Schiphol, which began as a military airfield on September 16, 1916, only began accommodating civil planes on December 17, 1920. This timeline enables Sydney Airport, which began operations in January 1920, to claim its status as one of the oldest continually operating commercial airports. Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport, which opened in 1920, has been in constant commercial service and currently handles about 35 million passengers annually. This major hub has recently expanded, adding a new 11,000-foot (3,355-meter) runway, making it one of the largest and busiest airports from this era still in operation. Other notable contenders include Rome Ciampino Airport, opened in 1916, and Don Mueang International Airport near Bangkok, Thailand, inaugurated in 1914. The surge in aircraft traffic during World War I prompted the construction of new landing fields, leading to the development of navigational aids for landing approaches.
text_ai_humanized: There is no consensus as to which is in fact the world's oldest airport, and competing claims have been made regarding which airport is actually the oldest.[non-primary source needed] For example, regarding Maryland's College Park Airport, operated by Prince George's County, as of 2008[update]: "The "world's oldest airport" is actually a title contested by around 20 airports, most notably by College Park. The issue for some is that College Park is not a commercial airport." Another contender: "Bisbee-Douglas International Airport, Arizona. 1943: US President Franklin D Roosevelt refers to Bisbee-Douglas as 'the first international airport of the Americas'." Pearson Field Airport in Vancouver, Washington affiliate has been in use since 1905 (a dirigible in that year, airplanes in 1911). [non-primary source needed] Bremen Airport opened in 1913 but was exclusively used as an American military field from 1945 to 1949. Amsterdam Airport Schiphol opened September 16, 1916 as a military airfield, but civil aircraft already landed there before December 17, 1920, when the airport officially switched to civil aviation. This thus leaves Sydney Airport, which has been operated continuously since January 1920, the oldest continually-operating commercial airport, although it served only as an air mail and freight depot for some time after opening.[6] Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport in the United States was opened in 1920 and has been in continuous commercial service since, now serving 35,000,000 passengers a year. One of this airport's four terminals has since been rebuilt three times within the original terminal's foundation footprint. [8][9] This recently expanded (11,000 ft (3,355 m) runway) major US hub airport even added another 8,000 ft (2,438 m) runway recently. This may be the largest and busiest commercial airport that has stood or sat (in ASM) in one place so long. Another contender is Rome Ciampino Airport (Aeroporto di Roma-Ciampino), near Rome, Italy, which opened in 1916. One of the world's oldest continually operating airports is Don Mueang International Airport near Bangkok, Thailand which began operations in 1914.[10][11] Increase in aircraft movements during World War I gave impetus to the development of landing fields.

text_human: By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its reentry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejecting from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft), and landing by parachute. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (International Federation of Aeronautics) credited Gagarin with the world's first human space flight, although their qualifying rules for aeronautical records at the time required pilots to take off and land with their craft. For this reason, the Soviet Union omitted from their FAI submission the fact that Gagarin did not land with his capsule. When the FAI filing for Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 disclosed the ejection landing technique, the FAI committee decided to investigate, and concluded that the technological accomplishment of human spaceflight lay in the safe launch, orbiting, and return, rather than the manner of landing, and so revised their rules accordingly, keeping Gagarin's and Titov's records intact.
text_ai_base: By 1959, American observers anticipated that the Soviet Union would be the first to send a human into space due to the time required for Mercury's inaugural launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world by sending Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around Earth aboard a spacecraft named Vostok 1. They referred to Gagarin as the first "cosmonaut," a term derived from Russian and Greek, meaning "sailor of the universe." Although Gagarin had an emergency option to manually control the spacecraft via a code contained in an envelope in the cabin, the craft operated automatically as a precaution, given the uncertainties about human health in the weightlessness of space at that time. Vostok 1 completed its orbit of Earth in 108 minutes, reentered over the Soviet Union, and Gagarin ejected from the spacecraft at 7,000 meters (23,000 ft), landing safely by parachute. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI) recognized Gagarin's mission as the world's first human spaceflight, despite their rules then requiring pilots to land with their craft. The Soviet Union omitted from their FAI report that Gagarin did not land with his capsule. When Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 revealed the ejection landing technique, the FAI investigated. They concluded that the primary achievement of human spaceflight was in the safe launch, orbit, and return, leading them to adjust their rules to uphold Gagarin's and Titov's records.
text_ai_humanized: As early as 1959, American observers believed that the USSR would make the first human spaceflight due to the time needed to prepare for the first Mercury launch.[citation needed] On April 12, 1961 the USSR launched Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a spacecraft named Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, an English transliteration of the Russian term for an astronaut.[citation needed] The word is an acronym for the Russian phrase "sailor of the universe".[citation needed] At the time, the term was used for Soviet space travelers, those of the United States were known as astronauts and those of China as taikonauts.[citation needed] Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had been given and entering the code it contained into the controls, it was flown in a fully automatic mode because medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space[citation needed]. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its re-entry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejected from the spacecraft at 7,000 metres (23,000 ft), and landed by parachute. The FAI rules at the time the Soviet Union did not require pilots to land with their craft, so it recognized Gagarin as the first human in space.[citation needed] Gagarin's flight was a propaganda coup, with the Soviet Union sending the FAI documentation for the flight that gave a precise time for a complete orbit of the Earth. Unknown to anyone outside the Soviet Union, the actual flight time was 104 minutes; it would not be revealed until 30 years later that Gagarin did not complete a full orbit. When the FAI filing for Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 disclosed the claim that the pilot had been ejected from the spacecraft and landed by parachute, officials considered whether this would disqualify Gagarin's claim to the first human to fly in space.[citation needed] They decided that the technological accomplishment of the launch, orbit, and safe return was the deciding factor, and therefore declined to seek to alter the list of record-holders.[53][54]

They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, an English transliteration of the Russian term for an astronaut.[citation needed] The word is an acronym for the Russian phrase "sailor of the universe".[citation needed] At the time, the term was used for Soviet space travelers, those of the United States were known as astronauts and those of China as taikonauts.[citation needed] Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had been given and entering the code it contained into the controls, it was flown in a fully automatic mode because medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space[citation needed]. Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its re-entry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejected from the spacecraft at 7,000 metres (23,000 ft), and landed by parachute. The FAI rules at the time the Soviet Union did not require pilots to land with their craft, so it recognized Gagarin as the first human in space.[citation needed] Gagarin's flight was a propaganda coup, with the Soviet Union sending the FAI documentation for the flight that gave a precise time for a complete orbit of the Earth. Unknown to anyone outside the Soviet Union, the actual flight time was 104 minutes; it would not be revealed until 30 years later that Gagarin did not complete a full orbit. When the FAI filing for Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 disclosed the claim that the pilot had been ejected from the spacecraft and landed by parachute, officials considered whether this would disqualify Gagarin's claim to the first human to fly in space.[citation needed] They decided that the technological accomplishment of the launch, orbit, and safe return was the deciding factor, and therefore declined to seek to alter the list of record-holders.[53][54]

text_human: Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern-day Scotland and the Isle of Man. Though the Vikings were eventually neutralised in Ireland, their influence remained in the cities of Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Wexford. England however was slowly conquered around the turn of the first millennium AD, and eventually became a feudal possession of Denmark. The relations between the descendants of Vikings in England and counterparts in Normandy, in northern France, lay at the heart of a series of events that led to the Norman conquest of England in 1066. The remnants of the Duchy of Normandy, which conquered England, remain associated to the English Crown as the Channel Islands to this day. A century later the marriage of the future Henry II of England to Eleanor of Aquitaine created the Angevin Empire, partially under the French Crown. At the invitation of a provincial king and under the authority of Pope Adrian IV (the only Englishman to be elected pope), the Angevins invaded Ireland in 1169. Though initially intended to be kept as an independent kingdom, the failure of the Irish High King to ensure the terms of the Treaty of Windsor led Henry II, as King of England, to rule as effective monarch under the title of Lord of Ireland. This title was granted to his younger son but when Henry's heir unexpectedly died the title of King of England and Lord of Ireland became entwined in one person.
