Although Vikings were eventually subdued in Ireland, their legacy endured in cities such as Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford, and Wexford. Meanwhile, England gradually fell under Viking control near the first millennium AD, eventually becoming a Danish feudal territory. The relationship between Viking descendants in England and their counterparts in Normandy, northern France, played a critical role in the sequence of events culminating in the Norman Conquest of England in 1066. The territory of Normandy that conquered England remains linked to the English Crown today as the Channel Islands. A century later, the union of Henry II of England and Eleanor of Aquitaine established the Angevin Empire, partially under French sovereignty. Under the invitation from a local king and the blessing of Pope Adrian IV, the only Englishman to become pope, the Angevins invaded Ireland in 1169. While initially intended to remain an independent kingdom, the Irish High King's failure to uphold the Treaty of Windsor led Henry II, as King of England, to govern as the effective monarch with the title Lord of Ireland. This title was bestowed on his younger son, but after Henry's heir died unexpectedly, the titles of King of England and Lord of Ireland were united under one ruler.

text_human: After independence, the Chief Commissioner's Province of H.P. came into being on 15 April 1948 as a result of integration of 28 petty princely states (including feudal princes and zaildars) in the promontories of the western Himalaya, known in full as the Simla Hills States and four Punjab southern hill states by issue of the Himachal Pradesh (Administration) Order, 1948 under Sections 3 and 4 of the Extra-Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947 (later renamed as the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1947 vide A.O. of 1950). The State of Bilaspur was merged in the Himachal Pradesh on 1 April 1954 by the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur (New State) Act, 1954. Himachal became a part C state on 26 January 1950 with the implementation of the Constitution of India and the Lt. Governor was appointed. Legislative Assembly was elected in 1952. Himachal Pradesh became a union territory on 1 November 1956. Following area of Punjab State namely Simla, Kangra, Kulu and Lahul and Spiti Districts, Nalagarh tehsil of Ambala District, Lohara, Amb and Una kanungo circles, some area of Santokhgarh kanungo circle and some other specified area of Una tehsil of Hoshiarpur District besides some parts of Dhar Kalan Kanungo circle of Pathankot tehsil of Gurdaspur District; were merged with Himachal Pradesh on 1 November 1966 on enactment of Punjab Reorganisation Act, 1966 by the Parliament. On 18 December 1970, the State of Himachal Pradesh Act was passed by Parliament and the new state came into being on 25 January 1971. Thus Himachal emerged as the 18th state of the Indian Union.
text_ai_base: After gaining independence, the Chief Commissioner's Province of Himachal Pradesh was established on 15 April 1948. This creation resulted from the merger of 28 small princely states, including feudal princes and local leaders known as zaildars, located in the western Himalayas. These territories, collectively called the Simla Hills States, along with four southern hill states from Punjab, were unified under the Himachal Pradesh (Administration) Order, 1948, in accordance with Sections 3 and 4 of the Extra-Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947, which was later renamed the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1947, by the Adaptation of Laws Order of 1950. The State of Bilaspur was integrated into Himachal Pradesh on 1 April 1954 via the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur (New State) Act, 1954. Himachal Pradesh became a Part C state on 26 January 1950 with the implementation of the Constitution of India, and a Lieutenant Governor was appointed. A Legislative Assembly was elected in 1952. On 1 November 1956, Himachal Pradesh was reclassified as a union territory. Additional areas from the Punjab State—specifically, the districts of Simla, Kangra, Kullu, and Lahaul and Spiti; Nalagarh tehsil from Ambala District; the Lohara, Amb, and Una revenue circles; parts of the Santokhgarh revenue circle; and other specified portions of Una tehsil from Hoshiarpur District, along with parts of the Dhar Kalan revenue circle from the Pathankot tehsil of Gurdaspur District—were merged into Himachal Pradesh on 1 November 1966 due to the Punjab Reorganisation Act, 1966, passed by the Parliament. On 18 December 1970, the State of Himachal Pradesh Act was enacted by Parliament, leading to the formation of the new state on 25 January 1971. Consequently, Himachal Pradesh became the 18th state of the Indian Union.

The State of Himachal Pradesh Act was passed by Parliament on 18 December 1970 and the new state came into being on 25 January 1971. Thus Himachal emerged as the eighteenth state of the Indian Union.[26]

text_human: Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats typically called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian", respectively, without implying a distinction between the two, and again in independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian", and "Serbian" were considered to be three names of a single official language. Croatian linguist Dalibor Brozović advocated the term Serbo-Croatian as late as 1988, claiming that in an analogy with Indo-European, Serbo-Croatian does not only name the two components of the same language, but simply charts the limits of the region in which it is spoken and includes everything between the limits (‘Bosnian’ and ‘Montenegrin’). Today, use of the term "Serbo-Croatian" is controversial due to the prejudice that nation and language must match. It is still used for lack of a succinct alternative, though alternative names have been used, such as Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian (BCS), which is often seen in political contexts such as the Hague War Crimes tribunal.
text_ai_base: Throughout the history of the South Slavs, their regional and ethnic languages (such as Chakavian, Kajkavian, and Shtokavian) developed independently. Before the 19th century, these languages were collectively referred to as "Illyric," "Slavic," "Slavonian," "Bosnian," "Dalmatian," "Serbian," or "Croatian." The term "Serbo-Croatian" was first introduced by Jacob Grimm in 1824, later popularized by Viennese philologist Jernej Kopitar, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At this time, the lands of the Serbs and Croats were still under Ottoman and Austrian rule. Officially, the language had several names, including Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, or Serbian or Croatian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats generally called it "Serbian" or "Croatian," respectively, often without distinguishing between the two. In independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian," "Croatian," and "Serbian" are considered names for the single official language. Croatian linguist Dalibor Brozović supported the term "Serbo-Croatian" as late as 1988, suggesting that like "Indo-European," it describes the region where the language is spoken, encompassing "Bosnian" and "Montenegrin." Today, the term "Serbo-Croatian" is controversial due to the belief that nation and language should align. It is still used because no succinct alternative exists, though alternatives like Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian (BCS) appear in political contexts, such as the Hague War Crimes tribunal.
text_ai_humanized: For most of the 20th century it was called Serbo-Croatian (Books 1,2,3). But during earlier centuries and millennia of South Slav history, the regional and ethnic languages (such as Chakavian, Kajkavian, and Shtokavian) developed independently. Until the 19th, century, these languages were generically called "Illyric," "Slavic," "Slavonian," "Bosnian," "Dalmatian," "Serbian," or "Croatian." The word "Serbo-Croatian" was coined by Jacob Grimm in 1824, adopted and popularized by Jernej Kopitar, a Viennese philologist, and endorsed by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and1859. This was at a time when the lands of the Serbs and Croats still bore the yoke of Ottoman and Austrian rule. Officially the language was called Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian or, less commonly, Serbian or Croatian as well as Croatoserbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats generally called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian," without distinguishing it from the other. In independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian" and "Serbian" are considered to be three names of a single official language. Croatian linguist Dalibor Brozović used the term "Serbo-Croatian" in the title of a scientific article published in the journal Jezik, and as late as 1988 the official seal of the Croatian language society had an inscription on the top, in parentheses, that said: Hrvatski (ili srpski), [Croatian (or Serbian)]. Brozović voted, alongside Ljudevit Jonke, in favor on Brozović's definition of the Croatian literary language in Matica hrvatska, slightly differently from the definition adopted by the Serbian Matica. Brozović admitted in his book from 1988 that the terms Croatian or Serbian (for a single language) were invented even earlier, but that he still considered the term Serbo-Croatian the most appropriate, because, in a similar way to, for example Indo-European and often used to name the languages of Southeastern Europe, it denoted the region where the language was spoken. Thus he accepted designation of the hypothetical language, no matter how many nations spoke it (he counted 4 including Bosnian and Montenegrin). (D. Brozović, J. Jelenić: Jezik i lingvistika. Prosvjeta, Zagreb, 1988.) In the 20th and 21st century, the term Serbo-Croatian is contentious due to the fact it is generally considered that a nation and a language should be one. The term Serbo-Croatian is in use because there is no better short name for the language to which subject books pertain (alternatives are proposed such as Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian (BCS), which is used only in strictly political contexts such as in the international Hague War Crimes tribunal). }

text_human: The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Gondwana; the Gulf of Mexico opened in the new rift between North America and what is now Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. The Jurassic North Atlantic Ocean was relatively narrow, while the South Atlantic did not open until the following Cretaceous Period, when Gondwana itself rifted apart. The Tethys Sea closed, and the Neotethys basin appeared. Climates were warm, with no evidence of glaciation. As in the Triassic, there was apparently no land near either pole, and no extensive ice caps existed. The Jurassic geological record is good in western Europe, where extensive marine sequences indicate a time when much of the continent was submerged under shallow tropical seas; famous locales include the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the renowned late Jurassic lagerstätten of Holzmaden and Solnhofen. In contrast, the North American Jurassic record is the poorest of the Mesozoic, with few outcrops at the surface. Though the epicontinental Sundance Sea left marine deposits in parts of the northern plains of the United States and Canada during the late Jurassic, most exposed sediments from this period are continental, such as the alluvial deposits of the Morrison Formation. The first of several massive batholiths were emplaced in the northern Cordillera beginning in the mid-Jurassic, marking the Nevadan orogeny. Important Jurassic exposures are also found in Russia, India, South America, Japan, Australasia and the United Kingdom.
text_ai_base: The Jurassic Period lasted from around 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 million years ago. In its early stages, the supercontinent Pangaea split into the northern continent Laurasia and the southern continent Gondwana. This separation led to the formation of the Gulf of Mexico between North America and what is now Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. The Jurassic North Atlantic remained relatively narrow, while the South Atlantic didn't open until the Cretaceous Period, when Gondwana split further. The Tethys Sea closed, and the Neotethys basin emerged. The climate was warm, with no signs of glaciation. Unlike the Triassic, no landmasses were near the poles, and large ice caps were absent. Western Europe has a well-preserved Jurassic geological record, with marine sequences indicating much of the area was submerged under shallow tropical seas. Notable sites include the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the late Jurassic Lagerstätten of Holzmaden and Solnhofen. In contrast, North America's Jurassic record is the least complete of the Mesozoic, with few surface outcrops. Although the epicontinental Sundance Sea left marine deposits in regions of the northern United States and Canada, most exposed sediments, like the Morrison Formation's alluvial deposits, are continental. The first of several major batholiths formed in the northern Cordillera during the mid-Jurassic, marking the Nevadan orogeny. Significant Jurassic deposits are also found in Russia, India, South America, Japan, Australasia, and the United Kingdom.
text_ai_humanized: The Jurassic Period is a geologic period and system that spans 56.3 million years from the end of the Triassic Period 201.3 ± 0.2 Mya (million years ago) Mya to the beginning of the Cretaceous Period 145.0 Mya The Jurassic constitutes the middle period of the Mesozoic Era, also known as the Age of Reptiles. The start of the period was marked by the major Triassic-Jurassic extinction event. Two other extinction events occurred during the period: the Pliensbachian-Toarcian extinction in the Early Jurassic, and the Tithonian event in the Late Jurassic. The Jurassic is named after the Jura Mountains within the European Alps, where limestone strata from the period were first identified. During the Early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea broke apart into the continents Laurasia to the north and Gondwana to the south. The Gulf of Mexico opened in the new rift between North America and the Yucatan platform of modern-day Mexico, and Atlantic ocean basin opened between Europe and Africa, but at first narrowed towards modern Iberia and was closed off by Iberia's collision with Europe. The North Atlantic was relatively narrow, while the South Atlantic did not open until the following Cretaceous period, when Gondwana itself rifted apart. The Tethys Sea closed, and the Neotethys basin appeared. Climates were warm, with no evidence of glaciation. As in the Triassic, there was apparently no land over either pole, and no extensive ice caps existed. The Jurassic geological record is represented by several exposures in Western Europe, where the stratigraphy is well-established. Marine sequences are also well exposed in the western North America and South America, and there is much known from a series of exposures in Russia, India, Japan, Australasia and the United Kingdom. The Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site in southern England is a prominent example of Jurassic marine life and showcases many excellent fossils. In contrast, the Jurassic stratigraphy of eastern North America is primarily continental, and consequently nonmarine; also, it is limited due to the absence of rifting at that time. The Jurassic was a golden age for dinosaurs, as they were the dominant terrestrial vertebrates. The first birds also appeared during the Jurassic, having evolved from a branch of theropod dinosaurs. Other major events include the appearance of the earliest lizards, and the evolution of therian mammals, including primitive placentals. Crocodylomorphs made the transition from land to water, leading to the evolution of modern day crocodilians. The oceans were inhabited by marine reptiles such as ichthyosaurs, plesiosaurs and ammonites, while pterosaurs were the dominant flying vertebrates.

text_human: In January 1920, Tito and his wife made a long and difficult journey home to Yugoslavia where he arrived in September. Upon his return, Broz joined the Communist Party of Yugoslavia. The CPY's influence on the political life of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia was growing rapidly. In the 1920 elections the Communists won 59 seats in the parliament and became the third strongest party. Winning numerous local elections, they gained a stronghold in the second largest city of Zagreb, electing Svetozar Delić for mayor. After the assassination of Milorad Drašković, the Yugoslav Minister of the Interior, by a young communist on 2 August 1921, the CPY was declared illegal under the Yugoslav State Security Act of 1921. During 1920 and 1921 all Communist-won mandates were nullified. Broz continued his work underground despite pressure on Communists from the government. As 1921 began he moved to Veliko Trojstvo near Bjelovar and found work as a machinist. In 1925, Broz moved to Kraljevica where he started working at a shipyard. He was elected as a union leader and a year later he led a shipyard strike. He was fired and moved to Belgrade, where he worked in a train coach factory in Smederevska Palanka. He was elected as Workers' Commissary but was fired as soon as his CPY membership was revealed. Broz then moved to Zagreb, where he was appointed secretary of Metal Workers' Union of Croatia. In 1928, he became the Zagreb Branch Secretary of the CPY. In the same year he was arrested, tried in court for his illegal communist activities, and sent to jail. During his five years at Lepoglava prison he met Moša Pijade, who became his ideological mentor. After his release, he lived incognito and assumed numerous noms de guerre, among them "Walter" and "Tito".
text_ai_base: In January 1920, Tito and his wife embarked on a lengthy and challenging journey back to Yugoslavia, arriving in September. Upon his return, Tito joined the Communist Party of Yugoslavia (CPY), which was rapidly increasing its influence in the Kingdom of Yugoslavia's political scene. In the 1920 elections, the CPY secured 59 parliamentary seats, becoming the third-largest party. They also won numerous local elections and gained a significant foothold in Zagreb, the second-largest city, by electing Svetozar Delić as mayor. However, on August 2, 1921, following the assassination of the Yugoslav Minister of the Interior, Milorad Drašković, by a young communist, the CPY was outlawed under the Yugoslav State Security Act of 1921, and all Communist-held mandates from 1920 and 1921 were annulled. Despite government pressure, Tito continued his underground communist activities. At the beginning of 1921, he relocated to Veliko Trojstvo near Bjelovar, working as a machinist. By 1925, Tito moved to Kraljevica and worked in a shipyard, where he was elected a union leader and led a strike the following year. After being fired, he relocated to Belgrade and worked at a train coach factory in Smederevska Palanka but lost his job when his CPY membership was discovered. Tito then moved to Zagreb and became the secretary of the Metal Workers' Union of Croatia. In 1928, he was appointed the CPY’s Zagreb Branch Secretary. That year, he was arrested for his illegal communist activities, tried, and imprisoned. While serving five years at Lepoglava prison, he met Moša Pijade, who became his ideological mentor. After his release, Tito lived under various assumed names, including "Walter" and "Tito."
text_ai_humanized: In January 1920, Tito and his wife returned to Yugoslavia, where in the autumn he entered the ranks of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia (CPY). The CPY's influence on the Kingdom of Yugoslavia's political scene increased rapidly. In the 1920 parliamentary elections the Communists won 59 seats and became the third strongest group. They also won several local elections and became an important factor in local politics in the second largest city Zagreb, electing Svetozar Delić as mayor. On 2 August 1921, in the aftermath of the assassination of the Yugoslav Minister of the Interior, Milorad Drašković, by a young communist, the Communist Party was declared illegal under the Yugoslav State Security Act of 1921, and the Communist MPs' mandates were nullified.[16][36] After the banning of the Communist party, Tito continued his illegal Communist party work in Yugoslavia. At the end of 1920, Tito moved to Veliko Trojstvo near Bjelovar, where he was employed as a machinist.[37] In 1925, he moved to Kraljevica where he got a job in a shipyard. There he was elected as a union leader and during 1926, he led a shipyard strike. He subsequently lost his job and moved to Belgrade. After his efforts to organize strikes in a train coach factory in Smederevska Palanka failed, he returned to Zagreb, where he was appointed secretary of the Metal Workers' Union of Croatia. In July 1928, he was appointed by the Zagreb Branch of the CPY to be their representative at the 4th Congress of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Dresden. On 4 November 1928, he was arrested and imprisoned in the Petrinjska Street prison where he spent several months.[38][39] In 1929, he was convicted of being a member of the then-illegal Communist Party of Yugoslavia and sentenced to five years' imprisonment.[40] He served out his sentence in Lepoglava and Maribor, where he became acquainted with Moša Pijade, who was to become his ideological mentor.[41] During his prison term he adopted the nom de guerre "Tito".[42] Stalinist purge wave (1936–1940) [ edit ] Image of the Moscow Trials where many of the accused and executed Yugoslav communists were co-defendants. It was during this period that Tito became closely intertwined with the Soviets' WKP(B) and delegate to the Comintern. After his release, he lived in Samobor, where he started a career as a communist functionary. In 1934 he became General Secretary of the CPY.[43] During his period in revolutionary underground activity within the League of Communists of Yugoslavia, Tito assumed various code names. "Walter" was one; "Tito" was another. This last was the name he adopted for the rest of his life.

text_human: A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God who punishes evil, the moral order of society was undermined. That is, since atheists gave themselves to no Supreme Authority and no law, and had no fear of eternal consequences, they were far more likely to disrupt society. Bayle (1647–1706) observed that in his day, "prudent persons will always maintain an appearance of [religion].". He believed that even atheists could hold concepts of honor and go beyond their own self-interest to create and interact in society. Locke said that if there were no God and no divine law, the result would be moral anarchy: every individual "could have no law but his own will, no end but himself. He would be a god to himself, and the satisfaction of his own will the sole measure and end of all his actions".
text_ai_base: During the Enlightenment, various new ideas about religion emerged, such as Deism and discussions surrounding atheism. Deism, as described by Thomas Paine, is the belief in a Creator God without reliance on the Bible or other miraculous sources. Instead, Deists used personal reason to shape their beliefs, a concept that resonated with many thinkers of that era. Although atheism was a topic of conversation, it had few supporters. Wilson and Reill explain that "very few enlightened intellectuals, even when critical of Christianity, were true atheists. They were more often critics of orthodoxy, leaning instead toward skepticism, deism, vitalism, or pantheism." Some, inspired by Pierre Bayle, argued that atheists could still be moral individuals. However, figures like Voltaire contended that absence of belief in a God who punishes evil would weaken societal moral order. They believed atheists, lacking allegiance to any Supreme Authority or fear of eternal consequences, posed a greater risk to societal stability. Bayle (1647–1706) noted that in his time, "prudent persons will always maintain an appearance of [religion]." He held that even atheists could possess honor and act beyond self-interest for societal interaction. Locke asserted that without God or divine law, moral anarchy would ensue, leading each individual to follow only personal whims, making themselves "a god to himself," with self-satisfaction as the measure and purpose of their actions.
text_ai_humanized: Other religious ideas were floated during the Enlightenment, such as Deism or the idea of atheism. As Thomas Paine put it, Deism entailed “the belief of a God, and only one God,” and did not “believe any thing” that came “ever of the Bible” or of the “other books called sacred and canonical. ” Instead, Deists believed that, with the power of “common reason,” they would form their own convictions, which was a principle many Enlightened thinkers gravitated toward. The idea of atheism was discussed, and few ever held to it. Wilson and Reill state that very few Enlightenment Ideas, even critics of Christianity, were actual atheists, but [rather] critics of orthodoxy were more often skeptics, deists, vitalists or even pantheists… and that some concluded (such as those influenced by Pierre Bayle) that atheists were not necessarily immoral. Others (like Voltaire) argued that if this world did not have a belief in a God that punishes sinners, then we would lose the moral fabric of society. Atheists, after all, were beholden to no Supreme Law or Authority and had no ultimate fear of damnation, so it would pose a threat to social order. Bayle (1647–1706) wrote that in this world, “prudent men will always be seen to observe [their religion]”. Bayle believed that atheists can be honorable and/or motivated by more than selfish necessity when dealing with other members of society. Some others (like Locke) wrote that the lack of God or authority of God’s Law would reduce the world into mere moral chaos, into an “everyone for himself”-type of society, because “everyone would become a god to himself, without any respect for any kind of resppect to anyone else’s authority.” Citing Locke, “Promising and covenanting would be vain, and no concernment unless men were naturally obliged to perform their covenants, they would have no tie nor hold upone them”, and “the taking away of God, though but even in thought, dissolves all, it takes away both the measure and reason of convenience.”

text_human: The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottoman sultan, pâdişâh or "lord of kings", served as the Empire's sole regent and was considered to be the embodiment of its government, though he did not always exercise complete control. The Imperial Harem was one of the most important powers of the Ottoman court. It was ruled by the Valide Sultan. On occasion, the Valide Sultan would become involved in state politics. For a time, the women of the Harem effectively controlled the state in what was termed the "Sultanate of Women". New sultans were always chosen from the sons of the previous sultan. The strong educational system of the palace school was geared towards eliminating the unfit potential heirs, and establishing support among the ruling elite for a successor. The palace schools, which would also educate the future administrators of the state, were not a single track. First, the Madrasa (Ottoman Turkish: Medrese‎) was designated for the Muslims, and educated scholars and state officials according to Islamic tradition. The financial burden of the Medrese was supported by vakifs, allowing children of poor families to move to higher social levels and income. The second track was a free boarding school for the Christians, the Enderûn, which recruited 3,000 students annually from Christian boys between eight and twenty years old from one in forty families among the communities settled in Rumelia or the Balkans, a process known as Devshirme (Devşirme).
text_ai_base: In Islam, the caliphate is the highest position, and since the time of Murad I, the Ottoman sultans claimed this role, establishing the Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottoman sultan, known as the pâdişâh or "lord of kings," was the Empire's sole regent and a symbol of its governance, although he did not always wield absolute power. The Imperial Harem held significant influence within the Ottoman court and was overseen by the Valide Sultan, who sometimes engaged in state politics. During certain periods, women from the Harem effectively governed the state in what became known as the "Sultanate of Women." New sultans were selected from the sons of the preceding sultan. The palace school system was designed to identify capable heirs and to secure support for a successor among the ruling elite. These schools also educated future state administrators and consisted of two tracks. The Madrasa (Ottoman Turkish: Medrese‎) educated Muslim scholars and officials in Islamic tradition, funded by vakifs, enabling children from poor families to rise socially and economically. The second track, the Enderûn, was a free boarding school for Christians, which annually recruited 3,000 Christian boys aged eight to twenty from one in every forty families in Rumelia or the Balkans, a practice known as Devshirme (Devşirme).
text_ai_humanized: The Caliph (in Arabic: خليفة‎, khalīfah, meaning successor) is the highest Islamic title in Islamic polity (see Caliphate), and the Ottoman sultans, starting with Murad I, were its claimants, regarded in later periods as the de facto holders of this title. Thus, the Ottoman state was by contemporaries and is today sometimes referred to as the Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottoman sultan, pâdişâh (sometimes padishah), was the sole regent and was considered the embodiment of the state, although he did not always exercise complete control. The Imperial Harem was one of the most important powers of the Ottoman court. It was ruled by the Valide Sultan. In certain times, the harem was able to rule the state, in a period known as the Sultanate of Women (kadınlar saltanatı). Occasionally, the sultan would be a minor, and a regent would rule instead, often the Valide Sultan, which means mother of the sultan. Sultans were typically chosen from among the sons of the previous sultan. The early organisation of the Ottoman state was propelled by the Beyliks, taking care of most of the administration. The palace school (Enderûn) was based on the devshirme system, a form of meritocracy designed to create the governing class which would support the sultan and keep the ruling elite fresh and capable, although it functioned for practical purposes to gather and to train future administrators and rulers of the Empire. The palace schools had two tracks, called an "inner" service (Enderûn) and an "outer" service (birun). The Madrasa (or medrese in Ottoman Turkish language) was a free Muslim school system intended for the education of the Muslim ulama, which educated scholars and state officials in accordance with the Islamic tradition. The curriculum of the Madrasa was considerably broader than the Enderûn, teaching a variety of subjects ranging from medicine to Islamic theology. There are many Madrases around the world, each usually affiliated with a single mosque. They were financed by vakifs, allowing children of poor families to move to higher social levels and income. The second track was the Enderûn, which was a free boarding school for Christians. 3,000 Christian boys between the ages of eight and 20 were taken from one in 40 families in Rumelia by the Devshirme, (Devşirme).

text_human: In the nineteenth century Burke was praised by both liberals and conservatives. Burke's friend Philip Francis wrote that Burke "was a man who truly & prophetically foresaw all the consequences which would rise from the adoption of the French principles" but because Burke wrote with so much passion, people were doubtful of his arguments. William Windham spoke from the same bench in the House of Commons as Burke had, when he had separated from Fox, and an observer said Windham spoke "like the ghost of Burke" when he made a speech against peace with France in 1801. William Hazlitt, a political opponent of Burke, regarded him as amongst his three favourite writers (the others being Junius and Rousseau), and made it "a test of the sense and candour of any one belonging to the opposite party, whether he allowed Burke to be a great man". William Wordsworth was originally a supporter of the French Revolution and attacked Burke in 'A Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff' (1793), but by the early nineteenth century he had changed his mind and came to admire Burke. In his Two Addresses to the Freeholders of Westmorland Wordsworth called Burke "the most sagacious Politician of his age" whose predictions "time has verified". He later revised his poem The Prelude to include praise of Burke ("Genius of Burke! forgive the pen seduced/By specious wonders") and portrayed him as an old oak. Samuel Taylor Coleridge came to have a similar conversion: he had criticised Burke in The Watchman, but in his Friend (1809–10) Coleridge defended Burke from charges of inconsistency. Later, in his Biographia Literaria (1817) Coleridge hails Burke as a prophet and praises Burke for referring "habitually to principles. He was a scientific statesman; and therefore a seer". Henry Brougham wrote of Burke: "... all his predictions, save one momentary expression, had been more than fulfilled: anarchy and bloodshed had borne sway in France; conquest and convulsion had desolated Europe...the providence of mortals is not often able to penetrate so far as this into futurity". George Canning believed that Burke's Reflections "has been justified by the course of subsequent events; and almost every prophecy has been strictly fulfilled". In 1823 Canning wrote that he took Burke's "last works and words [as] the manual of my politics". The Conservative Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli "was deeply penetrated with the spirit and sentiment of Burke's later writings".

His friend Philip Francis noted that Burke "truly and prophetically foresaw all the consequences that would arise from adopting French principles," yet his passionate writing led some to doubt his arguments. William Windham, speaking from the same bench in the House of Commons as Burke did after his split from Fox, was described by an observer as speaking "like the ghost of Burke" during his 1801 speech against peace with France. Despite being a political adversary, William Hazlitt ranked Burke among his three favorite writers, alongside Junius and Rousseau, and considered it a mark of sense and fairness for someone from the opposing party to recognize Burke's greatness. Initially a supporter of the French Revolution, William Wordsworth attacked Burke in 'A Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff' (1793). However, by the early nineteenth century, Wordsworth had changed his mind and admired Burke. In his Two Addresses to the Freeholders of Westmorland, Wordsworth described Burke as "the most sagacious Politician of his age," noting that time had verified his predictions. Later, Wordsworth revised his poem The Prelude to incorporate praise for Burke ("Genius of Burke! forgive the pen seduced/By specious wonders"), depicting him as an old oak. Similarly, Samuel Taylor Coleridge experienced a transformation in his views; he had criticized Burke in The Watchman, but defended him against charges of inconsistency in The Friend (1809–10). In Biographia Literaria (1817), Coleridge praised Burke as a prophet who "habitually referred to principles," calling him a scientific statesman and thus a visionary. Henry Brougham noted that Burke's predictions had largely been fulfilled, highlighting the chaos and bloodshed in France, as well as the upheaval in Europe. George Canning stated that Burke's Reflections had been validated by subsequent events, with nearly every prophecy fulfilled. In 1823, Canning admitted that he considered Burke's "last works and words [as] the manual of my politics." The Conservative Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli was said to be deeply influenced by the spirit and sentiment of Burke's later writings.

text_human: 6th-century BCE pre-Socratic Greek philosophers Thales of Miletus and Xenophanes of Colophon were the first in the region to attempt to explain the world in terms of human reason rather than myth and tradition, thus can be said to be the first Greek humanists. Thales questioned the notion of anthropomorphic gods and Xenophanes refused to recognise the gods of his time and reserved the divine for the principle of unity in the universe. These Ionian Greeks were the first thinkers to assert that nature is available to be studied separately from the supernatural realm. Anaxagoras brought philosophy and the spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens. Pericles, the leader of Athens during the period of its greatest glory was an admirer of Anaxagoras. Other influential pre-Socratics or rational philosophers include Protagoras (like Anaxagoras a friend of Pericles), known for his famous dictum "man is the measure of all things" and Democritus, who proposed that matter was composed of atoms. Little of the written work of these early philosophers survives and they are known mainly from fragments and quotations in other writers, principally Plato and Aristotle. The historian Thucydides, noted for his scientific and rational approach to history, is also much admired by later humanists. In the 3rd century BCE, Epicurus became known for his concise phrasing of the problem of evil, lack of belief in the afterlife, and human-centred approaches to achieving eudaimonia. He was also the first Greek philosopher to admit women to his school as a rule.
text_ai_base: In the 6th century BCE, pre-Socratic Greek philosophers Thales of Miletus and Xenophanes of Colophon paved the way for explaining the world through human reason rather than through myth and tradition, marking them as the first Greek humanists. Thales questioned the concept of anthropomorphic gods, while Xenophanes rejected the deities of his era, instead attributing divinity to the principle of unity in the universe. These Ionian philosophers pioneered the idea that nature could be studied independently of the supernatural. Anaxagoras transplanted philosophy and a spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens, where he was admired by Pericles, Athens' leader during its golden age. Other notable pre-Socratic philosophers include Protagoras, a friend of Pericles, known for his dictum "man is the measure of all things," and Democritus, who introduced the idea that matter is composed of atoms. Although much of their writings have been lost, these early thinkers are mainly known through fragments and quotations in the works of later philosophers like Plato and Aristotle. The historian Thucydides, renowned for his scientific and rational historical approach, is also highly esteemed by later humanists. In the 3rd century BCE, Epicurus became notable for articulating the problem of evil, his disbelief in an afterlife, and his focus on human-centered methods for achieving eudaimonia. Epicurus was also the first Greek philosopher to regularly admit women into his school.
text_ai_humanized: Thales (c. 624–545 BC) and Xenophanes (c. 570–480 BC) are both credited as first Greek humanists, for turning away from mythological worldviews, and offering cosmological views grounded in humans and their reasoning. Xenophanes was the first Greek who is known to have doubted religion and the anthropomorphic gods. He believed that there was one supreme god. Thales questioned the notion of anthropomorphic gods. These Ionian pre-Socratic philosophers argued that nature, and not the caprices of the gods, governed the cosmos. Anaxagoras brought philosophy and the spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens. He was a close friend of Pericles, who ruled Athens between the Persian and Peloponnesian wars. Other well-known pre-Socratics include Protagoras who coined the phrase "man is the measure of all things" and Democritus who proposed that matter was made up of atoms. The historian Thucydides is also much admired by later humanists. Nearly all of the writings of the pre-Socratics are lost. They are known mainly from fragments and quotations in the writings of later philosophers. In the 3rd century BC, Epicurus, studied atomism and agreed with the Cynics that the gods were unconcerned with human beings. He is known for writing Forthy Principal Doctrines, and for rejected the ideas of an afterlife, and for writing "the problem of evil". He taught No Fear, No Pain. He argued that humans should strive for euidamonia (happiness or wellbeing) through a strong knowledge of the world, and managing desires. His school was the first to regularly admit women.

text_human: Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for the government created by the U.S. Constitution.[citation needed] Under the UK Westminster system, based on parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, Parliament (consisting of the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), House of Lords and House of Commons) was the supreme lawmaking authority. The executive branch acted in the name of the King ("His Majesty's Government"), as did the judiciary. The King's Ministers were in most cases members of one of the two Houses of Parliament, and the Government needed to sustain the support of a majority in the House of Commons. One minister, the Lord Chancellor, was at the same time the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. Therefore, it may be seen that the three branches of British government often violated the strict principle of separation of powers, even though there were many occasions when the different branches of the government disagreed with each other. Some U.S. states did not observe a strict separation of powers in the 18th century. In New Jersey, the Governor also functioned as a member of the state's highest court and as the presiding officer of one house of the New Jersey Legislature. The President of Delaware was a member of the Court of Appeals; the presiding officers of the two houses of the state legislature also served in the executive department as Vice Presidents. In both Delaware and Pennsylvania, members of the executive council served at the same time as judges. On the other hand, many southern states explicitly required separation of powers. Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina and Georgia all kept the branches of government "separate and distinct."
text_ai_base: The United Kingdom did not adhere to a strict separation of powers, although its political structure often served as a model for the U.S. Constitution. The UK operates under the Westminster system, which is characterized by parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government. In this system, Parliament, which includes the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons, is the ultimate lawmaking body. The executive branch and judiciary functioned in the name of the King, referred to as "His Majesty's Government." Most of the King's Ministers were members of either the House of Lords or the House of Commons, and the government needed the support of a majority in the House of Commons. One minister, the Lord Chancellor, simultaneously served as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. As a result, the separation of powers in the British government was often not strictly observed, even though conflicts between different branches did occur. Similarly, some U.S. states in the 18th century did not strictly separate powers. For example, New Jersey's Governor also served on the state's highest court and presided over one house of the legislature. In Delaware, the President was a member of the Court of Appeals, and legislative leaders served in the executive role as Vice Presidents. Delaware and Pennsylvania had executive council members who also served as judges. However, many southern states required a clear separation of powers, with Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia ensuring their branches of government remained "separate and distinct."
text_ai_humanized: United Kingdom[edit] While the United Kingdom political system served as the predominant model for that of the U.S. constitution, the UK had not adopted a strict separation of powers into its own constitution. The United Kingdom had long since developed under an "unwritten constitution", that is to say, the sum of constitutional law as it stood in precedence, convention and statute. The King-in-Parliament had developed into the British Parliament (consisting nominally of the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons), the supreme legislative body within the United Kingdom and many of its colonies.[23] Similarly, the executive power had been extracted from the Crown (King-in-Council) and established as the Cabinet (privy council), and as the government responsible to Parliament. While the sovereign no longer (save in rare instances) presided at Cabinet meetings, the government remained, in its formulation of policy, "His Majesty's Government".[24] Moreover, members of the Cabinet (the King's Ministers) were required to be sitting members of either one of the two Houses of Parliament. Nearly all Ministers were drawn from the Commons rather than the Lords, with the prime minister remaining responsible to the Lower House alone.[25] The judiciary remained equally closely linked to Parliament; the House of Lords served as a court of appeal both domestically, and within the greater British Commonwealth were it was at the top of the hierarchy. The King (or more correctly, the Lord Chancellor) suggested appointment of judges, and in practice was held to consult with the Prime Minister.[26] One such minister who was selected from each Cabinet remained Lord Chancellor, both the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords.[27] Because of these extensive overlapping elements, the British constitution remained only partially separated between branches of government, in many cases not at all; resulting in starkly different lines of accountability and responsibility from those the US constitution developed.[28] Indeed, while conflicts of interest between members were present in other constitutions, such lines were well defined and uncommon within the British political system, and few months would go by without some agitation on the subject.[29] United States states[edit] Various eighteenth century U. S. state constitutions included no, partial, or complete, degrees of separation of powers. For example, the Governor of Delaware was also a member of the Court of Appeals, and the President of Delaware was a member of the Court of Appeals. In addition, Presidents of the Delaware General Assembly served as the state's vice president, while members of the state's Executive Council served as judges. In Pennsylvania, members of the Supreme Executive Council served as judges, and the Council's President served on the Court of Appeals. No state official in Delaware or Pennsylvania was able to exercise veto power, strengthening the legislature's capacity.[30] Of the Southern states, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia all maintained a very strict separation of powers, listing that the branches of government remain "separate and distinct."[31]

text_human: On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé unexpectedly released her eponymous fifth studio album on the iTunes Store without any prior announcement or promotion. The album debuted atop the Billboard 200 chart, giving Beyoncé her fifth consecutive number-one album in the US. This made her the first woman in the chart's history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one. Beyoncé received critical acclaim and commercial success, selling one million digital copies worldwide in six days; The New York Times noted the album's unconventional, unexpected release as significant. Musically an electro-R&B album, it concerns darker themes previously unexplored in her work, such as "bulimia, postnatal depression [and] the fears and insecurities of marriage and motherhood". The single "Drunk in Love", featuring Jay Z, peaked at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. In April 2014, after much speculation in the weeks before, Beyoncé and Jay Z officially announced their On the Run Tour. It served as the couple's first co-headlining stadium tour together. On August 24, 2014, she received the Video Vanguard Award at the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards. Knowles also took home three competitive awards: Best Video with a Social Message and Best Cinematography for "Pretty Hurts", as well as best collaboration for "Drunk in Love". In November, Forbes reported that Beyoncé was the top-earning woman in music for the second year in a row—earning $115 million in the year, more than double her earnings in 2013. Beyoncé was reissued with new material in three forms: as an extended play, a box set, as well as a full platinum edition.

The album immediately topped the Billboard 200 chart, marking Beyoncé's fifth consecutive number-one album in the US and making her the first woman in history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one. The album was met with widespread critical acclaim and commercial success, selling one million digital copies worldwide in just six days. The New York Times highlighted the album’s unconventional release as a significant event. Musically, it is an electro-R&B album exploring darker themes that Beyoncé had not previously addressed, such as bulimia, postnatal depression, and the fears and insecurities of marriage and motherhood. The single "Drunk in Love," featuring Jay Z, reached number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. After weeks of speculation, Beyoncé and Jay Z announced their On the Run Tour in April 2014, their first co-headlining stadium tour. On August 24, 2014, Beyoncé received the Video Vanguard Award at the MTV Video Music Awards and won three additional awards: Best Video with a Social Message and Best Cinematography for "Pretty Hurts," and Best Collaboration for "Drunk in Love." In November, Forbes revealed that Beyoncé was the highest-earning woman in music for the second consecutive year, making $115 million, more than double her earnings in 2013. The album "Beyoncé" was reissued with new material in three formats: an extended play, a box set, and a full platinum edition.

text_human: The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Clashes with the student body started on March 17, when students, aware of the anti-Catholic animosity, blocked the Klansmen from descending from their trains in the South Bend station and ripped the KKK clothes and regalia. On May 19 thousands of students massed downtown protesting the Klavern, and only the arrival of college president Fr. Matthew Walsh prevented any further clashes. The next day, football coach Knute Rockne spoke at a campus rally and implored the students to obey the college president and refrain from further violence. A few days later the Klavern broke up, but the hostility shown by the students was an omen and a contribution to the downfall of the KKK in Indiana.
text_ai_base: Notre Dame gained widespread recognition due to the success of its football team, which reflected the rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics united in support of the team, often listening to games on the radio, particularly when Notre Dame defeated schools representing the Protestant establishment in America, such as Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. However, Notre Dame's role as a leading Catholic institution also made it a target for anti-Catholic sentiment. A notable instance of violence occurred in 1924 when Notre Dame students clashed with the Ku Klux Klan. The KKK, known for promoting nativism and anti-Catholicism, viewed Notre Dame as a symbol of the Catholic Church's perceived threat. During a week-long Klavern in South Bend, tensions peaked on March 17, when students, aware of the Klan's hostile views, prevented Klansmen from disembarking their trains at the South Bend station, tearing apart their clothing and regalia. On May 19, thousands of students gathered downtown to protest the Klavern, and potential conflicts were avoided only by the intervention of college president Fr. Matthew Walsh. The following day, football coach Knute Rockne addressed the campus rally, urging students to follow the president's guidance and cease any violent actions. Shortly thereafter, the Klavern disbanded, but the student opposition foreshadowed and contributed to the KKK's decline in Indiana.

Soon, the Klavern dispersed, but the massive student outpouring showcased the negative view of the Klan in South Bend and undermined KKK's influence in Indiana.[41][42]

text_human: The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife Queen Mary was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, both restoring and adding to it. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the huge low room at the centre of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This room, 69 feet (21 metres) long, previously known as the South Drawing Room, has a ceiling designed specially by Nash, coffered with huge gilt console brackets.
text_ai_base: During King George V's reign, the last significant construction occurred in 1913 when Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to partly mirror Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. The revitalized main façade, crafted from Portland stone, was intended as the backdrop for the Victoria Memorial—a grand statue of Queen Victoria—placed outside the palace's main gates. Upon succeeding Edward VII in 1910, George V, whose personality was more serious compared to his father, shifted the focus from extravagant parties to official engagements and royal responsibilities. He organized a series of command performances featuring jazz artists like the Original Dixieland Jazz Band in 1919—the first jazz act for a head of state—followed by Sidney Bechet and Louis Armstrong in 1932. This led to the palace's nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, highlighting its significant contribution to jazz music in the UK. Queen Mary, George V’s wife, was an art enthusiast who actively engaged with the Royal Collection, restoring and expanding it. She introduced numerous new features, including a pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, originally from 1810, installed in the Bow Room on the ground floor—the large central room on the garden façade. Queen Mary also oversaw the decor of the Blue Drawing Room, which spans 69 feet (21 meters). Previously known as the South Drawing Room, its ceiling features a design by Nash with coffered details and grand gilt console brackets.
text_ai_humanized: The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble, in part, Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire.[8][43] The re-faced principal façade was designed as a backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, the creation of which had been the catalyst for the refacing of the palace, and the refacing was completed in time for the memorial's unveiling on 16 May 1911.[44] During World War I the palace, then the residence of King George V and Queen Mary, escaped unscathed. The King's children, the Princess Mary and the Prince of Wales (later Edward VIII) often visited wounded officers at the palace, with the Queen and her daughter knitting comforts for soldiers serving overseas. King George V, Edward VII's son, was a very different character from his ebullient, sociable father. He was not fond of the palace; his wife, Queen Mary preferred Clarence House. George V's reign saw the palace host the first of three command performances: jazz musicians, notably the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919), the first jazz band to play for a head of state[45] and, later, such jazz musicians as Sidney Bechet (1932) and Louis Armstrong (1932), and its nomination, in 2009, for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival for its services to jazz.[45] refname="kind of blue"/ Queen Mary was interested in the arts[46] and Buckingham Palace became the home of the Royal Collection's greatest treasures and masterpieces. Queen Mary was also an eager and competent curator of her collection.[46] A grande dame issime, she arranged the installation of a collection of miniatures in the new Bow Room on the ground floor (the large central room on the garden façade).[46] The queen also planned and furnished a series of rooms on the second floor at the north end of the palace with chintz fabric and comfortable arm chairs known as "the chintz rooms" and furnished with some of her favourite pieces of art. Another of Queen Mary's additions was the pair of Empire-style marble chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy with carving by Paul Storr from Carlton House in the Bow Room.[47] Also during this period, in the Blue Drawing Room, the tall windows were altered so that they were filled in with mirrors to allow for wall space. Formerly known as the South Drawing Room, redesigned by Nash in time for Queen Victoria's accession. This is one of the most lavishly decorated rooms in the palace and is the first room on the tour of the state rooms. The ceiling is of gilt and white plaster designed by Nash featuring a coffered design with huge gilt console brackets, a central skylight and trompe-l'œil clouds.[48]

text_human: Asian Americans in New York City, according to the 2010 Census, number more than one million, greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. New York contains the highest total Asian population of any U.S. city proper. The New York City borough of Queens is home to the state's largest Asian American population and the largest Andean (Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian) populations in the United States, and is also the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world. The Chinese population constitutes the fastest-growing nationality in New York State; multiple satellites of the original Manhattan Chinatown (紐約華埠), in Brooklyn (布鲁克林華埠), and around Flushing, Queens (法拉盛華埠), are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves, while also expanding rapidly eastward into suburban Nassau County (拿騷縣) on Long Island (長島), as the New York metropolitan region and New York State have become the top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, respectively, and large-scale Chinese immigration continues into New York City and surrounding areas. In 2012, 6.3% of New York City was of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly three-fourths living in either Queens or Brooklyn, geographically on Long Island. A community numbering 20,000 Korean-Chinese (Chaoxianzu (Chinese: 朝鲜族) or Joseonjok (Hangul: 조선족)) is centered in Flushing, Queens, while New York City is also home to the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, also centered in Queens. Koreans made up 1.2% of the city's population, and Japanese 0.3%. Filipinos were the largest Southeast Asian ethnic group at 0.8%, followed by Vietnamese, who made up 0.2% of New York City's population in 2010. Indians are the largest South Asian group, comprising 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and Pakistanis at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Queens is the preferred borough of settlement for Asian Indians, Koreans, and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians and other Southeast Asians; while Brooklyn is receiving large numbers of both West Indian as well as Asian Indian immigrants.

New York City boasts the largest Asian population of any U.S. city. The borough of Queens has the highest Asian American population in the state and hosts the largest Andean populations—Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian—in the U.S. It is also the most ethnically diverse urban area globally. The Chinese are the fastest-growing nationality in New York State, with multiple satellite Chinatowns thriving in Brooklyn and Flushing, Queens, while expanding into suburban Nassau County on Long Island. The New York metropolitan area and New York State are top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, fostering continued large-scale immigration into the city and its surroundings. In 2012, 6.3% of New Yorkers were of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly three-fourths residing in Queens or Brooklyn, which are geographically on Long Island. Flushing, Queens, houses a community of 20,000 Korean-Chinese, while New York City hosts the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, largely centered in Queens. Koreans comprised 1.2% of the city's population, and Japanese 0.3%. Filipinos were the largest Southeast Asian group at 0.8%, followed by Vietnamese at 0.2% in 2010. Indians, the largest South Asian group, made up 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and Pakistanis at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Queens is the preferred borough for Asian Indians, Koreans, and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians and other Southeast Asians. Brooklyn, on the other hand, is attracting increasing numbers of West Indian and Asian Indian immigrants.

Koreatown and Chinatown, Manhattan are also located in New York City. Ganesh Temple Street, in Flushing, Queens, is lined with Indian restaurants.[231] The 1970s and 80s also saw establishment of a large Pakistani community in New York City, primarily in New Queens, where Little Pakistan can be found. New York City is also home to the largest African community outside Africa, and the largest Russian-Jewish community outside Israel, with the major center of both communities being located in Brooklyn. South Asians constitute 3.8% of the city's population and 1.9% of the state's population. Indians are the largest South Asian group, representing 2.4% of the city population (up from 1.6% in 2000) and (tracking from 0.9% in 2000). Bangladeshis and Pakistanis have 0.7% and 0.5% of the city population, respectively. Filipinos are the largest Southeast Asian ethnic group, making up 0.8% of the city population, followed by Vietnamese at 0.2%. Koreans made up 1.2% of the city population, and Japanese 0.3%. New York City's metropolitan area is also home to the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, also centered in Queens.[232] Queens has the majority of Asian Indians, Koreans and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians, and other Southeast Asians; whereas Brooklyn and growing numbers continue to move into the area as well as Indians. In 2012, 6.3% of New York was of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly 3/4 of them living in either Queens or Brooklyn, geographically on Long Island. Flushing, Queens, is also home to a large community of 20,000 Korean Chinese,[233] or Joseonjok. The New York metropolitan region is also home to the largest number of overseas Chinese outside of Asia, combining for a population of over 800,000 as of 2013.[234] Continuing significant immigration from Mainland China, both legal and illegal in origin,[235] is adding to the Chinese American population in the area. The Chinese population in New York City is the highest of any city proper, other than the four cities of Greater China (Beijing, Hong Kong, Shanghai and Taipei).

text_human: The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez. The early a cappella polyphonies may have had an accompanying instrument, although this instrument would merely double the singers' parts and was not independent. By the 16th century, a cappella polyphony had further developed, but gradually, the cantata began to take the place of a cappella forms. 16th century a cappella polyphony, nonetheless, continued to influence church composers throughout this period and to the present day. Recent evidence has shown that some of the early pieces by Palestrina, such as what was written for the Sistine Chapel was intended to be accompanied by an organ "doubling" some or all of the voices. Such is seen in the life of Palestrina becoming a major influence on Bach, most notably in the aforementioned Mass in B Minor. Other composers that utilized the a cappella style, if only for the occasional piece, were Claudio Monteverdi and his masterpiece, Lagrime d'amante al sepolcro dell'amata (A lover's tears at his beloved's grave), which was composed in 1610, and Andrea Gabrieli when upon his death it was discovered many choral pieces, one of which was in the unaccompanied style. Learning from the preceding two composeres, Heinrich Schütz utilized the a cappella style in numerous pieces, chief among these were the pieces in the oratorio style, which were traditionally performed during the Easter week and dealt with the religious subject matter of that week, such as Christ's suffering and the Passion. Five of Schutz's Historien were Easter pieces, and of these the latter three, which dealt with the passion from three different viewpoints, those of Matthew, Luke and John, were all done a cappella style. This was a near requirement for this type of piece, and the parts of the crowd were sung while the solo parts which were the quoted parts from either Christ or the authors were performed in a plainchant.
text_ai_base: The development of Christian a cappella music in Europe began around the late 15th century with compositions by Josquin des Prez. Early polyphonic works sometimes included instrumental accompaniment, but instruments merely duplicated the singers' parts rather than acting independently. By the 16th century, a cappella polyphony had evolved significantly, although the cantata gradually began to replace it in popularity. Despite this shift, 16th-century a cappella polyphony continued to influence church composers both during and beyond that period. Recent evidence suggests that some of Palestrina's early works, such as those written for the Sistine Chapel, were meant to be accompanied by an organ that "doubled" some or all of the voices. Palestrina greatly influenced Bach, particularly in his Mass in B Minor. Other composers who occasionally employed the a cappella style include Claudio Monteverdi, known for his 1610 masterpiece "Lagrime d'amante al sepolcro dell'amata" ("A Lover's Tears at His Beloved's Grave"), and Andrea Gabrieli, whose unaccompanied choral works were discovered posthumously. Influenced by these predecessors, Heinrich Schütz used the a cappella style in many of his compositions, especially those in the oratorio style, which were traditionally performed during Easter week. These works often focused on religious themes, such as Christ's suffering and the Passion. Among Schütz's five "Historien" pieces for Easter, the final three—depicting the Passion from Matthew, Luke, and John—were performed a cappella. This style was almost essential for such compositions, where crowd parts were sung and solo parts, often representing Christ or the Gospel authors, were delivered in plainchant.
text_ai_humanized: The European a cappella tradition, which was developing at the same time, originated with the Gregorian chant, though a capeella became popular when it was developed, evolving into the polyphony of Josquin des Prez near the end of the 15th century. Early polyphony was often sung with instrumental accompaniment; however, the instruments did not partake in the music, but rather duplicated the notes being sung by the singers. By the early 16th century, a cappella polyphony had grown to a high degree of complexity, in turn soon to be replaced in popularity by the cantata. Nevertheless, the 16th century a capella polyphony itself drawn upon, was a persistent influence in church composers beyond the 16th, remaining so during the 16th. It has recently been found that part or all of Palestrina's works, such as his early compositions done for the Sistine Chapel, were intended to be performed with an organ, which would "double" some or all the voices. Palestrina served as a strong influence on Bach, particularly on his Mass in B Minor. Other composers, who used the a cappella style at least occasionally throughout the 16th and 17th centuries, were Claudio Monteverdi, (his "Largimea D’amante Al Sepolcro Dell’Amata" (A Lover’s Tears at His Beloved’s Grave) from the "Madrigali," (Madri Gali) from 1610); and Andrea Gabrieli, whose a cappella choral music was found and published after his death. Heinrich Schütz, drawing upon these influences, composed a number of pieces in the a cappella style, and particularly the works he composed in the style of the oratorio. These pieces, at the time mostly limited to Easter week, when oratorios would traditionally be performed, were often centered upon Christ’s suffering and the history of the Passion. Of the five "Historien" that Schütz wrote for Easter, the last three were the Passion, according to Matthew, Luke, and John, all composed and performed a cappella. The style of writing was almost at the time required for such music, with the crowd parts being sung, and the solos, usually to be Christ, though also the Evangelists, the writers of the Gospels, often switching roles, being in plainchant.

text_human: Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races". They find that the figure of 85% is misleading because it implies that all human populations contain on average 85% of all genetic diversity. They claim that this does not correctly reflect human population history, because it treats all human groups as independent. A more realistic portrayal of the way human groups are related is to understand that some human groups are parental to other groups and that these groups represent paraphyletic groups to their descent groups. For example, under the recent African origin theory the human population in Africa is paraphyletic to all other human groups because it represents the ancestral group from which all non-African populations derive, but more than that, non-African groups only derive from a small non-representative sample of this African population. This means that all non-African groups are more closely related to each other and to some African groups (probably east Africans) than they are to others, and further that the migration out of Africa represented a genetic bottleneck, with much of the diversity that existed in Africa not being carried out of Africa by the emigrating groups. This view produces a version of human population movements that do not result in all human populations being independent; but rather, produces a series of dilutions of diversity the further from Africa any population lives, each founding event representing a genetic subset of its parental population. Long and Kittles find that rather than 85% of human genetic diversity existing in all human populations, about 100% of human diversity exists in a single African population, whereas only about 70% of human genetic diversity exists in a population derived from New Guinea. Long and Kittles argued that this still produces a global human population that is genetically homogeneous compared to other mammalian populations.
text_ai_base: In their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles critically examine the use of FST in assessing human populations. They argue that the commonly cited figure of 85% is misleading, as it suggests that each human group contains, on average, 85% of the global genetic diversity. This perspective inaccurately represents human population history by treating all groups as independent entities. A more accurate depiction recognizes that some groups are ancestral to others, illustrating a paraphyletic relationship with their descendant groups. According to the recent African origin theory, the African population is paraphyletic to all non-African groups, serving as the ancestral source from which non-Africans emerge. Importantly, non-African populations arose from a small, non-representative subset of the African population. Consequently, non-African groups share a closer genetic relationship with each other and certain African groups (likely East Africans) than with other African populations. This migration out of Africa resulted in a genetic bottleneck, leaving much of the original African diversity behind. This interpretation of human population movements suggests that rather than being independent, human groups experienced a dilution of genetic diversity the farther they moved from Africa. Each migration event represented a genetic subset of its original population. Long and Kittles found that, rather than 85%, a single African population holds almost all human genetic diversity, while a population from New Guinea retains only about 70%. Despite this, Long and Kittles conclude that globally, human populations are genetically homogeneous when compared to other mammalian populations.
text_ai_humanized: Anthropologists Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles address the problem of FST in their 2003 article Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races. They note that, By far the most common misstatement of the 85% figure is a sentence of the form it has been shown that, on average, each human group contains 85% of all human genetic diversity. The historical aspects of a global population are often portrayed as each group acting independently of the others. But the conclusions of the recent African origin model shows that it is more accurate to say that some groups are paraphyletic with respect to others. The African population would be paraphyletic with respect to all other non-African groups, as non-Africans are derived from this ancestral African population. Non-African groups split off from African ones not by taking a representative slice of the African population. Instead, these non-African groups were the result of reproduction in only part of the population that crossed the geographical barrier out of Africa to form their own populations. As a result, non-African populations are closer to each other (and to at least one African group, presumably eastern Africans) than they are to other African populations. This shows that when humans moved out of Africa, they left the bulk of African diversity behind. This interpretation of geographical movement among human populations points away from independent human groups, to a dilution of diversity courses from the locations furthest away from Africa, with each movement resulting in a representative sample of the previous population. Instead of 85%, Long and Kittles found that nearly 100% of human genetic diversity is in a single African population, while only 70% is found within one taken from New Guinea. Yet even with these statistics, Long and Kittles still conclude that, relative to other mammalian populations, human ones are globally homogenous.
