text_human: Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to the anti-stress complex, with an oxytocin-attachment system, which plays a major role in bonding. Emotional phenotype temperaments affect social connectedness and fitness in complex social systems (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These characteristics are shared with other species and taxa and are due to the effects of genes and their continuous transmission. Information that is encoded in the DNA sequences provides the blueprint for assembling proteins that make up our cells. Zygotes require genetic information from their parental germ cells, and at every speciation event, heritable traits that have enabled its ancestor to survive and reproduce successfully are passed down along with new traits that could be potentially beneficial to the offspring. In the five million years since the linages leading to modern humans and chimpanzees split, only about 1.2% of their genetic material has been modified. This suggests that everything that separates us from chimpanzees must be encoded in that very small amount of DNA, including our behaviors. Students that study animal behaviors have only identified intraspecific examples of gene-dependent behavioral phenotypes. In voles (Microtus spp.) minor genetic differences have been identified in a vasopressin receptor gene that corresponds to major species differences in social organization and the mating system (Hammock & Young 2005). Another potential example with behavioral differences is the FOCP2 gene, which is involved in neural circuitry handling speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). Its present form in humans differed from that of the chimpanzees by only a few mutations and has been present for about 200,000 years, coinciding with the beginning of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization are all part of the basis for emotions.

Another example is the FOCP2 gene, which affects neural circuits related to speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). This gene's form in humans, which has only slightly mutated from its chimpanzee version, has been around for approximately 200,000 years, aligning with the emergence of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization underlie emotional expression.

text_human: In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. An early multi-record release was in 1903, when HMV in England made the first complete recording of an opera, Verdi's Ernani, on 40 single-sided discs. In 1940, Commodore released Eddie Condon and his Band's recording of "A Good Man Is Hard to Find" in four parts, issued on both sides of two 12-inch 78s. This limitation on the duration of recordings persisted from 1910 until the invention of the LP record, in 1948. In popular music, this time limitation of about 3:30 on a 10-inch 78 rpm record meant that singers usually did not release long pieces on record. One exception is Frank Sinatra's recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Soliloquy", from Carousel, made on May 28, 1946. Because it ran 7:57, longer than both sides of a standard 78 rpm 10-inch record, it was released on Columbia's Masterwork label (the classical division) as two sides of a 12-inch record. The same was true of John Raitt's performance of the song on the original cast album of Carousel, which had been issued on a 78-rpm album set by American Decca in 1945.

Another way to overcome time constraints was by splitting a song across both sides of a record. Similarly, John Raitt's rendition of the song on Carousel's original cast album was part of a 78-rpm album set by American Decca in 1945.
text_ai_humanized: Gabler started recording for his own new label, Commodore Records, in January 1938 and used 12-inch records to allow for longer performances.[2] Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room. Then, too, he put the music on twelve-inch records because the standard ten-inch variety wasn't long enough for what we had in mind."[3] The first two 12-inch recordings released by Commodore, "Carnegie Drag" and "Carnegie Jump", were only 3:15 and 2:41 in length, respectively, but Commodore's continuing releases would more often stretch out closer to (or over) the four-minute mark. (Carnegie Hall had strict rules banning dancing, so the musicians gave the titles different names in honor of The Hall.) Other examples were "Embraceable You" (4:05) and "Serenade to a Shylock" (4:32). An obvious way to get around the time limitation was to issue a song over two sides of a single record. As early as 1922, vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean released their "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean"—written by Irving and Jack Kaufman—as an A side and a B side that ran a total of 5:22 for the duo, issued on Cameo, which split both sides of the record into part 1 and part 2. An obvious solution for longer items was to release a "set" of several records. HMV in England produced an album with a complete recording of Verdi's opera Ernani in 1903. It used 40 single sided discs. In 1940, Commodore released a multi-part version of Eddie Condon and his Band's "A Good Man Is Hard to Find", with four "parts", one part per side, issued on both sides of two 12-inch 78s. Until the invention of the LP (Long Play) record in 1948, the typical record available to the public was a 10-inch type running no longer than about 3:30 or a 10-inch running no longer than 4:30; a long song might require listeners to change records in the middle of the song or piece. This may be one reason that many songs recorded before 1948 are about three minutes in length. One exception is Frank Sinatra's recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Soliloquy", from Carousel, made on 28 May 1946. Because the song runs 7:57, longer than both sides of a standard 78-rpm record, it had to be divided into two parts, one on each side of the disc. The record was released in July 1946[4] as part of an album set by Columbia Records. The song would not fit on just one side of a 10-inch 78-rpm record, so a two sided disc was used, a relatively unusual occurrence in the recording industry. "An entire book could be written about soliloquies on records. In order to get them all in, you'd need to use the large economy size."[5] (Ironically, this technically made the recording Sinatra's only classical album released during his lifetime, because the record was issued on Columbia's Masterwork label, the company's classical division.) John Raitt's performance of the song on the original cast album of Carousel is not divided, as it would have been if it had been issued on a commercial single; the cast album was issued in 1945 as a set of 78-rpm records by American Decca.

text_human: The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a fertile floodplain around Nordhausen with the Helme as most important river. The north-west includes the Eichsfeld, a hilly and sometimes forested region, where the Leine river emanates. The central and northern part of Thuringia is defined by the 3000 km² wide Thuringian Basin, a very fertile and flat area around the Unstrut river and completely surrounded by the following hill chains (clockwise from the north-west): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge and Hainich. Within the Basin the smaller hill chains Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Thuringian Basin is the Land's largest mountain range, marked by the Thuringian Forest in the north-west, the Thuringian Highland in the middle and the Franconian Forest in the south-east. Most of this range is forested and the Großer Beerberg (983 m) is Thuringia's highest mountain. To the south-west, the Forest is followed up by Werra river valley, dividing it from the Rhön Mountains in the west and the Grabfeld plain in the south. Eastern Thuringia, commonly described as the area east of Saale and Loquitz valley, is marked by a hilly landscape, rising slowly from the flat north to the mountainous south. The Saale in the west and the Weiße Elster in the east are the two big rivers running from south to north and forming densely settled valleys in this area. Between them lies the flat and forested Holzland in the north, the flat and fertile Orlasenke in the middle and the Vogtland, a hilly but in most parts non-forested region in the south. The far eastern region (east of Weiße Elster) is the Osterland or Altenburger Land along Pleiße river, a flat, fertile and densely settled agricultural area.
text_ai_base: Thuringia boasts a remarkably diverse landscape. In the far north, the region is characterized by the Harz Mountains, giving way to the Goldene Aue—a fertile floodplain enveloping Nordhausen, with the Helme River being its most significant waterway. To the northwest lies the Eichsfeld, a hilly and partially forested area where the Leine River originates. The central and northern parts of Thuringia are dominated by the expansive 3,000 km² Thuringian Basin, known for its flat, fertile land surrounding the Unstrut River. This basin is encircled by hill chains (clockwise from the northwest): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich. Inside the basin, you'll find smaller hill chains like Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Thuringian Basin lies the state's largest mountain range, featuring the Thuringian Forest in the northwest, the Thuringian Highland in the center, and the Franconian Forest to the southeast. This mostly forested range includes Thuringia's highest peak, the Großer Beerberg (983 meters). To the southwest, the Werra River Valley separates the Forest from the Rhön Mountains to the west and the Grabfeld plain to the south. Eastern Thuringia, typically defined as the area east of the Saale and Loquitz valleys, features a landscape that gradually transitions from flat in the north to mountainous in the south. The Saale to the west and the Weiße Elster to the east are the area’s major rivers, flowing from south to north through densely populated valleys. Between these rivers lies the Holzland, a flat and forested region in the north; the Orlasenke, a flat and fertile area in the center; and the Vogtland, a hilly and mostly unwooded region in the south. The far eastern part (east of the Weiße Elster) is known as the Osterland or Altenburger Land, a flat, fertile, and densely populated agricultural area along the Pleiße River.
text_ai_humanized: Thuringia is divided into a number of traditional landscapes, from north to south: In the extreme north lies the Harz mountains with the area of the Goldene Aue (floodplain around Nordhausen) in the south and the region of Eichsfeld in the west. It is a hilly, partially forested region where the Leine river rises. Another mountain chain is in the northwest, the Hainleite with Schmücke and Hohe Schrecke, part of the northern rim of the Thuringian Basin. The central and the northern part of Thuringia is defined by the 3,000 km2 (1,200 sq mi) flat and fertile Thuringian Basin around the Unstrut river, surrounded by various hill chains, called Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge and Hainich. Within the Basin, the Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhe are prominent hill chains. South of the Thuringian Basin follows the Thuringian Forest, the biggest mountain range of Thuringia with a highly forested part in the northwest, called Thuringian Forest, a less forested part in the middle, called Thuringian Highland and a plateau in the southeast, called Franconian Forest. This range has an average altitude around 800 m and also the highest mountain in Thuringia – Großer Beerberg with an altitude of 983 m. To the southwest, the Thuringian Forest leads into the Werra valley, followed by the Rhön Mountains on the western border with Hesse and the Grabfeld plain on the border with Bavaria. Eastern Thuringia south of the Harz mountains and east of the Thuringian Basin is an area which is described as flat to hilly but increasingly hilly and mountainous from north to south and from west to east. The two main rivers in the area are the Saale (west) and the Weiße Elster (east), both flow in a northwards direction in the densely populated valleys. Between the rivers, the Holzland in the north is a flat, forested region, followed by the flat and fertile Orlasenke, the hilly and unwooded region of the Vogtland in the south. The far east of Thuringia east of the White Elster is known as Osterland, sometimes further differentiated into the Altenburger Land and the Ronneburger Aue, a flat, fertile and densely populated agricultural area. The Pleiße is the main river of the region.

text_human: Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") is the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River region in China, which has long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. It is the capital city of Jiangsu province of People's Republic of China and the second largest city in East China, with a total population of 8,216,100, and legally the capital of Republic of China which lost the mainland during the civil war. The city whose name means "Southern Capital" has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capitals of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century AD to 1949. Prior to the advent of pinyin romanization, Nanjing's city name was spelled as Nanking or Nankin. Nanjing has a number of other names, and some historical names are now used as names of districts of the city, and among them there is the name Jiangning (江寧), whose former character Jiang (江, River) is the former part of the name Jiangsu and latter character Ning (寧, simplified form 宁, Peace) is the short name of Nanjing. When being the capital of a state, for instance, ROC, Jing (京) is adopted as the abbreviation of Nanjing. Although as a city located in southern part of China becoming Chinese national capital as early as in Jin dynasty, the name Nanjing was designated to the city in Ming dynasty, about a thousand years later. Nanjing is particularly known as Jinling (金陵, literally meaning Gold Mountain) and the old name has been used since the Warring States Period in Zhou Dynasty.
text_ai_base: Nanjing (listen; Chinese: 南京, meaning "Southern Capital") is a city located in the heartland of the lower Yangtze River region in China. It has long been a significant hub for culture, education, research, politics, economy, transportation, and tourism. As the capital city of Jiangsu province in the People's Republic of China, it is the second largest city in East China, with a population of 8,216,100. Historically, it was the legal capital of the Republic of China, which lost control of the mainland during the civil war. The name "Southern Capital" underscores Nanjing's rich historical and cultural significance, having served as the capital for various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms, and republican governments from the 3rd century AD until 1949. Before the introduction of pinyin romanization, Nanjing was spelled as Nanking or Nankin. The city also has other historical names, some of which are now used as district names, including Jiangning (江寧). Its character 'Jiang' (江, River) is part of the name Jiangsu, while 'Ning' (寧, Peace) is an abbreviated form of Nanjing. When serving as the capital city, such as for the ROC, Nanjing is abbreviated as Jing (京). Although the city became China's national capital as early as the Jin dynasty, the name Nanjing was officially given during the Ming dynasty, roughly a thousand years later. Nanjing is also famously known by its ancient name Jinling (金陵, meaning Gold Mountain), which dates back to the Warring States Period in the Zhou Dynasty.
text_ai_humanized: Nanjing (listen; Chinese: 南京, Mandarin pronunciation: [nǎn.tɕíŋ] (About this soundlisten)), historically also known as Nanking (pronounced /ˈnænˈdʒɪŋ/;[5][6] Chinese: 南京) and Nankin,[7] is the capital of Jiangsu province of the People's Republic of China and the second largest city in the East China region,[8] with an administrative area of 6,600 km2 (2,500 sq mi) and a total population of 8,216,100 as of 2018. The inner area of Nanjing enclosed by the city wall is Nanjing City (南京城), with an area of 55 km2 (21 sq mi), while the Nanjing Metropolitan Region includes surrounding cities and areas, covering over 60,000 km2 (23,000 sq mi), with a population of over 30 million.[citation needed] Situated in the Yangtze River Delta region, Nanjing has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capital of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century to 1949,[9] and has thus long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. Nanjing has been ranked seventh in the evaluation of "Cities with Strongest Comprehensive Strength" issued by the National Statistics Bureau, and second in the evaluation of cities with most sustainable development potential in the Yangtze River Delta. Nanjing has also been awarded the title of 2008 Habitat Scroll of Honour of China, Special UN Habitat Scroll of Honour Award and National Civilized City.

text_human: In the United States, macabre-rock pioneer Alice Cooper achieved mainstream success with the top ten album School's Out (1972). In the following year blues rockers ZZ Top released their classic album Tres Hombres and Aerosmith produced their eponymous début, as did Southern rockers Lynyrd Skynyrd and proto-punk outfit New York Dolls, demonstrating the diverse directions being pursued in the genre. Montrose, including the instrumental talent of Ronnie Montrose and vocals of Sammy Hagar and arguably the first all American hard rock band to challenge the British dominance of the genre, released their first album in 1973. Kiss built on the theatrics of Alice Cooper and the look of the New York Dolls to produce a unique band persona, achieving their commercial breakthrough with the double live album Alive! in 1975 and helping to take hard rock into the stadium rock era. In the mid-1970s Aerosmith achieved their commercial and artistic breakthrough with Toys in the Attic (1975), which reached number 11 in the American album chart, and Rocks (1976), which peaked at number three. Blue Öyster Cult, formed in the late 60s, picked up on some of the elements introduced by Black Sabbath with their breakthrough live gold album On Your Feet or on Your Knees (1975), followed by their first platinum album, Agents of Fortune (1976), containing the hit single "(Don't Fear) The Reaper", which reached number 12 on the Billboard charts. Journey released their eponymous debut in 1975 and the next year Boston released their highly successful début album. In the same year, hard rock bands featuring women saw commercial success as Heart released Dreamboat Annie and The Runaways débuted with their self-titled album. While Heart had a more folk-oriented hard rock sound, the Runaways leaned more towards a mix of punk-influenced music and hard rock. The Amboy Dukes, having emerged from the Detroit garage rock scene and most famous for their Top 20 psychedelic hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" (1968), were dissolved by their guitarist Ted Nugent, who embarked on a solo career that resulted in four successive multi-platinum albums between Ted Nugent (1975) and his best selling Double Live Gonzo (1978).
text_ai_base: Alice Cooper, a pioneer of macabre rock in the United States, gained mainstream popularity with his top ten album "School's Out" in 1972. The following year saw notable releases across various rock genres. Blues rockers ZZ Top unveiled their classic album "Tres Hombres," while Aerosmith, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and the New York Dolls launched their debut albums, showcasing the genre's diversity. 1973 marked the arrival of Montrose, featuring Ronnie Montrose and Sammy Hagar, as a formidable American hard rock band poised to challenge British dominance. Kiss built upon the theatrical style of Alice Cooper and the aesthetics of the New York Dolls, crafting a unique persona and achieving commercial success with their live album "Alive!" in 1975, ushering hard rock into the stadium rock era. By the mid-1970s, Aerosmith solidified their standing with "Toys in the Attic" (1975) and "Rocks" (1976), reaching notable chart positions of 11 and 3 respectively. Blue Öyster Cult, formed in the late '60s, echoed Black Sabbath's influence with their breakthrough gold album "On Your Feet or on Your Knees" (1975), followed by the platinum success of "Agents of Fortune" (1976), featuring the hit "(Don't Fear) The Reaper," which climbed to number 12 on the Billboard charts. Journey's debut in 1975 set the stage for Boston's successful first album the next year. That same year, hard rock bands with female members gained traction as Heart released "Dreamboat Annie" while The Runaways debuted their self-titled album. While Heart leaned towards a folk-inflected hard rock sound, The Runaways blended punk influences with hard rock. Ted Nugent dissolved The Amboy Dukes, known for their psychedelic hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" (1968), to pursue a solo career resulting in four consecutive multi-platinum albums from "Ted Nugent" (1975) to "Double Live Gonzo" (1978).
text_ai_humanized: In 1972, shock-rock pioneer Alice Cooper, who had been a leader of a number of U.S. proto-heavy metal bands, reached number 1 in the Hot 100 with "School's Out" and number 2 on the album chart with the LP of the same name. In 1973, ZZ Top released their classic hard-rocking blues album Tres Hombres, Aerosmith released their eponymous debut album, Lynyrd Skynyrd released their debut, pronounced léh-’nérd ‘skin-’nérd, and the New York Dolls released their self-titled first album. In 1973, another important act emerged in the form of Queen. Queen was one of the only bands in history to successfully blend progressive rock, heavy metal and even opera into a unique sound. With the release of their breakthrough album Sheer Heart Attack, Queen created a new form of hard rock, with a wide variety of musical influences and an almost unclassifiable sound. With their next releases, A Night at the Opera (containing the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody") and A Day at the Races, the band continued to push the limits of creativity. In 1973, Montrose, featuring Ronnie Montrose and Sammy Hagar, debuted with their self-titled album for Warner Bros; the band proved an influential American counterpart to Led Zeppelin and other BR/HM bands. Kiss formed in 1973 out of the ashes of the proto-glam band Wicked Lester. Drawing on the theatrical forerunners Alice Cooper and the New York Dolls (whose style was strongly influenced by glam rock), the band developed an even more complex shock rock style. Their hype-filled approach and the use of face paint and stage outfits, which mimicked various comic book characters, brought the band national notoriety. Derided as a "fad" by critics at the time, the band proved influential both in the short (through the adoption of the makeup and stage persona by bands such as Gwar and Slipknot) and medium term: their biggest hits, "Rock and Roll All Nite", "Shout It Out Loud" and "Detroit Rock City", helped make hard rock the most commercially successful genre of the decade and defined the sound of stadium rock. Their 1975 release Alive! (number 9, 1975) was the first of a series of top 10 selling albums that continued until 1979's compilation Greatest KISS Hits. In the mid-1970s, Aerosmith released a string of multi-platinum albums starting with Toys in the Attic (number 11, 1975) and continuing with Rocks (number 3, 1976). Blue Öyster Cult[7] (formed in 1967 as Soft White Underbelly) became popular in 1975 with the gold album On Your Feet or on Your Knees (number 22, 1975), in a similar vein to Black Sabbath both musically and in darkly themed stage shows. The release of the platinum-selling Agents of Fortune (number 29, 1976) and its single "Don't Fear) The Reaper" (number 12), (the latter promoted by an innovative video on the new medium of television), led to increased American exposure for hard rock acts in the growing arena and stadium rock scenes. Other American hard rock bands formed or rose to prominence in the mid-1970s included Journey (debut in 1975) and Boston (with their hit debut in 1976). 1976 was also notable for the appearance of hard rock bands with female members: the all-female The Runaways released their eponymous debut and Heart released their debut Dreamboat Annie. Whereas Heart displayed a hybrid of folk and hard rock born of roots in acoustic music, The Runaways mix of punk and hard rock made them more successful in the UK than at home. Ted Nugent, formerly of the Amboy Dukes (best known for the hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" in 1968), began a solo career with the release of Ted Nugent in 1975 which sold over a million copies, followed by four multi-platinum albums through 1978's Double Live Gonzo! .

text_human: It was the pub that first introduced the concept of the bar counter being used to serve the beer. Until that time beer establishments used to bring the beer out to the table or benches, as remains the practice in (for example) beer gardens and other drinking establishments in Germany. A bar might be provided for the manager to do paperwork while keeping an eye on his or her customers, but the casks of ale were kept in a separate taproom. When the first pubs were built, the main room was the public room with a large serving bar copied from the gin houses, the idea being to serve the maximum number of people in the shortest possible time. It became known as the public bar[citation needed]. The other, more private, rooms had no serving bar—they had the beer brought to them from the public bar. There are a number of pubs in the Midlands or the North which still retain this set up but these days the beer is fetched by the customer from the taproom or public bar. One of these is The Vine, known locally as The Bull and Bladder, in Brierley Hill near Birmingham, another the Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire a series of small rooms served drinks and food by waiting staff. In the Manchester district the public bar was known as the "vault", other rooms being the lounge and snug as usual elsewhere. By the early 1970s there was a tendency to change to one large drinking room and breweries were eager to invest in interior design and theming.
text_ai_base: The concept of using a bar counter to serve beer was first popularized by pubs. Before this innovation, beer was typically delivered to tables or benches, a practice still seen in beer gardens and other drinking spots in Germany. Bars existed primarily for managers to do paperwork while overseeing customers, with the ale casks stored in a separate taproom. Early pubs featured a main space known as the public room, which had a large serving bar inspired by gin houses to serve many customers quickly. This area came to be called the public bar[citation needed]. More private rooms lacked serving bars, with beer being brought in from the public bar instead. Some pubs in the Midlands or North, such as The Vine—known locally as The Bull and Bladder—in Brierley Hill near Birmingham, and The Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire, still retain this setup, though now customers fetch beer themselves from the taproom or public bar. In Manchester, the public bar was referred to as the "vault," while other areas were called the lounge and snug, as was common elsewhere. By the early 1970s, a shift toward larger, single drinking rooms began, with breweries keen to invest in interior design and themed environments.
text_ai_humanized: Pubs introduced the idea of a bar for serving beer. (Beer was most commonly served at the table or benches, as is still done in beer gardens and some other drinking establishments, such as in German[disambiguation needed] beer halls; nearly all drinking establishments in the United Kingdom serving beer from casks or tanks still have a bar-like area for ordering and serving, although those that cannot offer additional seating require drinkers to return to their table to consume.) Bars were until the early 19th century uncommon; liquor might be stored in a separate room or even a separate establishment; the "bar" was a place for the manager to do paperwork. In early pubs beer was served out of tapped casks, or drawn from them into pitchers or jugs brought to the table or bench; the room (usually the only room) in the pub was called the public room. Later, it became necessary to have a room with a large bar to serve beer to many customers quickly, inspired by the gin houses. This room evolved into the public bar. Other, more private rooms were the saloon bar (or lounge bar) and the snug, where beer was normally brought to the room from the public bar. In some cases the "snugs" were separated by a partition with access to the bar. Many midlands or northern pubs, such as the Vine, known by locals colloquially as the Bull and Bladder, in Brierley Hill, near Birmingham, or the Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire, retain this three-room layout. In some cases, mainly in the Midlands, they have no actual bar as such, and beer is fetched by the customer direct from the taproom or, in the Midlands, the outdoor or "jug and bottle" as it was always known when I lived in mid-Staffordshire). In the city of Manchester the name of the public bar was the "vault", other areas of the pub being the lounge and snug. Until the early 1970s, the idea of separate rooms for drinks came into vogue. A move towards one large drinking room became commonplace, with the breweries being eager to invest in interior design and theming.

text_human: Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewers’ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event – those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.
text_ai_base: Many people believe that memory works like recording equipment, but this is not accurate. The molecular processes involved in forming and maintaining memories are highly dynamic, comprising distinct phases that can last from seconds to a lifetime. Research shows that our memories are constructed, both during encoding and recall. A classic study by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) serves as an example. Participants watched a film of a traffic accident and were later questioned about what they saw. Those asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" provided higher speed estimates than those asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Additionally, a week later, those questioned with "smashed" were twice as likely to report seeing broken glass compared to those asked with "hit." There was actually no broken glass in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions altered their memory of the event, leading to the construction of different memories—those questioned with "smashed" recalled a more serious accident. This effect has been replicated globally, and studies consistently show that misleading information can lead to misremembering, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.
text_ai_humanized: Myth #1: Memory is like recording or play-back device. Reality: Memory’s molecular underpinnings are a vibrant and dynamic process, with distinct phases that can vary between seconds and years. According to evidence, we construct our memories, both when we remember and when we retrieve them. How do we know? Here’s but one example. Loftus and Palmer (1974) showed a group of students clips of traffic accidents and then tested their memory of these clips by asking them questions about it. When asked “How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?” participants gave faster speed estimates than when they were asked “How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?” Participants who were asked with “smashed” were more than twice as likely to recall seeing broken glass a week later, compared with participants who were asked with “hit.” (In reality, there was no broken glass in the film.) So by asking them “how fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other,” the experimenters changed what participants remembered about that accident. Specifically, their question constructed a memory of an accident more serious than that which was actually viewed. This experiment has been repeated in over twenty countries, and the results are always the same. This experiment shows the misinformation effect: we seem to mis-remember things when we are given misleading information about those events.

text_human: On 23 April 2014, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a faster track to send content, thus reversing their earlier net neutrality position. A possible solution to net neutrality concerns may be municipal broadband, according to Professor Susan Crawford, a legal and technology expert at Harvard Law School. On 15 May 2014, the FCC decided to consider two options regarding Internet services: first, permit fast and slow broadband lanes, thereby compromising net neutrality; and second, reclassify broadband as a telecommunication service, thereby preserving net neutrality. On 10 November 2014, President Barack Obama recommended that the FCC reclassify broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service in order to preserve net neutrality. On 16 January 2015, Republicans presented legislation, in the form of a U.S. Congress H.R. discussion draft bill, that makes concessions to net neutrality but prohibits the FCC from accomplishing the goal or enacting any further regulation affecting Internet service providers. On 31 January 2015, AP News reported that the FCC will present the notion of applying ("with some caveats") Title II (common carrier) of the Communications Act of 1934 to the internet in a vote expected on 26 February 2015. Adoption of this notion would reclassify internet service from one of information to one of the telecommunications and, according to Tom Wheeler, chairman of the FCC, ensure net neutrality. The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality in its vote, according to the New York Times.
text_ai_base: On April 23, 2014, the U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) was considering a new rule that would allow Internet service providers (ISPs) to offer content providers a faster pathway for content delivery, reversing its earlier stance on net neutrality. Municipal broadband may address net neutrality issues, suggested Harvard Law School’s Professor Susan Crawford, an expert in law and technology. On May 15, 2014, the FCC decided to explore two options for Internet services: firstly, allowing fast and slow broadband lanes, which would compromise net neutrality; and secondly, reclassifying broadband as a telecommunication service, which would uphold net neutrality. On November 10, 2014, President Barack Obama urged the FCC to reclassify broadband Internet as a telecommunications service to safeguard net neutrality. On January 16, 2015, Republicans proposed legislation in a U.S. Congress H.R. discussion draft bill that acknowledges net neutrality but blocks the FCC from achieving its aims or enacting further regulations impacting ISPs. On January 31, 2015, AP News reported that the FCC plans to propose applying Title II (common carrier) of the Communications Act of 1934 to the Internet—subject to certain caveats—in a vote expected on February 26, 2015. Adopting this proposal would shift the classification of internet service from information to telecommunications, ensuring net neutrality according to FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality with its vote, as noted by the New York Times.

That is a traffic cop, and the ability to negotiate with every Internet service provider on access. "[148] [151] According to Wheeler, the FCC vote will be held as scheduled in February 2015 and "the wireless industry will be regulated. "[148] The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality in its vote, according to the New York Times. [152]

text_human: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are more open to 'trying on' different behaviours and appearances to discover who they are. In other words, in an attempt to find their identity and discover who they are adolescents are liking to cycle through a number of identities to find one that suits them best. But, developing and maintaining identity (in adolescent years) is a difficult task due to multiple factors such as family life, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this process might be more accurately described as identity development, rather than formation, but confirms a normative process of change in both content and structure of one's thoughts about the self. The two main aspects of identity development are self-clarity and self-esteem. Since choices made during adolescent years can influence later life, high levels of self-awareness and self-control during mid-adolescence will lead to better decisions during the transition to adulthood.[citation needed] Researchers have used three general approaches to understanding identity development: self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem. The years of adolescence create a more conscientious group of young adults. Adolescents pay close attention and give more time and effort to their appearance as their body goes through changes. Unlike children, teens put forth an effort to look presentable (1991). The environment in which an adolescent grows up also plays an important role in their identity development. Studies done by the American Psychological Association have shown that adolescents with a less privileged upbringing have a more difficult time developing their identity.
text_ai_base: Identity development is a crucial stage in the adolescent life cycle, typically initiated during adolescence. At this time, adolescents explore different behaviors and appearances to understand themselves better. They often experiment with multiple identities to determine which fits them best. However, forming and maintaining identity during these years is challenging due to factors such as family dynamics, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this phase is better described as identity development rather than formation, highlighting a normative change in thoughts about the self's content and structure. Key aspects of identity development include self-clarity and self-esteem. Decisions made during adolescence can significantly impact later life, and high levels of self-awareness and self-control during these years are linked to more positive choices during the transition to adulthood.[citation needed] Researchers typically explore identity development through self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem. Adolescents invest considerable attention, time, and effort into their appearance as their bodies change, showing more conscientiousness compared to children (1991). The environment in which an adolescent grows significantly influences their identity development. Studies by the American Psychological Association demonstrate that those with less privileged backgrounds face greater challenges in developing their identity.
text_ai_humanized: Identity formation is a cornerstone of development during the adolescent years. It is a process that one goes through for a lifetime; however, during the adolescent life cycle it usually begins to be established. This stage is when teens seek more independence from their parents. They begin experimenting, in particularly with look and behavior. They go through several identities before figuring out what and who they are. Challenges in identity formation and maintenance are rampant throughout the adolescent years. These challenges may be due in part to family issues, environment, or social standing. However, research has shown that the developing sense of identity and identification with a number of roles is more empirically supported as a concept of identity development rather than one of formation. This suggests that adolescents change their conception of the content and structure of the self in a normative way. Two important features of identity development during adolescence are work on clarifying a sense of self and the adoption of a set of values with respect to one's future. What one does in his or her teen years can affect his or her later weeks in life and that a high level of self-awareness and self-control in those years translates into higher levels in the transition to adulthood.[citation needed] What adolescents comprehend and attribute meaning to is actively involved in the dynamic interrelation between self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem, which has been the common constructs that researchers study when observing the development of identity in adolescents. Physical appearance commands a large portion of adolescents' attention as well as time and energy. The adolescent is very conscientious to his appearance suggesting that he is putting more conscious effort into his physical appearance than he previously did in childhood (1991). The environment adolescents grow up in contribute significantly to the development of their identity. The American Psychological Association shows that adolescents who grow up with less have more trouble with developing their identity.

text_human: South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. He poured gasoline on himself but police quickly surrounded him and carried him away. Two other demonstrators tried to storm the torch but failed. Fighting broke out near the beginning of the relay between a group of 500 Chinese supporters and approximately 50 protesters who carried a banner that read: "Free North Korean refugees in China." The students threw stones and water bottles as approximately 2,500 police tried to keep the groups separated. Police said they arrested five people, including a Chinese student who was arrested for allegedly throwing rocks. Thousands of Chinese followed the torch on its 4.5 hour journey, some chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" By the end of the relay, Chinese students became violent, and it was reported in Korean media that they were "lynching" everyone who was disagreeing with them. One police man was also rushed to hospital after being attacked by Chinese students. On Apr 29, the Secretary of Justice, Kim Kyung Han, told the prime minister that he will find "every single Chinese who was involved and bring them to justice." Later in the day, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and National Intelligence Service made a joint statement saying that they will be deporting every Chinese student that was involved in the incident. China defended the conduct of the students.
text_ai_base: The event in Seoul, South Korea, took place on April 27, in the city that hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics. Designed torchbearers, Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun, boycotted the occasion to protest the Chinese government's actions in Tibet. Over 8,000 riot police were deployed to secure the 24-kilometer route starting at Olympic Park, the venue built for the 1988 Games. On the torch relay day, clashes erupted between Chinese students and protesters, with participants hurling rocks, bottles, and fists. A North Korean defector, whose brother defected to China but was caught and executed by the DPRK, attempted self-immolation to protest China's treatment of North Korean refugees. Doused in gasoline, he was quickly subdued and removed by police. Two other protesters attempted to disrupt the relay without success. Near the start, a skirmish broke out between 500 Chinese supporters and about 50 protesters waving a banner that read: "Free North Korean refugees in China." Approximately 2,500 police officers intervened as students threw stones and bottles. Five arrests were made, including a Chinese student accused of rock-throwing. Thousands of Chinese followed the torch's 4.5-hour journey, chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" By the relay's end, Chinese students turned violent, reportedly "lynching" dissenters, as described by Korean media. A police officer was hospitalized after an attack by Chinese students. On April 29, Justice Secretary Kim Kyung Han assured the prime minister that all involved Chinese would be brought to justice. Later, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and National Intelligence Service jointly announced they would deport all participating Chinese students. China defended the students' actions.

Two appointed torchbearers, Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun, refused to participate in the event, in protest at the actions of the Chinese Government in Tibet. Riot police numbering more than 8,000 officers were deployed to maintain order along the scheduled route. The 24. 3-km route began at the Olympic park, a stadium constructed during Seoul's 1988 Summer Olympic Games. On the day of the torch relay, clashes again erupted when Chinese students and "protestors threw rocks, punches and plastic bottles at each other". A North Korean refugee, whose brother fled to China but was arrested and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself alight in protest at what he described as China's mistreatment of North Korean refugees. The student, "soaked with paint thinner" was whisked away by police before he could do so. Two other protestors tried to disrupt the relay but were unsuccessful. Moments after the relay began, a flare-up occurred when up to 500 Chinese supporters and about 50 protestors[who? ] unfurled a banner which read: "Free North Korean refugees in China". About 2,500 police officers intervened when students began pelting the group with "stones and plastic and glass bottles". Five people were arrested, including a Chinese student "suspected of throwing rocks". Thousands of Chinese students accompanied the torch for more than 4½ hours, shouting "Go China, go Olympics!" Near the end of the relay, many thousands of Chinese students reportedly "lynched" some of those opposing the Games. The scenes have been widely reported by much of the Korean media. A S. Korean policeman was assaulted by Chinese students, and was consequently hospitalized. By 29 April, Justice Secretary Kim Kyung Han promised the prime minister that all participating Chinese would be prosecuted. On 15 May 50, South Korea's Supreme Prosecutors' Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and its National Intelligence Service, jointly announced that it would deport all the Chinese students who took part in the protests. China did not admit Chinese students' fault to the incident.

text_human: Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood called on the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on. Anger at new military conscription laws during the American Civil War (1861–1865), which spared wealthier men who could afford to pay a $300 (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) commutation fee to hire a substitute, led to the Draft Riots of 1863, whose most visible participants were ethnic Irish working class. The situation deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on black New Yorkers and their property after fierce competition for a decade between Irish immigrants and blacks for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, but more than 200 children escaped harm due to efforts of the New York City Police Department, which was mainly made up of Irish immigrants. According to historian James M. McPherson (2001), at least 120 people were killed. In all, eleven black men were lynched over five days, and the riots forced hundreds of blacks to flee the city for Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as well as New Jersey; the black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The white working class had established dominance. Violence by longshoremen against black men was especially fierce in the docks area. It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.

This resentment led to the 1863 Draft Riots, predominantly involving ethnic Irish working class men. Longshoremen's violence against black men was particularly brutal in the docks area, marking one of the most severe incidents of civil unrest in American history.

The white working class had established dominance.[36][41] By 1865 the black population fell below 10,000, the lowest since 1820.

text_human: France: The torch relay leg in Paris, held on April 7, began on the first level of the Eiffel Tower and finished at the Stade Charléty. The relay was initially supposed to cover 28 km, but it was shortened at the demand of Chinese officials following widespread protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists, who repeatedly attempted to disrupt, hinder or halt the procession. A scheduled ceremony at the town hall was cancelled at the request of the Chinese authorities, and, also at the request of Chinese authorities, the torch finished the relay by bus instead of being carried by athletes. Paris City officials had announced plans to greet the Olympic flame with peaceful protest when the torch was to reach the French capital. The city government attached a banner reading "Paris defends human rights throughout the world" to the City Hall, in an attempt to promote values "of all humanity and of human rights." Members from Reporters Without Borders turned out in large numbers to protest. An estimated 3,000 French police protected the Olympic torch relay as it departed from the Eiffel Tower and criss-crossed Paris amid threat of protests. Widespread pro-Tibet protests, including an attempt by more than one demonstrator to extinguish the flame with water or fire extinguishers, prompted relay authorities to put out the flame five times (according to the police authorities in Paris) and load the torch onto a bus, at the demand of Chinese officials. This was later denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, despite video footage broadcast by French television network France 2 which showed Chinese flame attendants extinguishing the torch. Backup flames are with the relay at all times to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet expressed his annoyance at the Chinese flame attendants who extinguished the torch which he was about to hand over to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame despite the fact that there was no risk, and they could see it and they knew it. I don't know why they did it."

Initially planned to cover 28 km, the route was shortened at the insistence of Chinese officials due to widespread protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists aiming to disrupt the event. A ceremony at the town hall was canceled at the Chinese authorities' request, and the torch concluded its journey by bus rather than with athletes running. Paris city officials had planned peaceful protests upon the torch's arrival, displaying a banner at City Hall declaring, "Paris defends human rights throughout the world," to advocate for global human rights values. Members of Reporters Without Borders joined the large protest turnout. Approximately 3,000 French police officers guarded the torch as it traversed Paris amidst protest threats. Significant pro-Tibet demonstrations, including attempts to douse the flame with water or extinguishers, led the relay authorities to extinguish the torch five times (according to Paris police) and place it on a bus, following demands from Chinese officials. This action was denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, despite France 2 broadcasting footage of Chinese attendants extinguishing the flame. Backup flames are always available to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet voiced his frustration when Chinese attendants extinguished the torch as he was about to pass it to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame, although there was no risk, and they were aware of it. I don't know why they did it."

text_human: Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality of decisions of State authorities: Government decisions, those of local authorities and other bodies and persons performing public functions under the law, and direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws enacted by the Knesset. The court has broad discretionary authority to rule on matters in which it considers it necessary to grant relief in the interests of justice, and which are not within the jurisdiction of another court or tribunal. The High Court of Justice grants relief through orders such as injunction, mandamus and Habeas Corpus, as well as through declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also sit at a further hearing on its own judgment. In a matter on which the Supreme Court has ruled - whether as a court of appeals or as the High Court of Justice - with a panel of three or more justices, it may rule at a further hearing with a panel of a larger number of justices. A further hearing may be held if the Supreme Court makes a ruling inconsistent with a previous ruling or if the Court deems that the importance, difficulty or novelty of a ruling of the Court justifies such hearing. The Supreme Court also holds the unique power of being able to order "trial de novo" (a retrial).
text_ai_base: Israel's Supreme Court stands at the apex of the country's judicial system, serving as the highest court in the nation. Located in Jerusalem, its jurisdiction encompasses the entire State of Israel. Its rulings are binding on all other courts, except itself. The Supreme Court functions as both an appellate court and the High Court of Justice. As an appellate court, it handles appeals concerning decisions from District Courts in both criminal and civil cases, and reviews various legal and quasi-legal decisions, including those related to Knesset elections and disciplinary actions by the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; commonly referred to by its initials, Bagatz בג"ץ), it serves as a court of first instance, addressing the legality of actions taken by state authorities, government, local authorities, and others performing public duties. It also hears direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws passed by the Knesset. The court possesses wide discretionary power to intervene in matters requiring justice when no other court or tribunal has jurisdiction. The High Court of Justice provides relief through orders like injunctions, mandamus, and Habeas Corpus, along with declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also conduct a further hearing on its previous rulings. If a decision, whether rendered as an appellate court or as the High Court of Justice, is made by a panel of three or more justices, a further hearing may be convened with an expanded panel. Such a hearing is warranted if the ruling conflicts with prior decisions or if its importance, complexity, or novelty demands reevaluation. Additionally, the Supreme Court has the exceptional authority to order a "trial de novo" (a retrial).
text_ai_humanized: The Supreme Court also sometimes referred to as the High Court is the highest court in Israel. It has ultimate appellate jurisdiction over all other courts and, in addition, it acts as the High Court of Justice. The Supreme Court consists of 15 Judges who are appointed by the President of Israel, upon nomination by the Judicial Selection Committee. Once appointed, Supreme Court justices can serve until the age of 70, the mandatory age of retirement. Court sessions are held in Jerusalem. The Supreme Court is situated in the Givat Ram neighborhood of Jerusalem, between the Knesset and the Hebrew University. Its jurisdiction applies to all of Israel and the Israeli-occupied territories. According to the principle of binding precedent (stare decisis), a ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every other court, except itself. Apart from being the final court of appeals, the Supreme Court and justices have a number of unique roles: The Supreme Court acts as a court of first instance as the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known as its acronym Bagatz בג"ץ). The function of the High Court of Justice is to give relief to persons who have no other court to turn to. The High Court of Justice is an address for protests against the authorities, the State, local authorities, and other bodies and persons carrying out public functions under the law, whether Religious Councils or courts or tribunals not subject to the regular judicial system. The actual scope of the cases is very broad - ranging from extradition of foreign citizens to third countries, through petitions of Knesset members against laws or other national or military authorities, to the unification of families where one spouse is an Israeli and the other or others are not. The Supreme Court may sit as a further instance over its previous judgments (further hearing, Hebrew: דיון נוסף diyyun nosef). In any case in which the Supreme Court has delivered a judgment, as a court of appeals or as the High Court of Justice, by a bench of three or more justices, any one of the justices may request to review the case in a further hearing. In a further hearing the court sits with an extended panel of judges. A further hearing may also be held on a criminal case where a death sentence was decreed in the district court appeal and upheld in the supreme court. The President of the Supreme Court may initiate such a hearing if: The ruling conflicts with a previous one by the Supreme Court or another ruling by a different Court; The hearing gives a legal rule which is so important, complicated or innovative that it is, for this reason, required to consider it in another Supreme Court hearing. In rare cases the Supreme Court might also order a "trial de novo"—a complete retry—of a particular case.

It has ultimate appellate jurisdiction over all other courts and, in addition, it acts as the High Court of Justice. The Supreme Court consists of 15 Judges who are appointed by the President of Israel, upon nomination by the Judicial Selection Committee. Once appointed, Supreme Court justices can serve until the age of 70, the mandatory age of retirement. Court sessions are held in Jerusalem. The Supreme Court is situated in the Givat Ram neighborhood of Jerusalem, between the Knesset and the Hebrew University. Its jurisdiction applies to all of Israel and the Israeli-occupied territories. According to the principle of binding precedent (stare decisis), a ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every other court, except itself. Apart from being the final court of appeals, the Supreme Court and justices have a number of unique roles: The Supreme Court acts as a court of first instance as the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known as its acronym Bagatz בג"ץ). text_human: In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the beverage was first brought from Turkey, and by the 18th century Parisian cafés were centres of the city's political and cultural life. The Cafe Procope on the Left Bank dates from this period. In the 20th century, the cafés of the Left Bank, especially Café de la Rotonde and Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain, all still in business, were important meeting places for painters, writers and philosophers. A bistro is a type of eating place loosely defined as a neighbourhood restaurant with a modest decor and prices and a regular clientele and a congenial atmosphere. Its name is said to have come in 1814 from the Russian soldiers who occupied the city; "bistro" means "quickly" in Russian, and they wanted their meals served rapidly so they could get back their encampment. Real bistros are increasingly rare in Paris, due to rising costs, competition from cheaper ethnic restaurants, and different eating habits of Parisian diners. A brasserie originally was a tavern located next to a brewery, which served beer and food at any hour. Beginning with the Paris Exposition of 1867; it became a popular kind of restaurant which featured beer and other beverages served by young women in the national costume associated with the beverage, particular German costumes for beer. Now brasseries, like cafés, serve food and drinks throughout the day.

In the 20th century, Left Bank cafés like Café de la Rotonde, Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse, and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain became key gathering spots for artists, writers, and philosophers, and they remain open today. A bistro is generally considered a neighborhood eatery known for its simple decor, affordable prices, loyal patrons, and friendly atmosphere. text_human: Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences alone; South America, Africa, and Australia all have regions with similar climates at similar latitudes, but those regions have very different plants and animals. The species found in one area of a continent are more closely allied with species found in other regions of that same continent than to species found on other continents. Darwin noted that barriers to migration played an important role in the differences between the species of different regions. The coastal sea life of the Atlantic and Pacific sides of Central America had almost no species in common even though the Isthmus of Panama was only a few miles wide. His explanation was a combination of migration and descent with modification. He went on to say: "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how it is that sections of genera, whole genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so commonly and notoriously the case." Darwin explained how a volcanic island formed a few hundred miles from a continent might be colonised by a few species from that continent. These species would become modified over time, but would still be related to species found on the continent, and Darwin observed that this was a common pattern. Darwin discussed ways that species could be dispersed across oceans to colonise islands, many of which he had investigated experimentally.
text_ai_base: Chapter XI explores biogeographical evidence, beginning with the observation that differences in flora and fauna across regions cannot be solely attributed to environmental factors. Despite having similar climates and latitudes, regions in South America, Africa, and Australia host vastly different plant and animal life. Within a continent, species tend to be more closely related to those in different areas of the same continent rather than to species on other continents. Darwin highlighted the significant role that migration barriers play in the unique species of various regions. For instance, the coastal marine life on the Atlantic and Pacific sides of Central America had almost no species in common, despite being divided by the narrow Isthmus of Panama. He explained these differences through the concepts of migration and descent with modification, stating: "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how sections of genera, entire genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so often observed." Darwin further explained that a volcanic island emerging a few hundred miles from a continent could be colonized by a few species from that continent. These species would evolve over time but remain related to their continental counterparts, a pattern he frequently noted. Additionally, Darwin explored various methods of how species might disperse across oceans to colonize islands, many of which he investigated experimentally.

text_human: The College Dropout was eventually issued by Roc-A-Fella in February 2004, shooting to number two on the Billboard 200 as his debut single, "Through the Wire" peaked at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for five weeks. "Slow Jamz", his second single featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, became an even bigger success: it became the three musicians' first number one hit. The College Dropout received near-universal critical acclaim from contemporary music critics, was voted the top album of the year by two major music publications, and has consistently been ranked among the great hip-hop works and debut albums by artists. "Jesus Walks", the album's fourth single, perhaps exposed West to a wider audience; the song's subject matter concerns faith and Christianity. The song nevertheless reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts, despite industry executives' predictions that a song containing such blatant declarations of faith would never make it to radio. The College Dropout would eventually be certified triple platinum in the US, and garnered West 10 Grammy nominations, including Album of the Year, and Best Rap Album (which it received). During this period, West also founded GOOD Music, a record label and management company that would go on to house affiliate artists and producers, such as No I.D. and John Legend. At the time, the focal point of West's production style was the use of sped-up vocal samples from soul records. However, partly because of the acclaim of The College Dropout, such sampling had been much copied by others; with that overuse, and also because West felt he had become too dependent on the technique, he decided to find a new sound.

At the time, the general conscious was that the radio stations would never put the song in rotation because of its heavy references to religion.[69] Nevertheless, the single reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts, and it garnered West "Special Recognition" at the 2004 Billboard Music Awards.[73] The College Dropout debuted at number two on the Billboard 200 and went on to be certified triple platinum in the United States.[74][75] The album peaked at number twelve on the UK Albums Chart, where it topped the UK R&B Chart.[76][77] It was the tenth highest selling album of 2004 in the US,[78] and became West's best-selling album to date, with domestic sales of over 3 million copies and worldwide sales of over 5 million copies.[74][79] At the 2005 Grammy Awards, The College Dropout and "Jesus Walks" were respectively awarded Best Rap Album and Best Rap Song. AllMusic senior editor Stephen Thomas Erlewine called West "easily the most innovative person in hip-hop during the 2000s" and "certainly the most critically acclaimed."[6] West's production style at the time was largely characterized by sped-up vocal samples from soul records; this brand of production contributed to the success of Jay-Z's The Blueprint album. Once The College Dropout was released to wide acclaim and he had the opportunity to compose in a style apart from soul music sampling, West decided to craft an entirely different sound for his sophomore album.[24]

text_human: These different explorations of 'identity' demonstrate how difficult a concept it is to pin down. Since identity is a virtual thing, it is impossible to define it empirically. Discussions of identity use the term with different meanings, from fundamental and abiding sameness, to fluidity, contingency, negotiated and so on. Brubaker and Cooper note a tendency in many scholars to confuse identity as a category of practice and as a category of analysis (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 5). Indeed, many scholars demonstrate a tendency to follow their own preconceptions of identity, following more or less the frameworks listed above, rather than taking into account the mechanisms by which the concept is crystallised as reality. In this environment, some analysts, such as Brubaker and Cooper, have suggested doing away with the concept completely (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 1). Others, by contrast, have sought to introduce alternative concepts in an attempt to capture the dynamic and fluid qualities of human social self-expression. Hall (1992, 1996), for example, suggests treating identity as a process, to take into account the reality of diverse and ever-changing social experience. Some scholars have introduced the idea of identification, whereby identity is perceived as made up of different components that are 'identified' and interpreted by individuals. The construction of an individual sense of self is achieved by personal choices regarding who and what to associate with. Such approaches are liberating in their recognition of the role of the individual in social interaction and the construction of identity.
text_ai_base: Explorations of 'identity' reveal the concept's complexity and elusive nature. Being virtual, identity cannot be empirically defined. The term 'identity' carries various meanings in discussions, ranging from stable sameness to changeable, contingent aspects subject to negotiation. Brubaker and Cooper highlight that many scholars often blur the lines between viewing identity as a practical category and an analytical one (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 5). Indeed, researchers frequently rely on their preconceived notions of identity, adhering to established frameworks, rather than focusing on how identity manifests in reality. In this context, some analysts, including Brubaker and Cooper, propose abandoning the concept altogether (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 1). Conversely, others suggest alternative ideas to better capture the dynamic and fluid nature of human social expression. Hall (1992, 1996), for instance, advocates understanding identity as a process to reflect diverse and evolving social experiences. Additionally, some scholars present the notion of identification, where identity comprises various elements 'identified' and interpreted by individuals. This personal construction of self is influenced by choices about affiliations and associations. These approaches are empowering, recognizing the individual's role in social interactions and identity formation.
text_ai_humanized: These studies show how 'identity' as an abstract notion is highly ambiguous or even problematic in a sense. As a virtual concept, 'identities' cannot be measured and thus defined. In fact, 'identity' is used as a broad term, with varying connotations in each discussion: from fixed, unchangeable same-ness to mutable, tentative differences subject to negotiation. Brubaker and Cooper point out that some scholar confuse their use of identity as both a needed category of practice and a category of analysis (Brubaker & Cooper 2000 5). Indeed, scholars tend to take their own assumption of identity, obeying to canonical codes, rather than seriously contemplating what identity really is. In this regard, some, including Brubaker and Cooper, suggest perhaps leaving the notion of identity itself (Brubaker & Cooper 2000 1). Others, instead, come up with alternative concepts to depict the diverse and transforming impulses of human social expressions. Hall (1992; 1996), for example, puts forward an idea of identity as a process, meaning that identity should be considered as such to represent the diverse and transient aspects of human society. Some scholars also suggest a notion of identification, namely that identity is comprised of fragments of ideas 'identified' and suggested by people, which inform their own definition of self exclusively with their decisions on what or who can be integrated. These suggestions all seem valuable, for they give the power to the individuals in social practice, at the same time, in construction of their own identity.
