text_human: In response to attribution of recent climate change, the City of Melbourne, in 2002, set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020 and Moreland City Council established the Zero Moreland program, however not all metropolitan municipalities have followed, with the City of Glen Eira notably deciding in 2009 not to become carbon neutral. Melbourne has one of the largest urban footprints in the world due to its low density housing, resulting in a vast suburban sprawl, with a high level of car dependence and minimal public transport outside of inner areas. Much of the vegetation within the city are non-native species, most of European origin, and in many cases plays host to invasive species and noxious weeds. Significant introduced urban pests include the common myna, feral pigeon, brown rat, European wasp, common starling and red fox. Many outlying suburbs, particularly towards the Yarra Valley and the hills to the north-east and east, have gone for extended periods without regenerative fires leading to a lack of saplings and undergrowth in urbanised native bushland. The Department of Sustainability and Environment partially addresses this problem by regularly burning off. Several national parks have been designated around the urban area of Melbourne, including the Mornington Peninsula National Park, Port Phillip Heads Marine National Park and Point Nepean National Park in the south east, Organ Pipes National Park to the north and Dandenong Ranges National Park to the east. There are also a number of significant state parks just outside Melbourne. Responsibility for regulating pollution falls under the jurisdiction of the EPA Victoria and several local councils. Air pollution, by world standards, is classified as being good. Summer and autumn are the worst times of year for atmospheric haze in the urban area.
text_ai_base: In 2002, the City of Melbourne set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020 in response to climate change concerns. Similarly, Moreland City Council initiated the Zero Moreland program. However, not all municipalities in the area have adopted such measures. For instance, in 2009, the City of Glen Eira chose not to pursue carbon neutrality. Melbourne's urban expanse is among the largest globally due to its low-density housing, leading to widespread suburban sprawl. This results in heavy car dependence and limited public transport options, especially outside the inner city. Much of the city's vegetation comprises non-native species, predominantly of European origin, often hosting invasive species and harmful weeds. Common urban pests include the common myna, feral pigeon, brown rat, European wasp, common starling, and red fox. Outlying suburbs, especially near the Yarra Valley and the northern and eastern hills, have experienced long periods without regenerative fires, resulting in minimal saplings and undergrowth in urbanised native bushland. To address this, the Department of Sustainability and Environment conducts controlled burns. Several national parks, such as Mornington Peninsula National Park, Port Phillip Heads Marine National Park, and Point Nepean National Park in the southeast, as well as Organ Pipes National Park to the north and Dandenong Ranges National Park to the east, surround Melbourne. Significant state parks are also located just outside the city. Pollution regulation is managed by the EPA Victoria and several local councils. By global standards, Melbourne's air quality is considered good, although summer and autumn bring heightened atmospheric haze to the urban area.
text_ai_humanized: Melbourne has minimal public housing and high demand for rental housing, which is becoming unaffordable for some.[note 3][90][91][92] Public housing is usually provided by the Housing Commission of Victoria, and operates within the framework of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, by which federal and state governments provide housing funding. Melbourne is experiencing high population growth, generating high demand for housing. This housing boom has increased house prices and rents, as well as the availability of low-income housing.[90] Subdivision regularly occurs in the far outer suburbs of Melbourne, with numerous developers offering house and land packages.[93] However, after many decades of planning for medium-density development, in 2005 Melbourne's housing density declined.[94][95] Middle-ring suburbs such as Eltham and Glen Waverley are seeing significant growth.[96] Melbourne consistently ranked as the most liveable city in the world from 2011 to 2017.[17][18][19] It held the top position for seven years, and placed 10th in 2022 from a ranking of 140 cities.[97] The Economist Intelligence Unit publishes its Global Liveability Ranking annually, and has awarded Melbourne consistently since 2011 at the top of its list, attributing this to its high level of healthcare, education, and infrastructure, and its government-favourable policies and legislation.[98] Melbourne has notably lessened urban sprawl in 2001, a separate planning scheme, the Melbourne 2030, was released, outlining a plan for sustainable growth to the year 2030. In response to Urban Sprawl in Australia and the increased environmental concerns, Melbourne 2030 was created.[99] This is a plan to combat environmental pollution, protect public transport and address urban congestion in highly populated and developing cities.[100] The plan seeks to curtail the urban sprawl that has dominated Melbourne's growth patterns with a roughly circular ring centred on the city, spanning approximately 40 km (25 mi) to the east, 21 km (13 mi) to the north and 42 km (26 mi) to the south, within which urban development will be contained, in accordance with the plan's aim to 'build up' the city rather than continue to 'build out'.[100] In 2002, the City of Melbourne set a target to achieve zero net emissions by 2020[101] and Moreland City Council established the Zero Moreland program in 2008 with the same goal.[102] Not all councils have actively pursued this, with the City of Glen Eira notably deciding in 2009 not to become carbon-neutral.[103] Melbourne has one of the largest urban footprints in the world due to its low-density housing, resulting in a vast spread of suburbs. This has resulted in an extensive dependence on motor vehicles for transportation.[104] The city is characterised by extensive areas of sprawl, and, in accordance with the 2030 Planning scheme, this is to be restricted in favour of higher-density development, particularly in existing areas of urban sprawl.[100] Much of the vegetation within the city is non-native species, most intentionally planted, many European, particularly introduced during the Victorian era of British settlement. Some of the most invasive species are the introduced European Wasp, Common Myna, Red Fox, rabbit and Cane Toad. Many outlying suburbs, particularly towards the Yarra Valley and the hills to the north-east and east, have gone for extended periods without regenerative fires leading to a lack of saplings and undergrowth in urbanised native bushland. The Department of Sustainability and Environment partially addresses this problem by regularly burning off.[105][106] Several of Melbourne's 37 national parks, such as Mornington Peninsula National Park and Port Phillip Heads Marine National Park, are located within the metropolitan area.[107][108][109] There are also a number of significant state parks just outside Melbourne.[110][111] Pollution of Melbourne's waterways and bays has been a problem; however, resource-bettering and community action have been undertaken in recent years to clean up the waterways.[112][113] Melbourne has the highest density of commercial solar panel installations in Australia.[114] Public solar power in Melbourne has increased rapidly since 2006.[115] Pollution by trams, cars and industry is monitored by the Environmental Protection Authority Victoria and EPA has power to prosecute polluters, with recent prosecutions resulting in fines to public transport and commercial companies exceeding $1 million[116] Air quality is generally good and has improved significantly since the 1980s.[117][118] On some days, usually in autumn, the quality is reduced due to atmospheric haze during days with light wind conditions and temperature inversion.[119] Melbourne's drinking water is sourced from a series of protected reservoirs located within and outside the Greater Melbourne area.[120]

text_human: Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, privilege and immunity. Therefore, civil and religious law limited the number and kind of religious offices allowed an individual and his family. Religious law was collegial and traditional; it informed political decisions, could overturn them, and was difficult to exploit for personal gain. Priesthood was a costly honour: in traditional Roman practice, a priest drew no stipend. Cult donations were the property of the deity, whose priest must provide cult regardless of shortfalls in public funding – this could mean subsidy of acolytes and all other cult maintenance from personal funds. For those who had reached their goal in the Cursus honorum, permanent priesthood was best sought or granted after a lifetime's service in military or political life, or preferably both: it was a particularly honourable and active form of retirement which fulfilled an essential public duty. For a freedman or slave, promotion as one of the Compitalia seviri offered a high local profile, and opportunities in local politics; and therefore business. During the Imperial era, priesthood of the Imperial cult offered provincial elites full Roman citizenship and public prominence beyond their single year in religious office; in effect, it was the first step in a provincial cursus honorum. In Rome, the same Imperial cult role was performed by the Arval Brethren, once an obscure Republican priesthood dedicated to several deities, then co-opted by Augustus as part of his religious reforms. The Arvals offered prayer and sacrifice to Roman state gods at various temples for the continued welfare of the Imperial family on their birthdays, accession anniversaries and to mark extraordinary events such as the quashing of conspiracy or revolt. Every January 3 they consecrated the annual vows and rendered any sacrifice promised in the previous year, provided the gods had kept the Imperial family safe for the contracted time.
text_ai_base: Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Upon election, a priest gained permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, granting him lifetime influence, privilege, and immunity. Consequently, civil and religious laws restricted the number and type of religious offices an individual and his family could hold. Religious law, being collegial and traditional, guided political decisions and could overturn them, making it hard to exploit for personal gain. Priesthood, while prestigious, was costly; in Roman tradition, priests earned no stipend. Donations to the cult were considered the property of the deity, and the priest was responsible for maintaining the cult, even if public funding was inadequate, often requiring personal financial support for acolytes and other cult needs. For those having completed the Cursus honorum, seeking permanent priesthood was ideal after a lifetime in military or political service, or preferably both, providing an honourable and active retirement and fulfilling an essential public duty. Freedmen or slaves achieving promotion as Compitalia seviri gained a prominent local profile, and opportunities in local politics and business. During the Imperial era, holding priesthood in the Imperial cult afforded provincial elites full Roman citizenship and public recognition exceeding their single year in religious office; this was essentially the first step in a provincial cursus honorum. In Rome, the Arval Brethren embodied this role for the Imperial cult—originally a lesser-known priesthood dedicated to multiple deities, then co-opted by Augustus in his religious reforms. The Arvals prayed and sacrificed to Roman state gods at various temples for the Imperial family’s continued welfare on birthdays, accession anniversaries, and during extraordinary events like quelling conspiracies or revolts. Each January 3, they renewed the annual vows and executed any sacrifices promised the previous year, as long as the gods ensured the Imperial family's safety for the agreed period.

Religious law was collegiate, traditional and could guide political decisions as well as rescind them; difficult to interpret for personal gain. text_human: The first Sky television rights agreement was worth £304 million over five seasons. The next contract, negotiated to start from the 1997–98 season, rose to £670 million over four seasons. The third contract was a £1.024 billion deal with BSkyB for the three seasons from 2001–02 to 2003–04. The league brought in £320 million from the sale of its international rights for the three-year period from 2004–05 to 2006–07. It sold the rights itself on a territory-by-territory basis. Sky's monopoly was broken from August 2006 when Setanta Sports was awarded rights to show two out of the six packages of matches available. This occurred following an insistence by the European Commission that exclusive rights should not be sold to one television company. Sky and Setanta paid a total of £1.7 billion, a two-thirds increase which took many commentators by surprise as it had been widely assumed that the value of the rights had levelled off following many years of rapid growth. Setanta also hold rights to a live 3 pm match solely for Irish viewers. The BBC has retained the rights to show highlights for the same three seasons (on Match of the Day) for £171.6 million, a 63 per cent increase on the £105 million it paid for the previous three-year period. Sky and BT have agreed to jointly pay £84.3 million for delayed television rights to 242 games (that is the right to broadcast them in full on television and over the internet) in most cases for a period of 50 hours after 10 pm on matchday. Overseas television rights fetched £625 million, nearly double the previous contract. The total raised from these deals is more than £2.7 billion, giving Premier League clubs an average media income from league games of around £40 million-a-year from 2007 to 2010.

text_human: The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds (1686). The book was produced specifically for women with an interest in scientific writing and inspired a variety of similar works. These popular works were written in a discursive style, which was laid out much more clearly for the reader than the complicated articles, treatises, and books published by the academies and scientists. Charles Leadbetter's Astronomy (1727) was advertised as "a Work entirely New" that would include "short and easie [sic] Rules and Astronomical Tables." The first French introduction to Newtonianism and the Principia was Eléments de la philosophie de Newton, published by Voltaire in 1738. Émilie du Châtelet's translation of the Principia, published after her death in 1756, also helped to spread Newton's theories beyond scientific academies and the university. Francesco Algarotti, writing for a growing female audience, published Il Newtonianism per le dame, which was a tremendously popular work and was translated from Italian into English by Elizabeth Carter. A similar introduction to Newtonianism for women was produced by Henry Pembarton. His A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy was published by subscription. Extant records of subscribers show that women from a wide range of social standings purchased the book, indicating the growing number of scientifically inclined female readers among the middling class. During the Enlightenment, women also began producing popular scientific works themselves. Sarah Trimmer wrote a successful natural history textbook for children titled The Easy Introduction to the Knowledge of Nature (1782), which was published for many years after in eleven editions.

These popular writings used a clear, conversational style, unlike the complex articles and treatises produced by academic scientists. Charles Leadbetter's "Astronomy" (1727) was marketed as "a Work entirely New," offering straightforward rules and astronomical tables. The first French guide to Newtonian physics, Voltaire's "Eléments de la philosophie de Newton," appeared in 1738. Émilie du Châtelet's posthumous translation of Newton's "Principia" in 1756 further disseminated his theories outside scientific circles. Writing for a growing female audience, Francesco Algarotti's "Il Newtonianism per le dame" became very popular and was translated into English by Elizabeth Carter. Similarly, Henry Pembarton wrote "A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy," published by subscription. During the Enlightenment, women also began creating popular scientific works. Sarah Trimmer authored a widely successful natural history textbook for children, "The Easy Introduction to the Knowledge of Nature" (1782), which was reprinted in eleven editions over many years.

text_human: In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. On February 19, 1942, President Franklin Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066, authorizing the removal of Japanese Americans from the West Coast. FBI Director Hoover opposed the subsequent mass removal and confinement of Japanese Americans authorized under Executive Order 9066, but Roosevelt prevailed. The vast majority went along with the subsequent exclusion orders, but in a handful of cases where Japanese Americans refused to obey the new military regulations, FBI agents handled their arrests. The Bureau continued surveillance on Japanese Americans throughout the war, conducting background checks on applicants for resettlement outside camp, and entering the camps (usually without the permission of War Relocation Authority officials) and grooming informants in order to monitor dissidents and "troublemakers." After the war, the FBI was assigned to protect returning Japanese Americans from attacks by hostile white communities.

text_human: Nanjing, one of the nation's most important cities for over a thousand years, is recognized as one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China, and had been the world's largest city aggregately for hundreds of years, enjoyed peace and prosperity and beared wars and disasters. Nanjing served as the capital of Eastern Wu, one of the three major states in the Three Kingdoms period (211-280); the Eastern Jin and each of the Southern Dynasties (Liu Song, Southern Qi, Liang and Chen), which successively ruled southern China from 317-589; the Southern Tang, one of the Ten Kingdoms (937-76); the Ming dynasty when, for the first time, all of China was ruled from the city (1368-1421); and the Republic of China (1927–37, 1945–49) prior to its flight to Taiwan during the Chinese Civil War. The city also served as the seat of the rebel Taiping Heavenly Kingdom (1851–64) and the Japanese puppet regime of Wang Jingwei (1940–45) during the Second Sino-Japanese War, and suffered appalling atrocities in both conflicts, including the Nanjing Massacre. It has been serving as the capital city of Jiangsu province after the China was established, and is still the nominal capital of Republic of China that accommodates many of its important heritage sites, including the Presidential Palace and Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum. Nanjing is famous for human historical landscapes, mountains and waters such as Fuzimiao, Ming Palace, Chaotian Palace, Porcelain Tower, Drum Tower, Stone City, City Wall, Qinhuai River, Xuanwu Lake and Purple Mountain. Key cultural facilities include Nanjing Library, Nanjing Museum and Art Museum.
text_ai_base: Nanjing has been a pivotal city in China for over a thousand years and is recognized as one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China. Historically, it has alternately enjoyed periods of peace and prosperity and endured wars and disasters. Nanjing served as the capital for Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period (211-280); the Eastern Jin and each of the Southern Dynasties (Liu Song, Southern Qi, Liang, and Chen) that governed southern China from 317 to 589; the Southern Tang, part of the Ten Kingdoms (937-976); and during the early Ming dynasty when it ruled all of China for the first time (1368-1421). Additionally, it was the capital of the Republic of China from 1927 to 1937 and again from 1945 to 1949 before the government retreated to Taiwan during the Chinese Civil War. Nanjing was also the base for the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom (1851-1864) and the Japanese puppet regime led by Wang Jingwei (1940-1945) during the Second Sino-Japanese War, suffering horrific events such as the Nanjing Massacre. Since the establishment of modern China, it has been the capital of Jiangsu province and remains the nominal capital of the Republic of China. Nanjing is renowned for its historical landscapes and scenic locations, including Fuzimiao, Ming Palace, Chaotian Palace, Porcelain Tower, Drum Tower, Stone City, City Wall, Qinhuai River, Xuanwu Lake, and Purple Mountain. Key cultural venues include the Nanjing Library, Nanjing Museum, and the Art Museum.
text_ai_humanized: Nanjing is one of the oldest cities in China. Nanjing has also served as the capital city of Jiangsu province since the establishment of People’s Republic of China. Its history can be traced back to the 6th century BC, the era of the state of Yue. The city has evolved from a political struggling stage on Jiangnan (Chinese: 江南; pinyin: Jiāngnán) to the capital of China from third century to 1949, and now the capital of Jiangsu Province, which highlights the development of Chinese nation. Before the Qing dynasty, the name of Nanjing and Beijing had not been designated on any cities, while they indicate distinguish cities: Nanjing means the southern capital, and Beijing the northern capital. Together with Beijing, Xi’an and Luoyang, Nanjing is commonly considered to be one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China. It is also the only city in China that has been a capital under many Chinese dynasties, one of the nation’s most important regions in education, research, transportation and tourism, with an abundance of historical landscapes and cultural sites such as Fuzimiao, Ming Palace, Chaotian Palace, Porcelain Tower, Drum Tower, Stone City, City Wall, Qinhuai River, Xuanwu Lake, Purple Mountain, Nanjing Library, Nanjing Museum and the Art Museum.

text_human: Protestantism also spread from the German lands into France, where the Protestants were nicknamed Huguenots. Calvin continued to take an interest in the French religious affairs from his base in Geneva. He regularly trained pastors to lead congregations there. Despite heavy persecution, the Reformed tradition made steady progress across large sections of the nation, appealing to people alienated by the obduracy and the complacency of the Catholic establishment. French Protestantism came to acquire a distinctly political character, made all the more obvious by the conversions of nobles during the 1550s. This established the preconditions for a series of conflicts, known as the French Wars of Religion. The civil wars gained impetus with the sudden death of Henry II of France in 1559. Atrocity and outrage became the defining characteristics of the time, illustrated at their most intense in the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre of August 1572, when the Roman Catholic party annihilated between 30,000 and 100,000 Huguenots across France. The wars only concluded when Henry IV of France issued the Edict of Nantes, promising official toleration of the Protestant minority, but under highly restricted conditions. Roman Catholicism remained the official state religion, and the fortunes of French Protestants gradually declined over the next century, culminating in Louis XIV's Edict of Fontainebleau which revoked the Edict of Nantes and made Roman Catholicism the sole legal religion once again. In response to the Edict of Fontainebleau, Frederick William I, Elector of Brandenburg declared the Edict of Potsdam, giving free passage to Huguenot refugees. In the late 17th century many Huguenots fled to England, the Netherlands, Prussia, Switzerland, and the English and Dutch overseas colonies. A significant community in France remained in the Cévennes region.
text_ai_base: Protestantism expanded from the German territories into France, where its adherents were called Huguenots. From his base in Geneva, Calvin remained involved in French religious matters, often training pastors to lead congregations. Despite severe persecution, the Reformed tradition steadily advanced across many parts of France, attracting those disenchanted by the rigidity and complacency of the Catholic establishment. French Protestantism developed a distinctly political nature, especially as many nobles converted during the 1550s, laying the groundwork for the French Wars of Religion. These civil conflicts intensified after the sudden death of Henry II of France in 1559, characterized by brutal violence, most notably the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre of August 1572, when the Roman Catholic faction slaughtered between 30,000 and 100,000 Huguenots across France. The wars eventually ended when Henry IV issued the Edict of Nantes, which granted the Protestant minority limited official tolerance. However, Catholicism remained the state religion, and the fortunes of French Protestants steadily declined, culminating in Louis XIV's Edict of Fontainebleau that revoked the Edict of Nantes and reestablished Catholicism as the sole legal religion. In response, Frederick William I of Brandenburg issued the Edict of Potsdam, allowing Huguenot refugees safe passage. In the late 17th century, many Huguenots relocated to England, the Netherlands, Prussia, Switzerland, and the English and Dutch overseas colonies. Nonetheless, a significant Huguenot community continued to exist in the Cévennes region of France.

However, enforcement of the prohibition against Protestants relaxed under Louis XV, and at least one Protestant community remained in the isolated Cévennes region. Moreover, many Huguenots continued to live in France, some as Nicodemites, who maintained Protestant practices in secret.

Protestants also spread from the German lands into France, where they became known as Huguenots. Calvin continued to take an interest in the religious affairs of his native land and often trained ministers for congregations. Reformation progressed in the French-speaking regions in spite of violent opposition from the French government. Several members of the French nobility were won over to the Reformed faith and this led to eight civil wars, known as the French Wars of Religion, during the period 1562
–1598. A series of conflicts and fragile peaces followed. The civil wars gained impetus with the sudden death of Henry II of France, and warfare ended only with the Edict of Nantes, which granted official toleration to the Protestants. In response to the Edict of Fontainebleau, Frederick William I, Elector of Brandenburg declared the Edict of Potsdam, giving free passage to Huguenot refugees. However, enforcement of the prohibition against Protestants relaxed under Louis XV, and at least one Protestant community remained in the isolated Cévennes region. Moreover, many Huguenots continued to live in France, some as Nicodemites, who maintained Protestant practices in secret.

text_human: In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy, where they were called Graeces. When the Romans encountered them they used this name for the colonists and then for all Greeks (Graeci.) The word γραῖα graia "old woman" comes from the PIE root *ǵerh2-/*ǵreh2-, "to grow old" via Proto-Greek *gera-/grau-iu; the same root later gave γέρας geras (/keras/), "gift of honour" in Mycenean Greek. The Germanic languages borrowed the word Greeks with an initial "k" sound which probably was their initial sound closest to the Latin "g" at the time (Goth. Kreks). The area out of ancient Attica including Boeotia was called Graïke and is connected with the older deluge of Ogyges, the mythological ruler of Boeotia. The region was originally occupied by the Minyans who were autochthonous or Proto-Greek speaking people. In ancient Greek the name Ogygios came to mean "from earliest days".
text_ai_base: In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is depicted as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, who was the sister of Hellen, the patriarch of the Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion, a ruler in Phthia, central Greece. The Parian Chronicle records that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the people formerly known as Graikoi were renamed Hellenes. Aristotle notes in Meteorologica I.xiv that the Hellenes were related to the Grai or Greeks, a name used by a Dorian tribe in Epirus, adopted by the Illyrians. He also suggests that the great deluge likely occurred around Dodona, home to the Selloi. Yet, Greek tradition often places the Greek homeland originally in central Greece. A modern theory posits that the name Greek (Latin Graeci) derives from Graikos, meaning "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a coastal town in Boeotia. Colonists from Graia founded Cumae in Italy around 900 BC, where they were called Graeces. The Romans later used this name for all Greeks (Graeci). The word γραῖα (graia), meaning "old woman," traces back to the Proto-Indo-European root *ǵerh2-/*ǵreh2-, meaning "to grow old," via Proto-Greek *gera-/grau-iu. This root also produced γέρας (geras), "gift of honor," in Mycenean Greek. Germanic languages adapted the word Greeks with a "k" sound due to its similarity to the Latin "g" at the time (Goth. Kreks). The area outside ancient Attica, including Boeotia, was known as Graïke and linked to the older deluge associated with Ogyges, the mythological ruler of Boeotia. This region was initially inhabited by the Minyans, who were either native or Proto-Greek-speaking peoples. In ancient Greek, Ogygios came to mean "from the earliest days."
text_ai_humanized: In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II,[10][11] the daughter of Deucalion and Pyrrha who became "the mother of Graecians and Latinus, peoples very brave and handsome". Pandora II was the sister of Hellen, the progenitor of the Hellenes, and Graecus' brother Latinus was the progenitor of the Latins.[10] Hellen was the son of Deucalion (mythical founder of the Greek nation), who was the son of Prometheus, who had ruled in Phthia, a region in southern Thessaly.[12] According to an ancient Greek myth, when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the Graikoi were named Hellenes.[13] According to the Parian Chronicle, when Deukalion became king of Phthia, the Graikoi (Γραικοί) were named Hellenes.[13] According to the account of Aristotle (Meteorologica I.xiv), the Hellenes were related to (and descended from) Graikoi: "... the deluge took place in the region of ancient Hellas, between Dodona and the Achelous, a river which rises in Pindus and flows into the sea on the borders of Acarnania and Aetolia. This region is inhabited by the Selli, and by the people who were formerly called Graikoi, but now Hellenes...".[14] Aristotle was referring to the older Greek mythological tradition,[15] when he mentioned that the Hellenes were formerly called Graikoi. He reveals the existence of a Dorian-Greek tribe in Epirus called Graikoi, which was also adopted by the Illyrians.[16] In his account, Aristotle is making a reference to the great deluge, when he mentions Graikoi and not the Hellenes. In Greek mythology, Graecus was the son of Thessalos. The focal point of the events related to Deucalion's flood is found in the area embracing the region of Dodona (in Epirus) and Thesprotia with the Achelous river, which were the lands of the Thesprotians, who were considered to be the first, primordial Greeks in the Greek cosmogony. The selloi were the armed priests of Dodona of the Thesprotians, who later were named Hellanes.[17][18] J. G. Th. Graesse based on the Greek myth mentions the names of Graecus and Pandrose and believes that the first inhabitant of Attica and Argos was called Graecus.[19] Though in Greek mythology the sons of Zeus and Pandrose were trespassers either in Attica or in Argos. According to Manfred Mayrhofer the Greek ethnonym Γραικός, Graikos, means "inhabitant of Graia/Graea",[20] a town at the mouth of Boeotia. Around 900 BC, these Graians together with local Euboeans established the colony of Cumae in Italy, when they were called Graeces.[21][20] When the Romans met with them they used this name for all Greeks (Graeci). The name of the region of Boeotia, Greece outside ancient Attica, was Graïke and was associated with the older times and the deluge associated with Ogyges, the mythical ruler of Boeotia. In ancient Greek, the adjective Ogygios came to mean "from the earliest ages" and also "primeval, primal", so retrieved by ancient writers like Plutarch.[ citation needed] Boeotia was in turn first inhabited by the Minyans,[ citation needed] an autochthonic or Proto-Greek-speaking group of the Aegean Bronze Age, and later by several waves of Proto-Greek speakers. The word γραῖα (graia) is a Proto-Indo-European word (PIE *ǵerh2-/*ǵreh2-, "to grow old")[22] through the Proto-Greek: *gera-/grau-iu and the Greek γήρας (Geras, "old age"), while the Latin word Grai is related to the Graeae and the Parcae. The Greek name of the parcae came from that word.[23] * Graios was also one of the names of the god Apollo in the region of Mount Olympus.[24] It is believed that the word γέρας (Geras, "gift of honour") in Mycenean Greek was also derived from the same PIE root (Mycenean Greek: γερα-, "gift of honour", related to the Homeric γέρας)[25][26] (see also list of Mycenaean Greek words). The central dialects of Ancient Greek as Attic and Ionic had a "k" insertion in the PIE *ǵerh2-*ǵreh2- ("to grow old"), while other peripheral dialects like Arcadocypriot Greek and Aeolic Greek didn't.[27] The Germanic peoples adopted the word Greeks with a k instead of a g sound, because the similarity of the sound of the Latin name Graeci by that time.[28][29] (Goth. Kreks, Old High German, Grieche, OHG pl Griohhan, O(GL) Griechs, Old Norse Grekar)[30] (see also list of IN words for Hellenic peoples). According to an alternative theory the proto-form of Γραικός is supposed to be the result of the root of " Νεμοριάς - Nemorías"[29]

text_human: Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the islands at the beginning of the 1st millennium AD. Much of Brittonic-controlled Britain was conquered by the Roman Empire from AD 43. The first Anglo-Saxons arrived as Roman power waned in the 5th century and eventually dominated the bulk of what is now England. Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements and political change—particularly in England. The subsequent Norman conquest of England in 1066 and the later Angevin partial conquest of Ireland from 1169 led to the imposition of a new Norman ruling elite across much of Britain and parts of Ireland. By the Late Middle Ages, Great Britain was separated into the Kingdoms of England and Scotland, while control in Ireland fluxed between Gaelic kingdoms, Hiberno-Norman lords and the English-dominated Lordship of Ireland, soon restricted only to The Pale. The 1603 Union of the Crowns, Acts of Union 1707 and Acts of Union 1800 attempted to consolidate Britain and Ireland into a single political unit, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, with the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands remaining as Crown Dependencies. The expansion of the British Empire and migrations following the Irish Famine and Highland Clearances resulted in the distribution of the islands' population and culture throughout the world and a rapid de-population of Ireland in the second half of the 19th century. Most of Ireland seceded from the United Kingdom after the Irish War of Independence and the subsequent Anglo-Irish Treaty (1919–1922), with six counties remaining in the UK as Northern Ireland.
text_ai_base: At the start of the 1st millennium AD, the islands were inhabited by the Hiberni tribes of Ireland, the Picts of northern Britain, and the Britons of southern Britain, all speaking Insular Celtic languages. From AD 43, the Romans began conquering much of Britain controlled by the Britons. As Roman power declined in the 5th century, the first Anglo-Saxons arrived and eventually dominated most of what is now England. The Vikings began invading in the 9th century, leading to more lasting settlements and major political shifts, especially in England. The Norman conquest of England in 1066 and the partial conquest of Ireland by the Angevins from 1169 introduced a new Norman elite ruling much of Britain and parts of Ireland. By the Late Middle Ages, Great Britain was divided into the kingdoms of England and Scotland, while control in Ireland shifted among Gaelic kingdoms, Hiberno-Norman lords, and the English-controlled Lordship of Ireland, which soon dwindled to just The Pale. Efforts to unify Britain and Ireland into one political entity resulted in the 1603 Union of the Crowns, Acts of Union 1707, and Acts of Union 1800, forming the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, with the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands as Crown Dependencies. Migration driven by the expansion of the British Empire, the Irish Famine, and the Highland Clearances dispersed the population and culture globally and led to significant depopulation in Ireland during the late 19th century. The Irish War of Independence and the Anglo-Irish Treaty (1919–1922) led most of Ireland to secede from the United Kingdom, leaving six counties as Northern Ireland within the UK.
text_ai_humanized: At the start of the 1st millennia, Great Britain and Ireland were inhabited by the Hiberni, the Picts and the Britons, all speaking Insular Celtic. Much of Brittonic controlled Britain was gradually conquered by the Romans from AD 43. With the collapse of Roman control in the 5th century, the Anglo-Saxons soon occupied most of Britain which would become England. Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements and political change, particularly in England. The Norman conquest of England in 1066 and the subsequent conquest of large parts of Ireland by the Anglo-Normans introduced a new Anglo-Norman ruling élite across much of Britain and parts of Ireland. By the Late Middle Ages, Great Britain was separated into the Kingdoms of England and Scotland, whilst control in Ireland fluxed between Gaelic kingdoms, Hiberno-Norman lords and the English-dominated Lordship of Ireland, soon restricted to The Pale. The subsequent formation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland in the 18th and 19th century united the entire British Isles under one state, clearly defined with the Two Acts of Union as well as the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands being Crown Dependencies. Immigration to the United Kingdom under British rule and the Great Famine, Highland Clearances and the colonization and mutiny of British India, spread the British people and culture across the globe and brought many non-British peoples to inhabit the British Isles. Irish and British culture, as well as the population, was reshaped. Waves of migration to Ireland in the Middle Ages, as well as the Ulster Plantation, resulted in populations which either came from Britain or adopted the English language. Northern Ireland is still sparsely inhabited and heavily urbanised, most notably in the Belfast Metropolitan Area. Economic changes following the Irish famine produced a large Irish diaspora. The Highland Clearances significantly reduced the population in many rural Scottish areas. Responding to Irish political autonomy, the Anglo-Irish Treaty and the formation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland created the situation where, with the exception of the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands, there are now two sovereign states in the British Isles.

text_human: The era saw Libya's return to the international arena. In 1999, Libya began secret talks with the British government to normalise relations. In 2001, Gaddafi condemned the September 11 attacks on the U.S. by al-Qaeda, expressing sympathy with the victims and calling for Libyan involvement in the War on Terror against militant Islamism. His government continued suppressing domestic Islamism, at the same time as Gaddafi called for the wider application of sharia law. Libya also cemented connections with China and North Korea, being visited by Chinese President Jiang Zemin in April 2002. Influenced by the events of the Iraq War, in December 2003, Libya renounced its possession of weapons of mass destruction, decommissioning its chemical and nuclear weapons programs. Relations with the U.S. improved as a result, while UK Prime Minister Tony Blair met with Gaddafi in the Libyan desert in March 2004. The following month, Gaddafi travelled to the headquarters of the European Union (EU) in Brussels, signifying improved relations between Libya and the EU, the latter ending its remaining sanctions in October. In October 2010, the EU paid Libya €50 million to stop African migrants passing into Europe; Gaddafi encouraged the move, saying that it was necessary to prevent the loss of European cultural identity to a new "Black Europe". Removed from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism in 2006, Gaddafi nevertheless continued his anti-western rhetoric, and at the Second Africa-South America Summit in Venezuela in September 2009, joined Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez in calling for an "anti-imperialist" front across Africa and Latin America. Gaddafi proposed the establishment of a South Atlantic Treaty Organization to rival NATO. That month he also addressed the United Nations General Assembly in New York for the first time, using it to condemn "western aggression". In Spring 2010, Gaddafi proclaimed jihad against Switzerland after Swiss police accused two of his family members of criminal activity in the country, resulting in the breakdown of bilateral relations.
text_ai_base: During this era, Libya reemerged on the international stage. In 1999, Libya began secret negotiations with the British government to restore diplomatic relations. In 2001, Gaddafi denounced the September 11 attacks in the U.S. by al-Qaeda, expressed sympathy for the victims, and advocated for Libya’s participation in the War on Terror against militant Islamism. His government continued to suppress domestic Islamism while Gaddafi simultaneously called for broader implementation of sharia law. Libya strengthened ties with China and North Korea, with Chinese President Jiang Zemin visiting in April 2002. Influenced by the Iraq War’s outcomes, Libya renounced its weapons of mass destruction in December 2003, dismantling its chemical and nuclear programs. As relations with the U.S. improved, UK Prime Minister Tony Blair met with Gaddafi in the Libyan desert in March 2004. A month later, Gaddafi visited the European Union headquarters in Brussels, marking better relations with the EU, which ended remaining sanctions against Libya in October. In October 2010, the EU compensated Libya €50 million to curb African migrant arrivals in Europe; Gaddafi supported the initiative, claiming it was essential to preserving European cultural identity from becoming a “Black Europe.” Removed from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism in 2006, Gaddafi persisted with anti-western rhetoric. At the Second Africa-South America Summit in Venezuela in September 2009, he joined Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez in advocating an "anti-imperialist" alliance across Africa and Latin America, proposing a South Atlantic Treaty Organization to rival NATO. That same month, he addressed the United Nations General Assembly in New York for the first time, condemning "western aggression." In Spring 2010, Gaddafi declared jihad against Switzerland after Swiss police accused two of his family members of crimes, leading to a breakdown in diplomatic relations.
text_ai_humanized: In this period Libya returned to the international scene—private Libyan–British negotiations began to resume full diplomatic relations in 1999. In 2001, Gaddafi condemned the September 11 attacks in the US by al-Qaeda,[286] and in October offered the U.S. and its allies assistance against al-Qaeda; he called for Libyan participation in the War on Terror and criticized Arab countries who opposed the US-led 2003 invasion of Iraq.[287] His position as an anti-Islamist[276] allowed him to foster closer links with western nations;[288] Islamists denounced him as the "enemy of Allah".[289] His intelligence agencies began sharing information with the U.S., with Gaddafi praising George W. Bush.[290] At the same time he wanted the West to adopt sharia law.[291] Gaddafi also continued efforts to encourage the spread of Islam into Europe, and, rejecting the view that Islam was inherently opposed to western culture, maintained that there was no contradiction between the two.[292][293] Libya expanded cooperation with China, and in April 2002 Gaddafi visited Beijing.[294] In 2003, Libya opened up negotiations with the United Kingdom and the United States over its chemical weapons program and nuclear program, and in December announced that it had renounced all weapons of mass destruction.[288] Expecting U.N. sanctions to be lifted, in March 2004 Gaddafi purchased a $170,000 Libyan country house in Englefield Green, Surrey, through a British-based company;[295] after protests, it was sold in April 2012.[296] Blair publicly met with Gaddafi in the Libyan desert in March 2004;[297] in the 2000s Blair visited Gaddafi more than any other world leader.[298] In 2004, Gaddafi travelled to the headquarters of the European Union (EU) in Brussels—signalling improved relations between Libya and the EU—accompanied by Berbers in traditional dress and brandishing swords to reflect his love of African culture. In Brussels, he advocated a common market of the African–EU partnership.[299][300] Relations with the EU improved further, and in October the EU abolished all remaining sanctions against Libya.[301] In October 2010, the EU paid Libya over €50 million to stop African migrants entering Europe;[302] Gaddafi had praised the anti-immigration measures, asserting that "If Europe does not pay for stopping African immigration, Europe will become black, it will be overcome by people with different religions."[303][304] In 2006, Gaddafi's government had been removed from the US list of state sponsors of terrorism.[305] Continuing his pan-African efforts, in August 2008 Gaddafi was proclaimed "King of Kings" by a committee of traditional African leaders.[306] In September 2009, Libya chaired the 64th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York City; Gaddafi attended, and addressed the General Assembly.[307] Following the First Libyan Civil War, some commentators said that the international community's relationship with Gaddafi was an obstacle to intervention and change in Egypt and Libya.[308][309] Gaddafi continued his anti-western rhetoric; at the Second Africa–South America Summit, held in Venezuela in September 2009, he called for an "anti-imperialist" front across Africa and Latin America, proclaiming that he was in "a battle against America in Latin America itself" and urging a "South Atlantic Treaty Organization" in rivalry to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.[310][311] During the summit he joined Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez in calling for NATO member states to be tried in the International Criminal Court for the 2002 killing of Ibrahim al-Hamidi,[312] a prominent Libyan journalist.[313] In September 2009, Gaddafi addressed the United Nations General Assembly in New York City for the first time.[314] In spring 2010, Gaddafi declared jihid on Switzerland after Swiss police accused two of his family members of crimes, two states cut off diplomatic relations.[315]

at the Second Africa–South America Summit, held in Venezuela in September 2009, he called for an "anti-imperialist" front across Africa and Latin America, proclaiming that he was in "a battle against America in Latin America itself" and urging a "South Atlantic Treaty Organization" in rivalry to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.[310][311] During the summit he joined Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez in calling for NATO member states to be tried in the International Criminal Court for the 2002 killing of Ibrahim al-Hamidi,[312] a prominent Libyan journalist.[313] In September 2009, Gaddafi addressed the United Nations General Assembly in New York City for the first time.[314] In spring 2010, Gaddafi declared jihid on Switzerland after Swiss police accused two of his family members of crimes, two states cut off diplomatic relations.[315]

text_human: President Truman, symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president, again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat. It was at this time that Eisenhower voiced his disagreements with the Democratic party and declared himself and his family to be Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement in the Republican Party persuaded him to declare his candidacy in the 1952 presidential election to counter the candidacy of non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. The effort was a long struggle; Eisenhower had to be convinced that political circumstances had created a genuine duty for him to offer himself as a candidate, and that there was a mandate from the populace for him to be their President. Henry Cabot Lodge, who served as his campaign manager, and others succeeded in convincing him, and in June 1952 he resigned his command at NATO to campaign full-time. Eisenhower defeated Taft for the nomination, having won critical delegate votes from Texas. Eisenhower's campaign was noted for the simple but effective slogan, "I Like Ike". It was essential to his success that Eisenhower express opposition to Roosevelt's policy at Yalta and against Truman's policies in Korea and China—matters in which he had once participated. In defeating Taft for the nomination, it became necessary for Eisenhower to appease the right wing Old Guard of the Republican Party; his selection of Richard M. Nixon as the Vice-President on the ticket was designed in part for that purpose. Nixon also provided a strong anti-communist presence as well as some youth to counter Ike's more advanced age.
text_ai_base: In 1951, President Truman, reflecting widespread support for an Eisenhower presidency, urged him once again to run for office as a Democrat. However, Eisenhower expressed his disagreements with the Democratic Party at that time, announcing that he and his family were Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement within the Republican Party convinced him to run in the 1952 presidential election to challenge non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. Persuading Eisenhower to enter the race required convincing him that the political climate demanded his candidacy and that there was popular support for him to become President. His campaign manager, Henry Cabot Lodge, along with others, managed to sway his decision, leading Eisenhower to resign from his NATO command in June 1952 to campaign full-time. Eisenhower eventually defeated Taft for the Republican nomination, pivotal to which was securing delegate votes from Texas. His campaign became famous for the straightforward yet powerful slogan, "I Like Ike." A critical aspect of his campaign was expressing opposition to Roosevelt's Yalta policies and Truman's actions in Korea and China—issues he had been involved in previously. To win over the conservative Old Guard of the Republican Party after defeating Taft, Eisenhower chose Richard M. Nixon as his Vice-Presidential running mate. Nixon added a strong anti-communist stance and youthful energy that complemented Eisenhower's seniority.
text_ai_humanized: Although much of the nation was eager for Eisenhower to run for president, Truman told Eisenhower in January 1951 that he "had to run as a Democrat", Eisenhower replied that it was "inconceivable!" and that he was "a Republican".[157] "I am and always have been a true Republican, and it is unthinkable to me to do anything that could possibly be construed otherwise", he wrote, Eisenhower then noted his disagreements with the contemporary party, while stating, "I am sure I said this over and over again in political discussions while I was at home."[158] By mid-1952, Eisenhower resigned his command at NATO to campaign full-time. He won a convincing victory in the general election that November. His campaign slogan was "I Like Ike." To appease the Old Guard of the Republican Party, who opposed Eisenhower, Nixon was selected as his Vice-President.

text_human: However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. This asymmetry is perceivable on account of two features: i) the relationship between the agent capacities of the human hand (i.e., what it is and is not capable of and what it is for) and non-animal agency (i.e., what floors are and are not capable of and what they are for) and ii) that the pieces of cup came to possess exactly the nature and number of those of a cup before assembling. In short, such asymmetry is attributable to the relationship between temporal direction on the one hand and the implications of form and functional capacity on the other.
text_ai_base: The asymmetry of causation can be observed in a tangible way, without resorting to metaphysical explanations, when a human hand drops a cup of water that shatters on a hard floor, causing the liquid to spill. In this sequence, the causes of the resulting pattern of shattered cup fragments and spilled water can be clearly traced to factors like the cup's trajectory, structural irregularities, and the angle of impact. However, if we imagine the event in reverse, it becomes challenging to explain how the scattered fragments would rise to the hand and reassemble into a cup, or how the spilled water would neatly return to the cup. The causes of such a reformation are not easily identified, as neither the hand nor the floor can achieve such a precise reassembly. This asymmetry arises from two key aspects: i) the capabilities of the human hand (what it can and cannot do) versus the properties of inanimate objects like floors, and ii) the pre-existing structure of the cup's fragments before they are reassembled. Essentially, this asymmetry highlights the relationship between the direction of time and the implications of form and function.
text_ai_humanized: This intimate relationship between the arrow of causation and time is not hypothetical and can be seen in the physical, without invoking the metaphysical, when a hand holding a cup of water drops the cup onto a hard floor, and the cup breaks and some water spills out: That an event happens only in the one direction (the cup breaking) and not the other (the fragments of the cup and the water rising from the floor to re-form the cup in the hand, without human assistance) is an asymmetry. That the asymmetry is between what is a detectable cause of the pattern of fragments into which the cup falls onto the hard floor (the trajectory of the cup and of its structural flaws and its angle of impact), and what are not detectable causes of the pattern of fragments (other influences, since nothing other than the trajectory and the flaws of the cup determine how it falls onto the hard floor) is a physical embodiment of the arrow of causation. That we cannot explain how the fragments of the cup rose into the hand like that, nor how the water re-entered the cup so, as we can explain how the cup broke when it was dropped, is also a physical embodiment of the asymmetry of causation. Where the causes of the cup breaking into a particular pattern of fragments when it was dropped are clear, the causes of the cup rising to re-form in the hand, and of the water returning to the cup, are not; the hand cannot arrange the fragments of the cup like that, and neither can the floor. In our invocation of what the hand can and cannot do, and of the effect of the cup impacting the floor at such and such an angle, and of the structure of the cup before it was dropped, we can see the source of the asymmetry: i) The potentials of the human hand versus the structure and function of the inanimate floor, and ii) the structure of the fragments of the cup before they are assembled in the reforming of the cup. The asymmetry, then, is between such an arrow of time and the implications of form and function.

text_human: The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps." In Silius Italicus, Virgil finds one of his most ardent admirers. With almost every line of his epic Punica Silius references Virgil. Indeed, Silius is known to have bought Virgil's tomb and worshipped the poet. Partially as a result of his so-called "Messianic" Fourth Eclogue—widely interpreted later to have predicted the birth of Jesus Christ—Virgil was in later antiquity imputed to have the magical abilities of a seer; the Sortes Vergilianae, the process of using Virgil's poetry as a tool of divination, is found in the time of Hadrian, and continued into the Middle Ages. In a similar vein Macrobius in the Saturnalia credits the work of Virgil as the embodiment of human knowledge and experience, mirroring the Greek conception of Homer. Virgil also found commentators in antiquity. Servius, a commentator of the 4th century AD, based his work on the commentary of Donatus. Servius' commentary provides us with a great deal of information about Virgil's life, sources, and references; however, many modern scholars find the variable quality of his work and the often simplistic interpretations frustrating.
text_ai_base: From their very publication, the works of Virgil revolutionized Latin poetry. His Eclogues, Georgics, and especially the Aeneid became essential texts in the educational curriculum that all educated Romans knew well. Poets who followed Virgil often referenced his work intertextually to enrich their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid, for instance, parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of Aeneas's story in the Metamorphoses Book 14—often called the "mini-Aeneid"—is an important example of how poets responded to Virgil's epic style. Lucan's Bellum Civile is regarded as an anti-Virgilian epic, as it omits divine intervention and focuses on historical events, markedly diverging from Virgilian epic conventions. The Flavian poet Statius, in his 12-book epic Thebaid, closely engages with Virgil's poetry. In his epilogue, he warns his poem not to compete with the divine Aeneid, but to respectfully follow and venerate it. Silius Italicus was one of Virgil's most devoted admirers. In his epic Punica, nearly every line references Virgil. He reportedly bought Virgil's tomb and revered him greatly. Virgil's "Messianic" Fourth Eclogue, later interpreted as predicting Jesus Christ's birth, contributed to his reputation in later antiquity as a seer. The practice of Sortes Vergilianae—using Virgil's poetry for divination—dates back to Hadrian's time and continued into the Middle Ages. Macrobius, in his Saturnalia, viewed Virgil's work as embodying human knowledge and experience, akin to the Greek perception of Homer. Virgil also attracted ancient commentators, such as the 4th-century Servius, who based his commentary on the works of Donatus. Servius' writings offer valuable insights into Virgil's life, sources, and allusions, although modern scholars often find his interpretations inconsistent and overly simplistic.
text_ai_humanized: Virgil's work has had wide and deep influence on Western literature, most notably Dante's Divine Comedy, in which Virgil appears as Dante's guide through hell and purgatory. In English literature his influence is most apparent in the works of Edmund Spenser and John Milton. Some phrases of Virgil have become proverbial in the English language, including "labor of love" (amor vincit omnia), "Time flies" (fugit inreparabile tempus), and "Love conquers all" (omnia vincit amor).[148]

text_human: In 680 Ibn al-Zubayr fled Medina for Mecca. Hearing about Husayn's opposition to Yazid I, the people of Kufa sent to Husayn asking him to take over with their support. Al-Husayn sent his cousin Muslim bin Agail to verify if they would rally behind him. When the news reached Yazid I, he sent Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad, ruler of Basrah, with the instruction to prevent the people of Kufa rallying behind Al-Husayn. Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad managed to disperse the crowd that gathered around Muslim bin Agail and captured him. Realizing Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad had been instructed to prevent Husayn from establishing support in Kufa, Muslim bin Agail requested a message to be sent to Husayn to prevent his immigration to Kufa. The request was denied and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad killed Muslim bin Agail. While Ibn al-Zubayr would stay in Mecca until his death, Husayn decided to travel on to Kufa with his family, unaware of the lack of support there. Husayn and his family were intercepted by Yazid I's forces led by Amru bin Saad, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim, who fought Al-Husayn and his male family members until they were killed. There were 200 people in Husayn's caravan, many of whom were women, including his sisters, wives, daughters and their children. The women and children from Husayn's camp were taken as prisoners of war and led back to Damascus to be presented to Yazid I. They remained imprisoned until public opinion turned against him as word of Husayn's death and his family's capture spread. They were then granted passage back to Medina. The sole adult male survivor from the caravan was Ali ibn Husayn who was with fever too ill to fight when the caravan was attacked.
text_ai_base: In 680, Ibn al-Zubayr fled Medina for Mecca. Meanwhile, the people of Kufa, hearing about Husayn's opposition to Yazid I, invited Husayn to lead them with their support. Husayn sent his cousin, Muslim bin Aqil, to confirm their intentions. However, when Yazid I learned of this, he dispatched Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad, the ruler of Basrah, to thwart Husayn’s support in Kufa. Ubayd-Allah successfully dispersed the crowd gathered around Muslim bin Aqil and captured him. Realizing Ubayd-Allah's orders were to prevent Husayn from gaining a foothold in Kufa, Muslim bin Aqil attempted to send a warning to Husayn advising against his journey to Kufa. Unfortunately, this message was intercepted, and Ubayd-Allah executed Muslim bin Aqil. While Ibn al-Zubayr remained in Mecca until his death, Husayn proceeded to Kufa with his family, unaware of the lack of support awaiting him. Husayn and his family were intercepted by Yazid I's forces led by Amru bin Saad, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim. They fought Husayn and his male relatives until they were killed. The caravan consisted of 200 people, many of whom were women, including Husayn's sisters, wives, daughters, and their children. The women and children were taken prisoner and brought to Damascus to face Yazid I. They remained imprisoned until public opinion turned against Yazid as news of Husayn's death and the capture of his family spread. Eventually, they were allowed to return to Medina. The only adult male survivor from the caravan was Ali ibn Husayn, who was too ill with fever to fight during the attack.
text_ai_humanized: So Ibn al-Zubayr left Medina and went to Mecca in 680. In the meantime the people in the city of Kufa in Iraq asked Husayn to rebel against Yazd I and offered their support. Husayn sent his cousin Muslim bin Aqil to make sure that these people really wanted his leadership. Yazid I was told about this request so he sent the ruler of Basrah, Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad to diffuse Husayn support in Kufa. Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad managed to disburse the people who gathered around Muslim bin Aqil and he arrested him. Muslim knew that Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad was asked by Yazid I to prevent Husayn from getting support in Kufa, so he thought of sending word to warn Husayn not to go to Kufa. Unfortunately that message never reached Husayn and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad killed Muslim bin Aqil. Even though Ibn al-Zubayr stayed in Mecca until he died, Husayn went with his family to Kufa where he had no support. Husayn with his family and kin were intercepted by Yazid I soldiers lead by Amru bin Saad bin Abi Waqas, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim. Those men fought Husayn and other male members of his family in the caravan until they killed them. That caravan had 200 people out of which many were women (husayn sisters, wives, daughters and their babies). Those women's and their babies were captured and taken to Dimashiq (Damascus) to the Yazid I. They were then kept in prison until people in Damascus started cursing Yazid I when they knew about Husayn death and the capture of his family. Then those people were let go and returned to Medina. The only grownup male survivor out of that caravan was Ali the son of Husayn who was gravely ill with fever and was unable to participate in battle during the attack.

text_human: Anthropologists such as C. Loring Brace, the philosophers Jonathan Kaplan and Rasmus Winther, and the geneticist Joseph Graves,[page needed] have argued that while there it is certainly possible to find biological and genetic variation that corresponds roughly to the groupings normally defined as "continental races", this is true for almost all geographically distinct populations. The cluster structure of the genetic data is therefore dependent on the initial hypotheses of the researcher and the populations sampled. When one samples continental groups, the clusters become continental; if one had chosen other sampling patterns, the clustering would be different. Weiss and Fullerton have noted that if one sampled only Icelanders, Mayans and Maoris, three distinct clusters would form and all other populations could be described as being clinally composed of admixtures of Maori, Icelandic and Mayan genetic materials. Kaplan and Winther therefore argue that, seen in this way, both Lewontin and Edwards are right in their arguments. They conclude that while racial groups are characterized by different allele frequencies, this does not mean that racial classification is a natural taxonomy of the human species, because multiple other genetic patterns can be found in human populations that crosscut racial distinctions. Moreover, the genomic data underdetermines whether one wishes to see subdivisions (i.e., splitters) or a continuum (i.e., lumpers). Under Kaplan and Winther's view, racial groupings are objective social constructions (see Mills 1998 ) that have conventional biological reality only insofar as the categories are chosen and constructed for pragmatic scientific reasons. In earlier work, Winther had identified "diversity partitioning" and "clustering analysis" as two separate methodologies, with distinct questions, assumptions, and protocols. Each is also associated with opposing ontological consequences vis-a-vis the metaphysics of race.
text_ai_base: Anthropologists like C. Loring Brace, along with philosophers Jonathan Kaplan and Rasmus Winther, and geneticist Joseph Graves, have suggested that while biological and genetic variation can indeed align with what are traditionally called "continental races," this pattern is observable in almost all geographically distinct populations. The way genetic data clusters is largely influenced by researchers' initial hypotheses and the populations they sample. For example, when continental groups are sampled, the resulting clusters are continental in nature. Different sampling methods would produce different clusters. Weiss and Fullerton point out that if only Icelanders, Mayans, and Maoris were sampled, three distinct genetic clusters would emerge, and other populations could be described as mixtures of these three groups. Kaplan and Winther argue that, from this perspective, both Lewontin and Edwards are correct in their discussions. They conclude that, although racial groups are identified by varying allele frequencies, this doesn't imply that racial classification is a natural categorization of humans, because numerous genetic patterns exist that go beyond racial distinctions. Additionally, genomic data does not decisively determine whether one prefers subdivisions (splitters) or a continuum (lumpers). According to Kaplan and Winther, racial groupings are objective social constructs that possess biological significance only when categories are intentionally selected and constructed for scientific purposes. In previous research, Winther distinguished between "diversity partitioning" and "clustering analysis" as two separate methodologies, each with its own questions, assumptions, and protocols, leading to different ontological implications regarding the nature of race.
text_ai_humanized: In this regard, anthropologists such as C. Loring Brace, philosophers Jonathan Kaplan and Rasmus Winther, and geneticist Joseph Graves have argued that biological and genetic variation do indeed fall along "lines" that can be construed as corresponding to traditional "continental race" groupings, but that this is true for almost all geographic regions that one may arbitrarily choose. Which genetic distance data is produced and which population "clusters" emerge is dependent on which populations are sampled. When one samples continentally, one produces continental clusters. Sampling differently would produce different clusters. Weiss and Fullerton argue that if Icelanders, Mayans, and Maoris are sampled, three clusters will emerge, and that those three clusters will be more like Icelanders, Mayans, and Maoris than Icelanders are like Mayans. They argued that if one sampled Icelanders, Kurds, and Maoris, one would find that populations are composed of Icelanders, Kurds, and Maoris, and so on. Kaplan & Winther therefore conclude: We believe that both Lewontin (i. e. , L. L. C. ) and Edwards (E. D. ) are right in important ways. Edwards is correct that racial groups may be characterized by different allele frequencies, but Lewontin is also right to argue that racial classification is not furthered by scientific discovery because there are multiple different patterns which extend far beyond racial classifications… The existence of patterns does not settle the question of whether one is a splitter (e. g. , dividing the "Caucasian" cluster into "Nordic" and "Mediterranean" clusters), or a lumper. … Races may only be objective social constructs, but social constructs nonetheless, categories into which the patterns of genetic data may be provisionally fitted only if researchers deem there are good scientific reasons to do so. In earlier work, "how to think about genetic data," Winther further discusses "diversity partitioning" and "clustering analysis" as two alternative means to operationalize one's ontology, that is, categories such as race, with significantly differing questions, assumptions, and protocols, and interest-relative differing results.

text_human: On release, Twilight Princess was considered to be the greatest Zelda game ever made by many critics including writers for 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN and The Washington Post. Game Informer called it "so creative that it rivals the best that Hollywood has to offer". GamesRadar praised Twilight Princess as "a game that deserves nothing but the absolute highest recommendation". Cubed3 hailed Twilight Princess as "the single greatest videogame experience". Twilight Princess's graphics were praised for the art style and animation, although the game was designed for the GameCube, which is technically lacking compared to the next generation consoles. Both IGN and GameSpy pointed out the existence of blurry textures and low-resolution characters. Despite these complaints, Computer and Video Games felt the game's atmosphere was superior to that of any previous Zelda game, and regarded Twilight Princess's Hyrule as the best version ever created. PALGN praised the game's cinematics, noting that "the cutscenes are the best ever in Zelda games". Regarding the Wii version, GameSpot's Jeff Gerstmann said the Wii controls felt "tacked-on", although 1UP.com said the remote-swinging sword attacks were "the most impressive in the entire series". Gaming Nexus considered Twilight Princess's soundtrack to be the best of this generation, though IGN criticized its MIDI-formatted songs for lacking "the punch and crispness" of their orchestrated counterparts. Hyper's Javier Glickman commended the game for its "very long quests, superb Wii controls and being able to save anytime". However, he criticised it for "no voice acting, no orchestral score and slightly outdated graphics".
text_ai_base: Upon its release, Twilight Princess was hailed by many critics as the greatest Zelda game ever made, with endorsements from publications like 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN, and The Washington Post. Game Informer described it as "so creative that it rivals the best that Hollywood has to offer." GamesRadar gave Twilight Princess the "absolute highest recommendation," while Cubed3 declared it "the single greatest videogame experience." The game's graphics, praised for their art style and animation, were developed for the GameCube, not as advanced as next-gen consoles. Even so, both IGN and GameSpy noted issues like blurry textures and low-resolution characters. Despite these criticisms, Computer and Video Games lauded the game's atmosphere as the best among Zelda titles, considering Twilight Princess's Hyrule the finest rendition yet. PALGN complimented the cinematics, calling the cutscenes "the best ever in Zelda games." In terms of the Wii version, GameSpot's Jeff Gerstmann felt the controls seemed "tacked-on," whereas 1UP.com admired the remote-swinging sword attacks as "the most impressive in the entire series." Gaming Nexus praised Twilight Princess's soundtrack as the best of this generation, though IGN found fault with the MIDI-formatted tracks for lacking "the punch and crispness" of orchestrated versions. Hyper's Javier Glickman applauded the game for its "very long quests, superb Wii controls, and the ability to save anytime," but criticized its lack of "voice acting, orchestral score, and slightly outdated graphics."

Similarly, Cubed3 gave the game its highest possible rating, stating that it "has managed to epitomize what makes a perfect game [...] one of the single greatest videogame experiences you will ever have."[44] Edge summarized that, although Twilight Princess "with its often archaic structure and lacking presentation, will not be the greatest game of all time", it "is the greatest version of Hyrule, and the most worthy of being called a legend."[50] Although Twilight Princess' graphics were not as advanced as those for other next-generation titles at its release, as the game was developed for the GameCube, they were praised for their art style and animation, while both IGN and GameSpy agreed that they appeared "embellished" on the Wii.[26][51] In addition, they were disappointed with the blurry, low-resolution textures of the characters and environments.
