In addition, some found the audio unmemorable and lackluster while others disagreed as stated above. Hyper's Javier Glickman commended the game for its "very long quests, fantastic Wii controls, and saving at any time," but criticized it for having "no voice acting, orchestral score, slightly dated graphics."

text_human: Japan: The event was held in Nagano, which hosted the 1998 Winter Olympics, on April 26. Japanese Buddhist temple Zenkō-ji, which was originally scheduled to be the starting point for the Olympic torch relay in Nagano, refused to host the torch and pulled out of the relay plans, amid speculation that monks there sympathized with anti-Chinese government protesters. as well as the risk of disruption by violent protests. Parts of Zenkō-ji temple's main building (Zenkō-ji Hondō), reconstructed in 1707 and one of the National Treasures of Japan, was then vandalized with spraypaint. A new starting point, previously the site of a municipal building and now a parking lot, was chosen by the city. An event the city had planned to hold at the Minami Nagano Sports Park following the torch relay was also canceled out of concern about disruptions caused by demonstrators protesting against China's recent crackdown in Tibet. Thousands of riot police were mobilized to protect the torch along its route. The show of force kept most protesters in check, but slogans shouted by pro-China or pro-Tibet demonstrators, Japanese nationalists, and human rights organizations flooded the air. Five men were arrested and four injured amidst scenes of mob violence. The torch route was packed with mostly peaceful demonstrators. The public was not allowed at the parking lot where the relay started. After the Zenkoji monks held a prayer ceremony for victims of the recent events in Tibet. More than 100 police officers ran with the torch and riot police lined the streets while three helicopters flew above. Only two Chinese guards were allowed to accompany the torch because of Japan's concern over their treatment of demonstrators at previous relays. A man with a Tibetan flag tried to stop the torch at the beginning of the relay but was dragged off by police. Some raw eggs were also thrown from the crowd.

Subsequently, part of Zenkō-ji's main building (Zenkō-ji Hondō), a National Treasure of Japan reconstructed in 1707, was vandalized with spray paint. The city selected a new starting location, a site that used to be a municipal building and is now a parking lot. An event planned at the Minami Nagano Sports Park after the relay was canceled over fears of interruptions from demonstrators protesting China's recent actions in Tibet. Thousands of riot police were deployed to safeguard the torch along its route. Although the heavy police presence kept most disturbances in check, various groups, including pro-China and pro-Tibet demonstrators, Japanese nationalists, and human rights activists, filled the air with shouted slogans. Five people were arrested and four injured amidst mob violence. The torch route was lined mostly with peaceful protesters, but the public was barred from the parking lot starting point. The Zenkoji monks held a prayer ceremony for victims of the recent events in Tibet. Over 100 police officers escorted the torch, with riot police guarding the streets and three helicopters overhead. Only two Chinese guards accompanied the torch due to Japan's concerns over their handling of demonstrators at previous relays. A man brandishing a Tibetan flag attempted to obstruct the relay's start but was swiftly removed by police. Some raw eggs were also hurled from the crowd.

text_human: In the 15th century the dome was added and the naves extended back of the choir, uniting the building to the tower and forming a main entrance. Archbishop Luis Alfonso de los Cameros began the building of the main chapel in 1674; the walls were decorated with marbles and bronzes in the Baroque style of that period. At the beginning of the 18th century the German Conrad Rudolphus built the façade of the main entrance. The other two doors lead into the transept; one, that of the Apostles in pure pointed Gothic, dates from the 14th century, the other is that of the Paláu. The additions made to the back of the cathedral detract from its height. The 18th-century restoration rounded the pointed arches, covered the Gothic columns with Corinthian pillars, and redecorated the walls. The dome has no lantern, its plain ceiling being pierced by two large side windows. There are four chapels on either side, besides that at the end and those that open into the choir, the transept, and the sanctuary. It contains many paintings by eminent artists. A silver reredos, which was behind the altar, was carried away in the war of 1808, and converted into coin to meet the expenses of the campaign. There are two paintings by Francisco Goya in the San Francesco chapel. Behind the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament is a small Renaissance chapel built by Calixtus III. Beside the cathedral is the chapel dedicated to the Our Lady of the Forsaken (Virgen de los desamparados or Mare de Déu dels Desamparats).

text_human: However, all of these facets of medieval university life are considered by standard scholarship to be independent medieval European developments with no tracable Islamic influence. Generally, some reviewers have pointed out the strong inclination of Makdisi of overstating his case by simply resting on "the accumulation of close parallels", but all the while failing to point to convincing channels of transmission between the Muslim and Christian world. Norman Daniel points out that the Arab equivalent of the Latin disputation, the taliqa, was reserved for the ruler's court, not the madrasa, and that the actual differences between Islamic fiqh and medieval European civil law were profound. The taliqa only reached Islamic Spain, the only likely point of transmission, after the establishment of the first medieval universities. In fact, there is no Latin translation of the taliqa and, most importantly, no evidence of Latin scholars ever showing awareness of Arab influence on the Latin method of disputation, something they would have certainly found noteworthy. Rather, it was the medieval reception of the Greek Organon which set the scholastic sic et non in motion. Daniel concludes that resemblances in method had more to with the two religions having "common problems: to reconcile the conflicting statements of their own authorities, and to safeguard the data of revelation from the impact of Greek philosophy"; thus Christian scholasticism and similar Arab concepts should be viewed in terms of a parallel occurrence, not of the transmission of ideas from one to the other, a view shared by Hugh Kennedy.

Consequently, Christian scholasticism and similar Arab ideas should be seen as parallel occurrences rather than ideas transmitted from one to the other, a view supported by Hugh Kennedy.

text_human: The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were hardly noticed by the fans when compared to that of Luís Figo, then club vice-captain. Figo had become a cult hero, and was considered by Catalans to be one of their own. However, Barcelona fans were distraught by Figo's decision to join arch-rivals Real Madrid, and, during subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was given an extremely hostile reception. Upon his first return, a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey were thrown at him from the crowd. The next three years saw the club in decline, and managers came and went. van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer who, despite an extensive investment in players in the summer of 2000, presided over a mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, and was eventually dismissed late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed as his replacement, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to at least steer the club to the last Champions League spot on the final day of the season. Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as a long-term solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. What followed, despite another decent Champions League performance, was one of the worst La Liga campaigns in the club's history, with the team as low as 15th in February 2003. This led to van Gaal's resignation and replacement for the rest of the campaign by Radomir Antić, though a sixth-place finish was the best that he could manage. At the end of the season, Antić's short-term contract was not renewed, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his position having been made completely untenable by such a disastrous season on top of the club's overall decline in fortunes since he became president three years prior.
text_ai_base: Compared to the departure of Luís Figo, the exits of Núñez and van Gaal barely registered with fans. Figo, the club's vice-captain, was a beloved figure among Catalans, who viewed him as one of their own. Barcelona supporters were heartbroken by Figo's decision to join their fierce rivals, Real Madrid. During his subsequent visits to Camp Nou, he faced intense hostility, with fans even hurling a piglet's head and a bottle of whiskey at him during his first return. Over the next three years, the club struggled, with managers frequently changing. Van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer in 2000, who, despite heavy investment in new players, oversaw a lackluster league campaign and an early exit from the Champions League, leading to his dismissal later that season. Veteran coach Carles Rexach took over temporarily and managed to secure the final Champions League spot on the season's last day. Though Barcelona's form improved in La Liga and they reached the Champions League semi-finals under Rexach, he wasn't seen as a long-term fix. Louis van Gaal returned the following summer, but despite a decent Champions League showing, the club endured one of their worst La Liga campaigns, plummeting to 15th place by February 2003. Van Gaal resigned and was succeeded by Radomir Antić, who only managed a sixth-place finish. At the season's end, Antić's contract wasn't renewed, and club president Joan Gaspart, whose tenure had been marked by continued decline, resigned.

text_human: In 2009, IGN named the Xbox 360 the sixth-greatest video game console of all time, out of a field of 25. Although not the best-selling console of the seventh-generation, the Xbox 360 was deemed by TechRadar to be the most influential, by emphasizing digital media distribution and online gaming through Xbox Live, and by popularizing game achievement awards. PC Magazine considered the Xbox 360 the prototype for online gaming as it "proved that online gaming communities could thrive in the console space". Five years after the Xbox 360's original debut, the well-received Kinect motion capture camera was released, which set the record of being the fastest selling consumer electronic device in history, and extended the life of the console. Edge ranked Xbox 360 the second-best console of the 1993–2013 period, stating "It had its own social network, cross-game chat, new indie games every week, and the best version of just about every multiformat game...Killzone is no Halo and nowadays Gran Turismo is no Forza, but it's not about the exclusives—there's nothing to trump Naughty Dog's PS3 output, after all. Rather, it's about the choices Microsoft made back in the original Xbox's lifetime. The PC-like architecture meant those early EA Sports titles ran at 60fps compared to only 30 on PS3, Xbox Live meant every dedicated player had an existing friends list, and Halo meant Microsoft had the killer next-generation exclusive. And when developers demo games on PC now they do it with a 360 pad—another industry benchmark, and a critical one."

text_human: The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) party has usually been the status quo within American politics. The first parties were called Federalist and Republican, followed by a brief period of Republican dominance before a split occurred between National Republicans and Democratic Republicans. The former became the Whig Party and the latter became the Democratic Party. The Whigs survived only for two decades before they split over the spread of slavery, those opposed becoming members of the new Republican Party, as did anti-slavery members of the Democratic Party. Third parties (such as the Libertarian Party) often receive little support and are very rarely the victors in elections. Despite this, there have been several examples of third parties siphoning votes from major parties that were expected to win (such as Theodore Roosevelt in the election of 1912 and George Wallace in the election of 1968). As third party movements have learned, the Electoral College's requirement of a nationally distributed majority makes it difficult for third parties to succeed. Thus, such parties rarely win many electoral votes, although their popular support within a state may tip it toward one party or the other. Wallace had weak support outside the South. More generally, parties with a broad base of support across regions or among economic and other interest groups, have a great chance of winning the necessary plurality in the U.S.'s largely single-member district, winner-take-all elections. The tremendous land area and large population of the country are formidable challenges to political parties with a narrow appeal.

The National Republicans evolved into the Whig Party, while the Democratic Republicans became the Democratic Party. The Whigs lasted only two decades before splitting over the issue of slavery, with anti-slavery members joining the new Republican Party, including some from the Democratic Party. Third parties, such as the Libertarian Party, frequently garner minimal support and rarely win elections. Nonetheless, there have been instances where third parties have diverted votes from leading candidates, as seen with Theodore Roosevelt in 1912 and George Wallace in 1968. Third-party movements often struggle due to the Electoral College, which requires a nationally distributed majority for success. As a result, these parties rarely win electoral votes, though they can influence state outcomes. For instance, Wallace had limited support outside the South. Generally, parties with widespread regional backing or broad economic and interest group support have a better chance of securing the plurality needed in the U.S.'s primarily single-member district, winner-takes-all elections. The country's vast size and population pose significant challenges for parties with limited appeal.

text_human: Early recommendations for the quantity of water required for maintenance of good health suggested that 6–8 glasses of water daily is the minimum to maintain proper hydration. However the notion that a person should consume eight glasses of water per day cannot be traced to a credible scientific source. The original water intake recommendation in 1945 by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Research Council read: "An ordinary standard for diverse persons is 1 milliliter for each calorie of food. Most of this quantity is contained in prepared foods." More recent comparisons of well-known recommendations on fluid intake have revealed large discrepancies in the volumes of water we need to consume for good health. Therefore, to help standardize guidelines, recommendations for water consumption are included in two recent European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) documents (2010): (i) Food-based dietary guidelines and (ii) Dietary reference values for water or adequate daily intakes (ADI). These specifications were provided by calculating adequate intakes from measured intakes in populations of individuals with “desirable osmolarity values of urine and desirable water volumes per energy unit consumed.” For healthful hydration, the current EFSA guidelines recommend total water intakes of 2.0 L/day for adult females and 2.5 L/day for adult males. These reference values include water from drinking water, other beverages, and from food. About 80% of our daily water requirement comes from the beverages we drink, with the remaining 20% coming from food. Water content varies depending on the type of food consumed, with fruit and vegetables containing more than cereals, for example. These values are estimated using country-specific food balance sheets published by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. Other guidelines for nutrition also have implications for the beverages we consume for healthy hydration- for example, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommend that added sugars should represent no more than 10% of total energy intake.

Additionally, nutrition guidelines impact beverage choices for healthy hydration; for example, the World Health Organization (WHO) advises that added sugars should account for no more than 10% of total energy intake.

text_human: The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Elections in 2006 were again won by Rahmon (with 79% of the vote) and he began his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States claimed the elections were legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for its censorship and repression of the media. The OSCE claimed that the Tajik Government censored Tajik and foreign websites and instituted tax inspections on independent printing houses that led to the cessation of printing activities for a number of independent newspapers.

text_human: The biographical tradition asserts that Virgil began the hexameter Eclogues (or Bucolics) in 42 BC and it is thought that the collection was published around 39–38 BC, although this is controversial. The Eclogues (from the Greek for "selections") are a group of ten poems roughly modeled on the bucolic hexameter poetry ("pastoral poetry") of the Hellenistic poet Theocritus. After his victory in the Battle of Philippi in 42 BC, fought against the army led by the assassins of Julius Caesar, Octavian tried to pay off his veterans with land expropriated from towns in northern Italy, supposedly including, according to the tradition, an estate near Mantua belonging to Virgil. The loss of his family farm and the attempt through poetic petitions to regain his property have traditionally been seen as Virgil's motives in the composition of the Eclogues. This is now thought to be an unsupported inference from interpretations of the Eclogues. In Eclogues 1 and 9, Virgil indeed dramatizes the contrasting feelings caused by the brutality of the land expropriations through pastoral idiom, but offers no indisputable evidence of the supposed biographic incident. While some readers have identified the poet himself with various characters and their vicissitudes, whether gratitude by an old rustic to a new god (Ecl. 1), frustrated love by a rustic singer for a distant boy (his master's pet, Ecl. 2), or a master singer's claim to have composed several eclogues (Ecl. 5), modern scholars largely reject such efforts to garner biographical details from works of fiction, preferring to interpret an author's characters and themes as illustrations of contemporary life and thought. The ten Eclogues present traditional pastoral themes with a fresh perspective. Eclogues 1 and 9 address the land confiscations and their effects on the Italian countryside. 2 and 3 are pastoral and erotic, discussing both homosexual love (Ecl. 2) and attraction toward people of any gender (Ecl. 3). Eclogue 4, addressed to Asinius Pollio, the so-called "Messianic Eclogue" uses the imagery of the golden age in connection with the birth of a child (who the child was meant to be has been subject to debate). 5 and 8 describe the myth of Daphnis in a song contest, 6, the cosmic and mythological song of Silenus; 7, a heated poetic contest, and 10 the sufferings of the contemporary elegiac poet Cornelius Gallus. Virgil is credited[by whom?] in the Eclogues with establishing Arcadia as a poetic ideal that still resonates in Western literature and visual arts and setting the stage for the development of Latin pastoral by Calpurnius Siculus, Nemesianus, and later writers.
text_ai_base: According to biographical tradition, Virgil began composing the hexameter *Eclogues* (or *Bucolics*) in 42 BC, with the collection likely published around 39–38 BC, though this timing is debated. The *Eclogues*, meaning "selections" in Greek, consist of ten poems inspired by the pastoral hexameter poetry of Theocritus, a Hellenistic poet. After Octavian's triumph at the Battle of Philippi in 42 BC against the forces that assassinated Julius Caesar, he sought to compensate his veterans with land seized from northern Italian towns. Tradition suggests Virgil's own estate near Mantua was among these confiscated lands. As a result, it has long been believed that Virgil wrote the *Eclogues* to reclaim his lost family farm through poetic appeal, although this interpretation lacks strong evidence. In *Eclogues* 1 and 9, Virgil indeed captures the upheaval caused by land expropriations using pastoral themes but provides no definitive account of his personal experience in these events. Readers have sometimes linked the poet to his characters, whether it’s the grateful elder to a new god in *Eclogue 1*, a singer’s unrequited love in *Eclogue 2*, or a master singer’s claim in *Eclogue 5*. However, modern scholars dismiss attempts to extract biographical facts from fiction, opting to view these characters and themes as reflections of contemporary thought and daily life. The *Eclogues* blend traditional pastoral themes with new insights. *Eclogues* 1 and 9 focus on the impact of land seizures in Italy. *Eclogues* 2 and 3 weave pastoral and erotic themes, exploring homosexual love in *Eclogue 2* and broader romantic attraction in *Eclogue 3*. In *Eclogue 4*, dedicated to Asinius Pollio and often dubbed the "Messianic Eclogue," Virgil invokes imagery of a golden age tied to the birth of a child, sparking debate on the child’s identity. *Eclogues* 5 and 8 recount the myth of Daphnis in a singing contest, *Eclogue 6* features the cosmic song of Silenus, *Eclogue 7* presents a fervent poetic rivalry, and *Eclogue 10* reveals the struggles of the elegiac poet Cornelius Gallus. Virgil is credited with establishing Arcadia as an enduring poetic ideal in Western literature and arts, paving the way for the Latin pastoral tradition, later advanced by Calpurnius Siculus, Nemesianus, and subsequent writers.

Now scholars, they quit hunting biography hidden in fiction, just see characters and themes as plain mirrors of what folks think and live today. text_human: Initially, the Turkish Cypriots favoured the continuation of the British rule. However, they were alarmed by the Greek Cypriot calls for enosis as they saw the union of Crete with Greece, which led to the exodus of Cretan Turks, as a precedent to be avoided, and they took a pro-partition stance in response to the militant activity of EOKA. The Turkish Cypriots also viewed themselves as a distinct ethnic group of the island and believed in their having a separate right to self-determination from Greek Cypriots. Meanwhile, in the 1950s, Turkish leader Menderes considered Cyprus an "extension of Anatolia", rejected the partition of Cyprus along ethnic lines and favoured the annexation of the whole island to Turkey. Nationalistic slogans centred on the idea that "Cyprus is Turkish" and the ruling party declared Cyprus to be a part of the Turkish homeland that was vital to its security. Upon realising the fact that the Turkish Cypriot population was only 20% of the islanders made annexation unfeasible, the national policy was changed to favour partition. The slogan "Partition or Death" was frequently used in Turkish Cypriot and Turkish protests starting in the late 1950s and continuing throughout the 1960s. Although after the Zürich and London conferences Turkey seemed to accept the existence of the Cypriot state and to distance itself from its policy of favouring the partition of the island, the goal of the Turkish and Turkish Cypriot leaders remained that of creating an independent Turkish state in the northern part of the island.
text_ai_base: Initially, the Turkish Cypriots supported the continuation of British rule. They were, however, alarmed by the Greek Cypriot calls for enosis, recalling the precedent of Crete's union with Greece, which forced Cretan Turks to leave. In response to the militant actions of EOKA, they adopted a pro-partition stance. The Turkish Cypriots regarded themselves as a distinct ethnic group with a separate right to self-determination from the Greek Cypriots. During the 1950s, Turkey's leader, Menderes, saw Cyprus as an "extension of Anatolia," opposed dividing Cyprus along ethnic lines, and initially sought to annex the whole island to Turkey. Nationalist slogans, declaring "Cyprus is Turkish," emphasized that the island was a crucial part of Turkey's homeland and vital for its security. Recognizing the Turkish Cypriots made up only 20% of the island's population, making annexation impractical, national policy shifted toward favoring partition. The slogan "Partition or Death" became prevalent in Turkish Cypriot and Turkish protests from the late 1950s through the 1960s. Although after the Zürich and London conferences, Turkey seemed to accept Cyprus's existence as a state and distanced itself from preferring partition, the leaders still aimed to establish an independent Turkish state in the north of the island.

text_human: Throughout her career Madonna has been involved in writing and producing most of her own music. Madonna's early songwriting skill was developed during her time with the Breakfast Club in 1979. According to author Carol Gnojewski, her first attempts at songwriting are perceived as an important self-revelation, as Madonna said: "I don't know where [the songs] came from. It was like magic. I'd write a song every day. I said 'Wow, I was meant to do this'." Mark Kamins, her first producer, believed that Madonna is "a much underrated musician and lyricist." Rolling Stone has named her "an exemplary songwriter with a gift for hooks and indelible lyrics." According to Freya Jarman-Ivens, Madonna's talent for developing "incredible" hooks for her songs allows the lyrics to capture the attention of the audience, even without the influence of the music. As an example, Jarman-Ivens cites the 1985 single "Into the Groove" and its line "Live out your fantasy here with me, just let the music set you free; Touch my body, and move in time, now I know you're mine." Madonna's songwriting are often autobiographical over the years, dealing with various themes from love and relationships to self-respect and female empowerment. Her songs also speak about taboo and unconventional issues of their period, such as sexuality and AIDS on Erotica (1992). Many of her lyrics contain innuendos and double entendre, which lead to multiple interpretations among music critics and scholars. Madonna has been nominated for being inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame twice, for 2014 and 2016 ceremony. Rolling Stone listed Madonna at number 56 on the "100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time".

text_human: Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. Prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore minimize the influence of the Atlantic Ocean. The hottest month is July, with a mean temperature of 73.4 °F (23.0 °C). The coldest month is January, with a mean of 29.0 °F (−1.7 °C). Periods exceeding 90 °F (32 °C) in summer and below freezing in winter are not uncommon but rarely extended, with about 13 and 25 days per year seeing each, respectively. The most recent sub-0 °F (−18 °C) reading occurring on February 14, 2016 when the temperature dipped down to −9 °F (−23 °C), the coldest reading since 1957. In addition, several decades may pass between 100 °F (38 °C) readings, with the most recent such occurrence on July 22, 2011 when the temperature reached 103 °F (39 °C). The city's average window for freezing temperatures is November 9 through April 5.[c] Official temperature records have ranged from −18 °F (−28 °C) on February 9, 1934, up to 104 °F (40 °C) on July 4, 1911; the record cold daily maximum is 2 °F (−17 °C) on December 30, 1917, while, conversely, the record warm daily minimum is 83 °F (28 °C) on August 2, 1975.

text_human: Nevertheless, Makdisi has asserted that the European university borrowed many of its features from the Islamic madrasa, including the concepts of a degree and doctorate. Makdisi and Hugh Goddard have also highlighted other terms and concepts now used in modern universities which most likely have Islamic origins, including "the fact that we still talk of professors holding the 'Chair' of their subject" being based on the "traditional Islamic pattern of teaching where the professor sits on a chair and the students sit around him", the term 'academic circles' being derived from the way in which Islamic students "sat in a circle around their professor", and terms such as "having 'fellows', 'reading' a subject, and obtaining 'degrees', can all be traced back" to the Islamic concepts of aṣḥāb ('companions, as of Muhammad'), qirāʼah ('reading aloud the Qur'an') and ijāzah ('licence [to teach]') respectively. Makdisi has listed eighteen such parallels in terminology which can be traced back to their roots in Islamic education. Some of the practices now common in modern universities which Makdisi and Goddard trace back to an Islamic root include "practices such as delivering inaugural lectures, wearing academic robes, obtaining doctorates by defending a thesis, and even the idea of academic freedom are also modelled on Islamic custom." The Islamic scholarly system of fatwá and ijmāʻ, meaning opinion and consensus respectively, formed the basis of the "scholarly system the West has practised in university scholarship from the Middle Ages down to the present day." According to Makdisi and Goddard, "the idea of academic freedom" in universities was also "modelled on Islamic custom" as practised in the medieval Madrasa system from the 9th century. Islamic influence was "certainly discernible in the foundation of the first deliberately planned university" in Europe, the University of Naples Federico II founded by Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor in 1224.
text_ai_base: Makdisi argues that the European university adopted several features from the Islamic madrasa, such as the concepts of degrees and doctorates. Alongside Hugh Goddard, he notes other university terms and practices that likely have Islamic origins. For example, the notion of professors holding the "Chair" of their subject is rooted in the Islamic teaching style where professors sat on chairs surrounded by students—a precursor to our "academic circles" in which students gathered around their professor. The use of terms like "fellows," "reading" a subject, and earning "degrees" can be linked to Islamic educational concepts of aṣḥāb ('companions'), qirāʼah ('reading [the Qur'an]'), and ijāzah ('teaching license'). Makdisi identifies eighteen such parallels between Islamic education and modern university terminology. Common university practices today, such as inaugural lectures, wearing academic robes, defending a thesis to earn a doctorate, and even the notion of academic freedom, all have roots in Islamic traditions. The Islamic scholarly practices of fatwá (opinion) and ijmāʻ (consensus) laid the groundwork for Western scholarly systems from the Middle Ages onward. According to Makdisi and Goddard, the concept of academic freedom in universities mirrors the Islamic customs of the medieval madrasa system of the 9th century. This influence is evident in the establishment of the first intentionally planned university in Europe, the University of Naples Federico II, founded by Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, in 1224.
text_ai_humanized: He also relates that there were many other things one sees in a modern university which were based on practices in the Islamic madrasa, as well as "trappings" such as "the cap and gown, the hood, the tassel. Goddard and Makdisi further note that many commonly used terms such as "to read... as in the subject one chooses to read; chair, as in the 'chair' of a department; fellow as in graduate fellow; and the term 'degree' itself of the doctoral degree", can trace their origins back to the Islamic tradition. The system of academic ranks are also similar to the Islamic system of isnad and ijazah. For example, the term fellow is derived from the Arabic term aṣḥāb ("companions, as of Muhammad"); the term written examination is derived from the Arabic term imtihān; and the term candidate is derived from the Arabic term ṭālib, meaning "student." This is similar to the way in which words from Arabic or Islamic origin can be found in many European languages. According to Turner, however, the terms "reading" and "fellow" were introduced into the "vocabulary of the learned in Europe" with "their use in specific scholarly contexts in the seventeenth century." There are a number of other terms and practices from the Islamic madrasah which influenced the early European university including, for example, the "class" of scholars as the Turkish ulama, the terms bachelor (Arabic: bakkālī) and specialist (Arabic: takhaṣṣus), and the practice of changing clothes depending on the subject one teaches. However, Makdisi criticizes Turner for "failing to distinguish between recipient, beneficiary, lender"; thus, he concludes that even though "a word, a library, a hospital, or an astrolabe," for example, may have existed "in ancient Greece, or Rome, or India," this "does not mean that the objector some practice connected with it was transmitted, much less that it lent itself to revival." Makdisi also suggests that the medieval ijazah resembles somewhat, the modern university bachelor’s degree. The madrasa is one of the relics that influenced the establishment of the Western university. There were originally three academic ranks beneath the professorial rank, this was supplemented around the 9th century by the use of the term "reader," which referred to the intermediate rank of associate professor. The term reading is translated from the 9th-century Arabic term, qirāʼah, while the equivalent of a thesis in the 12th-century Islamic jadal (lit. "disputation, argument, debate"; from Greek διαλεκτική, dialektike) is a "position" or "statement" (called maqālah) which is "defended by the student, who, rather than finding a patron... has to undergo rigorous examination in order to obtain a teaching certificate." According to Makdisi, "the teachers of law in fifth-century Islamic society, along with their students, developed a system of education which reappeared five or six hundred years later in the medieval universities from which our modern system of education is derived. The classical university of the Middle Ages, and of modern times, is thus a Latinized imitation of the medieval madrasa; and, like the madrasa, it could exist anywhere, independently of the presence of the ancient classics, for which humanists devoted so much of their energies, and which exist in Islamic civilization, but had no place in Islamic law." He lists eighteen such parallels in terminology between the Islamic institutions and the Western universities system whereof, as just mentioned, ‘reading’ is one; also inaugural lecture, the wearing of academic robes, obtaining of a license or a degree, and the practices of academic freedom, the defense, and the doctoral degrees have their roots in the Islamic tradition. The practice of inaugurating a course, as well as the inaugural lecture was an Islamic administrative practice, while the idea of academic freedom was an Islamic concept that was borrowed into the planning of the University of Naples Frederico II, the first intentionally planned university in Europe. The concept of acadeic freedom in universities was based on the Islamic customs of the medieval madrasa system. The idea of academic freedom which is known in the modern university as the right of scholars to make scholarly judgments without pressure, is closely aligned to the Islamic fatwá, meaning opinion, and ijmāʻ, meaning scholarly consensus, and is one of the essential features of the Western university system today. Muslim influence was "certainly discernible" in the establishment of the first deliberately planned university in Europe, the University of Naples Federico II, in 1224, where, for the first time in Europe, the distinctions between the bachelor's degree and the doctoral degree began to appear.

According to Turner, however, the terms "reading" and "fellow" were introduced into the "vocabulary of the learned in Europe" with "their use in specific scholarly contexts in the seventeenth century." However, Makdisi criticizes Turner for "failing to distinguish between recipient, beneficiary, lender"; thus, he concludes that even though "a word, a library, a hospital, or an astrolabe," for example, may have existed "in ancient Greece, or Rome, or India," this "does not mean that the objector some practice connected with it was transmitted, much less that it lent itself to revival." Makdisi also suggests that the medieval ijazah resembles somewhat, the modern university bachelor’s degree. The madrasa is one of the relics that influenced the establishment of the Western university. There were originally three academic ranks beneath the professorial rank, this was supplemented around the 9th century by the use of the term "reader," which referred to the intermediate rank of associate professor. The term reading is translated from the 9th-century Arabic term, qirāʼah, while the equivalent of a thesis in the 12th-century Islamic jadal (lit. "disputation, argument, debate"; from Greek διαλεκτική, dialektike) is a "position" or "statement" (called maqālah) which is "defended by the student, who, rather than finding a patron... has to undergo rigorous examination in order to obtain a teaching certificate." According to Makdisi, "the teachers of law in fifth-century Islamic society, along with their students, developed a system of education which reappeared five or six hundred years later in the medieval universities from which our modern system of education is derived. The classical university of the Middle Ages, and of modern times, is thus a Latinized imitation of the medieval madrasa; and, like the madrasa, it could exist anywhere, independently of the presence of the ancient classics, for which humanists devoted so much of their energies, and which exist in Islamic civilization, but had no place in Islamic law." He lists eighteen such parallels in terminology between the Islamic institutions and the Western universities system whereof, as just mentioned, ‘reading’ is one; also inaugural lecture, the wearing of academic robes, obtaining of a license or a degree, and the practices of academic freedom, the defense, and the doctoral degrees have their roots in the Islamic tradition. The practice of inaugurating a course, as well as the inaugural lecture was an Islamic administrative practice, while the idea of academic freedom was an Islamic concept that was borrowed into the planning of the University of Naples Frederico II, the first intentionally planned university in Europe. The concept of acadeic freedom in universities was based on the Islamic customs of the medieval madrasa system. The idea of academic freedom which is known in the modern university as the right of scholars to make scholarly judgments without pressure, is closely aligned to the Islamic fatwá, meaning opinion, and ijmāʻ, meaning scholarly consensus, and is one of the essential features of the Western university system today. Muslim influence was "certainly discernible" in the establishment of the first deliberately planned university in Europe, the University of Naples Federico II, in 1224, where, for the first time in Europe, the distinctions between the bachelor's degree and the doctoral degree began to appear.

text_human: Others argue that the rule of law has survived but was transformed to allow for the exercise of discretion by administrators. For much of American history, the dominant notion of the rule of law, in this setting, has been some version of A. V. Dicey's: “no man is punishable or can be lawfully made to suffer in body or goods except for a distinct breach of law established in the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land.” That is, individuals should be able to challenge an administrative order by bringing suit in a court of general jurisdiction. As the dockets of worker compensation commissions, public utility commissions and other agencies burgeoned, it soon became apparent that letting judges decide for themselves all the facts in a dispute (such as the extent of an injury in a worker's compensation case) would overwhelm the courts and destroy the advantages of specialization that led to the creation of administrative agencies in the first place. Even Charles Evans Hughes, a Chief Justice of the United States, believed “you must have administration, and you must have administration by administrative officers.” By 1941, a compromise had emerged. If administrators adopted procedures that more-or-less tracked "the ordinary legal manner" of the courts, further review of the facts by "the ordinary Courts of the land" was unnecessary. That is, if you had your "day in commission," the rule of law did not require a further "day in court." Thus Dicey's rule of law was recast into a purely procedural form.
text_ai_base: Some argue that while the rule of law has persisted, it has evolved to incorporate administrative discretion. Throughout much of American history, the prevailing idea of the rule of law resembles A.V. Dicey's definition: “no man is punishable or can be lawfully made to suffer in body or goods except for a distinct breach of law established in the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land.” In essence, individuals ought to have the ability to challenge administrative decisions by filing a lawsuit in a general jurisdiction court. However, as the caseloads of workers' compensation commissions, public utility commissions, and other agencies expanded, it became clear that allowing judges to independently assess all the facts of a dispute (like determining the severity of an injury in a workers' compensation case) would overwhelm the judicial system and negate the benefits of specialization that motivated the establishment of these administrative agencies. Even Charles Evans Hughes, a Chief Justice of the United States, acknowledged the necessity of administration by administrative officers. By 1941, a middle ground was established: if administrators adopted procedures closely resembling the traditional legal processes of the courts, additional fact review by "the ordinary Courts of the land" became unwarranted. In other words, if parties received their "day in commission," the rule of law did not necessitate another "day in court." Consequently, Dicey's rule was adjusted to focus purely on procedural aspects.
text_ai_humanized: There is an argument that instead, the rule of law simply came to require administrative justice. For most of US history, the meaning of the rule of law has something close to A. V. Dicey's “no man is punishable or can be lawfully made to suffer in body or goods except for a distinct breach of law established in the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land”. This means, at the end of the day, people must be able to take an administrative action to a court of general jurisdiction. However, workers' compensation commissions, public utility commissions, and others had grown such large dockets that simple practicality made clear that allowing courts to make up their own minds anew on all the facts of a given case (e. g the extent of the injury suffered in a workers' compensation claim) would crush any court system, and eliminate the specialization for all other reasons that those administrative agencies were created in the first place. Also, the necessity and virtue of administration by administrative officers was acknowledged by no less than Chief Justice of the United States Charles Evans Hughes. The compromise that was reached by 1941 was that where the administrators themselves adopted procedures highly similar to “the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land”, there was no need for further review of fact by “the ordinary Courts of the land”. If one had a “day in commission”, then the rule of law did not require a further “day in court”. So Dicey's rule was modified to become strictly a matter of procedure.

text_human: The Third (1919–23) and Fourth Aliyahs (1924–29) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to Palestine. Finally, the rise of Nazism and the increasing persecution of Jews in 1930s Europe led to the Fifth Aliyah, with an influx of a quarter of a million Jews. This was a major cause of the Arab revolt of 1936–39 during which the British Mandate authorities alongside the Zionist militias of Haganah and Irgun killed 5,032 Arabs and wounded 14,760, resulting in over ten percent of the adult male Palestinian Arab population killed, wounded, imprisoned or exiled. The British introduced restrictions on Jewish immigration to Palestine with the White Paper of 1939. With countries around the world turning away Jewish refugees fleeing the Holocaust, a clandestine movement known as Aliyah Bet was organized to bring Jews to Palestine. By the end of World War II, the Jewish population of Palestine had increased to 33% of the total population. On July 22, 1946, Irgun attacked the British administrative headquarters for Palestine, which was housed in the southern wing of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem. 91 people of various nationalities were killed and 46 were injured. The hotel was the site of the central offices of the British Mandatory authorities of Palestine, principally the Secretariat of the Government of Palestine and the Headquarters of the British Armed Forces in Palestine and Transjordan. The attack initially had the approval of the Haganah (the principal Jewish paramilitary group in Palestine). It was conceived as a response to Operation Agatha (a series of widespread raids, including one on the Jewish Agency, conducted by the British authorities) and was the deadliest directed at the British during the Mandate era (1920–1948).
text_ai_base: During the Third (1919–23) and Fourth Aliyahs (1924–29), around 100,000 Jews migrated to Palestine. The rise of Nazism and escalating persecution of Jews in Europe during the 1930s triggered the Fifth Aliyah, bringing an additional 250,000 Jews. This influx significantly contributed to the Arab revolt of 1936–39, during which the British Mandate authorities, alongside Zionist militias like the Haganah and Irgun, resulted in the deaths of 5,032 Arabs and 14,760 wounded. Consequently, over ten percent of the adult male Palestinian Arab population was killed, wounded, imprisoned, or exiled. In response, the British issued the 1939 White Paper, imposing restrictions on Jewish immigration to Palestine. As countries worldwide refused Jewish refugees fleeing the Holocaust, a secret movement, Aliyah Bet, emerged to transport Jews to Palestine. By WWII's end, Jews comprised 33% of Palestine's population. On July 22, 1946, Irgun bombed the southern wing of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, the British administrative center for Palestine, killing 91 people and injuring 46. This attack, initially approved by the Haganah, targeted the British in response to Operation Agatha, a series of raids carried out by British authorities, and marked the deadliest assault on the British during the Mandate era (1920–1948).

text_human: Protestants also took the initiative in advocating for religious freedom. Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological, philosophical, and political agendas since Luther refused to recant his beliefs before the Diet of the Holy Roman Empire at Worms (1521). In his view, faith was a free work of the Holy Spirit and could, therefore, not be forced on a person. The persecuted Anabaptists and Huguenots demanded freedom of conscience, and they practised separation of church and state. In the early seventeenth century, Baptists like John Smyth and Thomas Helwys published tracts in defense of religious freedom. Their thinking influenced John Milton and John Locke's stance on tolerance. Under the leadership of Baptist Roger Williams, Congregationalist Thomas Hooker, and Quaker William Penn, respectively, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania combined democratic constitutions with freedom of religion. These colonies became safe havens for persecuted religious minorities, including Jews. The United States Declaration of Independence, the United States Constitution, and the American Bill of Rights with its fundamental human rights made this tradition permanent by giving it a legal and political framework. The great majority of American Protestants, both clergy and laity, strongly supported the independence movement. All major Protestant churches were represented in the First and Second Continental Congresses. In the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, the American democracy became a model for numerous other countries and regions throughout the world (e.g., Latin America, Japan, and Germany). The strongest link between the American and French Revolutions was Marquis de Lafayette, an ardent supporter of the American constitutional principles. The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen was mainly based on Lafayette's draft of this document. The United Nations Declaration and Universal Declaration of Human Rights also echo the American constitutional tradition.

The importance of freedom of conscience was emphasized in theological, philosophical, and political discussions, particularly after Martin Luther refused to recant his beliefs at the Diet of Worms in 1521. Luther believed that faith was a free gift of the Holy Spirit and could not be imposed on individuals. Persecuted groups like the Anabaptists and Huguenots demanded freedom of conscience and practiced the separation of church and state. In the early 1600s, Baptists such as John Smyth and Thomas Helwys wrote extensively in support of religious freedom, influencing thinkers like John Milton and John Locke. Under the leadership of Baptist Roger Williams, Congregationalist Thomas Hooker, and Quaker William Penn, the colonies of Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania were established with democratic constitutions and religious freedom, becoming sanctuaries for persecuted religious minorities, including Jews. The United States Declaration of Independence, Constitution, and Bill of Rights enshrined this tradition in a lasting legal and political framework. Most American Protestants, both clergy and laity, fervently supported the independence movement, and all major Protestant denominations were represented in the First and Second Continental Congresses. In the 19th and 20th centuries, American democracy inspired many other nations, including those in Latin America, Japan, and Germany. Marquis de Lafayette, a key link between the American and French Revolutions, ardently supported American constitutional principles. The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen was heavily based on Lafayette's draft. The United Nations Declaration and Universal Declaration of Human Rights also reflect the American constitutional tradition.
text_ai_humanized: Protestants were at the forefront of the struggles for freedom of conscience. Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological, philosophical and political agendas, since the refusal of Martin Luther to recant his beliefs before the assembly of the Holy Roman Empire at Worms in 1521. For Luther, faith was a free work of the Holy Spirit and could therefore not be forced on a person. The persecuted Anabaptists and Huguenots demanded freedom of conscience, and they practiced separation of church and state. In the early seventeenth century, Baptists like John Smyth and Thomas Helwys published tracts in defense of religious freedom. Their thinking influenced John Milton and John Locke's stance on toleration. Under the leadership of Baptist Roger Williams, Congregationalist Thomas Hooker, and Quaker William Penn, respectively, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania combined democratic constitutions with freedom of religion, becoming safe havens for persecuted religious minorities, including Jews. The United States Declaration of Independence, the United States Constitution, and the American Bill of Rights with its fundamental human rights enshrined this Protestant tradition in a form of constitutional documents with legal force. Other human rights were implemented in the form of constitutional amendments. The United States became the first modern democracy and religiously plural society. Alexis de Tocqueville emphasised the contribution of the American Revolution, to egalitarianism, in his Democracy in America. Within the United States most congregational Protestants, Episcopalians and Presbyterians were Whigs, and these denominations produced many of the nation's leaders. Unitarianism and Quakerism, which both had roots in the Protestant Reformation, guided the spirit of the American Revolution towards the emancipation of slaves and the freedom of conscientious objection. Most American Protestants, both clergy and laity, strongly supported the war effort. All of the above revolutionary movements had controversial relationships with the Roman Catholic Church. In the First and Second Continental Congress, besides the presence of American Catholic John Carroll, the great majority of professed Christians were Protestants with a continental Reformed background. The American Revolution was inspired by the radical Whig ideology, which was heavily a Protestant ideology. The American Revolution began in a dispute regarding taxes without representation. According to historian J.C.D. Clark, English society as a whole characterised by strong beliefs in hierarchical order, privilege and inequality, wherein the American Revolution represented a "culmination of a long term process towards realization of a Protestant natural rights philosophy". Historian Mark A. Noll adds that, "protestantism also carried within it the means of criticizing the prevailing order in the light of higher principles." In the 19th and 20th centuries, the American democracy became a model for numerous other countries, including, but not limited to, the Latin-American states, Japan, and Germany. The strongest link between the American and French Revolutions was Marquis de Lafayette, leader of the French moderate party. He was the adoptive son of George Washington and the founding father of the French democracy. He, among the moderate politicians and reformists of the time, was highly inspired by the United States Declaration of Independence and the American constitutional tradition. The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen was mainly based by Lafayette's draft of this document. The United Nations Declaration and Universal Declaration of Human Rights also echo the American constitutional tradition.

text_human: Established acts benefited from the new commercial climate, with Whitesnake's self-titled album (1987) selling over 17 million copies, outperforming anything in Coverdale's or Deep Purple's catalogue before or since. It featured the rock anthem "Here I Go Again '87" as one of 4 UK top 20 singles. The follow-up Slip of the Tongue (1989) went platinum, but according to critics Steve Erlwine and Greg Prato, "it was a considerable disappointment after the across-the-board success of Whitesnake". Aerosmith's comeback album Permanent Vacation (1987) would begin a decade long revival of their popularity. Crazy Nights (1987) by Kiss was the band's highest charting release in the US since 1979 and the highest of their career in the UK. Mötley Crüe with Girls, Girls, Girls (1987) continued their commercial success and Def Leppard with Hysteria (1987) hit their commercial peak, the latter producing seven hit singles (a record for a hard rock act). Guns N' Roses released the best-selling début of all time, Appetite for Destruction (1987). With a "grittier" and "rawer" sound than most glam metal, it produced three top 10 hits, including the number one "Sweet Child O' Mine". Some of the glam rock bands that formed in the mid-1980s, such as White Lion and Cinderella experienced their biggest success during this period with their respective albums Pride (1987) and Long Cold Winter (1988) both going multi-platinum and launching a series of hit singles. In the last years of the decade, the most notable successes were New Jersey (1988) by Bon Jovi, OU812 (1988) by Van Halen, Open Up and Say... Ahh! (1988) by Poison, Pump (1989) by Aerosmith, and Mötley Crüe's most commercially successful album Dr. Feelgood (1989). New Jersey spawned five Top 10 singles, a record for a hard rock act. In 1988 from 25 June to 5 November, the number one spot on the Billboard 200 album chart was held by a hard rock album for 18 out of 20 consecutive weeks; the albums were OU812, Hysteria, Appetite for Destruction, and New Jersey. A final wave of glam rock bands arrived in the late 1980s, and experienced success with multi-platinum albums and hit singles from 1989 until the early 1990s, among them Extreme, Warrant Slaughter and FireHouse. Skid Row also released their eponymous début (1989), reaching number six on the Billboard 200, but they were to be one of the last major bands that emerged in the glam rock era.

text_ai_humanized: Established acts adapted and thrived in this environment. One expample is Whitesnake's self-titled album (1987), which sold over seventeen million copies (more than Coverdale, or Deep Purple, had sold ever before), producing a number one single in "Here I Go Again '87", and the power ballad "Is This Love", with the album's four singles charting in the top 20 in the UK.[37][38] The follow-up album Slip of the Tongue (1989) was also a success, selling over three million copies and providing several hit singles, but Steve Earlwine and Greg Prato have stated that "it couldn't replicate the mass success of Whitesnake".[38] Aerosmith made a remarkable comeback in the late 1980s with the album Permanent Vacation (1987), which launched a sequence of multi-platinum albums that lasted all the way into the 2000s.[citation needed] Kiss released the glam-influenced album Crazy Nights in 1987. It did not return the band to the heights of their 1970s heyday, but it was their highest-charting album in the U.S. since 1979 and in the UK it was their highest-charting album ever.[39] Mötley Crüe produced two more hit albums, Girls, Girls, Girls (1987) and their most successful album, Dr. Feelgood (1989).[27] Def Leppard's Hysteria (1987) hit number one[40] and assigned a glam image to the band, but it was also their commercial peak, producing an extraordinary seven hit singles.[41] Guns N' Roses emerged in 1987 with a "grittier" and "rawer" sound dispelling glam metal qualities, but it still had influenced their image and was likened to the "Rolling Stones-meet-Aerosmith 1970s raunch".[42][43][44] Their debut album Appetite for Destruction (1987), which combined glam with punk and metal, but also with ballads, topped the Billboard 200,[45][46] on its way to being certified sixteen times platinum by the RIAA. It was the best-selling debut album and the eleventh best-selling album of all time in the United States,[47] with a worldwide sales total of more than 28 million.[48] It produced three top 10 singles, including the number one "Sweet Child o' Mine".[49] The mid-1980s glam rock bands saw their greatest level of success in the late 1980s, with White Lion's Pride (1987) and Cinderella's Long Cold Winter (1988) both going multi-platinum and featuring a number of hit singles.[50][51] Among the biggest albums of the clash between veteran bands and newcomers toward the end of the decade, Bon Jovi's New Jersey (1988), Van Halen's OU812 (1988), Poison's Open Up and Say...Ahh! (1988), Aerosmith's Pump (1989), and Mötley Crüe's most successful album, Dr. Feelgood (1989). New Jersey featured five Top 10 hits on the Billboard Hot 100, which was hard rock record for a single album. On the Billboard 200 album charts, from June 25, 1988 to the start of November 5, 1988, hard rock albums held the top spot in 18 out of 20 weeks with OU812 (4 weeks), Hysteria (6 weeks), Appetite for Destruction (4 weeks) and New Jersey (4 weeks). A new set of glam rock bands would experience success in the late 1980s and sometimes into the early 1990s. They had multi-platinum albums and hit singles, including Extreme, Warrant, Slaughter and FireHouse.[8][15][27] Skid Row released their self-titled debut album in 1989, it reached number six on the Billboard 200, and went five times platinum in the U.S. It was one of the last major successes in the glam metal era.[26]

It did not return the band to the heights of their 1970s heyday, but it was their highest-charting album in the U.S. since 1979 and in the UK it was their highest-charting album ever.[39] Mötley Crüe produced two more hit albums, Girls, Girls, Girls (1987) and their most successful album, Dr. Feelgood (1989).[27] Def Leppard's Hysteria (1987) hit number one[40] and assigned a glam image to the band, but it was also their commercial peak, producing an extraordinary seven hit singles.[41] Guns N' Roses emerged in 1987 with a "grittier" and "rawer" sound dispelling glam metal qualities, but it still had influenced their image and was likened to the "Rolling Stones-meet-Aerosmith 1970s raunch".[42][43][44] Their debut album Appetite for Destruction (1987), which combined glam with punk and metal, but also with ballads, topped the Billboard 200,[45][46] on its way to being certified sixteen times platinum by the RIAA. It was the best-selling debut album and the eleventh best-selling album of all time in the United States,[47] with a worldwide sales total of more than 28 million.[48] It produced three top 10 singles, including the number one "Sweet Child o' Mine".[49] The mid-1980s glam rock bands saw their greatest level of success in the late 1980s, with White Lion's Pride (1987) and Cinderella's Long Cold Winter (1988) both going multi-platinum and featuring a number of hit singles.[50][51] Among the biggest albums of the clash between veteran bands and newcomers toward the end of the decade, Bon Jovi's New Jersey (1988), Van Halen's OU812 (1988), Poison's Open Up and Say...Ahh! (1988), Aerosmith's Pump (1989), and Mötley Crüe's most successful album, Dr. Feelgood (1989). New Jersey featured five Top 10 hits on the Billboard Hot 100, which was hard rock record for a single album. On the Billboard 200 album charts, from June 25, 1988 to the start of November 5, 1988, hard rock albums held the top spot in 18 out of 20 weeks with OU812 (4 weeks), Hysteria (6 weeks), Appetite for Destruction (4 weeks) and New Jersey (4 weeks). A new set of glam rock bands would experience success in the late 1980s and sometimes into the early 1990s. They had multi-platinum albums and hit singles, including Extreme, Warrant, Slaughter and FireHouse.[8][15][27] Skid Row released their self-titled debut album in 1989, it reached number six on the Billboard 200, and went five times platinum in the U.S. It was one of the last major successes in the glam metal era.[26]

text_human: When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of competitors and to avoid the generally poor reputation that game consoles had acquired following the video game crash of 1983. One result of this philosophy was to disguise the cartridge slot design as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket, designed to resemble the front-loading mechanism of a VCR. The newly designed connector worked quite well when both the connector and the cartridges were clean and the pins on the connector were new. Unfortunately, the ZIF connector was not truly zero insertion force. When a user inserted the cartridge into the NES, the force of pressing the cartridge down and into place bent the contact pins slightly, as well as pressing the cartridge’s ROM board back into the cartridge itself. Frequent insertion and removal of cartridges caused the pins to wear out from repeated usage over the years and the ZIF design proved more prone to interference by dirt and dust than an industry-standard card edge connector. These design issues were not alleviated by Nintendo’s choice of materials; the console slot nickel connector springs would wear due to design and the game cartridge copper connectors were also prone to tarnishing. Many players would try to alleviate issues in the game caused by this corrosion by blowing into the cartridges, then reinserting them, which actually hurt the copper connectors by speeding up the tarnishing.
text_ai_base: When Nintendo launched the NES in the US, the system was designed to stand out from other game consoles. This differentiation aimed to set Nintendo apart from competitors and avoid the negative reputation consoles had gained after the 1983 video game crash. As part of this approach, the NES featured a front-loading cartridge slot that mimicked the appearance of a VCR's mechanism, marketed as a zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket. This design worked effectively when the connectors and cartridges were clean and the connector pins were new. However, despite its name, the ZIF connector wasn’t truly zero insertion force. Insertion required pushing the cartridge down and into place, which bent the connector pins and pressed the cartridge's ROM board back into itself. Over time, repeated insertion and removal wore out the pins, and the ZIF layout was more susceptible to dirt and dust than standard card edge connectors. These issues were compounded by Nintendo’s choice of materials: the console's nickel connector springs would deteriorate due to the design, and the cartridges' copper connectors were prone to tarnishing. Many players tried to avoid game issues caused by this corrosion by blowing into the cartridges before reinserting them, unfortunately accelerating the tarnishing process of the copper connectors.
text_ai_humanized: To make the NES differentiate from the other consoles, and make it appear as not being a console (with the intention of dissociating it from most consoles, which at the time had a bad reputation due to the video game crash of 1983), when they released the NES in the US they changed how the device functioned, by using a front-loading cartridge mechanism, fashioned to closely resemble the front-loading mechanisms of video cassette recorders, and marketing it as having a "zero insertion force" (ZIF) cartridge socket. This mechanism functioned flawlessly and minimized wear and tear on cartridge connectors – when they were kept clean, and when used with new power edge connectors. However, despite the name, the ZIF connector was not truly zero insertion force. In order to keep the inserted cartridge flush with the internal connector, the cartridge still needed to be pressed down and by using it bent the connector pins and pushed the cartridge's ROM board backward, into the cartridge itself. As the system was used, repeated insertion and removal of cartridges caused the pins to wear; the ZIF socket design proved to be far more prone to collecting dust than a standard card edge connector. Nintendo's choice of materials exacerbated this flaw: the edge connector springs in the console were singled out as a substantial problem. Eventually, the nickel plating on the springs would wear out, due to mechanical abrasion, and the copper beneath would quickly corrode due to its poor resistance to oxygen. Many players would try to alleviate issues in rusty connectors by blowing into the cartridges, then reinserting them; this process sped up the tarnishing of the copper connectors in the cartridges due to moisture.

text_human: In 1565, the powerful Rinbung princes were overthrown by one of their own ministers, Karma Tseten who styled himself as the Tsangpa, "the one of Tsang", and established his base of power at Shigatse. The second successor of this first Tsang king, Karma Phuntsok Namgyal, took control of the whole of Central Tibet (Ü-Tsang), reigning from 1611–1621. Despite this, the leaders of Lhasa still claimed their allegiance to the Phagmodru as well as the Gelug, while the Ü-Tsang king allied with the Karmapa. Tensions rose between the nationalistic Ü-Tsang ruler and the Mongols who safeguarded their Mongol Dalai Lama in Lhasa. The fourth Dalai Lama refused to give an audience to the Ü-Tsang king, which sparked a conflict as the latter began assaulting Gelug monasteries. Chen writes of the speculation over the fourth Dalai Lama's mysterious death and the plot of the Ü-Tsang king to have him murdered for "cursing" him with illness, although Chen writes that the murder was most likely the result of a feudal power struggle. In 1618, only two years after Yonten Gyatso died, the Gelug and the Karma Kargyu went to war, the Karma Kargyu supported by the secular Ü-Tsang king. The Ü-Tsang ruler had a large number of Gelugpa lamas killed, occupied their monasteries at Drepung and Sera, and outlawed any attempts to find another Dalai Lama. In 1621, the Ü-Tsang king died and was succeeded by his young son Karma Tenkyong, an event which stymied the war effort as the latter accepted the six-year-old Lozang Gyatso as the new Dalai Lama. Despite the new Dalai Lama's diplomatic efforts to maintain friendly relations with the new Ü-Tsang ruler, Sonam Rapten (1595–1657), the Dalai Lama's chief steward and treasurer at Drepung, made efforts to overthrow the Ü-Tsang king, which led to another conflict. In 1633, the Gelugpas and several thousand Mongol adherents defeated the Ü-Tsang king's troops near Lhasa before a peaceful negotiation was settled. Goldstein writes that in this the "Mongols were again playing a significant role in Tibetan affairs, this time as the military arm of the Dalai Lama."

text_human: Some rock musicians today use mandolins, often single-stringed electric models rather than double-stringed acoustic mandolins. One example is Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys. In addition to electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band uses several instruments associated with traditional Celtic music, including mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes. The band explains that these instruments accentuate the growling sound they favor. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was driven by a few simple mandolin licks played by guitarist Peter Buck, who also played the mandolin in nearly a dozen other songs. The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart (#1 on the rock and alternative charts), Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes has made frequent use of the mandolin, most notably on the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." Armenian American rock group System of A Down makes extensive use of the mandolin on their 2005 double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize. Pop punk band Green Day has used a mandolin in several occasions, especially on their 2000 album, Warning. Boyd Tinsley, violin player of the Dave Matthews Band has been using an electric mandolin since 2005. Frontman Colin Meloy and guitarist Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly employ the mandolin in the band's music. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist of Heart, uses a mandolin in Heart's song "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen, as well as in Heart's cover of Led Zeppelin's song "The Battle of Evermore." "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, the theme song to the film Days of Thunder, prominently features a mandolin.
text_ai_base: Today, several rock musicians incorporate mandolins into their music, often opting for single-stringed electric versions rather than traditional double-stringed acoustic models. Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys is one such musician. Alongside electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band integrates instruments linked to Celtic music, like the mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes, to enhance their favored growling sound. The 1991 hit "Losing My Religion" by R.E.M. showcased simple mandolin riffs played by guitarist Peter Buck, who used mandolin in nearly a dozen other songs. The single reached No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and topped the rock and alternative charts. Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes often features the mandolin, notably in the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." The Armenian-American band System of a Down extensively used mandolin in their 2005 double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize. The pop punk band Green Day incorporated mandolin several times, particularly in their 2000 album Warning. Boyd Tinsley, the violinist from Dave Matthews Band, has played electric mandolin since 2005. Colin Meloy and Chris Funk of The Decemberists frequently use mandolin in their band's music. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist for Heart, employs mandolin in songs like "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen and in Heart's rendition of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore." Additionally, "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, the theme song for the film Days of Thunder, prominently features the mandolin.
text_ai_humanized: Some contemporary rock musicians also use mandolins, often single instead of the more common double string. Tim Brennan of Dropkick Murphys usually uses an electric mandolin during live performances. Alongside electric guitar, electric bass, and drumkit, the group blends mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes into its predominantly growling punk sound. R.E.M.'s 1991 song "Losing My Religion" features simple mandolin riffs integral to the song performed by guitarist Peter Buck (he has also used the instrument in at least 10 other R.E.M. songs). The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and No. 1 on the rock and alternative charts.[27][28] Mandolin is featured extensively in the music of the Levellers and is occasionally used in the music by hard rock band Led Zeppelin ("Going to California" and "The Battle of Evermore", John Paul Jones on mandolin). Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull has played mandolin on "Fat Man", "Cold Wind to Valhalla", "Blood on the Rooftops", and "The Chequered Flag (Dead or Alive)". Nazareth's hit song "Please Don't Judas Me" features mandolin played by band member Manny Charlton. Mandolin is heard in "Boat on the River" by Styx, "St. Teresa" by Joan Osborne, "Tell Her This" by Del Amitri, "Dust to Dust" by The Civil Wars, "Galway Girl" by Steve Earle, "Give a Little Bit" by Supertramp, "Mandolin Rain" by Bruce Hornsby and the Range, "Half the World" by Rush, and Save Me by Jellyfish. Crash Test Dummies often used mandolin in their songs, especially on their album God Shuffled His Feet in songs like "Here I Stand Before Me" (although it can be heard in nearly half of the album's songs). Tom Petty often used mandolin in his recordings. The mandolin is featured extensively in the music of singer-songwriter Butch Walker. Jimmy Stafford of the band Train plays a Yamaha electric 4-string mandolin. Luther Dickinson of the North Mississippi Allstars and the Black Crowes uses the mandolin throughout the former's music and in some of the latter's songs, most notably "Locust Street". Mandolin was frequently used in the music of Elvis Presley, such as "Don't Be Cruel", "Kentucky Rain" and "He's Your Uncle, Not Your Dad". The Armenian-American band System of a Down used mandolin extensively on their double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize, released in 2005. It was also featured in two songs on their 2002 album Steal This Album! The pop punk band Green Day has used the mandolin on a few occasions; it appears most notably in their 2000 song "Minority" from the album Warning. Boyd Tinsley, violinist from Dave Matthews Band, has used an electric mandolin in many songs dating back to 2005. Colin Meloy and Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly use the mandolin (Meloy, solos; Funk, with Meloy or to accompany Meloy). Nancy Wilson of Heart plays mandolin on the songs "Dream of the Archer" (from the album Little Queen) and Heart's cover of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore".[29][30] The theme song for the film Days of Thunder, "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, prominently features the mandolin. Bones Hillman, bass guitarist in Midnight Oil, also plays mandolin on songs such as "In the Valley" (from the album Earth and Sun and Moon).[citation needed]
