text_human: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet type. Since small mammals have a high ratio of heat-losing surface area to heat-generating volume, they tend to have high energy requirements and a high metabolic rate. Mammals that weigh less than about 18 oz (500 g) are mostly insectivorous because they cannot tolerate the slow, complex digestive process of a herbivore. Larger animals, on the other hand, generate more heat and less of this heat is lost. They can therefore tolerate either a slower collection process (those that prey on larger vertebrates) or a slower digestive process (herbivores). Furthermore, mammals that weigh more than 18 oz (500 g) usually cannot collect enough insects during their waking hours to sustain themselves. The only large insectivorous mammals are those that feed on huge colonies of insects (ants or termites).
text_ai_base: Maintaining a consistently high body temperature requires a significant amount of energy, so mammals need a diet that is both nutritious and abundant. Although the earliest mammals were likely predators, various species have since adapted to fulfill their dietary needs in diverse ways. Some mammals are carnivorous and consume other animals, including insects. Herbivores, on the other hand, eat plants, with subcategories like fruit-eating and grass-eating diets. Omnivores eat both animals and plants. Carnivores have a straightforward digestive system because proteins, lipids, and minerals in meat require minimal specialized digestion. In contrast, plants contain complex carbohydrates like cellulose, so herbivores have digestive tracts equipped with bacteria to ferment these substances and aid digestion. These bacteria reside either in multi-chambered stomachs or a large cecum. An animal's size also influences its dietary adaptation. Smaller mammals have a higher ratio of heat-losing surface area to heat-generating volume, resulting in increased energy demands and a rapid metabolism. Thus, mammals weighing less than about 18 ounces (500 grams) are typically insectivorous, as they cannot manage the slow, complex digestion required for a herbivorous diet. Conversely, larger mammals generate more heat and lose less of it, allowing them to tolerate either a slower prey collection process or the lengthy digestion typical of herbivores. Additionally, mammals weighing over 18 ounces (500 grams) usually find it difficult to gather enough insects during their active hours to sustain themselves. The only large insect-eating mammals concentrate on feeding on extensive insect colonies, such as ants or termites.

api_response.result: This takes a lot of energy, so mammals must have a highly nutritious and plentiful diet. The first mammals were probably insect predators, but now many mammals have evolved to meet their food needs in different ways. Some mammals eat other animals, even just insects, while some are herbivores and eat only plants. (There are different types of herbivores, like frugivores and grassivores that eat primarily fruit and grass or klubberer, respectively). Others types of mammals are omnivores and eat a combination of other animals and plants. Carnivores have a simpler digestive tract as proteins, lipids and minerals from and meats require little in the way of special digestion. Plants consist of complex carbohydrates like cellulose so herbivores need digestive tracts containing bacteria that will ferment these substances and digest them. These bacteria are stored either in multi-chambered stomachs or in a large cecum. Size also affects how a mammal adapts its nutrition. Smaller mammals have more heat-losing surface area relative to heat-generating volume, fixed upon body shape, so their energy demands are greater on an absolute scale and they have a fast metabolism. So mammals capable adult body mass less than about 18 oz. (500g) are insectivores because they cannot afford the slow, complex processing required for herbivory. Larger mammals generate more heat and save more of it, so they can afford to capture prey more slowly or undergo the protracted digestion of a herbivore. Also, mammals weighing more than 18 oz. (500g) typically can't capture enough insects in their waking hours to stay alive. The only large insectivores feed by licking up millions of colonial insects like ants or termites.

text_human: Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey for cats and snakes, and snakes may be the prey of hawks. One way of classifying predators is by trophic level. Organisms that feed on autotrophs, the producers of the trophic pyramid, are known as herbivores or primary consumers; those that feed on heterotrophs such as animals are known as secondary consumers. Secondary consumers are a type of carnivore, but there are also tertiary consumers eating these carnivores, quartary consumers eating them, and so forth. Because only a fraction of energy is passed on to the next level, this hierarchy of predation must end somewhere, and very seldom goes higher than five or six levels, and may go only as high as three trophic levels (for example, a lion that preys upon large herbivores such as wildebeest, which in turn eat grasses). A predator at the top of any food chain (that is, one that is preyed upon by no organism) is called an apex predator; examples include the orca, sperm whale, anaconda, Komodo dragon, tiger, lion, tiger shark, Nile crocodile, and most eagles and owls—and even omnivorous humans and grizzly bears. An apex predator in one environment may not retain this position as a top predator if introduced to another habitat, such as a dog among alligators, a skunk in the presence of the great horned owl immune to skunk spray, or a snapping turtle among jaguars; a predatory species introduced into an area where it faces no predators, such as a domestic cat or a dog in some insular environments, can become an apex predator by default.
text_ai_base: Predators often serve as prey for other animals, while those designated as prey can also be predators. For example, blue jays consume insects but may fall prey to cats and snakes. In turn, snakes can be preyed upon by hawks. Predators can be classified by their trophic level: herbivores, or primary consumers, feed on autotrophs—the producers in the trophic pyramid—while secondary consumers, a type of carnivore, feed on other animals. Tertiary consumers then eat these carnivores, and quartary consumers eat them, continuing this sequence. However, because only a small fraction of energy moves to the next level, the predation hierarchy typically ends after five or six levels, often stopping at three. For instance, a lion hunts large herbivores such as wildebeest, which consume grasses. A predator at the apex of any food chain, meaning it isn't preyed upon by any other organism, is called an apex predator. Examples include orcas, sperm whales, anacondas, Komodo dragons, tigers, lions, tiger sharks, Nile crocodiles, most eagles and owls, as well as omnivorous humans and grizzly bears. The status of an apex predator can change if it enters a new environment. For instance, a dog may lose its top status among alligators, or a skunk among a great horned owl that is immune to skunk spray. A snapping turtle would not be a top predator among jaguars. However, in certain areas with no natural predators, domestic cats or dogs can become apex predators by default.
text_ai_humanized: Predators may be prey to other predators. The blue jay preys on invertebrates, but is prey to cats and snakes, and the snake is prey to hawks. Prey may or may not be predators. Predators are often characterized by their consumer-resource levels : primary consumers eat producers, secondary consumers eat other consumers, and tertiary consumers eat the secondary consumers. Quartary consumers eat tertiary consumers, etc. In practice the chain of consumption can reach up to six levels but there usually are three or four. Due to the 10 energy transfer between levels in the pyramid of energy , there can be less biomass at higher levels. So there is rarely a fifth level. A predator at the top of any food chain (i.e. one that is not preyed upon) is called an "apex predator". Earthly apex predators include orcas, sperm whales, anacondas, Komodo dragons, tigers, lions, tiger sharks, Nile crocodiles, most eagles and owls, omnivorous humans and grizzly bears. An apex predator may lose that status if it enters a new ecosystem: while it may remain unpreyed upon, it may not hunt or detract the current dominant predator. While a dog may not be considered under an alligator's food chain, it could certainly lose dominant status in one, same for a skunk in a horned owl, that does not get blinded by its spray. While a snapping turtle may rarely get eaten by a jaguar, it would not be considered a dominant predator amongst various predators. However, cats and dogs may become apex predators in areas where there are no contenders.

text_human: The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. Napoleon sent an expedition under General Leclerc designed to reassert control over Sainte-Domingue. Although the French managed to capture Toussaint Louverture, the expedition failed when high rates of disease crippled the French army. In May 1803, the last 8000 French troops left the island and the slaves proclaimed an independent republic that they called Haïti in 1804. Seeing the failure of his colonial efforts, Napoleon decided in 1803 to sell the Louisiana Territory to the United States, instantly doubling the size of the U.S. The selling price in the Louisiana Purchase was less than three cents per acre, a total of $15 million.
text_ai_base: During a brief period of peace in Europe, Napoleon shifted his attention to the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had gained significant political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture establishing himself as a de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw an opportunity to reclaim the once prosperous colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. Back in February 1794, the National Convention had voted to abolish slavery. However, to satisfy British demands under the Treaty of Amiens, Napoleon agreed not to abolish slavery in colonies where the 1794 decree had never been enforced. The resulting Law of 20 May did not apply to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, although some rogue generals and officials exploited the peace to reinstate slavery in parts of these places. Officially, the Law of 20 May restored the slave trade to Caribbean colonies, but not slavery itself. Napoleon dispatched an expedition under General Leclerc to reassert control over Saint-Domingue. Although the French captured Toussaint Louverture, the expedition was derailed by a severe outbreak of disease among the troops. In May 1803, the remaining 8,000 French soldiers evacuated the island, and the former slaves declared independence, forming the Republic of Haiti in 1804. After his colonial efforts failed, Napoleon decided in 1803 to sell the Louisiana Territory to the United States, instantly doubling its size. The Louisiana Purchase price amounted to less than three cents per acre, totaling $15 million.

Although the French managed to capture Toussaint Louverture, the expedition ended in disaster when sickness struck the French army, and by the end of October 1803, the remaining 8,000 French troops went back after several losses in open battle against former slave forces; the last and decisive defeat of the French was the Battle of Vertieres. text_human: The opening years of the 1980s saw a number of changes in personnel and direction of established hard rock acts, including the deaths of Bon Scott, the lead singer of AC/DC, and John Bonham, drummer with Led Zeppelin. Whereas Zeppelin broke up almost immediately afterwards, AC/DC pressed on, recording the album Back in Black (1980) with their new lead singer, Brian Johnson. It became the fifth-highest-selling album of all time in the US and the second-highest-selling album in the world. Black Sabbath had split with original singer Ozzy Osbourne in 1979 and replaced him with Ronnie James Dio, formerly of Rainbow, giving the band a new sound and a period of creativity and popularity beginning with Heaven and Hell (1980). Osbourne embarked on a solo career with Blizzard of Ozz (1980), featuring American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Some bands, such as Queen, moved away from their hard rock roots and more towards pop rock, while others, including Rush with Moving Pictures (1981), began to return to a hard rock sound. The creation of thrash metal, which mixed heavy metal with elements of hardcore punk from about 1982, particularly by Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth and Slayer, helped to create extreme metal and further remove the style from hard rock, although a number of these bands or their members would continue to record some songs closer to a hard rock sound. Kiss moved away from their hard rock roots toward pop metal: firstly removing their makeup in 1983 for their Lick It Up album, and then adopting the visual and sound of glam metal for their 1984 release, Animalize, both of which marked a return to commercial success. Pat Benatar was one of the first women to achieve commercial success in hard rock, with three successive Top 5 albums between 1980 and 1982.
text_ai_base: In the early 1980s, the hard rock scene experienced significant shifts in both personnel and direction. Notably, Bon Scott, AC/DC's lead singer, and John Bonham, Led Zeppelin's drummer, both passed away. Following Bonham's death, Led Zeppelin disbanded. Conversely, AC/DC continued forward, recruiting Brian Johnson as their new lead singer and releasing the album "Back in Black" (1980). This album became immensely successful, ranking as the fifth highest-selling in the U.S. and the second worldwide. Meanwhile, Black Sabbath replaced their original vocalist, Ozzy Osbourne, with Ronnie James Dio from Rainbow. This change heralded a new era of creativity and popularity for the band, starting with the "Heaven and Hell" album (1980). Osbourne launched his solo career with "Blizzard of Ozz" (1980), showcasing American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Some bands, like Queen, shifted from their hard rock beginnings to a pop rock sound, while others, such as Rush with "Moving Pictures" (1981), revisited their hard rock roots. Around 1982, thrash metal emerged, blending heavy metal with hardcore punk, led by bands like Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer. This new genre solidified extreme metal's identity, further distancing it from traditional hard rock, although many of these bands continued to record tracks with a hard rock influence. Kiss transitioned from hard rock to pop metal, starting with their makeup-free album "Lick It Up" in 1983, and embraced glam metal with "Animalize" in 1984, reviving their commercial success. Additionally, Pat Benatar broke new ground for women in hard rock with three consecutive Top 5 albums between 1980 and 1982.
text_ai_humanized: The hard rock genre underwent various changes in the early 1980s. The deaths of AC/DC's lead singer Bon Scott and Led Zeppelin's drummer John Bonham led to the former band's new album Back in Black (1980, with new singer Brian Johnson) rising to the fifth best-selling album in the US and the second best-selling album worldwide,[116][117] while the latter band disbanded soon after. Black Sabbath replaced original member, vocalist Ozzy Osbourne, with former Rainbow singer Ronnie James Dio, ushering in a new era of increased creativity and popularity for the band, beginning with the Heaven and Hell (1980) album. Meanwhile, Osbourne began a highly successful solo career with his debut album Blizzard of Ozz (1980), featuring gifted American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Some hard rock bands moved away from the hard rock style altogether, such as Queen who shifted to pop rock by the early 1980s, and Rush who adopted a more synthesizer-oriented sound, though the Canadian power trio shifted back to their hard rock sound for the most part with their successful Moving Pictures (1981) release.[118] The formation in 1982 of thrash metal, a form of heavy metal combining the genre with hardcore punk, and led by bands such as Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer, popularized the concept of extreme metal and took it a further step away from the hard rock genre, that many bands of the Nu metal are still recording hard rock songs like Korn, Avenged Sevenfold and others. Kiss moved the hard rock genre to pop metal with the first album without makeup, Lick It Up (1983) and adopted a glam metal look and sound for Animalize (1984) which returned them to commercial success.[119][120] Female hard rock musicians of the 1980s include Pat Benatar who had three consecutive multi-platinum albums from 1980 to 1982.[121]

text_human: Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture ultimately would not be able to compete against RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) processors. While the Motorola 68040 offered the same features as the Intel 80486 and could on a clock-for-clock basis significantly outperform the Intel chip, the 486 had the ability to be clocked significantly faster without suffering from overheating problems, especially the clock-doubled i486DX2 which ran the CPU logic at twice the external bus speed, giving such equipped IBM compatible systems a significant performance lead over their Macintosh equivalents. Apple's product design and engineering didn't help matters as they restricted the use of the '040 to their expensive Quadras for a time while the 486 was readily available to OEMs as well as enthusiasts who put together their own machines. In late 1991, as the higher-end Macintosh desktop lineup transitioned to the '040, Apple was unable to offer the '040 in their top-of-the-line PowerBooks until early 1994 with the PowerBook 500 series, several years after the first 486-powered IBM compatible laptops hit the market which cost Apple considerable sales. In 1993 Intel rolled out the Pentium processors as the successor to the 486, while the Motorola 68050 was never released, leaving the Macintosh platform a generation behind IBM compatibles in the latest CPU technology. In 1994, Apple abandoned Motorola CPUs for the RISC PowerPC architecture developed by the AIM alliance of Apple Computer, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh line, the first to use the new chips, proved to be highly successful, with over a million PowerPC units sold in nine months. However, in the long run, spurning Intel for the PowerPC was a mistake as the commoditization of Intel-architecture chips meant Apple couldn't compete on price against "the Dells of the world".
text_ai_base: Intel made multiple attempts to persuade Apple to transition the Macintosh platform to its chips, but Apple resisted. Apple decided that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture wouldn't effectively compete with RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) processors. Although the Motorola 68040 offered similar functionality to the Intel 80486 and could outperform it at equal clock speeds, the 486 could run at much higher clock speeds without overheating, particularly the i486DX2, which operated at twice the external bus speed. As a result, IBM-compatible systems had a notable performance edge over their Macintosh counterparts. Apple's decision to limit the Motorola 68040 to their high-priced Quadra models initially, while the 486 was widely available for OEMs and hobbyists, further compounded the issue. By late 1991, even as the more advanced Macintosh desktops began using the 68040, Apple couldn't offer it in their top-tier PowerBooks until the PowerBook 500 series launched in early 1994, leaving them lagging behind IBM-compatible laptops that began using the 486 years earlier—a factor that hurt Apple's sales substantially. In 1993, Intel introduced the Pentium processors to replace the 486, while the Motorola 68050 was never released, putting Macintosh a generation behind in CPU technology compared to IBM compatibles. In 1994, Apple decided to switch from Motorola CPUs to the RISC PowerPC architecture developed through the AIM alliance with Apple, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh series, utilizing these new chips, achieved great success, selling over a million units in nine months. Despite this initial success, the decision to bypass Intel for PowerPC ultimately proved misguided, as Intel-based chips became standardized, leaving Apple unable to compete on pricing with companies like Dell.
text_ai_humanized: Intel tried several times to convince Apple to use its processors in the Macintosh platform, but the company refused for many years. Apple concluded that the complex instruction set computing (CISC) -based Intel architecture could not compete with the reduced instruction set (RISC) computing architecture in the desktop computing market. While the Motorola 68040 performed similarly to the Intel 80486 and could beat it at the same clock rate, the 486 reached higher available clock rates for the time without overheating — especially the i486DX2, which was clocked at twice the external bus speed. This meant that IBM-compatible hardware had a significant advantage over their competitor at the time. Apple's policy of restricting the Motorola 68040 to their high-end (and expensive, relative to IBM-compats) Quadras at first while the 486 was accessible to any infiltrator or hobbyist did not help. By the end of 1991 even the more advanced Macintosh desktops had adopted the 68040, but Apple was still unable to offer it in their flagship PowerBooks (laptop computers) until the launch of the PowerBook 500 series in early 1994, by which time IBM-compatible laptops had adopted the 486 years earlier (Apple's PowerBook featured a Motorola 68030). This seriously impacted Apple's sales, especially in the business market. In 1993, Intel moved beyond the 486 by introducing the Pentium processors, while the never-released successor to the 68040 processor — the Motorola 68050 — was effectively skipped over in development, leaving the Macintosh a generation behind in CPU technology compared to IBM-compatible platforms. In 1994, Apple stopped incorporating Motorola CPUs in their computers. Since 1991, they had been developing a new RISC architecture platform (the PowerPC) in partnership with IBM and the AIM alliance with Apple, IBM, and Motorola. [95] The Power Macintosh line, using these new chips, proved very successful and ensured Apple's survival. [96] More than a million PowerPC machines sold. [97] However, the switch from the Motorola platform to the PowerPC in 1994 ultimately ended up being a poor choice, as AIM could not keep up with Intel once Intel-based chips became standardized, and Apple had permanently lost the ability to compete with companies like Dell on price. It took nine months for Apple to sell a million Power Macs. [97]

text_human: Other historians find incongruity in the proposition that the very place where the vast number of the scholars that influenced the scientific revolution received their education should also be the place that inhibits their research and the advancement of science. In fact, more than 80% of the European scientists between 1450–1650 included in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography were university trained, of which approximately 45% held university posts. It was the case that the academic foundations remaining from the Middle Ages were stable, and they did provide for an environment that fostered considerable growth and development. There was considerable reluctance on the part of universities to relinquish the symmetry and comprehensiveness provided by the Aristotelian system, which was effective as a coherent system for understanding and interpreting the world. However, university professors still utilized some autonomy, at least in the sciences, to choose epistemological foundations and methods. For instance, Melanchthon and his disciples at University of Wittenberg were instrumental for integrating Copernican mathematical constructs into astronomical debate and instruction. Another example was the short-lived but fairly rapid adoption of Cartesian epistemology and methodology in European universities, and the debates surrounding that adoption, which led to more mechanistic approaches to scientific problems as well as demonstrated an openness to change. There are many examples which belie the commonly perceived intransigence of universities. Although universities may have been slow to accept new sciences and methodologies as they emerged, when they did accept new ideas it helped to convey legitimacy and respectability, and supported the scientific changes through providing a stable environment for instruction and material resources.
text_ai_base: Some historians find it puzzling that the very institutions where scholars of the scientific revolution were educated could also be seen as hindering scientific progress. Interestingly, more than 80% of the European scientists from 1450 to 1650, as listed in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography, were trained at universities, and about 45% held positions there. The universities, rooted in medieval traditions, offered a stable environment that supported significant growth and development. Although there was hesitance to abandon the comprehensive and symmetrical Aristotelian system, which effectively explained the world, university professors in the sciences were allowed some independence in choosing their methods and foundational ideas. For example, Melanchthon and his followers at the University of Wittenberg played a key role in incorporating Copernican mathematical models into astronomical discussions and teaching. Similarly, the relatively quick acceptance of Cartesian thought at European universities, along with the ensuing debates, illustrated an openness to change and ushered in more mechanistic approaches to scientific inquiries. These examples challenge the notion that universities were resistant to change. While universities may have initially been slow to embrace new sciences and methodologies, they ultimately provided legitimacy and respectability to these ideas, supporting scientific advancements by offering a stable setting for teaching and resources.
text_ai_humanized: This idea is curious to some historians considering the fact that it was within such institutions that most scientific revolutionaries were educated. The information compiled by Thorndike in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography suggested that over 8 of every 10 individuals that performed some type of scientific work in Europe between 1450-1650 were university educated, and approximately 45% of those individuals received academic appointments at the respective institutions. The medieval universities provided a stability that allowed them to flourish. Despite the reluctance to veraciously transform the medieval all encompassing and symmetrical Aristotelian model that so readily clarified world, professors within scientific fields received some degree autonomy to determine their own approach and axioms. The University of Wittenberg's Melanchthon and his adherents contributed to the application of Copernican mathematical models in the practice and teaching of astronomy. The swift dissemination of Cartesian thinking throughout continental universities and the controversies concerning Cartesians and anti-Cartesians, for example, demonstrate the willingness to accept something new and the creation of more mechanistic interpretations of scientific analysis. Both of these instances are hardly indicative of a reluctance to change. Universities may have been slow in the initial adoption of various sciences, disciplines, and methodologies, but once incorporation took place, they effectively legitimated and rendered science reputable, as well as contributing to its further development because of the stability it provided to diffuse the teaching and resources.

text_human: Regarding the timing of German rapprochement, many historians agree that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov, whose Jewish ethnicity was viewed unfavorably by Nazi Germany, removed an obstacle to negotiations with Germany. Stalin immediately directed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Given Litvinov's prior attempts to create an anti-fascist coalition, association with the doctrine of collective security with France and Britain, and pro-Western orientation by the standards of the Kremlin, his dismissal indicated the existence of a Soviet option of rapprochement with Germany.[f] Likewise, Molotov's appointment served as a signal to Germany that the USSR was open to offers. The dismissal also signaled to France and Britain the existence of a potential negotiation option with Germany. One British official wrote that Litvinov's disappearance also meant the loss of an admirable technician or shock-absorber, while Molotov's "modus operandi" was "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr argued that the Soviet Union's replacement of Foreign Minister Litvinov with Molotov on May 3, 1939 indicated not an irrevocable shift towards alignment with Germany, but rather was Stalin's way of engaging in hard bargaining with the British and the French by appointing a proverbial hard man, namely Molotov, to the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis stated that the Litvinov dismissal gave the Soviets freedom to pursue faster-paced German negotiations, but that they did not abandon British–French talks. Derek Watson argued that Molotov could get the best deal with Britain and France because he was not encumbered with the baggage of collective security and could negotiate with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts argued that Litvinov's dismissal helped the Soviets with British–French talks, because Litvinov doubted or maybe even opposed such discussions.
text_ai_base: Historians often agree that Maxim Litvinov's dismissal played a crucial role in facilitating negotiations between Germany and the Soviet Union. Litvinov's Jewish ethnicity was considered unfavorable by Nazi Germany, and his removal reduced barriers to diplomacy. Stalin swiftly instructed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Litvinov had previously tried to form an anti-fascist coalition and was closely associated with collective security arrangements with France and Britain. His pro-Western stance by Kremlin standards signaled a possible Soviet shift towards rapprochement with Germany. Molotov's appointment was intended as a clear signal to Germany that the USSR was open to dialogue. Simultaneously, Litvinov's dismissal communicated to France and Britain that the USSR might negotiate with Germany. A British official noted that Litvinov's exit marked the loss of a skilled negotiator, while Molotov's approach was "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr argued that replacing Litvinov with Molotov on May 3, 1939 was not an irreversible alignment with Germany, but rather Stalin's strategy to engage in tough negotiations with Britain and France by appointing Molotov, known for his firmness, to the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis believed that Litvinov's dismissal freed the Soviets to pursue quicker negotiations with Germany, while maintaining talks with Britain and France. Derek Watson supported the idea that Molotov could secure the best deal with Britain and France since he was free from the constraints of collective security and able to engage with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts contended that Litvinov's dismissal furthered Soviet discussions with Britain and France, as Litvinov had doubts or even opposed such negotiations.
text_ai_humanized: Some historians believe Litvinov's removal was a signal to Germany that the Soviet Union was ready for talks regarding a non-aggression pact;[citation needed] they view that as one of the key steps to the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact. Litvinov's Jewish heritage was also viewed unfavorably by Germany's antisemitic Nazi government, and Litvinov's dismissal eased the conclusion of a Soviet–German agreement. Upon being appointed head of the ministry, Molotov was told by Stalin that before long he must "purge the ministry of Jews." For his part, Litvinov had proactively pushed for an anti-fascist coalition. He was closely identified with collective security—a system which, in Stalin's words, so far had only trapped "the small and weak states." His successor, Molotov, considered by some members of the diplomatic corps a "steel-hard Bolshevik", was reputedly more "pliable" in Stalin's hands. As a consequence of the replacement, the pro-Western diplomatic approach was soon replaced by a pro-German one, signifying the existence of a Soviet option of rapprochement with Germany. Time magazine described Molotov's appointment as "the signal for a complete reversal of Soviet policy" and observed that Litvinov had "staked his career on collective security against the Hitler menace." Stalin immediately directed Molotov to "clean the ministry of Jews." According to the popular interpretation of Soviet motives, the replacement of Litvinov by Molotov indicated an inclination on Stalin's part to respond positively to German diplomatic advances. Literary Digest echoed that sentiment by proclaiming that "this act of ours [SSR] was the first step down the path of an agreement with Germany." Meanwhile, Polish envoy to Moscow; Wacław Grzybowski concluded that the dismissal indicated the Soviets "really sought an understanding with Hitler." The dismissal served as a warning to France and Britain that the Soviets might be negotiating with Germany. In fact, Soviet historians place the beginning of such negotiations just after Litvinov's dismissal. A British government official wrote: "the Litvinov incident did most certainly harm to our negotiations… we lost Litvinov, a friend, knowledgeable about the West, and replaced him with Molotov—the Politburo yes-man, a man who had to get special translator even in speaking to our Ambassador." Charles (Carlos) De Beaulieu, a German diplomat, similarly wrote: "during the sudden dismissal of Litvinov and the execution of Moscow purge trials… one could learn about it from the news how valuable mutual trust was in Litvinov's eyes; but today things are very different, today the two systems (fascist Germany versus Communist USSR) pursue a policy of appeasement and close collaboration." In his essay "The Sources of Soviet Conduct", published in Foreign Affairs in 1947 under the pseudonym "X", George F. Kennan wrote "Stalin's hostility to the West was profound, instinctive, and implacable, and that he truly aspired to nothing so much as the 'composition of differences' with Hitler." Just a few months later Kennan recanted this position. Post-Cold-War historical research shows that revisionist historians already questioned this view as early as the late 1970s. Carr argued that the "removal of Litvinov and the appointment of Molotov on 3 May 1939 was not… an irrevocable step on the road to the German alliance; it was in fact more probably, as one well-informed observer supposed, an attempt to speed up the negotiations with Great Britain on which the Soviet government had at last decided to embark by putting at the head of the Foreign Commissariat a leading member of the Politburo who would have the necessary authority 'to negotiate on equal terms'" Carr adds that "Litvinov had long been the foreign statesman who stood for no retreat from collective security towards Germany… replacing of Litvinov by Molotov might be designed to clear the way for 'conversations' with Germany on an economic basis." Historian Albert Resis noted that "Whatever Stalin's motive, Litvinov's replacement by Molotov cheered the Germans, deeply concerned the British and the French, and freed the Soviets to move more rapidly towards a German-Soviet agreement." When conducting literature reviews, Derek Watson postulates that, "as long as Litvinov remained Commissar, the Soviets could undertake no more than tentative, exploratory talks with Berlin. Molotov, however, could get the best deal with Great Britain and France since he liberated from the constraints of collective security that Germany no longer seemed disposed to attack." Geoffrey Roberts argued that the removal of Litvinov was not the beginning of Soviet rapprochement with Germany, but rather "it facilitated negotiations with Britain and France. Litvinov was opposed to or at least had serious doubts about such a shift in policy."

text_human: The Mughals were perhaps the richest single dynasty to have ever existed. During the Mughal era, the dominant political forces consisted of the Mughal Empire and its tributaries and, later on, the rising successor states – including the Maratha Empire – which fought an increasingly weak Mughal dynasty. The Mughals, while often employing brutal tactics to subjugate their empire, had a policy of integration with Indian culture, which is what made them successful where the short-lived Sultanates of Delhi had failed. This period marked vast social change in the subcontinent as the Hindu majority were ruled over by the Mughal emperors, most of whom showed religious tolerance, liberally patronising Hindu culture. The famous emperor Akbar, who was the grandson of Babar, tried to establish a good relationship with the Hindus. However, later emperors such as Aurangazeb tried to establish complete Muslim dominance, and as a result several historical temples were destroyed during this period and taxes imposed on non-Muslims. Akbar declared "Amari" or non-killing of animals in the holy days of Jainism. He rolled back the jizya tax for non-Muslims. The Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local maharajas, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating a unique Indo-Saracenic architecture. It was the erosion of this tradition coupled with increased brutality and centralization that played a large part in the dynasty's downfall after Aurangzeb, who unlike previous emperors, imposed relatively non-pluralistic policies on the general population, which often inflamed the majority Hindu population.
text_ai_base: The Mughal dynasty is considered one of the wealthiest in history. During their rule, the Mughal Empire and its tributaries were the dominant political forces, although eventually they faced challenges from emerging successor states like the Maratha Empire, which contested the progressively weakening Mughal dynasty. Despite their often brutal methods of control, the Mughals succeeded by integrating with Indian culture—a strategy that distinguished them from the short-lived Sultanates of Delhi. This era saw significant social changes as the Hindu majority came under the rule of Mughal emperors, who mostly displayed religious tolerance and actively supported Hindu culture. Akbar, the notable emperor and grandson of Babar, aimed to foster good relations with Hindus. In contrast, later emperors like Aurangzeb pursued complete Muslim dominance, leading to the destruction of historic temples and the imposition of taxes on non-Muslims. Akbar had introduced "Amari," banning animal killings on holy Jain days, and abolished the jizya tax on non-Muslims. Mughal emperors often married into local royalty, allied with regional maharajas, and blended their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, giving rise to unique Indo-Saracenic architecture. The erosion of these traditions, alongside increasing brutality and centralization, contributed significantly to the dynasty’s decline after Aurangzeb, whose policies departed from his predecessors' pluralism, provoking unrest among the predominantly Hindu population.
text_ai_humanized: The Mughals or Moghul dynasty were an empire of Turko-Mongol origin that ruled most of North India by 1600. In the height of their existence, around 1700, the Mughal Empire and its tributaries comprised the dominant political forces in the Indian Subcontinent, but they were eventually superseded by the British and later the Maratha and Sikh empires. Mughals eventually moved around later successor states such as the Maratha Empire, which challenged and weakened the Mughal dynasty. Although, it was common to see oppressive power, the "Mughals" managed to rule through India by adopting a "Indian" approach. This was in stark contrast to the sultanates of Delhi, which lost most of its powers and fell. During this period of time, the majority Hindu population came to be ruled over by Mughal emperors, some of whom showed tolerance towards the beliefs of non-Muslim Hindu religion, while encouraging practices of Hindu culture. Akbar the Great (grandson of Babar) was known in Indian history for his tolerant attitude towards Hindus. Until the last quarter of his reign, when he adopted a puritanical form of Islam, Aurangzeb also persecuted Hindus. He destroyed several historically important temples, and imposed taxes on non-Hindus. Akbar., in establishing the "Amari" (non-killing of the animals) on the holy days of the Jains, and lifting "jizya", the tax on non-Hindus, that was reimposed later by Aurangzeb. Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local Mahrajas, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating unique Indo-Saracenic architecture. The destruction of these practices and cultures, along with increased brutality and centralization, were a major factor in the dynasty's downfall after Aurangzeb, due to the lack of public support. Although Persian-speaking, the Moguls were of Turko-Mongol origin. Under the Mughal Empire, India once again achieved political unity. Aurangzeb’s lack of pluralism caused rifts in the mainly Hindu populace. Although Mughal power was at its peak under his rule, his persecution of certain religious communities eventually undermined the stability of the Mughal Empire.

text_human: Medieval Cholas rose to prominence during the middle of the 9th century C.E. and established the greatest empire South India had seen. They successfully united the South India under their rule and through their naval strength extended their influence in the Southeast Asian countries such as Srivijaya. Under Rajaraja Chola I and his successors Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola and Kulothunga Chola I the dynasty became a military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia. Rajendra Chola I's navies went even further, occupying the sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, the Lakshadweep (Laccadive) islands, Sumatra, and the Malay Peninsula in Southeast Asia and the Pegu islands. The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the Ganges which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of Srivijaya in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China. They dominated the political affairs of Sri Lanka for over two centuries through repeated invasions and occupation. They also had continuing trade contacts with the Arabs in the west and with the Chinese empire in the east. Rajaraja Chola I and his equally distinguished son Rajendra Chola I gave political unity to the whole of Southern India and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power. Under the Cholas, the South India reached new heights of excellence in art, religion and literature. In all of these spheres, the Chola period marked the culmination of movements that had begun in an earlier age under the Pallavas. Monumental architecture in the form of majestic temples and sculpture in stone and bronze reached a finesse never before achieved in India.
text_ai_base: The Medieval Cholas emerged as a powerful dynasty in the mid-9th century C.E., creating the most significant empire South India had ever witnessed. They unified South India and leveraged their naval prowess to extend their influence to Southeast Asian regions like Srivijaya. Under rulers such as Rajaraja Chola I and his successors—Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola, and Kulothunga Chola I—the dynasty became an influential military, economic, and cultural force in South and Southeast Asia. Rajendra Chola I's fleets sailed far, establishing control along sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, the Lakshadweep islands, Sumatra, and the Malay Peninsula. The empire's might was showcased through Rajendra Chola I's expedition to the Ganges, the occupation of cities within Srivijaya, and multiple embassies to China. The Cholas dominated Sri Lanka's politics for over two centuries through invasions and occupations and maintained robust trade with both Arab regions and the Chinese empire. Rajaraja Chola I and his prominent son Rajendra Chola I achieved political cohesion across Southern India, solidifying the Chola Empire's status as a commanding sea power. This era saw South India reach unparalleled levels in art, religion, and literature, with the Chola period representing the pinnacle of cultural movements initiated earlier by the Pallavas. Their monumental temples and exquisite stone and bronze sculptures set new standards of excellence in India.
text_ai_humanized: The Medieval Cholas rose to prominence in middle of the 9th century C.E. and established the greatest empire South India has seen. They successfully united South India and held their influence over Southeast Asian countries including Srivijaya. During the period of Chola naval power, the Medieval Cholas under great kings such as Rajaraja Chola I, his son Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola and Kulothunga Chola I were the most powerful military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia.[159] The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the Ganges which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of Srivijaya in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China,[160] The Chola fleet represented the zenith of ancient Indian sea power. Chola territories stretched from the islands of Maldives in the south to as far north as the banks of the Godavari River in Andhra Pradesh. Rajaraja Chola conquered peninsular South India, annexed parts of which is now Sri Lanka and occupied the islands of the Maldives.[161] Rajendra Chola sent a victorious expedition to northern India that touched the river Ganges and defeated the Pala ruler of Pataliputra, Mahipala.[162] He also successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia: the areas now part of Malaysia, Indonesia and southern Thailand and Sri Lanka in 1018 C.E.[163] The Chola dynasty went into decline at the beginning of the 13th century C.E. with the rise of the Pandyan Dynasty, which ultimately caused their downfall.[164][165] South India during the Chola period had the most advanced civilization in the subcontinent.[166] The Cholas excelled in foreign trade and maritime activity, extending their influence overseas to China and Southeast Asia. Towards the end of the 9th century, south India had developed extensive sea trade with the Arabs (west) and the Chinese (east).[167] Rajaraja Chola I and his equally distinguished son Rajendra Chola I, instituted a coherent system of administration and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power.[168][169] The Chola Dynasty, in addition to its military achievements, was at the forefront of art, religion, and literature. It was during the Chola period that the Tamil culture reached its greatest expression and influenced the culture of Southeast Asia. In all of these spheres, the Cholas excelled other contemporary Indian dynasties. The Chola kings were prolific temple builders right from the times of the first medieval king Vijayalaya Chola.[170] These temples exhibit the mature classical style of Tamil architecture. The Cholas continued to govern over an expanding kingdom until it eventually grew into a vast empire[171] during the tenth and eleventh centuries. During the period 1010–1200 C.E., South India reached new heights in art, religious literature, and architecture.[172] The Chola Empire was at its peak and its dominions stretched from the islands of the Maldives in the south to as far north as the banks of the Godavari River in Andhra Pradesh. The monuments of the Cholas are scattered all over the globe. And bigger temples include the Tanjavur temple[173] and Gangaikondacholapuram.

text_human: On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by his son Richard. A tragic blow fell upon Burke with the loss of Richard in August 1794, to whom he was tenderly attached, and in whom he saw signs of promise, which were not patent to others and which, in fact, appear to have been non-existent (though this view may have rather reflected the fact that Richard Burke had worked successfully in the early battle for Catholic emancipation). King George III, whose favour he had gained by his attitude on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield, but the death of his son deprived the opportunity of such an honour and all its attractions, so the only award he would accept was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest reward was attacked by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, to whom Burke replied in his Letter to a Noble Lord (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He argued that he was rewarded on merit, but the Duke of Bedford received his rewards from inheritance alone, his ancestor being the original pensioner: "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth". Burke also hinted at what would happen to such people if their revolutionary ideas were implemented, and included a description of the British constitution:
text_ai_base: On June 20, 1794, Burke was honored with a vote of thanks from the Commons for his role in the Hastings Trial. He then resigned, with his son Richard taking his place. Sadly, in August 1794, Burke suffered a devastating loss with Richard’s passing. Burke was deeply attached to his son and saw great potential in him, which was not apparent to others, although Richard had played a successful part in the early fight for Catholic emancipation. King George III, appreciating Burke’s stance on the French Revolution, wanted to make him Earl of Beaconsfield. However, the possibility of this honor diminished with Richard’s death, leaving Burke only willing to accept a £2,500 pension. The pension became the target of criticism from the Duke of Bedford and Earl of Lauderdale, prompting Burke’s well-known retort in his "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform." Burke insisted he was awarded based on merit, while the Duke of Bedford's rewards came solely from inheritance, highlighting that Burke's compensation was granted by a kind sovereign and Bedford’s ancestor from Henry VIII. Burke also hinted at the consequences if their radical ideas were realized, providing an insightful view of the British constitution.
text_ai_humanized: Burke was praised by Charles James Fox, who said that “Burke’s genius and eloquence entitle him to rank with our greatest men”, and in 1794 he was presented with the vote of thanks by the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial. Soon, he published the “Letter to a Noble Lord.” After the Commons passed the Vote of Thanks to Burke, he resigned his seat and left Parliament, leaving his son Richard as member for Malton. In May 1794 a curate named Dupont, who was a leader of the peasantry in Brittany, had settled in London and in August Richard Burke died. His death left his father devastated with grief. Burke’s son had been seen as the next leader of the Whigs and had inherited his father’s talents. Although Richard had apparently been his father’s closest friend and ally, Burke had supported his son in ways not many saw as bright, although his efforts in the early struggle for Catholic emancipation were fruitful. Because of his own stand against the French Revolution, Burke received recognition in the form of an offer from King George III to be raised to the peerage as Earl of Beaconsfield. Whense this prospect ended with the early death of his son, his sole condition for accepting it—Burke then accepted only a pension of £2,500. On the subject, he published the “Letter to a Noble Lord” (1796), at once a reply to the Duke of Bedford and Earl of Lauderdale who had attacked his pension as well as a treatise on the value of nobility. Burke claimed that he was rewarded on the basis of a merit which the Duke of Bedford lacked, he being only honoured by inheritance. Burke closed the work with a defence of his life and conduct: It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform. Burke owned that he was given his position from a humane sovereign whilst the Duke of Bedford’s was from Henry VIII: …the merit of the Crown has been in its bounty to him and the merit of the Duke of Bedford is in receiving and in keeping the bounty of the Crown. Burke, in the “Letter”, also hinted at what would happen to such people if their ideas were implemented, giving a passage from what would happen to be an aristocratic point of view on the British constitution.

In May 1794 a curate named Dupont, who was a leader of the peasantry in Brittany, had settled in London and in August Richard Burke died. His death left his father devastated with grief. Burke’s son had been seen as the next leader of the Whigs and had inherited his father’s talents. Although Richard had apparently been his father’s closest friend and ally, Burke had supported his son in ways not many saw as bright, although his efforts in the early struggle for Catholic emancipation were fruitful. Because of his own stand against the French Revolution, Burke received recognition in the form of an offer from King George III to be raised to the peerage as Earl of Beaconsfield. Whense this prospect ended with the early death of his son, his sole condition for accepting it—Burke then accepted only a pension of £2,500. text_human: The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction between black and white Bermudians, other than those characterising recent immigrant communities. In the 17th century, this was not so. For the first hundred years of settlement, white Protestants of English heritage were the distinct majority, with white minorities of Irish (the native language of many of whom can be assumed to have been Gaelic) and Scots sent to Bermuda after the English invasions of their homelands that followed the English Civil War. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking, free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black chattel slaves primarily captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans, primarily from the Algonquian and other tribes of the Atlantic seaboard, but possibly from as far away as Mexico. By the 19th century, the white ethnically-English Bermudians had lost their numerical advantage. Despite the banning of the importation of Irish, and the repeated attempts to force free blacks to emigrate and the owners of black slaves to export them, the merging of the various minority groups, along with some of the white English, had resulted in a new demographic group, "coloured" (which term, in Bermuda, referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry) Bermudians, gaining a slight majority. Any child born before or since then to one coloured and one white parent has been added to the coloured statistic. Most of those historically described as "coloured" are today described as "black", or "of African heritage", which obscures their non-African heritage (those previously described as "coloured" who were not of African ancestry had been very few, though the numbers of South Asians, particularly, is now growing. The number of persons born in Asian countries doubled between the 2000 and the 2010 censuses), blacks have remained in the majority, with new white immigration from Portugal, Britain and elsewhere countered by black immigration from the West Indies.
text_ai_base: The complex ancestral history of Bermuda's population has been obscured over the last four centuries due to ethnic homogenization. Today, there is virtually no ethnic distinction between black and white Bermudians, apart from those reflected in recent immigrant communities. However, this was not the case in the 17th century. During the first hundred years of settlement, the majority consisted of white Protestants with English heritage, accompanied by smaller groups of Irish, who likely spoke Gaelic, and Scots, sent to Bermuda following English invasions after the English Civil War. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black slaves typically captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans from tribes along the Atlantic seaboard, and possibly as far as Mexico. By the 19th century, the white, ethnically English Bermudians had lost their numerical dominance. Although laws were enacted to ban Irish importation and efforts were made to force free blacks to emigrate and export black slaves, the blending of various minority groups, including some white English, led to the emergence of a new demographic termed "coloured." In Bermuda, "coloured" referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry, forming a slight majority. Children born to one coloured and one white parent were categorized as coloured. Most individuals historically labeled as "coloured" are now described as "black" or "of African heritage," which largely masks their non-African ancestry. Individuals previously identified as "coloured" without African roots were few, though numbers of South Asians are now rising, evidenced by the doubling of those born in Asian countries between the 2000 and 2010 censuses. Although blacks have remained the majority, this demographic has been balanced by new white immigration from Portugal, Britain, and other regions, countered by black immigration from the West Indies.

text_human: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. To prevent the risk of an arc being drawn across from one section of wire to earth, when passing through the neutral section, the train must be coasting and the circuit breakers must be open. In many cases, this is done manually by the drivers. To help them, a warning board is provided just before both the neutral section and an advance warning some distance before. A further board is then provided after the neutral section to tell drivers to re-close the circuit breaker, although drivers must not do this until the rear pantograph has passed this board. In the UK, a system known as Automatic Power Control (APC) automatically opens and closes the circuit breaker, this being achieved by using sets of permanent magnets alongside the track communicating with a detector on the train. The only action needed by the driver is to shut off power and coast and therefore warning boards are still provided at and on the approach to neutral sections.
text_ai_base: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of rail fed from different feeder stations must remain thoroughly isolated. This is accomplished through Neutral Sections, also called Phase Breaks, which are typically located at feeder stations and halfway between them. Normally, only half of these sections are active, allowing another feeder station to be shut down as power is supplied from nearby feeder stations. Neutral Sections consist of an earthed section of wire separated from live wires on either side by insulating materials, such as ceramic beads, enabling the pantograph to transition smoothly between sections. The grounded section prevents arcing between live sections due to potentially high voltage differences when live sections exist on separate phases. Protective circuit breakers might struggle to safely handle the significant current that could occur. To avoid drawing an arc from one wire section to the ground while passing through the neutral section, trains must coast with circuit breakers open. This is often done manually by drivers, who are aided by a warning board placed before the neutral section and an advance warning board some distance ahead. Another board follows the neutral section, instructing drivers to close the circuit breaker, but only after the rear pantograph has passed it. In the UK, an Automatic Power Control (APC) system manages the opening and closing of circuit breakers automatically using sets of permanent magnets along the track that interact with a detector on the train. Despite this automation, drivers must still cut off power and coast, so warning boards remain in place near neutral sections and along their approach.
text_ai_humanized: Since supplies that are back to back are not in phase with each other, sections of rail supplied by different feeder stations have to be kept well separated. This separation is provided by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase break) that can be found at the feeder stations and half-way between feeder stations. Only every other section is normally energised, to allow another feeder station to be shut down, whilst power is provided from adjacent feeder stations. The neutral section consists of a short section of wire that is earthed and separated from the live wires to each side, by insulators (e. g. fairly large beads of ceramic), so that the pantograph can easily move across the section. The section is earthed, so that the live sections (that may be at significantly different voltages when on different phases) don't arc between each other, which might be difficult for the protective circuit breakers to safely handle the relatively massive currents that could result. The train is also not allowed to draw an arc between a live section of wire and earth whilst passing between (by having energised electrical equipment), so trains are not allowed to draw power whilst passing through a neutral section. This is usually manually controlled by the driver, energising and de-energising the circuit breaker that connects the pantograph (and hence the equipment on the train) to the contact wire; the driver is assisted in this task by a warning board on the wayside, adjacent to the neutral section and an advance warning board some distance before it. A third board is located after the neutral section, when the driver is allowed to close the circuit breaker however, the driver has to wait until the rear pantograph is past the notification board to close the circuity. This task in the UK is now performed automatically by an Automatic Power Control (APC) system. The APC permanently opens the circuit breakers with the first set of permanent magnets that are attached on the rails and connected to a detector on the train, and then closes the circuit breakers with the second set of permanent magnets, allowing the driver to close the circuit breakers, once the rear panograph is beyond the APC Air Gap. The drivers however, are still required to cut the traction power and coast, so the boards indicating the neutral sections and APC Air Gaps are still in place near neutral sections and perhaps in advance of the locations.

text_human: Fearing the worst, the Romans began a major mobilization, all but pulling out of recently pacified Spain and Gaul. They even established a major garrison in Sicily in case the Seleucids ever got to Italy. This fear was shared by Rome's Greek allies, who had largely ignored Rome in the years after the Second Macedonian War, but now followed Rome again for the first time since that war. A major Roman-Greek force was mobilized under the command of the great hero of the Second Punic War, Scipio Africanus, and set out for Greece, beginning the Roman-Syrian War. After initial fighting that revealed serious Seleucid weaknesses, the Seleucids tried to turn the Roman strength against them at the Battle of Thermopylae (as they believed the 300 Spartans had done centuries earlier). Like the Spartans, the Seleucids lost the battle, and were forced to evacuate Greece. The Romans pursued the Seleucids by crossing the Hellespont, which marked the first time a Roman army had ever entered Asia. The decisive engagement was fought at the Battle of Magnesia, resulting in a complete Roman victory. The Seleucids sued for peace, and Rome forced them to give up their recent Greek conquests. Although they still controlled a great deal of territory, this defeat marked the decline of their empire, as they were to begin facing increasingly aggressive subjects in the east (the Parthians) and the west (the Greeks). Their empire disintegrated into a rump over the course of the next century, when it was eclipsed by Pontus. Following Magnesia, Rome again withdrew from Greece, assuming (or hoping) that the lack of a major Greek power would ensure a stable peace. In fact, it did the opposite.

text_human: Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia's market reforms put it among the economic leaders in the former COMECON area.[citation needed] In 1994, based on the economic theories of Milton Friedman, Estonia became one of the first countries to adopt a flat tax, with a uniform rate of 26% regardless of personal income. In January 2005, the personal income tax rate was reduced to 24%. Another reduction to 23% followed in January 2006. The income tax rate was decreased to 21% by January 2008. The Government of Estonia finalised the design of Estonian euro coins in late 2004, and adopted the euro as the country's currency on 1 January 2011, later than planned due to continued high inflation. A Land Value Tax is levied which is used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, however 100% of the revenue is used to fund Local Councils. The rate is set by the Local Council within the limits of 0.1–2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities. The Land Value Tax is levied on the value of the land only with improvements and buildings not considered. Very few exemptions are considered on the land value tax and even public institutions are subject to the tax. The tax has contributed to a high rate (~90%) of owner-occupied residences within Estonia, compared to a rate of 67.4% in the United States.
text_ai_base: Since regaining independence, Estonia has positioned itself as a gateway between East and West, actively pursuing economic reform and integration with Western countries. Its market reforms have made Estonia a leader among former COMECON nations.[citation needed] In 1994, inspired by Milton Friedman’s economic theories, Estonia implemented a flat tax, initially set at 26% for personal income, regardless of individual earnings. The rate was lowered to 24% in January 2005, to 23% in January 2006, and further reduced to 21% by January 2008. Estonia finalized its euro coin designs in late 2004 and adopted the euro as its currency on January 1, 2011, a delay caused by persistently high inflation. Estonia also levies a Land Value Tax to fund local municipalities, setting the rate at the state level but allocating 100% of the revenue to local councils. The local council determines the tax rate within a range of 0.1–2.5%. This tax, based solely on land value without considering buildings, is among the most critical funding sources for municipalities. There are minimal exemptions, and even public institutions must pay the tax. Consequently, Estonia boasts a high rate of owner-occupied homes at about 90%, significantly higher than the 67.4% in the United States.

text_human: In 1718, at the behest of either Rector Samuel Andrew or the colony's Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather contacted a successful businessman named Elihu Yale, who lived in Wales but had been born in Boston and whose father, David, had been one of the original settlers in New Haven, to ask him for financial help in constructing a new building for the college. Through the persuasion of Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had made a fortune through trade while living in Madras as a representative of the East India Company, donated nine bales of goods, which were sold for more than £560, a substantial sum at the time. Cotton Mather suggested that the school change its name to Yale College. Meanwhile, a Harvard graduate working in England convinced some 180 prominent intellectuals that they should donate books to Yale. The 1714 shipment of 500 books represented the best of modern English literature, science, philosophy and theology. It had a profound effect on intellectuals at Yale. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards discovered John Locke's works and developed his original theology known as the "new divinity." In 1722 the Rector and six of his friends, who had a study group to discuss the new ideas, announced that they had given up Calvinism, become Arminians, and joined the Church of England. They were ordained in England and returned to the colonies as missionaries for the Anglican faith. Thomas Clapp became president in 1745, and struggled to return the college to Calvinist orthodoxy; but he did not close the library. Other students found Deist books in the library.
text_ai_base: In 1718, prompted by either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather reached out to Elihu Yale, a prosperous businessman living in Wales. Born in Boston, Yale's father, David, was among New Haven's earliest settlers. Mather sought Yale’s financial assistance to construct a new building for the college. Persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had accumulated wealth through trade during his stay in Madras with the East India Company, contributed nine bales of goods. These were sold for over £560, a considerable amount back then. In honor of Yale’s generosity, Mather proposed renaming the school to Yale College. Concurrently, a Harvard alumnus in England convinced about 180 leading intellectuals to donate books to Yale. The 1714 shipment, containing 500 volumes, represented the best of contemporary English literature, science, philosophy, and theology, significantly influencing Yale’s intellectual climate. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards encountered John Locke's works, which inspired his "new divinity" theology. In 1722, the Rector and six friends, who formed a group to study these new ideas, renounced Calvinism, adopted Arminianism, and joined the Church of England. They were ordained in England and returned as Anglican missionaries. Thomas Clapp became president in 1745 and attempted to steer the college back to Calvinist orthodoxy, though he left the library open. Some students discovered Deist literature there.

The 1714 shipments of 500 books represented the best of modern English literature, science, philosophy and theology at the time. It had a profound effect on intellectuals at Yale. A wooden sculpture of the school's first mascot, Handsome Dan Mather suggested that the school change its name to Yale College. Meanwhile, a Harvard graduate working in England convinced 180 prominent intellectuals to donate books to Yale. The 1714 shipments of 500 books represented the best of modern English literature, science, philosophy and theology at the time. It had a profound effect on intellectuals at Yale. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards discovered John Locke's works and developed his original theology known as the “new divinity.” In 1722 the Rector and six of his friends, who had a study group to discuss the new ideas, announced that they had given up Calvinism, become Arminians, and joined the Church of England. They were ordained in England and returned to the colonies as missionaries for the Anglican faith.[10] Thomas Clapp became president in 1745, and although he attempted to return the college to Calvinist orthodoxy, he did not close the library. Other students found Deist books in the library.[11]

text_human: Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who stayed on the Maluku Islands (Ternate and Gilolo). It enclosed twenty pages describing an evolutionary mechanism, a response to Darwin's recent encouragement, with a request to send it on to Lyell if Darwin thought it worthwhile. The mechanism was similar to Darwin's own theory. Darwin wrote to Lyell that "your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled" and he would "of course, at once write and offer to send [it] to any journal" that Wallace chose, adding that "all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed". Lyell and Hooker agreed that a joint publication putting together Wallace's pages with extracts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray should be presented at the Linnean Society, and on 1 July 1858, the papers entitled On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection, by Wallace and Darwin respectively, were read out but drew little reaction. While Darwin considered Wallace's idea to be identical to his concept of natural selection, historians have pointed out differences. Darwin described natural selection as being analogous to the artificial selection practised by animal breeders, and emphasised competition between individuals; Wallace drew no comparison to selective breeding, and focused on ecological pressures that kept different varieties adapted to local conditions. Some historians have suggested that Wallace was actually discussing group selection rather than selection acting on individual variation.
