Inside were twenty pages outlining an evolutionary mechanism, sent in response to Darwin's recent encouragement, with a request to forward the document to Lyell if Darwin deemed it valuable. This mechanism was strikingly similar to Darwin’s own theory. In a letter to Lyell, Darwin remarked that "your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled," and stated he would "of course, at once write and offer to send [it] to any journal" Wallace preferred, adding that "all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed." Lyell and Hooker proposed a joint presentation, combining Wallace's pages with excerpts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray, to be submitted to the Linnean Society. On 1 July 1858, the papers titled On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection, by Wallace and Darwin respectively, were read aloud but received little reaction. Although Darwin viewed Wallace's idea as identical to his own concept of natural selection, historians have noted differences. Darwin likened natural selection to artificial selection practiced by animal breeders, emphasizing individual competition. In contrast, Wallace did not draw comparisons to selective breeding and focused on ecological pressures that maintained varieties adapted to local environments. Some historians suggest Wallace may have been addressing group selection rather than individual variation.
text_ai_humanized: Darwin was hard at work on the manuscript for his 'big book' on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who remained in the Maluku Islands (Ternate and Gilolo). It enclosed about twenty pages describing an evolutionary mechanism, sent to him for his comments, with a request to pass it on to Lyell if Darwin thought it worthwhile. Wallace's evolutionary mechanism was similar to Darwin's own theory. Darwin sent a letter to Lyell, saying 'your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled', and enclosed Wallace's pages to be sent on to Darwin's friend, botanist Joseph Hooker, saying 'He could not have made a better short abstract! Even his terms now stand as heads of my chapters... he does not say he wishes me to publish, but I shall of course at once write & offer to send to any journal. So all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed'. At Lyell's urging, Darwin sent a letter to Wallace telling him that he had not intended "to forestall you", which as "far as the mere [evolutionary] theory is concerned", was "right, & original". While Wallace had not asked for publication of the manuscript, Darwin "would, at once, have sent [it] to some journal" had Wallace not instead sent it to him.[54] Darwin, Lyell and Hooker agreed on a joint presentation to a meeting of the Linnean Society of London, with publication of Wallace's pages in the Society's journal, together with extracts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray. On 1 July 1858, the papers by Wallace and Darwin were read on On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection. Darwin's paper was titled "An abstract from an unpublished work on Species by C. Darwin, Esq., consisting of a portion of a chapter entitled "On the variation of organic beings in a state of nature; on the natural means of selection; on the comparison of domestic races; and on the conditions favourable to the formation of new species", and written July 1837.[55] Wallace's paper was titled "On the Tendency of Varieties to Depart Indefinitely from the Original Type". Papers read to the Linnean Society were not discussed at the meetings, so no debate occurred, but the president of the society remarked in May 1859 that the year had not been marked by any striking discoveries; and Darwin wrote "our joint productions excited very little attention, & the only published notice of them was by Professor Haughton of Dublin, whose verdict was that 'all that was new in them was false, and what was true was old.'".[56] Wallace's paper was titled "On the Tendency of Varieties to Depart Indefinitely from the Original Type". Darwin considered Wallace's idea to be identical to his concept of natural selection; historians have noted differences. Darwin described natural selection among individual variations, emphasizing competition between individuals; Wallace drew no comparison to selective breeding of animals, and Darwin pictured no role for ecological pressures while Wallace focused on pressures that kept varieties adapted to local conditions. Wallace appears to have been discussing group selection rather than individual variation.[57][58]

text_human: The interface of Windows 8 has been the subject of mixed reaction. Bright wrote that its system of hot corners and edge swiping "wasn't very obvious" due to the lack of instructions provided by the operating system on the functions accessed through the user interface, even by the video tutorial added on the RTM release (which only instructed users to point at corners of the screen or swipe from its sides). Despite this "stumbling block", Bright said that Windows 8's interface worked well in some places, but began to feel incoherent when switching between the "Metro" and desktop environments, sometimes through inconsistent means. Tom Warren of The Verge wrote that the new interface was "as stunning as it is surprising", contributing to an "incredibly personal" experience once it is customized by the user, but had a steep learning curve, and was awkward to use with a keyboard and mouse. He noted that while forcing all users to use the new touch-oriented interface was a risky move for Microsoft as a whole, it was necessary in order to push development of apps for the Windows Store. Others, such as Adrian Kingsley-Hughes from ZDNet, considered the interface to be "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design (going as far as considering it "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together"), and concluded that "Windows 8 wasn't born out of a need or demand; it was born out of a desire on Microsoft's part to exert its will on the PC industry and decide to shape it in a direction—touch and tablets -- that allows it to compete against, and remain relevant in the face of Apple's iPad."
text_ai_base: Windows 8's interface has received a mixed response from critics. Bright observed that the system's use of hot corners and edge swiping "wasn't very obvious," as the operating system provided minimal guidance on accessing functions through the user interface, even with the video tutorial included in the RTM release. This tutorial only suggested that users point at screen corners or swipe its sides. Despite this challenge, Bright mentioned that the interface worked well in certain aspects but became incoherent when transitioning between the "Metro" and desktop environments, sometimes using inconsistent methods. Tom Warren of The Verge described the new interface as "stunning" and "surprising," noting that it created a "personal" experience once customized by users, though he acknowledged its steep learning curve and awkwardness when used with a keyboard and mouse. Warren highlighted that while compelling all users to adopt the touch-focused interface was a risky strategy for Microsoft, it was essential for driving app development for the Windows Store. Conversely, Adrian Kingsley-Hughes from ZDNet criticized the interface as "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design, likening it to "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together." He argued that "Windows 8 wasn't born out of necessity or demand; it was Microsoft's attempt to shape the PC industry toward touch and tablets, allowing competition against Apple's iPad and ensuring relevance."
text_ai_humanized: Critical reception of the Windows 8 interface have been mixed. Bright noted that the operating system's use of hot corners as parts of its interface was "not very obvious" due to the lack of any on-screen hints beyond the video tutorial added to the RTM version, which only advised users to point at corners, or the sides of the screen and swipe them for touchscreen users, to access features. Despite this "stumbling block", Bright stated that operating system some of worked well, but felt that transitioning between the "Metro" and desktop interfaces could "be" jarring at times, and that some of their parts used different, inconsistent methods. Tom Warren of The Verge said that although were an "initial frustrations", such as the difference between the user interfaces and "low" learning curve, he felt that the new interface was "stunning" and "utterly surprised" once it was personalized, but still felt that it was "almost impossible to use with a classic keyboard and mouse." Warren also stated that forcing all users to adopt the touch-oriented interface was a "risk" for Microsoft since it "was really trying to kickstart adoption for touch," which in turn "required strong buy-in from developers to pull off." However Warren said that was the "right decision" since "most PCs do not include even a basic touchscreen," bringing in developers to write apps for the Windows Store. Adrian Kingsley-Hughes of ZDNet however panned the interface for being "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design, and described Windows 8 as being "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together." He argued that Windows 8 had "no tangible benefits for motorists over Windows 7," and "wasn't born out of necessity or demanded by the masses; it was a hedge by Microsoft to push the PC – still to this day Microsoft's bread and butter – toward a touch and tablet future, so it can attempt to compete against Apple and its iPad."

text_human: In September 2012 at the Tokyo Game Show, Sony announced that a new, slimmer PS3 redesign (CECH-4000) was due for release in late 2012 and that it would be available with either a 250 GB or 500 GB hard drive. Three versions Super Slim model were revealed: one with a 500 GB hard drive, a second with a 250 GB hard drive which is not available in PAL regions, and a third with a 12 GB flash storage that was only available in PAL regions. The storage of 12 GB model is upgradable with an official standalone 250 GB hard drive. A vertical stand was also released for the model. In the United Kingdom, the 500 GB model was released on September 28, 2012; and the 12 GB model was released on October 12, 2012. In the United States, the PS3 Super Slim was first released as a bundled console. The 250 GB was model was bundled with Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception and released on September 25, 2012; and the 500 GB model was bundled with Assassin's Creed III and released on October 30, 2012. In Japan, the black colored Super Slim model was released on October 4, 2012; and the white colored Super Slim model was released on November 22, 2012. The Super Slim model is 20 percent smaller and 25 percent lighter than the Slim model and features a manual sliding disc cover instead of a motorized slot-loading disc cover of the Slim model. The white colored Super Slim model was released in the United States on January 27, 2013 as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. The Garnet Red and Azurite Blue colored models were launched in Japan on February 28, 2013. The Garnet Red version was released in North America on March 12, 2013 as part of the God of War: Ascension bundle with 500 GB storage and contained God of War: Ascension as well as the God of War Saga. The Azurite Blue model was released as a GameStop exclusive with 250GB storage.

text_human: In the wake of the racially-motivated" church shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, Yale was under criticism again in the summer of 2015 for Calhoun College, one of 12 residential colleges, which was named after John C. Calhoun, a slave-owner and strong slavery supporter in the nineteenth century. In July 2015 students signed a petition calling for the name change. They argued in the petition that—while Calhoun was respected in the 19th century as an "extraordinary American statesman"—he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in the history of the United States. In August 2015 Yale President Peter Salovey addressed the Freshman Class of 2019 in which he responded to the racial tensions but explained why the college would not be renamed. He described Calhoun as a "a notable political theorist, a vice president to two different U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and of state, and a congressman and senator representing South Carolina." He acknowledged that Calhoun also "believed that the highest forms of civilization depend on involuntary servitude. Not only that, but he also believed that the races he thought to be inferior, black people in particular, ought to be subjected to it for the sake of their own best interests." Racial tensions increased in the fall of 2015 centering on comments by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika regarding freedom of speech. In April 2016 Salovey announced that "despite decades of vigorous alumni and student protests," Calhoun's name will remain on the Yale residential college explaining that it is preferable for Yale students to live in Calhoun's "shadow" so they will be "better prepared to rise to the challenges of the present and the future." He claimed that if they removed Calhoun's name, it would "obscure" his "legacy of slavery rather than addressing it." "Yale is part of that history" and "We cannot erase American history, but we can confront it, teach it and learn from it." One change that will be issued is the title of “master” for faculty members who serve as residential college leaders will be renamed to “head of college” due to its connotation of slavery.

Named after John C. Calhoun, a 19th-century slave owner and staunch supporter of slavery, the college’s name drew controversy. In July 2015, students signed a petition demanding a name change, asserting that despite Calhoun's recognition as an "extraordinary American statesman" during his time, he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in U.S. history. In August 2015, Yale President Peter Salovey addressed these racial tensions while speaking to the Freshman Class of 2019. He explained why the college would retain its name, citing Calhoun as a "notable political theorist" and highlighting his roles as vice president to two U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and state, and a congressman and senator for South Carolina. Salovey admitted Calhoun believed civilization depended on involuntary servitude and held that black people, whom he deemed inferior, should be subjected to slavery for their own benefit. As a related change, the title "master" for faculty leading residential colleges will be changed to "head of college" due to its slavery-related connotation.

text_human: The Feinberg School of Medicine (previously the Northwestern University Medical School) has produced a number of notable graduates, including Mary Harris Thompson, Class of 1870, ad eundem, first female surgeon in Chicago, first female surgeon at Cook County Hospital, and founder of the Mary Thomson Hospital, Roswell Park, Class of 1876, prominent surgeon for whom the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York, is named, Daniel Hale Williams, Class of 1883, performed the first successful American open heart surgery; only black charter member of the American College of Surgeons, Charles Horace Mayo, Class of 1888, co-founder of Mayo Clinic, Carlos Montezuma, Class of 1889, one of the first Native Americans to receive a Doctor of Medicine degree from any school, and founder of the Society of American Indians, Howard T. Ricketts, Class of 1897, who discovered bacteria of the genus Rickettsia, and identified the cause and methods of transmission of rocky mountain spotted fever, Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons, internationally recognized as founder of modern hand and peripheral nerve surgery, Robert F. text_ai_base: The Feinberg School of Medicine, formerly known as Northwestern University Medical School, has a legacy of notable graduates. Among them is Mary Harris Thompson, Class of 1870, ad eundem, who became Chicago's first female surgeon, the first female surgeon at Cook County Hospital, and the founder of the Mary Thomson Hospital. Roswell Park, Class of 1876, was a prominent surgeon who lent his name to the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York. Daniel Hale Williams, Class of 1883, was a trailblazer who performed the first successful American open-heart surgery and was the only Black charter member of the American College of Surgeons. Charles Horace Mayo, Class of 1888, co-founded the Mayo Clinic. Carlos Montezuma, Class of 1889, was one of the first Native Americans to earn a Doctor of Medicine degree and established the Society of American Indians. Howard T. Ricketts, Class of 1897, discovered the bacteria genus Rickettsia and uncovered the cause and transmission of Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, was the founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons, recognized globally as a pioneer in modern hand and peripheral nerve surgery. Nobel laureate Robert F. Furchgott, Class of 1940, won a 1996 Lasker Award and the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his co-discovery of nitric oxide. Thomas E. Starzl, Class of 1952, made history with the first successful liver transplant in 1967 and earned the National Medal of Science in 2004 and a Lasker Award in 2012. Joseph P. Kerwin, the first physician in space, participated in three Skylab missions and subsequently became director of Space and Life Sciences at NASA. C. Richard Schlegel, Class of 1972, advanced the dominant patent for the HPV vaccine (marketed as Gardasil) to prevent cervical cancer. David J. Skorton, Class of 1974, was a distinguished cardiologist who became president of Cornell University in 2006. Andrew E. Senyei, Class of 1979, is known as an inventor, venture capitalist, and entrepreneur, founding several biotech and genetics companies and serving as a university trustee.

text_human: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. An example of this is the use of a particular language by a newcomer in a room full of people speaking various languages. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. Those who do not understand it might take the newcomer's use of this particular language merely as a neutral sign of identity. But they might also perceive it as imposing an exclusive boundary that is meant to mark them off from her. On the other hand, those who do understand the newcomer's language could take it as an inclusive boundary, through which the newcomer associates herself with them to the exclusion of the other people present. Equally, however, it is possible that people who do understand the newcomer but who also speak another language may not want to speak the newcomer's language and so see her marker as an imposition and a negative boundary. It is possible that the newcomer is either aware or unaware of this, depending on whether she herself knows other languages or is conscious of the plurilingual quality of the people there and is respectful of it or not.
text_ai_base: Boundaries can be seen as either inclusive or exclusive, depending on how others perceive them. An exclusive boundary is created when someone adopts a marker that restricts the behavior of others. Conversely, an inclusive boundary forms when a marker allows others to easily associate with it. However, inclusive boundaries also impose restrictions by limiting individuals to one group, thereby excluding them from others. For instance, if a newcomer in a multilingual room chooses to speak a particular language, some may understand it, while others may not. Those who don't understand might view this choice simply as a neutral identity marker or as an exclusive boundary that separates them from the newcomer. Conversely, those who do understand the language might see it as an inclusive boundary, connecting them with the newcomer while excluding others. However, even among those who understand the language, some may prefer not to use it, viewing the newcomer's choice as an unwelcome imposition. The newcomer might be aware or unaware of these dynamics, depending on whether she knows other languages or understands and respects the multilingual nature of the group.
text_ai_humanized: Another distinction can be drawn between inclusive boundaries and exclusive boundaries, in terms of evaluations by other people. A person marking herself to or for herself can have exclusive boundaries if the marker chosen constrains the behavior of the other. Similarly, a marker can form inclusive boundaries if it is one which can be easily marked by the other. While exclusive boundaries obviously constrain interaction, inclusive boundaries do as well, as many people are thereby constrained to one group and thereby exclude others. For example, if a room full of people with knowledge of numerous languages, but no common spoken language known by all, is joined by a newcomer who chooses a language to speak, some within the room may understand it and others may not. Some of those who do not may treat this as a marker of identity, and think no more of it. Others of those who do not may feel this is a construed boundary on the part of the newcomer designed to exclude them. Dually, some of those who can speak and/or understand the language chosen may view this as an inclusive boundary to them, which at the same time excludes other people. Finally, some few who can speak or understand the language chosen may not feel positively about this, due to unwillingness to speak the language chosen. The newcomer might understand these positions, if she is capable of speaking multiple languages, or does not due to inability to speak other languages, or failure to recognize (for whatever reason) the nature of the group.

text_human: In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office. They included The Sun's head of news Chris Pharo, who faced six charges, while ex-managing editor Graham Dudman and ex-Sun deputy news editor Ben O'Driscoll were accused of four charges each. Thames Valley district reporter Jamie Pyatt and picture editor John Edwards were charged with three counts each, while ex-reporter John Troup was accused of two counts. The trial related to illegal payments allegedly made to public officials, with prosecutors saying the men conspired to pay officials from 2002–11, including police, prison officers and soldiers. They were accused of buying confidential information about the Royal Family, public figures and prison inmates. They all denied the charges. On 16 January 2015, Troup and Edwards were cleared by the jury of all charges against them. The jury also partially cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman but continued deliberating over other counts faced by them, as well as the charges against Pharo and Pyatt. On 21 January 2015, the jury told the court that it was unable to reach unanimous verdicts on any of the outstanding charges and was told by the judge, Richard Marks, that he would accept majority verdicts. Shortly afterwards, one of the jurors sent a note to the judge and was discharged. The judge told the remaining 11 jurors that their colleague had been "feeling unwell and feeling under a great deal of pressure and stress from the situation you are in", and that under the circumstances he was prepared to accept majority verdicts of "11 to zero or 10 to 1". On 22 January 2015, the jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the outstanding charges. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced that it would seek a retrial.
text_ai_base: In October 2014, a trial commenced for six senior staff and journalists from The Sun newspaper, who were charged with conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office. Among them was The Sun’s head of news, Chris Pharo, facing six charges. Former managing editor Graham Dudman and ex-deputy news editor Ben O'Driscoll each faced four charges. Thames Valley district reporter Jamie Pyatt and picture editor John Edwards were charged with three counts, while ex-reporter John Troup was accused of two counts. The trial centered on illegal payments allegedly made to public officials, with prosecutors claiming the group conspired to pay officials, including police, prison officers, and soldiers, from 2002 to 2011 to buy confidential information about the Royal Family, public figures, and prison inmates. All the accused denied the charges. On January 16, 2015, Troup and Edwards were acquitted by the jury. The jury partially cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman but continued deliberating on other charges against them, as well as those against Pharo and Pyatt. On January 21, the jury informed the court they couldn't reach unanimous verdicts on the remaining charges. Judge Richard Marks said he would accept majority verdicts shortly after one juror was discharged for health reasons. The judge informed the remaining 11 jurors that he would accept verdicts of "11 to zero or 10 to 1." On January 22, the jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the outstanding charges, and the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced plans to seek a retrial.

The CPS said that it would seek a retrial on the outstanding charges.[108]

text_human: Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, not all of which were entirely true. As Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, told his staff: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much of a fuss about it afterwards." Newspaper editor Donald Trelford wrote in The Observer of 21 September 1986: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost sight of ... it is not just that some papers don't check their facts or accept denials: they don't care if the stories are true or not." It was reported, most notably in The Sunday Times of 20 July 1986, that the Queen was worried that Margaret Thatcher's economic policies fostered social divisions and was alarmed by high unemployment, a series of riots, the violence of a miners' strike, and Thatcher's refusal to apply sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa. The sources of the rumours included royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, but Shea claimed his remarks were taken out of context and embellished by speculation. Thatcher reputedly said the Queen would vote for the Social Democratic Party—Thatcher's political opponents. Thatcher's biographer John Campbell claimed "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making". Belying reports of acrimony between them, Thatcher later conveyed her personal admiration for the Queen, and the Queen gave two honours in her personal gift—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—to Thatcher after her replacement as prime minister by John Major. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Elizabeth was a "behind the scenes force" in ending apartheid.
text_ai_base: During the 1980s, intense media fascination with the opinions and private lives of the royal family led to numerous sensationalized press stories, many of which were less than truthful. Kelvin MacKenzie, then editor of The Sun, famously instructed his team: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much fuss about it afterwards." On September 21, 1986, newspaper editor Donald Trelford commented in The Observer: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost ... not only do some papers avoid fact-checking or dismiss denials: they don’t care if the stories are true or not." A notable report in The Sunday Times on July 20, 1986, claimed that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, which she feared encouraged social divisions. The report also mentioned her alarm over high unemployment, civil unrest, violent miners' strikes, and Thatcher's refusal to enforce sanctions against apartheid in South Africa. These rumors were reportedly sourced from royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, though Shea insisted his comments were taken out of context and exaggerated. Thatcher was rumored to have claimed that the Queen would vote for her political rivals, the Social Democratic Party. According to Thatcher's biographer, John Campbell, "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making." Contrary to reports of tension between Thatcher and the Queen, Thatcher later expressed her personal admiration for the monarch. The Queen, in turn, awarded Thatcher two prestigious honors—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—after she was succeeded by John Major as prime minister. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described Elizabeth as a "behind the scenes force" in the abolition of apartheid.
text_ai_humanized: The media became preoccupied by Elizabeth's immediate family, in particular, focusing on their lives, relationships, and supposed marital problems. Persistent, exaggerated, and often false reports in the press undermined Elizabeth's reputation in the 1980s. As Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, said, "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much fuss about it afterwards." Journalist Donald Trelford wrote in The Observer of 21 September 1986: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost ... not only do some papers not check their facts but they ignore denials ... they simply do not care whether the stories are true or not." In 1986, Elizabeth was reportedly worried that Thatcher's economic policies favoured "the rich over the poor", and was alarmed by high unemployment, a series of riots, the violence of a miners' strike, and Thatcher's refusal to apply sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa. Rumours of a rift were proven to have been exaggerated after Thatcher later conveyed her personal admiration for Elizabeth and was awarded two of the highest honours in which she was eligible to receive by Elizabeth—the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—after Thatcher's replacement as prime minister by John Major. Thatchers term as prime minister ended in November 1990. Thatcher later described the alleged rift, however, as "a lot of nonsense". Reports of acrimony between them were sparked by their differences of opinion on the issue of sanctions on South Africa. Thatcher's biographer, John Campbell, claimed, "Thatcher ... was famously closer to the Queen than any prime minister before or since." Brian Mulroney, Canadian prime minister from 1984–93, said Elizabeth was a "behind the scenes force" in ending apartheid.

text_human: Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. There are a variety of different mechanisms by which insects perceive sound, while the patterns are not universal, insects can generally hear sound if they can produce it. Different insect species can have varying hearing, though most insects can hear only a narrow range of frequencies related to the frequency of the sounds they can produce. Mosquitoes have been found to hear up to 2 kHz., and some grasshoppers can hear up to 50 kHz. Certain predatory and parasitic insects can detect the characteristic sounds made by their prey or hosts, respectively. For instance, some nocturnal moths can perceive the ultrasonic emissions of bats, which helps them avoid predation.:87–94 Insects that feed on blood have special sensory structures that can detect infrared emissions, and use them to home in on their hosts.
text_ai_base: Many insects have incredibly sensitive and specialized perception organs. Bees, for instance, can see ultraviolet light and detect polarized light, while male moths use their antennae to sense female moths' pheromones from kilometers away. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) communicates within its colony through distinctive wagging movements at a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging signals indicate new material has arrived at the nest, and aggressive interactions among workers can encourage increased foraging activity. Typically, insects exhibit a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile perception, with insects possessing well-developed eyes often having simplified antennae, and vice versa. Insects perceive sound through various mechanisms, although these are not universally shared. Generally, insects can hear sound if they produce it, albeit within a narrow range of frequencies typically tied to the sounds they generate. For example, mosquitoes can hear up to 2 kHz, while some grasshoppers can hear as high as 50 kHz. Certain predatory and parasitic insects recognize the characteristic sounds of their prey or hosts. Some nocturnal moths can detect bats' ultrasonic emissions, aiding them in evading these predators. Additionally, blood-feeding insects are equipped with sensory structures that detect infrared emissions, enabling them to locate their hosts.
text_ai_humanized: Insects possess very sensitive and specialized organs of perception. Bees, for instance, are capable of seeing ultraviolet light, and are also sensitive to the polarization of light. Male moths have highly developed olfactory organs that allow them to detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometres. Polistes versicolor, a eusocial wasp species from the neotropics, utilizes a form of communication called drumming. Drumming is performed by the wasp gaster being tapped in a particular rhythm pattern against the nest, and this pattern is recognized by other wasps in the colony. Wasps use this form of communication to stimulate other workers to increase foraging behavior and also to promote worker interactions. The most signal frequency observed was at about 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). Wagging movements or tail wagging signals are also very important in intraspecies communication. It was observed that wagging signals were an indicator of new material deliveries to the nest, and that physical aggression of workers increased their foraging. In general, the organs of perception of various insects are suited to the kind of life they lead; typically, specialized insects that possess large and well-developed eyes tend to have taste and smell organs that are more simply organized with fewer sensory cells. Conversely, insects that have mainly mechanical sense organs tend to be organized in ways that possess less specialized organs of sight. Sound is sensed in insects by special hairs and by tympanal organs. Further, there is considerable evidence that insects are capable of hearing sound waves traveling through the air, independent of the method by which the sound is detected. Generally, insects only hear up to a few kilohertz, with the highest sensitivity characterized up to about 20 kilohertz, although higher frequencies have been tested in certain moths. For example, mosquitoes are capable of hearing up to about 2 kilohertz, and grasshoppers can hear up to 50 kilohertz. There are a variety of predatory and parasitic insects capable of perceiving the characteristic sound of their prey or hosts. Many nocturnal moths, for example, are capable of hearing the ultrasounds produced by the echolocation of bats. Many blood-feeding insects can locate their hosts by sensing infrared rays emitted by warm-blooded animals.

text_human: The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the phrase le bataillon-carré ('square battalion'). In the bataillon-carré system, the various corps of the Grande Armée would march uniformly together in close supporting distance. If any single corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help. Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, rapidly marching on the right bank of the River Saale. As in previous campaigns, his fundamental objective was to destroy one opponent before reinforcements from another could tip the balance of the war. Upon learning the whereabouts of the Prussian army, the French swung westwards and crossed the Saale with overwhelming force. At the twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt, fought on 14 October, the French convincingly defeated the Prussians and inflicted heavy casualties. With several major commanders dead or incapacitated, the Prussian king proved incapable of effectively commanding the army, which began to quickly disintegrate. In a vaunted pursuit that epitomized the "peak of Napoleonic warfare," according to historian Richard Brooks, the French managed to capture 140,000 soldiers, over 2,000 cannons and hundreds of ammunition wagons, all in a single month. Historian David Chandler wrote of the Prussian forces: "Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered." Despite their overwhelming defeat, the Prussians refused to negotiate with the French until the Russians had an opportunity to enter the fight.

This system had the various corps of the Grande Armée advancing uniformly and maintaining close proximity. This allowed for rapid support; if one corps was attacked, the others could swiftly come to its aid. Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, advancing rapidly along the right bank of the River Saale. As in earlier campaigns, his primary goal was to defeat one adversary before reinforcements from another could alter the war's outcome. Upon discovering the Prussian army's location, the French shifted west and crossed the Saale with overwhelming force. During the twin battles at Jena and Auerstedt on 14 October, the French decisively defeated the Prussians, causing significant casualties. With several key commanders killed or incapacitated, the Prussian king failed to effectively lead the army, which began to unravel quickly. In a pursuit celebrated as the "peak of Napoleonic warfare," according to historian Richard Brooks, the French captured 140,000 soldiers, over 2,000 cannons, and numerous ammunition wagons within a month. Historian David Chandler remarked on the Prussian forces: "Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered." Despite their crushing defeat, the Prussians refused to enter negotiations with the French until Russia had a chance to join the conflict.
text_ai_humanized: The first military manoeuvres began in September 1806. Writing to Marshal Soult at this time, Napoleon described the war strategy in the following way: "My objective is to engage and destroy the German army wherever I find them; that done, I shall engage and destroy the Russian army, after which the war will be finished."[161] In a letter to Minister of War Henri Clarke, Napoleon revealed his estimation on the numbers of enemy Russian troop deployments by 1807. [162] At the outset of the campaign, Napoleon issued a memo to his marshals in which he emphasised the overarching importance of speed: "We must not lose a single hour; not a moment must be lost without our being on the heels of the enemy and harassing their rearguard, otherwise they will escape."[163] For the campaign plan, Napoleon incorporated many principles elaborated in the 1797 Milan letter to the Directory. The French emperor judged that the most effective way to destroy the enemy was to target the main body of the opposing army. When the decisive battle came, he expected to push the enemy right bank of the River Saale combatants up against a major geographical barrier (in this case the Elbe) and then annihilate them in battle. To achieve this, Napoleon kept his army in one massive group as they advanced into Prussian territory. He expected that by the time he made contact with the enemy, he would outnumber them with his group concentration. The campaign plan for this region is now known as the strategem of the central position, another idea elaborated in Milan letter XVI.[164] The campaign is also noted for its incorporation of the first Napoleonic battle plan—the left-echelon attack at Jena—which became a staple technique of his battlefield tactics. As military historian Gunther Rothenberg notes, "In the centre-position confrontation with the Prussians, at the twin battles of Jena and Auerstädt, the Napoleonic juggernaut showed its usual speed, operational mastery, and tactical brilliance. Both the campaign and the battles that followed displayed many of the hallmarks of Napoleonic warfare."[165] The initial military manoeuvres began in September 1806. [166] Napoleon himself rode out from the palace at Saint-Cloud on 25 September.[167] In a famous memo to Marshal Soult describing the operational objectives, the Emperor laid out the foundational aspects of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the concept of le bataillon-carré ("square battalion"). This battalion formation saw the independent corps of the Grande Armée marching uniformly together in close supporting distance. Consequently, if one corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help.[168] Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 men and marched rapidly on the right bank of the river Saale. It was the same grand plan he had used against Austria in 1805, leaving only secondary forces to cover Prussia's Russian ally on the eastern front. As in previous campaigns, the French objective was to destroy one opponent before the other could arrive to alter the course of the war.[169] After finding the Prussian army in the Braunschweig area, the French swung westwards in full force and crossed the Saale with lightning speed. It was too late for the Prussians to counter the move, and at the twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt, fought on 14 October, the French inflicted a severe drubbing on the Prussian forces, inflicting heavy losses. Several generals and marshals in Prussian service were killed or wounded, and the King proved incapable of commanding the army effectively. Orders to regroup and resist the French invasion translated into an increasing disorganisation in the Prussian rear, and the Prussian command structure rapidly collapsed as the military situation became more desperate. In a famous pursuit that epitomised the "peak of Napoleonic warfare" (Richard Brooks),[170] the French troops captured 140,000 soldiers, more than 2,000 cannons, and hundreds of ammunition wagons within a single month. David Chandler equated the Prussian loss to the battle of Leuthen in 1757: "But Frederick the Great himself could hardly have inflicted more terrible damage on the Habsburgs after Leuthen than was now suffered by the men who so proudly called themselves Frederick's inheritors. Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered".[171] Despite being thoroughly beaten, the Prussians refused to capitulate to the French until the Russians had an opportunity to enter the conflict.

text_human: As a boy, Schwarzenegger played several sports, heavily influenced by his father. He picked up his first barbell in 1960, when his soccer coach took his team to a local gym. At the age of 14, he chose bodybuilding over soccer as a career. Schwarzenegger has responded to a question asking if he was 13 when he started weightlifting: "I actually started weight training when I was 15, but I'd been participating in sports, like soccer, for years, so I felt that although I was slim, I was well-developed, at least enough so that I could start going to the gym and start Olympic lifting." However, his official website biography claims: "At 14, he started an intensive training program with Dan Farmer, studied psychology at 15 (to learn more about the power of mind over body) and at 17, officially started his competitive career." During a speech in 2001, he said, "My own plan formed when I was 14 years old. My father had wanted me to be a police officer like he was. My mother wanted me to go to trade school." Schwarzenegger took to visiting a gym in Graz, where he also frequented the local movie theaters to see bodybuilding idols such as Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller on the big screen. When Reeves died in 2000, Schwarzenegger fondly remembered him: "As a teenager, I grew up with Steve Reeves. His remarkable accomplishments allowed me a sense of what was possible, when others around me didn't always understand my dreams. Steve Reeves has been part of everything I've ever been fortunate enough to achieve." In 1961, Schwarzenegger met former Mr. Austria Kurt Marnul, who invited him to train at the gym in Graz. He was so dedicated as a youngster that he broke into the local gym on weekends, when it was usually closed, so that he could train. "It would make me sick to miss a workout... I knew I couldn't look at myself in the mirror the next morning if I didn't do it." When Schwarzenegger was asked about his first movie experience as a boy, he replied: "I was very young, but I remember my father taking me to the Austrian theaters and seeing some newsreels. The first real movie I saw, that I distinctly remember, was a John Wayne movie."

text_human: The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about actual and possible sense data. If a physical object statement is to be translatable into a sense-data statement, the former must be at least deducible from the latter. But it came to be realized that there is no finite set of statements about actual and possible sense-data from which we can deduce even a single physical-object statement. Remember that the translating or paraphrasing statement must be couched in terms of normal observers in normal conditions of observation. There is, however, no finite set of statements that are couched in purely sensory terms and can express the satisfaction of the condition of the presence of a normal observer. According to phenomenalism, to say that a normal observer is present is to make the hypothetical statement that were a doctor to inspect the observer, the observer would appear to the doctor to be normal. But, of course, the doctor himself must be a normal observer. If we are to specify this doctor's normality in sensory terms, we must make reference to a second doctor who, when inspecting the sense organs of the first doctor, would himself have to have the sense data a normal observer has when inspecting the sense organs of a subject who is a normal observer. And if we are to specify in sensory terms that the second doctor is a normal observer, we must refer to a third doctor, and so on (also see the third man).
text_ai_base: By the 1940s, the phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism had concluded. It became clear that statements about physical objects could not be converted into statements about actual and possible sensory data. For a statement about physical objects to be translatable into one about sensory data, it must be at least deducible from the latter. However, it was realized that we cannot derive even a single statement about physical objects from any finite set of statements describing actual and possible sensory data. Remember that these translating or paraphrasing statements must involve normal observers in typical conditions. Yet, no finite set of purely sensory statements can satisfy the requirement of having a normal observer present. According to phenomenalism, claiming the presence of a normal observer is akin to hypothetically stating that if a doctor were to examine the observer, they would find the observer normal. However, this doctor must also be a normal observer. To specify the doctor's normality in sensory terms, we would need a second doctor, who would have to experience the usual sensory data when examining the first doctor's sensory organs. To further specify the second doctor as a normal observer using sensory terms, we must refer to a third doctor, continuing the cycle indefinitely (see also the third man problem).
text_ai_humanized: By early the 1940s, the phenomenalist period of post-Humean empiricism ended. It was realized that claims about physical objects are not translatable into claims about actual and possible appearances. For a claim about physical objects to be translatable into a claim about actual and possible appearances, it must be at least logically implied by the latter. However, it was realized that no single claim about physical objects logically follows from any finite set of claims about actual and possible appearances. Recall that the translating, or paraphrasing, claims have to be couched in terms of normal observers in normal conditions. But no finite claim in the observation language be such as to satisfy the criterion has a normal observer. To say that there is a normal observer , in the sense required by phenomenalism, amounts to supposing that if a doctor examined this observer, he would find the latter to be normal. Obviously, the doctor in question must himself be a normal observer; to specify him as such, in the vocabulary of observation, we are apparently forced to refer to a second doctor who will have to have the sense-experiences normally caused by examining the sense-organs of the first doctor. To specify this second doctor, again, as a normal observer, in the vocabulary of the given observation language, we apparently have to refer to a third doctor, and so on ad infinitum (cf. third man problem).

text_human: Although the doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception appears only later among Latin (and particularly Frankish) theologians, it became ever more manifest among Byzantine theologians reliant on Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology in the Medieval or Byzantine East. Although hymnographers and scholars, like the Emperor Justinian I, were accustomed to call Mary "prepurified" in their poetic and credal statements, the first point of departure for more fully commenting on Nazianzen's meaning occurs in Sophronius of Jerusalem. In other places Sophronius explains that the Theotokos was already immaculate, when she was "purified" at the Annunciation and goes so far as to note that John the Baptist is literally "holier than all 'Men' born of woman" since Mary's surpassing holiness signifies that she was holier than even John after his sanctification in utero. Sophronius' teaching is augmented and incorporated by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750). John, besides many passages wherein he extolls the Theotokos for her purification at the Annunciation, grants her the unique honor of "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them." This honor was most famously and firstly attributed to Christ, especially in the legacy of Nazianzen. As such, Nazianzen's assertion of parallel holiness between the prepurified Mary and purified Jesus of the New Testament is made even more explicit in Damascene in his discourse on Mary's holiness to also imitate Christ's baptism at the Jordan. The Damascene's hymnongraphy and De fide Orthodoxa explicitly use Mary's "pre purification" as a key to understanding her absolute holiness and unsullied human nature. In fact, Damascene (along with Nazianzen) serves as the source for nearly all subsequent promotion of Mary's complete holiness from her Conception by the "all pure seed" of Joachim and the womb "wider than heaven" of St. Ann.
text_ai_base: The doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception emerged later among Latin theologians, especially the Franks, but found clearer expression among Byzantine theologians with roots in Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology during the Medieval Byzantine era. Poets and scholars, including Emperor Justinian I, often referred to Mary as "prepurified" in their writings and creeds. Sophronius of Jerusalem offered a pivotal interpretation of Nazianzen's ideas, explaining that Mary was already immaculate at the time of the Annunciation. He even suggested that John the Baptist was "holier than all 'Men' born of woman," acknowledging that Mary's extraordinary holiness eclipsed even John's, who was sanctified in utero. Sophronius' teachings were further developed by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750), who praised Mary for her purification at the Annunciation and uniquely recognized her role in "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them," an honor traditionally reserved for Christ, according to Nazianzen's legacy. Damascene elaborated on the parallel holiness between Mary's prepurification and Jesus' purification in the New Testament, likening her holiness at the Annunciation to Christ's baptism at the Jordan. His hymns and the work "De fide Orthodoxa" utilized Mary's "pre purification" to emphasize her unparalleled holiness and pure human nature. Damascene, along with Nazianzen, influenced nearly all later depictions of Mary's complete holiness, stemming from her conception by the "all pure seed" of Joachim and the womb of St. Ann, which is metaphorically described as "wider than heaven."

text_human: United States of America: The torch relay's North American leg occurred in San Francisco, California on April 9. On the day of the relay officials diverted the torch run to an unannounced route. The start was at McCovey Cove, where Norman Bellingham of the U.S. Olympic Committee gave the torch to the first torchbearer, Chinese 1992 Olympic champion swimmer Lin Li. The planned closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was cancelled and instead, a ceremony was held at San Francisco International Airport, where the torch was to leave for Buenos Aires. The route changes allowed the run to avoid large numbers of China supporters and protesters against China. As people found out there would be no closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza, there were angry reactions. One demonstrator was quoted as saying that the route changes were an effort to "thwart any organized protest that had been planned." San Francisco Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, a critic of Mayor Gavin Newsom, said that it was a "cynical plan to please the Bush State Department and the Chinese government because of the incredible influence of money." Newsom, on the other hand, said he felt it was in "everyone's best interest" and that he believed people had been "afforded the right to protest and support the torch" despite the route changes. Peter Ueberroth, head of the U.S. Olympic Committee, praised the route changes, saying, "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded." People who saw the torch were surprised and cheered as shown from live video of CBS and NBC. The cost to the city for hosting the event was reported to be USD $726,400, nearly half of which has been recovered by private fundraising. Mayor Gavin Newsom said that "exponential" costs associated with mass arrests were avoided by his decision to change the route in consultation with police chief Heather Fong.
text_ai_base: On April 9, the North American leg of the torch relay took place in San Francisco, California. That day, officials rerouted the torch to an undisclosed path. The relay began at McCovey Cove, where Norman Bellingham of the U.S. Olympic Committee handed the torch to Lin Li, the Chinese swimmer and 1992 Olympic champion. The anticipated closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was cancelled, replaced by an event at San Francisco International Airport as the torch departed for Buenos Aires. The route adjustment aimed to sidestep large crowds of both supporters of China and protesters. The sudden change sparked anger among some who had gathered at Justin Herman Plaza; one demonstrator claimed the reroute was intended to "thwart any organized protest." Aaron Peskin, President of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors and critic of Mayor Gavin Newsom, described the changes as a "cynical plan" to satisfy the Bush administration and the Chinese government, pointing to "the incredible influence of money." In contrast, Newsom argued the move was in "everyone's best interest" and maintained that people retained their right to protest and support the torch despite the revised route. Peter Ueberroth, head of the U.S. Olympic Committee, praised the changes, stating, "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded." Spectators who managed to see the torch expressed surprise and joy, as evident in live video footage from CBS and NBC. The city's cost for hosting the event was reported at $726,400, with nearly half offset by private fundraising. Mayor Newsom noted that the route change, made in consultation with Police Chief Heather Fong, avoided "exponential" expenses related to potential mass arrests.

The relay commenced in McCovey Cove from Norman Bellingham of the USOC to Lin Li, Chinese swimmer and Olympic gold medalist in 1992. A ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza marking the end of the relay was cancelled in favor of a departure ceremony at San Francisco International Airport as the torch continued on to Buenos Aires. The planned route was changed in an effort to avoid tens of thousands of pro-Chinese and anti-Chinese protesters. Last-minute change of plan elicited vociferous objections from some spectators who had waited in Justin Herman Plaza; one protester said the reroute was to "squelch any organized protest". [8] Aaron Peskin, President of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, who has had a tense relationship with Mayor Gavin Newsom, called the decision a "double cross" and "convoluted, cynical plan" to appease the Bush administration and Chinese government, blaming "the power of money, and it's extraordinary." [9] Newsom, his political rival in city government, defended the scheme as in "everyone's best interest" and that the reroute did not deny people the right to protest and celebrate the torch. [9] U.S. Olympic Committee president Peter Ueberroth, aboard the departure flight, hailed the decision to reroute: "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded. "[10] Spectators who did get to see the torch appeared surprised and happy in CBS and NBC video footage taken live at the scene. Public costs to the city related to the event was $726, 400; a fundraising effort paid for nearly half of the total, according to the mayor's finances office. Newsom said the reroute decision undertaken with Police Chief Heather Fong saved "exponential" costs with mass arrests. [11]

text_human: The current Mac product family uses Intel x86-64 processors. Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), much as it did during the transition from Motorola 68000 architecture a decade earlier. The Macintosh is the only mainstream computer platform to have successfully transitioned to a new CPU architecture, and has done so twice. All current Mac models ship with at least 8 GB of RAM as standard other than the 1.4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (without Retina Display), and MacBook Air. Current Mac computers use ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphics cards as well as Intel graphics built into the main CPU. All current Macs (except for the MacBook Pro without Retina Display) do not ship with an optical media drive that includes a dual-function DVD/CD burner. Apple refers to this as a SuperDrive. Current Macs include two standard data transfer ports: USB and Thunderbolt (except for the MacBook (2015 version), which only has a USB-C port and headphone port). MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and Mac Mini computers now also feature the "Thunderbolt" port, which Apple says can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. USB was introduced in the 1998 iMac G3 and is ubiquitous today, while FireWire is mainly reserved for high-performance devices such as hard drives or video cameras. Starting with the then-new iMac G5, released in October 2005, Apple started to include built-in iSight cameras on appropriate models, and a media center interface called Front Row that can be operated by an Apple Remote or keyboard for accessing media stored on the computer. Front Row has been discontinued as of 2011, however, and the Apple Remote is no longer bundled with new Macs.

text_ai_humanized: Current Macintosh models use Intel's x86-64 architecture Central Processing Units (CPUs). Apple first used Intel chips in 2006, but as of 1998 had begun using chips produced by AMD in addition to its original arrangement with Intel, as well as HID controller chips. [31] Current Macs use ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphic cards as well as Intel graphics built into the main CPU. Starting in 2006 with the Mac Pro and later the early 2008 MacBook Pro update, Apple computers offer the AltiVec performance-enhanced vector processing library which utilizes SIMD processing, previously built into the PowerPC versions of Mac computers. With the change to the Intel platform, the Macintosh is the only mainstream computer platform to have successfully transitioned to a new CPU architecture, and the only to have done so twice. [28] The transition to Intel x86-64 was facilitated by the inclusion of an emulator layer in Mac OS X 10.4 "Tiger". Since Mac OS X is derived from Unix, the 2006 transition was easier, as Unix-based operating systems like OS X are natively designed for supporting more than one platform. In a similar manner, a decade previously, Apple had included a 68k processor emulation layer when moving the Macintosh from the Motorola 68000 architecture to the PowerPC. As a result, many University workstations became Mac-compatibles and ran Mac applications as the benchmarks were found to be fast and native. The Rosetta emulation, , allowed PowerPC-based applications to work on Intel-based Macs until 2011. Virtually all new Macs ship with at least 8 GB (gigabytes) of DDR3 SDRAM, with the exception of the 1. 4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (No Retina Display), and MacBook Air. As of February 2006, nearly all portable Macs use the PCI Express expansion bus. With the original MacBook Pro and MacBook Air as the exceptions, they include on-board gigabit Ethernet. All current Macs, excluding the MacBook Pro (No Retina Display), do not incorporate an optical media drive for reading and writing dual purpose DVD/CD rewritable media, also called a SuperDrive. Today all Macs are also built with two data transfer ports as a standard: USB and Thunderbolt (). The 2015 version of the MacBook is the only Mac that includes only a USB-C port and headphone port. MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and discontinued Mac Mini computers now include the Thunderbolt port, which Apple says can transfer data at a speed of up to 10 Gbit/s (gigabits per second). The USB standard has been in use by Macs since it was first introduced in the 1998 iMac G3 (the first Mac to have a port like this and be completely legacy, floppy disk absent). It has since been commonplace, while FireWire was only normally reserved for high-performance devices such as hard-drives or video cameras. The iMac G5, announced August 31, 2004, has built-in iSight cameras (Apple's version of a webcam) on select models and comes with Front Row media center software, which is controlled by an Apple Remote or the keyboard's Function keys. However Front Row has since been discontinued as of 2011, and the Apple Remote used to control it is no longer supplied with Macs.

text_human: As anticipated by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived off Midway on 4 June and was spotted by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo executed a first strike against Midway, while Fletcher launched his aircraft, bound for Nagumo's carriers. At 09:20 the first U.S. carrier aircraft arrived, TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet, but their attacks were poorly coordinated and ineffectual; thanks in part to faulty aerial torpedoes, they failed to score a single hit and all 15 were wiped out by defending Zero fighters. At 09:35, 15 additional TBDs from Enterprise attacked in which 14 were lost, again with no hits. Thus far, Fletcher's attacks had been disorganized and seemingly ineffectual, but they succeeded in drawing Nagumo's defensive fighters down to sea level where they expended much of their fuel and ammunition repulsing the two waves of torpedo bombers. As a result, when U.S. dive bombers arrived at high altitude, the Zeros were poorly positioned to defend. To make matters worse, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation in their efforts to avoid torpedoes, reducing the concentration of their anti-aircraft fire. Nagumo's indecision had also created confusion aboard his carriers. Alerted to the need of a second strike on Midway, but also wary of the need to deal with the American carriers that he now knew were in the vicinity, Nagumo twice changed the arming orders for his aircraft. As a result, the American dive bombers found the Japanese carriers with their decks cluttered with munitions as the crews worked hastily to properly re-arm their air groups.
text_ai_base: As expected by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived near Midway on June 4, where it was detected by PBY patrol aircraft. The first U.S. carrier aircraft to reach the scene were TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet at 09:20, but their assaults were poorly coordinated and ineffective; partially due to faulty aerial torpedoes, they did not land a single hit, and all 15 were shot down by defending Zero fighters. At 09:35, 15 more TBDs from Enterprise attacked, with 14 lost and again no hits achieved. Though Fletcher's attacks seemed disorganized and largely ineffective, they managed to lure Nagumo's defensive fighters down to sea level, where they used up much of their fuel and ammunition repelling the two waves of torpedo bombers. Consequently, when U.S. dive bombers arrived at high altitude, the Zeros were ill-positioned to defend. Furthermore, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation while evading torpedoes, diminishing their concentration of anti-aircraft fire. Nagumo's indecision added to the confusion on his carriers as he contemplated a second strike on Midway while being aware of American carriers nearby. Twice, he altered the arming orders for his aircraft, leading the American dive bombers to find the Japanese carriers cluttered with munitions as crews hurried to properly re-arm their air groups.

In fact, the four carriers had almost drifted out of formation due to evasive action, reducing their AA concentration. He twice changed arming orders for his air groups, and the American dive bombers found the Japanese carrier decks littered with bombs as their crews attempted to get properly re-armed and ready.

text_human: Scotland, meanwhile had remained an independent Kingdom. In 1603, that changed when the King of Scotland inherited the Crown of England, and consequently the Crown of Ireland also. The subsequent 17th century was one of political upheaval, religious division and war. English colonialism in Ireland of the 16th century was extended by large-scale Scottish and English colonies in Ulster. Religious division heightened and the King in England came into conflict with parliament. A prime issue was, inter alia, over his policy of tolerance towards Catholicism. The resulting English Civil War or War of the Three Kingdoms led to a revolutionary republic in England. Ireland, largely Catholic was mainly loyal to the king. Following defeat to the parliaments army, large scale land distributions from loyalist Irish nobility to English commoners in the service of the parliamentary army created the beginnings a new Ascendancy class which over the next hundred years would obliterate the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish nobility in Ireland. The new ruling class was Protestant and British, whilst the common people were largely Catholic and Irish. This theme would influence Irish politics for centuries to come. When the monarchy was restored in England, the king found it politically impossible to restore all the lands of former land-owners in Ireland. The "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 repeated similar themes: a Catholic king pushing for religious tolerance in opposition to a Protestant parliament in England. The king's army was defeated at the Battle of the Boyne and at the militarily crucial Battle of Aughrim in Ireland. Resistance held out, and a guarantee of religious tolerance was a cornerstone of the Treaty of Limerick. However, in the evolving political climate, the terms of Limerick were superseded, a new monarchy was installed, and the new Irish parliament was packed with the new elite which legislated increasing intolerant Penal Laws, which discommoded both Dissenters and Catholics.

The following century was marked by political unrest, religious division, and warfare. English colonialism, which began in Ireland in the 16th century, expanded with the establishment of large Scottish and English colonies in Ulster. Tensions rose, especially as the English king's policy of tolerance towards Catholicism clashed with Parliament. This discord led to the English Civil War, also known as the War of the Three Kingdoms, resulting in a revolutionary republic. Although predominantly Catholic Ireland mostly supported the king, defeat by Parliament's army led to significant land redistribution from loyalist Irish nobility to English commoners serving in the parliamentary forces. This shift began the rise of a new "Ascendancy" class that, over the next hundred years, replaced the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish nobility. This new ruling class, Protestant and British, contrasted with the largely Catholic and Irish populace, influencing Irish politics for centuries. When the English monarchy was restored, the king could not politically restore the lands of former Irish landowners. The "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 echoed these themes, with a Catholic king advocating for religious tolerance against a Protestant Parliament. The king's army was defeated in Ireland at the Battle of the Boyne and the crucial Battle of Aughrim. Despite resistance and a pledge for religious tolerance in the Treaty of Limerick, its terms were later overridden in the shifting political landscape. A new monarchy emerged, and the Irish parliament, now dominated by the new elite, enacted increasingly oppressive Penal Laws affecting both Dissenters and Catholics.

text_human: Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase , gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. Taste and smell stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata. After this it is routed through the vagus nerve and release of acetylcholine. Gastric secretion at this phase rises to 40% of maximum rate. Acidity in the stomach is not buffered by food at this point and thus acts to inhibit parietal (secretes acid) and G cell (secretes gastrin) activity via D cell secretion of somatostatin. The gastric phase takes 3 to 4 hours. It is stimulated by distension of the stomach, presence of food in stomach and decrease in pH. Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes. This activates the release of acetylcholine, which stimulates the release of more gastric juices. As protein enters the stomach, it binds to hydrogen ions, which raises the pH of the stomach. Inhibition of gastrin and gastric acid secretion is lifted. This triggers G cells to release gastrin, which in turn stimulates parietal cells to secrete gastric acid. Gastric acid is about 0.5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), which lowers the pH to the desired pH of 1-3. Acid release is also triggered by acetylcholine and histamine. The intestinal phase has two parts, the excitatory and the inhibitory. Partially digested food fills the duodenum. This triggers intestinal gastrin to be released. Enterogastric reflex inhibits vagal nuclei, activating sympathetic fibers causing the pyloric sphincter to tighten to prevent more food from entering, and inhibits local reflexes.

The cephalic phase begins with the sight, thought, and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. These stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata, then routed through the vagus nerve, leading to the release of acetylcholine. During this phase, gastric secretion reaches 40% of its maximum rate. Since the acidity in the stomach isn't buffered by food, it inhibits the activity of parietal cells (which secrete acid) and G cells (which secrete gastrin) via D cell secretion of somatostatin. The gastric phase lasts 3 to 4 hours and is triggered by the stomach's distension, the presence of food, and decreased pH. Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes, releasing acetylcholine and stimulating more gastric juice production. As proteins enter the stomach, they bind with hydrogen ions, increasing the pH and lifting the inhibition on gastrin and gastric acid secretion. This causes G cells to release gastrin, prompting parietal cells to secrete gastric acid, which consists of about 0.5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), lowering the pH to 1-3. Acetylcholine and histamine also trigger acid release. The intestinal phase has two parts: excitatory and inhibitory. Partially digested food enters the duodenum, triggering the release of intestinal gastrin. The enterogastric reflex inhibits the vagal nuclei, activates sympathetic fibers which tighten the pyloric sphincter to prevent more food from entering, and inhibits local reflexes.

text_human: The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi announced the start of the "Revolution within a Revolution", which began with reforms to industry and agriculture and saw the re-opening of small business. Restrictions were placed on the activities of the Revolutionary Committees; in March 1988, their role was narrowed by the newly created Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership to restrict their violence and judicial role, while in August 1988 Gaddafi publicly criticised them, asserting that "they deviated, harmed, tortured" and that "the true revolutionary does not practise repression." In March, hundreds of political prisoners were freed, with Gaddafi falsely claiming that there were no further political prisoners in Libya. In June, Libya's government issued the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, in which 27 articles laid out goals, rights and guarantees to improve the situation of human rights in Libya, restricting the use of the death penalty and calling for its eventual abolition. Many of the measures suggested in the charter would be implemented the following year, although others remained inactive. Also in 1989, the government founded the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, to be awarded to figures from the Third World who had struggled against colonialism and imperialism; the first year's winner was South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela. From 1994 through to 1997, the government initiated cleansing committees to root out corruption, particularly in the economic sector.

In May 1987, Gaddafi launched the "Revolution within a Revolution," focusing on industrial and agricultural reforms and the revival of small businesses. The Revolutionary Committees faced restrictions; in March 1988, a new Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership limited their violent and judicial activities. In August 1988, Gaddafi criticized these committees, stating they had "deviated, harmed, tortured" and insisted that "true revolutionaries do not practice repression." That March, hundreds of political prisoners were released, although Gaddafi inaccurately claimed there were none left in Libya. In June, the government published the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, outlining 27 articles to improve human rights, limit the death penalty, and call for its eventual abolition. While some measures in the charter were implemented the following year, others were not. Additionally, in 1989, the government established the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, honoring Third World figures who opposed colonialism and imperialism, with Nelson Mandela as the first recipient. text_human: ARC was acquired in 1938 by the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS, which, in turn, had been formed by the Columbia Phonograph Company, but then sold off). ARC was renamed Columbia Recording Corporation. The Columbia Phonograph Company had international subsidiaries and affiliates such as the Columbia Graphophone Company in the United Kingdom, but they were sold off prior to CBS acquiring American Columbia. RCA Victor Records executive Ted Wallerstein convinced CBS head William S. Paley to buy ARC and Paley made Wallerstein head of the newly acquired record company. The renamed company made Columbia its flagship label with Okeh its subsidiary label while deemphasizing ARC's other labels. This allowed ARC's leased labels Brunswick Records and Vocalion Records to revert to former owner Warner Bros. which sold the labels to Decca Records. Columbia kept the Brunswick catalogue recorded from December 1931 onward which was reissued on the Columbia label as well as the Vocalion label material from the same time period which was reissued on the Okeh label. Wallerstein, who was promoted at the end of 1947 from president to chairman of the record company, restored Columbia's status as a leading record company and spearheaded the successful introduction of the long playing (LP) record before he retired as Columbia's chairman in 1951. James Conkling then became head of Columbia Records. Also in 1951, Columbia severed its ties with the EMI-owned record label of the same name and began a UK distribution deal with Philips Records, whereas Okeh Records continued to be distributed by EMI on the Columbia label.
