James Conkling subsequently took over as head of Columbia Records. text_human: The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the bleacher section at Wrigley Field. Initially, the group was called "bums" because it referred to a group of fans who were at most games, and since those games were all day games, it was assumed they did not work. Many of those fans were, and are still, students at Chicago area colleges, such as DePaul University, Loyola, Northwestern University, and Illinois-Chicago. A Broadway play, starring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi ran for years and was based on a group of Cub fans who frequented the club's games. The group was started in 1967 by dedicated fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall and "mad bugler" Mike Murphy, who was a sports radio host during mid days on Chicago-based WSCR AM 670 "The Score". Murphy alleges that Grousl started the Wrigley tradition of throwing back opposing teams' home run balls. The current group is headed by Derek Schaul (Derek the Five Dollar Kid). Prior to the 2006 season, they were updated, with new shops and private bar (The Batter's Eye) being added, and Bud Light bought naming rights to the bleacher section, dubbing them the Bud Light Bleachers. Bleachers at Wrigley are general admission, except during the playoffs. The bleachers have been referred to as the "World's Largest Beer Garden." A popular T-shirt (sold inside the park and licensed by the club) which says "Wrigley Bleachers" on the front and the phrase "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer" on the reverse fuels this stereotype.

text_human: In 1824, the French physicist François Arago formulated the existence of rotating magnetic fields, termed Arago's rotations, which, by manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated in 1879 as in effect the first primitive induction motor. In the 1880s, many inventors were trying to develop workable AC motors because AC's advantages in long-distance high-voltage transmission were counterbalanced by the inability to operate motors on AC. The first alternating-current commutatorless induction motors were independently invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla, a working motor model having been demonstrated by the former in 1885 and by the latter in 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris' research detailing the foundations of motor operation while however concluding that "the apparatus based on that principle could not be of any commercial importance as motor." In 1888, Tesla presented his paper A New System for Alternating Current Motors and Transformers to the AIEE that described three patented two-phase four-stator-pole motor types: one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor winding. One of the patents Tesla filed in 1887, however, also described a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor. George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla's patents, employed Tesla to develop them, and assigned C. F. Scott to help Tesla, Tesla left for other pursuits in 1889. The constant speed AC induction motor was found not to be suitable for street cars but Westinghouse engineers successfully adapted it to power a mining operation in Telluride, Colorado in 1891. Steadfast in his promotion of three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890. This type of motor is now used for the vast majority of commercial applications. However, he claimed that Tesla's motor was not practical because of two-phase pulsations, which prompted him to persist in his three-phase work. Although Westinghouse achieved its first practical induction motor in 1892 and developed a line of polyphase 60 hertz induction motors in 1893, these early Westinghouse motors were two-phase motors with wound rotors until B. G. Lamme developed a rotating bar winding rotor. The General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891. By 1896, General Electric and Westinghouse signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor design, later called the squirrel-cage rotor. Induction motor improvements flowing from these inventions and innovations were such that a 100 horsepower (HP) induction motor currently has the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 HP motor in 1897.
text_ai_base: In 1824, French physicist François Arago introduced the concept of rotating magnetic fields, known as Arago's rotations. This idea led to the creation of the first primitive induction motor in 1879 when Walter Baily manually switched it on and off. Throughout the 1880s, inventors aimed to develop AC motors, as AC was beneficial for long-distance, high-voltage transmission but lacked operable motors. Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla independently invented the first AC commutatorless induction motors, with Ferraris presenting a working model in 1885 and Tesla in 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris' research on motor operation but doubted its commercial potential. Meanwhile, Tesla presented a paper to the AIEE describing three types of two-phase, four-stator-pole motors: a non-self-starting reluctance motor, a self-starting induction motor with a wound rotor, and a synchronous motor with a separately excited DC rotor winding. One of Tesla's patents from 1887 also detailed a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor. George Westinghouse quickly purchased Tesla’s patents, hired him to develop them, and enlisted C. F. Scott to assist, although Tesla left in 1889. While constant-speed AC induction motors were unsuitable for streetcars, Westinghouse successfully powered a Telluride, Colorado mining operation in 1891. Committed to three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890, which are now standard in commercial applications. Despite Dolivo-Dobrovolsky's claims of impracticality due to two-phase pulsations, Westinghouse developed its first practical induction motor in 1892, followed by a line of polyphase motors in 1893. These were initially two-phase motors with wound rotors, until B.G. Lamme's rotating bar winding rotor design emerged. The General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891, and by 1896, they signed a cross-licensing agreement with Westinghouse for the bar-winding-rotor design, later known as the squirrel-cage rotor. These advancements and innovations have led to modern 100 horsepower (HP) induction motors sharing the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 HP motor from 1897.
text_ai_humanized: The rotating magnetic field: the key principle in AC motor operation A rotating magnetic field was proposed as early as 1824 by the French physicist François Arago. By manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated the first primitive induction motor in 1879. In the 1880s, many inventors were trying to develop workable AC motors because AC's advantages in long distance high voltage transmission were offset by the inability to operate motors on AC. The first AC commutator-free two phase induction motors were invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla. Ferraris developed the idea of a rotating magnetic field in 1885, the working model was demonstrated in 1885 by Ferraris and he published his research in 1888. Tesla conceived the rotating magnetic field principle in 1882 and had a working prototype induction motor by 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris's research detailing the foundations of motor operation, while concluding at that time that "the apparatus based on that principle could not be of any interest from a practical point of view." In 1888 Tesla presented a paper to the AIEE that included diagrams of three types of two-phase four-stator-pole motor, one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor field winding. One of Tesla's patents also claims the use of shorted bands instead of winding to form the equivalent of a squirrel-cage induction motor. George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla's patents, hired Tesla to be a consultant at Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Company's Pittsburgh labs, and assigned C. F. Scott to assist Tesla; however, Tesla left for New York within a year. Tesla was awarded the American Institute of Electrical Engineers (AIEE) highest award, the Edison Medal, in 1917 for discovering the rotating magnetic field. Steadfast in his promotion of three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the first three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890. This type of motor is now used for the vast majority of commercial applications. Furthermore, Wilhelm Kempe and Friedrich August Haselwander, who was looking for assistance in perfecting his design, were certain that this motor would become the prime standard, in May 1888. Haselwander was a technician of Mechanical Engineering who independently developed the first single-phase AC induction motor to be used in a power plant for the generation of electricity, and received a patent for that just a few months before Ferraris and Tesla. In 1889, Dolivo-Dobrovolsky developed a three-phase cage-rotor induction motor, and ran it successfully at the Allis Chalmers factory in the US. Nevertheless, Westinghouse achieved its first practical induction motor in 1892 and developed a line of polyphase 60 hertz induction motors in 1893, but these early Westinghouse motors were two-phase powered with wound rotors. General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891. By 1896, General Electric and Westinghouse signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor (squirrel cage) design, later called the squirrel-cage rotor, in which they agreed to share royalties, as the B.G. Lamme's principle of the bar-winding rotor had been applied by Siemens in the development of their induction motors, leading to a legal dispute. The General Electric Company, in 1896, developed a line of induction motors, which were the first to use a cast-aluminum cage rotor. Westinghouse and General Electric signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor design, later called the bar rotor, in which they agreed to share the patents of the bar-winding induction motor and the synchronous motors, agreeing neither company would sue over the bar-winding patent. These inventions led to the modern 100 h.p. induction motor that has the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 h.p. motor in 1897.

The rotating magnetic field: the key principle in AC motor operation

A rotating magnetic field was proposed as early as 1824 by the French physicist François Arago. By manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated the first primitive induction motor in 1879. In the 1880s, many inventors were trying to develop workable AC motors because AC's advantages in long distance high voltage transmission were offset by the inability to operate motors on AC. The first AC commutator-free two phase induction motors were invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla. Ferraris developed the idea of a rotating magnetic field in 1885, the working model was demonstrated in 1885 by Ferraris and he published his research in 1888. Tesla conceived the rotating magnetic field principle in 1882 and had a working prototype induction motor by 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris's research detailing the foundations of motor operation, while concluding at that time that "the apparatus based on that principle could not be of any interest from a practical point of view." In 1888 Tesla presented a paper to the AIEE that included diagrams of three types of two-phase four-stator-pole motor, one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor field winding. One of Tesla's patents also claims the use of shorted bands instead of winding to form the equivalent of a squirrel-cage induction motor. George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla's patents, hired Tesla to be a consultant at Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Company's Pittsburgh labs, and assigned C. F. Scott to assist Tesla; however, Tesla left for New York within a year. Tesla was awarded the American Institute of Electrical Engineers (AIEE) highest award, the Edison Medal, in 1917 for discovering the rotating magnetic field. text_human: With the help of Charles Stearn, an expert on vacuum pumps, in 1878, Swan developed a method of processing that avoided the early bulb blackening. This received a British Patent in 1880.[dubious – discuss] On 18 December 1878, a lamp using a slender carbon rod was shown at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society, and Swan gave a working demonstration at their meeting on 17 January 1879. It was also shown to 700 who attended a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on 3 February 1879. These lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. Thus they had low resistance and required very large conductors to supply the necessary current, so they were not commercially practical, although they did furnish a demonstration of the possibilities of incandescent lighting with relatively high vacuum, a carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. Besides requiring too much current for a central station electric system to be practical, they had a very short lifetime. Swan turned his attention to producing a better carbon filament and the means of attaching its ends. He devised a method of treating cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and obtained British Patent 4933 in 1880. From this year he began installing light bulbs in homes and landmarks in England. His house was the first in the world to be lit by a lightbulb and also the first house in the world to be lit by hydroelectric power. In 1878 the home of Lord Armstrong at Cragside was also among the first houses to be lit by electricity. In the early 1880s he had started his company. In 1881, the Savoy Theatre in the City of Westminster, London was lit by Swan incandescent lightbulbs, which was the first theatre, and the first public building in the world, to be lit entirely by electricity.
text_ai_base: In 1878, with the assistance of vacuum pump expert Charles Stearn, Swan developed a method to prevent early bulb blackening, earning a British Patent in 1880. On December 18, 1878, he displayed a lamp with a slender carbon rod at a Newcastle Chemical Society meeting, followed by a working demonstration on January 17, 1879. The lamp was also showcased to 700 visitors at a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on February 3, 1879. These lamps employed a carbon rod typical of arc lamps, rather than a slender filament, resulting in low resistance and requiring large conductors for sufficient current. While not commercially viable, they demonstrated the potential for incandescent lighting using a high vacuum, carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. However, due to the excessive current requirement and short lifespan, Swan shifted focus to improving the carbon filament and its attachment technique. He pioneered a method using cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and secured British Patent 4933 in 1880. That year, Swan began to install light bulbs in homes and landmarks across England, including his own house, which became the first in the world lit by a lightbulb and by hydroelectric power. In 1878, Lord Armstrong's home at Cragside was also among the first to be electrified. By the early 1880s, Swan had founded his own company. In 1881, Swan's incandescent lightbulbs illuminated the Savoy Theatre in Westminster, London, marking it as the first theatre, and public building globally, to be exclusively lit by electricity.

His lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. The cost of the vacuum pump equipment and difficulty getting sufficient vacuum limited the size of his demonstrations.[13] Swan turned his attention to producing a better carbon filament and the means of attaching its ends. He devised a method of treating cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and obtained British Patent 4933 in 1880. From this year he began installing light bulbs in homes and landmarks in England. His house, in Low Fell, Gateshead, was the world's first to have working light bulbs installed. In the early 1880s he had started his company.[6][10] Seats at the Savoy Theatre were in high demand as members of the upper-class in London flocked to see its first theatrical performances in 1881, all of which featured Swan's incandescent lighting, to great acclaim. Swan's light was during its early development used predominantly in England. In response to Swan's lights, which looked very similar to Edison's, Edison sued Swan in court for patent infringement but the lawsuit stopped when it was shown Swan's version was a proven earlier version of the light bulb. In the United States, Edison lost the right to the claim of "first inventor" of the light bulb; however, he continued to claim that title throughout his life.[14][15] Swan sold his US patent rights to the Brush Electric Company in June 1882.[9][10]

text_human: The state united behind the Plan of Ayutla and ratified the new constitution in 1855. The state was able to survive through the Reform War with minimal damage due to the large number of liberal political figures. The 1858 conservative movement did not succeed in the state even after the successful military campaign of the conservative Zuloaga with 1,000 men occupied the cities of Chihuahua and Parral. In August 1859, Zuloaga and his forces were defeated by the liberal Orozco and his forces; Orozco soon after deposed the state governor, but had to flee to Durango two months later. In the late 1860s the conservative General Cajen briefly entered the state after his campaign through the state of Jalisco and helped establish conservative politicians and ran out the liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. Cajen took possession of the state capital and established himself as governor; he brooked no delay in uniting a large force to combat the liberal forces which he defeated in La Batalla del Gallo. Cajen attained several advantages over the liberals within the state, but soon lost his standing due to a strong resurgence of the liberal forces within the state. The successful liberal leaders José María Patoni of Durango and J.E. Muñoz of Chihuahua quickly strengthened their standing by limiting the political rights of the clergy implementing the presidential decree. The state elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal leader, as governor; he would continue to fight small battles within the state to suppress conservative uprisings during 1861.

In August 1859, Zuloaga and his forces were defeated by the liberal leader Orozco, who then briefly deposed the state governor before fleeing to Durango two months later. In the late 1860s, conservative General Cajen entered the state following his campaign through Jalisco. He helped install conservative politicians and ousted liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. Despite his initial success, Cajen soon lost power due to a strong liberal resurgence. Liberal leaders José María Patoni of Durango and J.E. Muñoz of Chihuahua regained influence by limiting the clergy's political rights according to a presidential decree. The state elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal, as governor. text_human: Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman country villas, once common in the Eastern Mediterranean. The most superb example can be found in the bath house of Hisham's Palace, Palestine which was made around 744. The main panel depicts a large tree and underneath it a lion attacking a deer (right side) and two deers peacefully grazing (left side). The panel probably represents good and bad governance. Mosaics with classical geometric motifs survived in the bath area of the 8th-century Umayyad palace complex in Anjar, Lebanon. The luxurious desert residence of Al-Walid II in Qasr al-Hallabat (in present-day Jordan) was also decorated with floor mosaics that show a high level of technical skill. The best preserved panel at Hallabat is divided by a Tree of Life flanked by "good" animals on one side and "bad" animals on the other. Among the Hallabat representations are vine scrolls, grapes, pomegranates, oryx, wolves, hares, a leopard, pairs of partridges, fish, bulls, ostriches, rabbits, rams, goats, lions and a snake. At Qastal, near Amman, excavations in 2000 uncovered the earliest known Umayyad mosaics in present-day Jordan, dating probably from the caliphate of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan (685–705). They cover much of the floor of a finely decorated building that probably served as the palace of a local governor. The Qastal mosaics depict geometrical patterns, trees, animals, fruits and rosettes. Except for the open courtyard, entrance and staircases, the floors of the entire palace were covered in mosaics.

The best-preserved panel at Hallabat features a Tree of Life divided among "good" and "bad" animals. text_human: On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged. Many more ports were attacked. Plymouth was attacked five times before the end of the month while Belfast, Hull, and Cardiff were hit. Cardiff was bombed on three nights, Portsmouth centre was devastated by five raids. The rate of civilian housing lost was averaging 40,000 people per week dehoused in September 1940. In March 1941, two raids on Plymouth and London dehoused 148,000 people. Still, while heavily damaged, British ports continued to support war industry and supplies from North America continued to pass through them while the Royal Navy continued to operate in Plymouth, Southampton, and Portsmouth. Plymouth in particular, because of its vulnerable position on the south coast and close proximity to German air bases, was subjected to the heaviest attacks. On 10/11 March, 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of high explosives and 46,000 incendiaries. Many houses and commercial centres were heavily damaged, the electrical supply was knocked out, and five oil tanks and two magazines exploded. Nine days later, two waves of 125 and 170 bombers dropped heavy bombs, including 160 tons of high explosive and 32,000 incendiaries. Much of the city centre was destroyed. Damage was inflicted on the port installations, but many bombs fell on the city itself. On 17 April 346 tons of explosives and 46,000 incendiaries were dropped from 250 bombers led by KG 26. The damage was considerable, and the Germans also used aerial mines. Over 2,000 AAA shells were fired, destroying two Ju 88s. By the end of the air campaign over Britain, only eight percent of the German effort against British ports was made using mines.

On April 17, 250 bombers led by KG 26 dropped 346 tons of explosives and 46,000 incendiaries, causing significant damage and deploying aerial mines. By the end of the air campaign over Britain only eight per cent of the German effort against British ports were mines.

text_human: "The first Ottoman Medrese was created in İznik in 1331 and most Ottoman medreses followed the traditions of Sunni Islam." "When an Ottoman sultan established a new medrese, he would invite scholars from the Islamic world—for example, Murad II brought scholars from Persia, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn who helped enhance the reputation of the Ottoman medrese". This reveals that the Islamic world was interconnected in the early modern period as they travelled around to other Islamic states exchanging knowledge. This sense that the Ottoman Empire was becoming modernised through globalization is also recognised by Hamadeh who says: "Change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity." İnalcık also mentions that while scholars from for example Persia travelled to the Ottomans in order to share their knowledge, Ottomans travelled as well to receive education from scholars of these Islamic lands, such as Egypt, Persia and Turkestan. Hence, this reveals that similar to today's modern world, individuals from the early modern society travelled abroad to receive education and share knowledge and that the world was more interconnected than it seems. Also, it reveals how the system of "schooling" was also similar to today's modern world where students travel abroad to different countries for studies. Examples of Ottoman madaris are the ones built by Mehmed the Conqueror. He built eight madaris that were built "on either side of the mosque where there were eight higher madaris for specialised studies and eight lower medreses, which prepared students for these." The fact that they were built around, or near mosques reveals the religious impulses behind madrasa building and it reveals the interconnectedness between institutions of learning and religion. The students who completed their education in the lower medreses became known as danismends. This reveals that similar to the education system today, the Ottomans' educational system involved different kinds of schools attached to different kinds of levels. For example, there were lower madaris and specialised ones, and for one to get into the specialised area meant that he had to complete the classes in the lower one in order to adequately prepare himself for higher learning.
text_ai_base: The first Ottoman Medrese was established in İznik in 1331, and most Ottoman medreses adhered to the traditions of Sunni Islam. When an Ottoman sultan founded a new medrese, he would invite scholars from across the Islamic world. For instance, Murad II brought in scholars from Persia, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn, to enhance the medrese’s reputation. This demonstrates the interconnectedness of the Islamic world during the early modern period, as scholars traveled between Islamic states to exchange knowledge. Hamadeh notes that this globalization indicated the Ottoman Empire's modernization, stating: “Change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity.” İnalcık also mentions that Ottomans traveled abroad to places like Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan to further their education, illustrating the reciprocity of knowledge exchange. Much like today, individuals traveled internationally to learn and share knowledge, suggesting the world was more interconnected than it might appear. This parallels modern systems where students study abroad. An example of Ottoman madaris includes those built by Mehmed the Conqueror, who constructed eight madaris on each side of a mosque—eight for specialized studies and eight for preparatory education. Their proximity to mosques highlights the religious motivations underpinning madrasa construction and the blend of educational and religious institutions. Students who completed their education at the lower medreses were called danismends. Similar to today's educational systems, the Ottoman system comprised various school levels, requiring students to advance from lower to more specialized madaris to prepare for higher learning.
text_ai_humanized: The first Ottoman Medrese was built in 1331 at İznik, and the majority of Ottoman medereses followed the practice of the Sunni branch of Islam. When an Ottoman sultan created a new medrese, he would invite people from all over the Islamic world to study at his new center. For example, Murad II proceeded to establish a new medrese by inviting scholars from among the Persians, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn. By bringing foreign scholars into his madrasah Murad II expanded the name and prestige of his medrese. This example shows how the Islamic world of the early modern period was globalized with the transfer of students from one Islamic state to another. Hamadeh comments on this globalization, and writes that: …change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity. This quotation proves that the Ottoman Empire was modernized just like other places in the world. İnalcık states that Ottomans also went abroad in order to gain higher education: Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan. Just as other people came to the Ottoman Empire Ottomans went to other place of the Islamic world in order to further their education. Just as nowadays, people went all over the world to learn and transmit their knowledge. This suggests that the early modern world may have been more connected with itself than one would think. This system is very similar to the one we have now when students go to other places and learn new things. One example of Ottoman madrasas is the building of a group of madaris by Mehmed the Conquerer. Mehmed the Conquerer constructed eight madaris on one side of a mosque and another eight madaris on the other side of the same mosque; one set of these madaris were for specialization and the other for preparatory education. This example illustrates two major things about the Ottoman Empire, their common location near mosques and the number of them built at one time. Madaris were constructed with a religious purpose due to their location near the mosque. These examples show the combination of both madaris and mosques in achieving the religious goal of the sultans. Another aspect of madaris in the Ottoman Empire was the multiplicity of madaris in one area. This shows that the Ottomans had different types of school for different age groups and that when a student finished his education in the small medrese the student would go to the medrese for specialization. The students who successfully finished their studies in a small medrese were called danismend. Just as in the modern world the Ottoman system of education had multiple kinds of schools and a students had to move up to a higher medrese in order to better prepare himself for the madaris teaching specialization.

text_human: To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. The Kangxi Emperor was able to successfully expel Galdan's invading forces from these regions, which were then incorporated into the empire. Galdan was eventually killed in the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces received the surrender of Taiwan from Zheng Keshuang, grandson of Koxinga, who had conquered Taiwan from the Dutch colonists as a base against the Qing. Zheng Keshuang was awarded the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was inducted into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners when he moved to Beijing. Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661-1662, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, where they lived in the Kingdom of Tungning. The Qing sent the 17 Ming princes still living on Taiwan in 1683 back to mainland China where they spent the rest of their lives in exile since their lives were spared from execution. Winning Taiwan freed Kangxi's forces for series of battles over Albazin, the far eastern outpost of the Tsardom of Russia. Zheng's former soldiers on Taiwan like the rattan shield troops were also inducted into the Eight Banners and used by the Qing against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk was China's first formal treaty with a European power and kept the border peaceful for the better part of two centuries. After Galdan's death, his followers, as adherents to Tibetan Buddhism, attempted to control the choice of the next Dalai Lama. Kangxi dispatched two armies to Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, and installed a Dalai Lama sympathetic to the Qing.

In response, Kangxi sent two armies to Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, to install a Qing-friendly Dalai Lama.
text_ai_humanized: To secure his empire, Kangxi personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. He managed to drive Galdan's forces back and incorporated Outer Mongolia into the empire. He was also responsible for the final demise of the remnants of the Dzungar Khanate. Galdan died in the Dzungar–Qing War. Qing troops received the surrender of Formosa in 1683 from Zheng Keshuang, grandson of Koxinga, who had used the island as a base against the Qing, after the surrender of the Zheng family, Qing troops also executed all the male members of the Zheng family in return for a plot against betrayal. Zheng Keshuang was awarded the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was inducted into the Eight Banners as part of the Plain Red Banner, marrying the daughter of Sun Sike (孫思克).[53] Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661–1662, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, Prince of Lu. The Qing sent the 17 Ming princes still living on Taiwan back to mainland China where they spent the rest of their lives.[54] Winning Taiwan freed up the Qing navy to use in the conflict against the Russian Empire along the Amur River, the Siege of Albazin. Qing forces routed a Russian army at Albazin in 1686. The Kangxi Emperor's government had issued edicts in 1668 and 1670 to recruit Albazin Cossacks to join the Eight Banners. Albazin Cossacks who defected to the Qing were given civilian jobs or enrolled in the Eight Banners. Qing naval forces included Chinese style war junk, bow and arrow, gun and cannon-armed soldiers. Former Zheng (鄭) forces like the rattan shield troops (Tengpaiying) were used against the Russian Cossacks at Albazin. 20–30 Russians were killed in a raid on the Cossack fort's cattle by a Qing army with former Ming soldiers using bows and arrows. After being besieged by 3,000 Qing troops and their native auxiliaries, the Russian Cossacks outside the fort surrendered. After Galdan was overthrown, Galdan's own followers among the Oirats brought the 5th Dalai Lama, Tibetan Buddhism's spiritual leader, into their realm. Fearing a revival of Galdan's power, Kangxi sent two armies into Tibet in 1696 to install a Dalai Lama loyal to the Qing dynasty.

text_human: After the death of the president Benito Juárez in 1872, the first magistracy of the country was occupied by the vice-president Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada, who called for new elections. Two candidates were registered; Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, one of the heroes of the Battle of Puebla which had taken place on May 5, 1862. Lerdeo de Tejada won the election, but lost popularity after he announced his intent to run for re-election. On March 21, 1876, Don Porfirio Díaz rebelled against President Sebastian Lerdo de Tejada. The Plan of Tuxtepec defended the "No Re-election" principle. On June 2, 1876 the garrisons in the state of Chihuahua surrendered to the authority of General Porfirio Díaz; Governor Antonio Ochoa was arrested until all the Lerdista forces were suppressed throughout the state. Porfirio Díaz then helped Tíras regain the governorship of the state of Chihuahua allowing for the Plan of Tuxtepec to be implemented. The victory of the Plan of Tuxtepec, gave the interim presidency to Jose Maria Iglesias and later, as the only candidate, the General Porfirio Díaz assumed the presidency on May 5, 1877. During the first years of the Porfiriato (Porfirio Díaz Era), the Díaz administration had to combat several attacks from the Lerdista forces and the Apache. A new rebellion led by the Lerdista party was orchestrated from exile in the United States. The Lerdista forces were able to temporarily occupy the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. During 1877 the northern parts of the state suffered through a spell of extreme drought which were responsible for many deaths in El Paso del Norte.
text_ai_base: Following the death of President Benito Juárez in 1872, Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada assumed the presidency and called for new elections. The two candidates were Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, a renowned hero of the Battle of Puebla on May 5, 1862. Lerdo de Tejada won the election but lost favor when he announced plans to seek re-election. On March 21, 1876, Porfirio Díaz launched a rebellion against President Lerdo de Tejada, advocating for the "No Re-election" principle through the Plan of Tuxtepec. On June 2, 1876, the garrisons in Chihuahua state surrendered to Díaz's authority, resulting in the arrest of Governor Antonio Ochoa and the suppression of Lerdista forces across the state. Díaz then supported the reinstatement of Tíras as the governor of Chihuahua, facilitating the implementation of the Plan of Tuxtepec. This victory led to Jose Maria Iglesias briefly holding the interim presidency until Díaz, as the sole candidate, became president on May 5, 1877. In the early years of Díaz's administration, known as the Porfiriato, his government faced attacks from both Lerdista forces and Apache groups. Exiled Lerdistas orchestrated a new rebellion from the United States, temporarily capturing the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. That year, the northern region suffered a severe drought, causing many deaths in El Paso del Norte.
text_ai_humanized: Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada became President of the Republic by succession after Benito Juárez's death in 1872. He called for new elections, where the candidates were Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, one of the heroes of the battle of Puebla on 5 May 1862. Lerdo de Tejada was victorious, and fell sharply out of favour when he declared that he would stand for another re-election. Porfirio Díaz mounted a rebellion against President Lerdo de Tejada on 21 March 1876, under the Plan of Tuxtepec, promoting the "No Re-election" principle. On 2 June 1876, the garrisons in state of Chihuahua yielded to the authority of Porfirio Díaz, arresting the governor, Antonio Ochoa, and crushing the Lerdista forces wherever found. Porfirio Díaz promoted the return of the governor of Chihuahua, Tíras, as a sign of the implementation of the Plan of Tuxtepec. This triumph resulted in the brief interim presidency of Jose Maria Iglesias until Porfirio Díaz, as only candidate, assumed the presidency on 5 May 1877. In the first years of the Porfiriato, Porfirio Díaz's government was assaulted by Lerdista and Apache boots. The former Lerdistas from the United States managed to begin a new rebellion where they temporarily took the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. This year there was a great drought that struck the north, resulting in a large number of civilian deaths in El Paso del Norte.

text_human: In December 2015, West released a song titled "Facts". He announced in January 2016 on Twitter that SWISH would be released on February 11, after releasing new song "Real Friends" and a snippet of "No More Parties in L.A." with Kendrick Lamar. This also revived the GOOD Fridays initiative in which Kanye releases new singles every Friday. On January 26, 2016, West revealed he had renamed the album from SWISH to Waves, and also announced the premier of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line at Madison Square Garden. In early 2016, several weeks prior to the release of his new album, West became embroiled in a short-lived social media altercation with rapper Wiz Khalifa on Twitter that eventually involved their mutual ex-partner, Amber Rose, who protested to West's mention of her and Khalifa's child. The feud involved allegations by Rose concerning her sexual relationship with West, and received significant media attention. As of February 2, 2016, West and Khalifa had reconciled. Several days ahead of the album's release, West again changed the title, this time to The Life of Pablo. On February 11, West premiered the album at Madison Square Garden as part of the presentation of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line. Following the preview, West announced that he would be modifying the track list once more before its release to the public, and further delayed its release to finalize the recording of the track "Waves" at the behest of co-writer Chance the Rapper. He released the album exclusively on Tidal on 14 February 2016 following a performance on SNL.

This marked the revival of the GOOD Fridays initiative, where Kanye would release new singles every Friday. The album debuted exclusively on Tidal on February 14, 2016, following a performance on SNL.
text_ai_humanized: On December 31, 2015, West released a song titled "Facts". On January 8, 2016, West released "Real Friends" and a snippet of "No More Parties in L.A." featuring Kendrick Lamar; the latter of which was released in full the following week. This also marked the return of West's GOOD Fridays series where he releases new singles every Friday.[96] On January 26, he announced he had changed the title of the album from Swish to Waves and also announced the release of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line would debut on the album's release date at Madison Square Garden.[97] In the weeks leading up to his album's release, West became embroiled in several Twitter controversies and released several songs, including "No More Parties in L.A." with Lamar and "30 Hours". On February 9, West released the track list for his new album, again revising the title, this time changing it to The Life of Pablo.[98] A day ahead of its release and his accompanying Yeezy fashion show event, West was embroiled in an internet controversy over the third track to be released from the album, "Famous".[99] West premiered the album on February 11, 2016, at Madison Square Garden. He simultaneously premiered his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line, and further announced that the album would be released exclusively through the streaming service Tidal.[100] Some of the album was made available to stream live, and afterwards West announced he would change the track list again before its release to include a new version of "Wolves" featuring Sia and Vic Mensa.[101] He updated the album through February 12, 2016, and West continued to adjust the tracklist. On February 14, 2016, West released The Life of Pablo exclusively through Tidal. He performed "Highlights" on an episode of SNL. The same day, West tweeted that he would be remastering the album and re-releasing it with several new songs, including a new song called "Day One" and a new version of "Wolves" featuring Sia and Vic Mensa.[99] West postponed the release of The Life of Pablo by a week in order to complete the recording of the track "Waves", which West did at the behest of Chance the Rapper. West's decision to add additional tracks to The Life of Pablo delayed its release to February 14, 2016.

text_human: Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and comb the remaining hair into the queue hairstyle which was worn by Manchu men, on pain of death. The popular description of the order was: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; To keep your head, you cut the hair." To the Manchus, this policy was a test of loyalty and an aid in distinguishing friend from foe. For the Han Chinese, however, it was a humiliating reminder of Qing authority that challenged traditional Confucian values. The Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing) held that "a person's body and hair, being gifts from one's parents, are not to be damaged." Under the Ming dynasty, adult men did not cut their hair but instead wore it in the form of a top-knot. The order triggered strong resistance to Qing rule in Jiangnan and massive killing of ethnic Han Chinese. It was Han Chinese defectors who carried out massacres against people refusing to wear the queue.. Li Chengdong, a Han Chinese general who had served the Ming but surrendered to the Qing, ordered his Han troops to carry out three separate massacres in the city of Jiading within a month, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths. At the end of the third massacre, there was hardly any living person left in this city. Jiangyin also held out against about 10,000 Han Chinese Qing troops for 83 days. When the city wall was finally breached on 9 October 1645, the Han Chinese Qing army led by the Han Chinese Ming defector Liu Liangzuo (劉良佐), who had been ordered to "fill the city with corpses before you sheathe your swords," massacred the entire population, killing between 74,000 and 100,000 people. The queue was the only aspect of Manchu culture which the Qing forced on the common Han population. The Qing required people serving as officials to wear Manchu clothing, but allowed non-official Han civilians to continue wearing Hanfu (Han clothing).
text_ai_base: In July 1645, Dorgon issued a contentious edict, known as the "haircutting order," requiring adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and style the remaining hair into a queue, similar to that worn by Manchu men. Failure to comply meant death. The edict was famously summarized as: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; to keep your head, you cut the hair." For the Manchus, this policy served as a loyalty test and a way to identify allies. However, for the Han Chinese, it was a humiliating symbol of Qing dominance, clashing with traditional Confucian values outlined in the Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing), which stated that "a person's body and hair, as gifts from one's parents, should not be harmed." Under the preceding Ming dynasty, men wore their hair in top-knots and did not cut it. The edict sparked fierce resistance to Qing rule in Jiangnan, leading to mass killings of Han Chinese. Ironically, it was Han Chinese defectors who carried out massacres against those refusing the queue. Li Chengdong, a former Ming general who surrendered to the Qing, commanded his troops to perform three separate massacres in Jiading within a month, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths. By the end of the third massacre, scarcely anyone in the city remained alive. Jiangyin resisted the Qing forces for 83 days, but when the city walls fell on October 9, 1645, the Qing army, led by Ming defector Liu Liangzuo (劉良佐), massacred the entire population, killing between 74,000 and 100,000 people, under orders to "fill the city with corpses before you sheathe your swords." The queue was the only element of Manchu culture imposed on the general Han populace. While officials were required to wear Manchu attire, ordinary Han civilians were permitted to continue wearing Hanfu.
text_ai_humanized: In July 1645, Dorgon promulgated a controversial edict ordering all Han Chinese men to shave their foreheads and to braid the rest of their hair into a queue, the traditional Manchu hairstyle, on pain of death. The edict was harshly enforced: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; to keep your head, you cut the hair."[30] For the Manchus, the policy was a test of loyalty and a mark of acceptance of Manchu authority. For Han Chinese, however, it was a humiliation because traditional teachings held that people should not alter their bodies, as they were gifts from their parents. Under the Ming, Han Chinese wore their hair in a top-knot and wore no head-shaving.[31] The Qing hairstyle was symbolic of submission to the new dynasty. This edict triggered widespread resistance to Qing rule, especially in the former Ming capital of Jiankang (Nanjing), whose residents attacked anyone who had a queue. During the ensuing Jiangnan massacres, these Han Chinese killed many Han who had surrendered to the Qing. The Nanjing Han population was later massacred or driven into the countryside. Han Chinese Defectors who joined the Qing slaughtered Han Chinese resisters to the Qing. Li Chengdong, a Han Chinese general who had served the Ming but surrendered to the Qing, ordered troops to carry out three separate massacres in the city of Jiading within one month, resulting in tens of thousands deaths. At the end of the third massacre, there was hardly a living person left in this city. Jiangyin also held out against about 10,000 Han Chinese Qing troops for 83 days. It was estimated that 74,000 inhabitants were killed when the city fell on 9 October 1645. Another massacre was conducted in Changzhou. Although Dorgon himself repealed the order in 1645, the demand was reinstituted when resistance resumed.[citation needed] Hundreds of thousands of people were killed before all of China was brought into compliance. The queue was the only aspect of Manchu culture that the Qing sought to impose on the common Han population. Qing laws did not force Han civilians to wear Manchu clothing, only Manchu-style officials and men serving the emperor were required to wear it; Han civilian men were forced to make way for Manchus and Mongols on the street and received a beating if they did not do so.[32]

text_human: The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender currently coached by Bill Self. The team has won five national titles, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988, and 2008. The basketball program is currently the second winningest program in college basketball history with an overall record of 2,070–806 through the 2011–12 season. The team plays at Allen Fieldhouse. Perhaps its best recognized player was Wilt Chamberlain, who played in the 1950s. Kansas has counted among its coaches Dr. James Naismith (the inventor of basketball and only coach in Kansas history to have a losing record), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Phog Allen ("the Father of basketball coaching"), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Roy Williams of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Basketball Hall of Fame inductee and former NBA Champion Detroit Pistons coach Larry Brown. In addition, legendary University of Kentucky coach and Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Adolph Rupp played for KU's 1922 and 1923 Helms National Championship teams, and NCAA Hall of Fame inductee and University of North Carolina Coach Dean Smith played for KU's 1952 NCAA Championship team. Both Rupp and Smith played under Phog Allen. Allen also coached Hall of Fame coaches Dutch Lonborg and Ralph Miller. Allen founded the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC), which started what is now the NCAA Tournament. The Tournament began in 1939 under the NABC and the next year was handed off to the newly formed NCAA.
text_ai_base: Since 1898, the KU men's basketball team has consistently been in the game. Known as the Jayhawks, they're perennial national contenders, currently led by coach Bill Self. With five national titles to their name, the team boasts three NCAA tournament championships from 1952, 1988, and 2008. By the end of the 2011–12 season, Kansas had amassed an overall record of 2,070 wins and 806 losses, making it the second-winningest program in college basketball history. They play at the renowned Allen Fieldhouse. Among their most famous players was Wilt Chamberlain, who starred in the 1950s. Kansas's coaching roster has included legendary figures like Dr. James Naismith, the inventor of basketball and the only KU coach with a losing record; Phog Allen, revered as "the Father of basketball coaching"; Roy Williams, a Hall of Fame inductee and former North Carolina coach; and Larry Brown, another Hall of Fame inductee and former NBA champion coach with the Detroit Pistons. Furthermore, renowned Kentucky coach Adolph Rupp, a Hall of Fame inductee, and Dean Smith, an NCAA Hall of Fame inductee and former North Carolina coach, both played for KU's championship teams in 1922, 1923, and 1952. Rupp and Smith were coached by Phog Allen, who also mentored Hall of Famers Ralph Miller and Dutch Lonborg. Allen was instrumental in founding the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC), which initiated the NCAA Tournament in 1939 before handing it over to the newly established NCAA the following year.
text_ai_humanized: The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender, coached by Bill Self. KU is considered one of the most prestigious college basketball programs. The Jayhawks have won a total of five national championships, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988 and 2008. They also were retroactively awarded championships by the Helms Foundation for the 1922 and 1923 seasons. The team currently ranks third in Division I all-time winning percentage and second in Division I all-time wins. By the end of the 2011–12 season, Kansas had an overall record of 2,070–806 (.719). This record includes a 623–107 (.853) mark at historic Allen Fieldhouse. The Jayhawks are first all-time in conference titles. Famous former Jayhawk players include Wilt Chamberlain and Paul Pierce. The Jayhawks have been led by many great coaches, including the inventor of the game of basketball, Dr. James Naismith (the game's only coach with a losing record), Phog Allen (named the "Father of basketball coaching" by the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame), Dick Harp, Ted Owens, and Hall of Fame coaches Larry Brown, and Roy Williams. Not only has Kansas had many notable former players and coaches, many basketball legends have had some connection to KU, including Dean Smith (as a player only), Adolph Rupp (as a player only), Dutch Lonborg, and Ralph Miller (as players and coaches). Smith and Rupp played for KU's 1952 and 1923 championship teams, respectively; they were teammates on the 1922 team. Allen took over for Naismith; Rupp and Lonborg played for Allen, while Smith, Owens, and Harp played for Allen and later served as assistants under him.[citation needed] The University is a founding member of the Big 12 Conference, and is the only school to win at least 10 games in conference play each year for the last 28 seasons starting in 1983–1984. Since the 1987–88 season, the Jayhawks have won 20 or more games every season.

text_human: The Defence Committee—Third Report "Defence Equipment 2009" cites an article from the Financial Times website stating that the Chief of Defence Materiel, General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue, had instructed staff within Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) through an internal memorandum to reprioritize the approvals process to focus on supporting current operations over the next three years; deterrence related programmes; those that reflect defence obligations both contractual or international; and those where production contracts are already signed. The report also cites concerns over potential cuts in the defence science and technology research budget; implications of inappropriate estimation of Defence Inflation within budgetary processes; underfunding in the Equipment Programme; and a general concern over striking the appropriate balance over a short-term focus (Current Operations) and long-term consequences of failure to invest in the delivery of future UK defence capabilities on future combatants and campaigns. The then Secretary of State for Defence, Bob Ainsworth MP, reinforced this reprioritisation of focus on current operations and had not ruled out "major shifts" in defence spending. In the same article the First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, Royal Navy, acknowledged that there was not enough money within the defence budget and it is preparing itself for tough decisions and the potential for cutbacks. According to figures published by the London Evening Standard the defence budget for 2009 is "more than 10% overspent" (figures cannot be verified) and the paper states that this had caused Gordon Brown to say that the defence spending must be cut. The MoD has been investing in IT to cut costs and improve services for its personnel.
text_ai_base: The Defence Committee's Third Report, "Defence Equipment 2009," references an article from the Financial Times website, noting that General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue, Chief of Defence Materiel, directed Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) staff via an internal memo to reprioritize the approvals process. This refocusing emphasizes support for current operations over the next three years, deterrence-related programs, defense obligations that are either contractual or international, and projects with signed production contracts. The report also highlights concerns about potential cuts to the defence science and technology research budget, inaccurate estimates of Defence Inflation impacting budgets, underfunding in the Equipment Programme, and the challenge of balancing short-term focuses on current operations with the need to invest in future UK defense capabilities. Bob Ainsworth MP, the then Secretary of State for Defence, endorsed this shift towards current operations, mentioning that "major shifts" in defense spending were not off the table. Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, acknowledged the insufficient funding in the defense budget, indicating the necessity for tough decisions and possible cutbacks. According to the London Evening Standard, the 2009 defense budget was "more than 10% overspent," though these figures are unverified, prompting Gordon Brown to declare the need for defense spending cuts. To manage costs and enhance services for its personnel, the Ministry of Defence has been investing in IT.
text_ai_humanized: In its Third Report, Defence Equipment 2009, the Defence Committee quoted a report on the Financial Times web-site which claimed that Chief of Defence Materiel General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue issued an internal memo, telling DE&S staff to "refocus" the approvals process on "defence priorities": support for current operations for the next three years, the deterrent, defence commitments that are "contractual or international" and programmes for which production contracts have been signed.[166] The report also spotlighted defence science and technology research budget cuts, estimated but inaccurate Defence Inflation budgets, underfunding of the Equipment Programme and the apparent incompatibility between the near-term focus on current operations and the investment required to provide future UK defence capabilities. The Rt Hon. Bob Ainsworth MP, then Secretary of State for Defence, welcomed the emphasis on current operations and said that while "there was to be no review of the major decisions of the 1998 SDR, major shifts in defence spending "could not'' be ruled out."[166] As for the underfunded defence budget, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff stated: "There is not enough money in the defence programme at the moment. There are some tough decisions to be taken to try and balance the books. I am pretty sure there will be some cuts."[167] In 2009, the defence budget was reportedly "more than 10% overspent", but those numbers have not been confirmed. London Evening Standard reported: "According to official Ministry of Defence figures obtained by freedom of information requests, Gordon Brown is right — defence spending cannot be exempt from cuts."[168] The MoD has made significant investments in IT in order to cut costs and provide better services for its personnel.

text_human: West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense and outspokenness have additionally set him apart from other rappers. Early in his career, he was among the first rappers to publicly criticize the preponderance of homophobia in hip hop. The sales competition between rapper 50 Cent's Curtis and West's Graduation altered the direction of hip hop and helped pave the way for new rappers who did not follow the hardcore-gangster mold. Rosie Swash of The Guardian viewed the sales competition as a historical moment in hip-hop, because it "highlighted the diverging facets of hip-hop in the last decade; the former was gangsta rap for the noughties, while West was the thinking man's alternative." Rolling Stone credited West with transforming hip hop's mainstream, "establishing a style of introspective yet glossy rap [...]", and called him "as interesting and complicated a pop star as the 2000s produced—a rapper who mastered, upped and moved beyond the hip-hop game, a producer who created a signature sound and then abandoned it to his imitators, a flashy, free-spending sybarite with insightful things to say about college, culture and economics, an egomaniac with more than enough artistic firepower to back it up." His 2008 album 808s & Heartbreak polarized both listeners and critics upon its release, but was commercially successful and impacted hip hop and pop stylistically, as it laid the groundwork for a new wave of artists who generally eschewed typical rap braggadocio for intimate subject matter and introspection, including Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy. According to Ben Detrick of XXL magazine, West effectively led a new wave of artists, including Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who lacked the interest or ability to rap about gunplay or drug-dealing.
text_ai_base: Kanye West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense, and outspoken nature have distinguished him from other rappers. Early in his career, West was one of the first to openly criticize the pervasive homophobia in hip hop. The sales rivalry between 50 Cent's "Curtis" and West's "Graduation" changed hip hop's trajectory, opened doors for new artists, and broke away from the hardcore gangster mold. Rosie Swash of The Guardian regarded this competition as a pivotal moment, highlighting hip hop's divergent trends: gangsta rap for the 2000s versus West's intellectual alternative. Rolling Stone attributed West with transforming mainstream hip hop by creating introspective yet polished rap. They described him as one of the most intriguing and complex pop stars of the 2000s—a rapper who mastered and then transcended the hip hop scene, a producer with a distinctive sound that he left for his imitators, and a flashy yet insightful figure discussing college, culture, and economics. His 2008 album, "808s & Heartbreak," divided listeners and critics but was a commercial success. It had a stylistic impact on hip hop and pop, paving the way for artists like Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy, who favored introspection over traditional rap braggadocio. Ben Detrick of XXL magazine noted that West led a new wave of artists, such as Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who were uninterested in or incapable of rapping about gunplay or drug dealing.
text_ai_humanized: His middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense, and outspokenness have set him apart from other rappers. West was the first rapper to criticize the path in which hip hop was developing, and the first to openly ridicule the homophobic attitudes of many rappers. The sales competition between West's Graduation and 50 Cent's Curtis was publicized as a "great day for hip hop". Many saw it as a "face-off" between gangsta rap and conscious rap, two of the most prevalent trends in the genre. Stereo Williams of The Daily Beast wrote that, "For the first time, hip-hop's new archetype was at odds with hip-hop's former poster boy and a new commercial dominance was established in the music.... Hip-hop was changing, and the pop-cultural zeitgeist was too." 50 Cent was one of the more prominent rappers to emerge during West's absence in 2006. He had been in a sales competition with his own album, Curtis, against West's Graduation that year, West's outsold 50 Cent's—signaling West's usurping of 50 Cent as the figurehead of hip hop. Slant Magazine called the defeat a "changing of the guard" moment in the music scene, as it proved that rap music was no longer "defined by gritty street narratives and odes to one's hood" like gangsta rap, given that West's lyrical topics dealt with themes of "wanting more out of life" and "personal progression" as a person. Steve Yates of The Observer commented that West snatched "ownership of mainstream hip-hop" from 50 Cent, "who took a street-hustling template and filled it with cartoonish violence". In 2007, West's robust album sales and hot concert tour put him at the top of MTV's annual "Hottest MCs in the Game" list. Thought his influence, West was said to be the figure who transformed hip-hop with the passage of time. Danyel Smith of The Root noted, "Kanye's progression from hip-hop beat-maker to megawatt pop-cultural icon is a timeframe in modern American history, one for which we'll probably be able to say, 'Back in the day folks used to rap like that, before Kanye West.'" Rosie Swash of The Guardian deemed the sales competition between Curtis and Graduation a "pivotal moment in the genres history", declaring: "It was a clash between two very different heroes of the genre for the right to become its king, not just in the commercial sense. In his performance 50 Cent's world-bleary ghetto persona would represent hip hop for the noughties, whereas West's bookish, bear-loving, gaffe-prone ditz would be championing a different, more intellectual alternative." Swash also expressed the importance of West's huge success, particularly in 2007, as his new-found popularity kanyefied hip hop: "Kanye West kanyefied hip hop, taking away its anger, its neutrality towards its own misogyny and its obsession with nihilistic materialism, and bringing it to a new place of experimentation, self-questioning, musical diversity and passion." In 2008, Rolling Stone mentioned that caused West Injects masses of self into continental commercially successful hip-hop. According to Rolling Stone: What artist ever garnered more headlines, album by album, song by song, even photo by photo, than Kanye West? One of the most fascinating pop stars of the 00s was also one of the most relentlessly mercurial: a rapper who conquered the hip-hop world, then rose above it, a producer who cast aside his sonic signature to let the copycats have it all to themselves, a preening, blingy whant-a-celebrity genius who sang about college, culture, commerce and all points in between — and who was forced to parody and sadly transcend his own persona by decade’s end, as life’s harshness destroyed his innocence. Nobody sounds like West — mainly because there’s nobody who can sound like him tion injects masses of self into continental. Mainstream hip-hop, into the mainstream, creating introspective, ruminative, self-analyzing (but still street-hip) rap. Although opening to mixed views from critics and audiences, West's 2008 album 808s & Heartbreaks, which produced "downbeat melodies and wedding-band human beatbox", proved to be a commercial success. In this light, Rolling Stone opined that there was no papering over the shameless sentimentality, Auto-Tuned warbling and brutal romanticism of West's break-up album, and later awaiting for a hip-hop album so unlikely and avant-garde, there could be no imitating it. The album have been associated for progressing hip-hop and pop music. The album helped pave the way for hip hop's 2010s embracing of indulgent and extravagantly produced melodic tendencies, "as well as its realisation that authenticity in hip hop could be achieved even when the protagonist shrouded behind a wall of vocoders". It paved the way for future innovation from artists such as Frank Ocean, The Weekend, Drake, Future, and Kid Cudi, even Kid Cudi and Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy who instead sought a thoughtful alternative to rap bombast. Reviewing West's musical career prior The Life of Pablo in Rolling Stone, Rob Sheffield considered: There’s a lot of 808s & Heartbreak in the mix. His emo crooner phase remains his most maligned by fans and critics — it’s the bridge between the acclaimed genius of his 2000s era and his post-Yeezus villain persona. Yet once the dust settled, 808s was easily the most influential album of his career. Who needs friends when you can turn your voice into a cyborg-raccoon power tool for sad-man melodrama? In 808s, the debut formula for realness began to take over vague outlines of the emo-hop future: Kid Cudi, Drake, The Weeknd, Future, etc — or even Keef and Durk for that matter. Ben Detrick of XXL recognized West as "a new archetype in which honest personal themes trump the minstrel posturing of gangsta rap." He is followed by rappers "who don’t care, or aren’t smart enough to care, about rapping about gunplay or bricks." Detrick cited Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake.

Ben Detrick of XXL recognized West as "a new archetype in which honest personal themes trump the minstrel posturing of gangsta rap." He is followed by rappers "who don’t care, or aren’t smart enough to care, about rapping about gunplay or bricks." Detrick cited Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake.

text_human: Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot enabled by default using a key provided by Microsoft. Concerns were raised that secure boot could prevent or hinder the use of alternate operating systems such as Linux. In a post discussing secure boot on the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste indicated that vendors would provide means to customize secure boot, stating that "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide means for users to re-configure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware. It also revealed that ARM devices (Windows RT) would be required to have secure boot permanently enabled, with no way for users to disable it. However, Tom Warren of The Verge noted that other vendors have implemented similar hardware restrictions on their own ARM-based tablet and smartphone products (including those running Microsoft's own Windows Phone platform), but still argued that Microsoft should "keep a consistent approach across ARM and x86, though, not least because of the number of users who'd love to run Android alongside Windows 8 on their future tablets." No mandate is made regarding the installation of third-party certificates that would enable running alternative programs.

On the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste addressed these concerns, noting that vendors would offer ways to customize secure boot. He emphasized, "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide the best experience first, allowing customers to make their own decisions." There were no requirements for installing third-party certificates to run alternative programs.

text_human: Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the wrestlers or teams of wrestlers must climb a ladder to obtain a prize that is hoisted above the ring. The key to winning this match is that the wrestler or team of wrestlers must try to incapacitate each other long enough for one wrestler to climb the ladder and secure that prize for their team. As a result, the ladder can be used as a weapon. The prizes include – but are not limited to any given championship belt (the traditional prize), a document granting the winner the right to a future title shot, or any document that matters to the wrestlers involved in the match (such as one granting the winner a cash prize). Another common specialty match is known as the battle royal. In a battle royal, all the wrestlers enter the ring to the point that there are 20-30 wrestlers in the ring at one time. When the match begins, the simple objective is to throw the opponent over the top rope and out of the ring with both feet on the floor in order to eliminate that opponent. The last wrestler standing is declared the winner. A variant on this type of match is the WWE's Royal Rumble where two wrestlers enter the ring to start the match and other wrestlers follow in 90 second intervals (previously 2 minutes) until 30-40 wrestlers have entered the ring. All other rules stay the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.
text_ai_base: Many modern specialty matches have been designed with distinct winning conditions. One of the most popular is the ladder match, where wrestlers or wrestling teams must climb a ladder to retrieve a prize suspended above the ring. To win, a wrestler or team must incapacitate their opponents long enough for a member to climb the ladder and secure the prize. Consequently, the ladder often becomes a weapon. Typical prizes include a championship belt (the traditional reward), a document granting a future title shot, or anything significant to the wrestlers, such as a cash prize. Another popular specialty match is the battle royal, where all wrestlers enter the ring until it fills with around 20-30 contestants. Once the match begins, each wrestler's goal is to throw opponents over the top rope, landing them outside the ring with both feet on the floor to eliminate them. The last wrestler remaining wins. A variation of this match is WWE's Royal Rumble, where two wrestlers start, and others enter at 90-second intervals (formerly 2 minutes) until 30-40 wrestlers are in the ring. All other rules remain the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.
text_ai_humanized: Many modern specialty matches, besides being no-disqualification, have an "automatic" victory condition. Perhaps the most common is the ladder match, in which the object is to set up and climb a ladder and reach an object (usually a championship belt) suspended above the ring. In these cases, the ladder may be used as a weapon. The object can be anything of importance to the wrestlers involved, be it a championship belt, a document granting a future title shot, or even money. Another common specialty match is the battle royal, in which 20 0r 30 contestants (comprising the majority of the roster of an average federation) all enter the ring at the same time, and all attempt to toss opponents over the top rope, with both feet touching the floor; the last person remaining in the ring is the winner. The variation, used in WWE (traditionally at the Royal Rumble), is the Royal Rumble in which 2 wrestlers start out at the start of the match and every 90 seconds (or 2 minutes formerly) another wrestler enters the ring until all 30 or 40 wrestlers enter the ring. All other rules are the same. (For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types)

text_human: In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. During the 19th century, Iran irrevocably lost swaths of its territories in the Caucasus which made part of the concept of Iran for centuries, to neighboring Imperial Russia. Popular unrest culminated in the Persian Constitutional Revolution of 1906, which established a constitutional monarchy and the country's first Majles (parliament). Following a coup d'état instigated by the U.K. and the U.S. in 1953, Iran gradually became close allies with the United States and the rest of the West, remained secular, but grew increasingly autocratic. Growing dissent against foreign influence and political repression culminated in the 1979 Revolution, which led to the establishment of an Islamic republic on 1 April 1979.
text_ai_base: In 633 AD, the Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran, conquering it by 651 AD. This led to a significant conversion of Iranians from their indigenous faiths, such as Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism, to Sunni Islam. Arabic became the official language, though Persian persisted as the language of the people and literature. Iran played a crucial role in the Islamic Golden Age, contributing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. The rise of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501 marked a shift as Iranians were converted from Sunni to Twelver Shia Islam, establishing it as the official religion and representing a significant turning point in Iranian and Muslim history. Under Nader Shah in 1736, Iran reached its largest territorial expansion since the Sassanid Empire, briefly becoming one of the era's most powerful empires. In the 19th century, Iran lost extensive territories in the Caucasus to Imperial Russia, lands that had been part of its identity for centuries. Popular unrest led to the Persian Constitutional Revolution of 1906, ushering in a constitutional monarchy and the country's first parliament (Majles). A coup d'état in 1953, backed by the U.K. and the U.S., aligned Iran closely with the West, maintaining a secular but increasingly autocratic government. Widespread dissatisfaction with foreign influence and political repression fueled the 1979 Revolution, resulting in the establishment of an Islamic republic on April 1, 1979.

Most of Iranians converted from their original religion such as Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic was established as the official language of Iran. Persian language, however, remained an active common language and also a literary language. After Iran became part of the Islamic world, Iran began to play a significant role in the Islamic Golden Age, with many prominent scientists and scholars such as Avicenna, Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi, Abu Rayhan Biruni, Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, Zamakhshari, Abdolhossein Zarrinkoob, Rumi, Khayyam, Ferdowsi, Attar, Sanai, Nizami, Nasir al-Din al-Tusi.
