The athletic teams' mascot, the Notre Dame Leprechaun, was created by Theodore W. Drake in 1964. The leprechaun first appeared on the football pocket schedule and program covers, eventually gaining national recognition when it appeared on the cover of Time magazine in November 1964.
text_ai_humanized: In July 2013, after a prolonged period of conference realignment, Notre Dame joined the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) in all sports except football and men's ice hockey. The Fighting Irish previously competed in the Big East Conference as full members;[43] the university left the Big East at a time when it was unstable, with many members departing for other conferences and its future uncertain. The ACC and Big East reached an agreement, allowing Notre Dame to leave the Big East for the ACC a year earlier than planned. Notre Dame retains its status as a football independent, but has committed to play five games per season against ACC opponents.[44][45] In ice hockey, Notre Dame moved to Hockey East at the same time as the other changes.[46][47] This move was necessitated by the Big Ten Conference's decision to add men's ice hockey as an official conference sport beginning in 2013–14. At that time, both the ACC and Big East do not sponsor ice hockey. The Irish were forced to find a new home for that sport, which was at the time under the control of the Central Collegiate Hockey Association (CCHA; another conference that would soon cease operations, following the 2012-13 season, due to the formation of the short-lived men's ice hockey league of the Big Ten). When Notre Dame joined the ACC, the conference announced that it would add fencing as a sponsored sport in the 2014–15 school year.[48] The "Fighting Irish" nickname has been used by the university since 1919, and there are several legends about how the moniker came to be. One comes from the story of Irish immigrant soldiers, fighting in the Civil War, used as assault troops for daredevil attacks on the opposition. Another story focuses on the Irish ancestry of the school's founder, Fr. William Corby, and the patron saint of the university's athletes, Saint Edward the Martyr. Notre Dame was known for many things in its early years, but football was not one of them.[49] The college first played football in November 1887 when a group of students from Michigan traveled to South Bend to teach the game to students from the university.[50] The game incorporated elements from soccer and rugby initially, and it took a few years for the rules to become standardized with those of Division I-A football that we know today.[51] The university eventually adopted the current version of the game, but before then it was still called Notre Dame Football because they were playing football at Notre Dame University.[52] Although there are several theories as to the origin of the Fighting Irish nickname, it was used as a moniker for the football team throughout most of the 1920s. The nickname became popular throughout the country because alumnus Francis Wallace wrote it in his columns in the New York Daily News.[53] It was unofficial until 1951, when then-University President Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, adopted the moniker at the request of students.[54][55][a] The official colors of the University of Notre Dame are Navy Blue and Gold Rush.[56] The school's athletic teams wear a combination of the two on their uniforms for competitions. Additionally, as the "Fighting Irish", Notre Dame also often uses green, traditionally the color of the fighting Irish or clover that is associated with Ireland. Athletics mascot The Notre Dame Leprechaun was designed by sports artist Theodore W. Drake in 1964.[57] The leprechaun logo was first featured on the football pocket schedule and later it was on the football program covers. The leprechaun was featured on the cover of Time magazine (November 1964). This is the logo most usually associated with Notre Dame sports.[58][59]

text_human: The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844. Continuing to anticipate a war, the state legislature on July 11, 1846 by decree enlisted 6,000 men to serve along the border; during that time Ángel Trías quickly rose to power by portraying zealous anti-American rhetoric. Trías took the opportunity to dedicate important state resources to gain economic concessions from the people and loans from many municipalities in preparation to defend the state; he used all the money he received to equip and organize a large volunteer militia. Ángel Trías took measures for state self-dependence in regards to state militia due to the diminishing financial support from the federal government.
text_ai_base: Until 1841, the state maintained relative calm compared to the rest of the country because of its close ties to the United States. However, by 1843, the state government anticipated the possibility of war and began reinforcing defense lines along the border with Texas. Weapons and supplies were sent to fully equip the military, and steps were taken to enhance efficiency at the presidios. Subsequently, the state organized the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border, which included light cavalry, four squads consisting of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officers, costing 160,603 pesos annually. At the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens attempted to halt commercial caravans carrying supplies from the United States. However, since the state was isolated from large suppliers in central Mexico, the caravan was permitted to continue in March 1844. Still anticipating war, on July 11, 1846, the state legislature decreed the enlistment of 6,000 men to serve along the border. During this period, Ángel Trías quickly ascended to power by adopting fervent anti-American rhetoric. He used the chance to secure economic concessions from the populace and loans from municipalities, preparing to defend the state by organizing and equipping a large volunteer militia with the funds obtained. Trías implemented measures to ensure the state militia's self-sufficiency, as federal government support dwindled.

text_human: The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most populous colonies. British attention soon turned towards Asia, Africa, and the Pacific. After the defeat of France in the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars (1792–1815), Britain emerged as the principal naval and imperial power of the 19th century (with London the largest city in the world from about 1830). Unchallenged at sea, British dominance was later described as Pax Britannica ("British Peace"), a period of relative peace in Europe and the world (1815–1914) during which the British Empire became the global hegemon and adopted the role of global policeman. In the early 19th century, the Industrial Revolution began to transform Britain; by the time of the Great Exhibition in 1851 the country was described as the "workshop of the world". The British Empire expanded to include India, large parts of Africa and many other territories throughout the world. Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, British dominance of much of world trade meant that it effectively controlled the economies of many regions, such as Asia and Latin America. Domestically, political attitudes favoured free trade and laissez-faire policies and a gradual widening of the voting franchise. During this century, the population increased at a dramatic rate, accompanied by rapid urbanisation, causing significant social and economic stresses. To seek new markets and sources of raw materials, the Conservative Party under Disraeli launched a period of imperialist expansion in Egypt, South Africa, and elsewhere. Canada, Australia, and New Zealand became self-governing dominions.

This era, marked by Britain’s sea supremacy, was later referred to as Pax Britannica ("British Peace"). During this period of relative peace in Europe and the world (1815–1914), the British Empire established itself as the global powerhouse and took on the role of the world’s policeman. In the early 19th century, the Industrial Revolution began reshaping Britain, leading it to be dubbed the "workshop of the world" by the time of the Great Exhibition in 1851. The British Empire expanded significantly to include India, large portions of Africa, and many other territories worldwide. Through formal colonial control and its dominance over global trade, Britain effectively influenced economies in regions like Asia and Latin America. Canada, Australia, and New Zealand evolved into self-governing dominions.

text_human: In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. For a difficult task of only a few seconds' duration, a person can put out thousands of watts, many times the 746 watts in one official horsepower. For tasks lasting a few minutes, a fit human can generate perhaps 1,000 watts. For an activity that must be sustained for an hour, output drops to around 300; for an activity kept up all day, 150 watts is about the maximum. The human equivalent assists understanding of energy flows in physical and biological systems by expressing energy units in human terms: it provides a "feel" for the use of a given amount of energy.
text_ai_base: In biology, energy is a fundamental aspect of all living systems, ranging from the entire biosphere down to the smallest organism. Within an organism, it drives the growth and development of cells and organelles. Energy is typically stored in the molecular structures of substances like carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, which release energy when they react with oxygen during respiration. In human terms, the concept of human equivalents (H-e) is used to indicate the energy required for human metabolism based on an average expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For instance, if our bodies operate at an average of 80 watts, a 100-watt light bulb would be running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80), or 1.25 H-e. During short bursts of intense activity, a person can generate thousands of watts, surpassing the 746 watts of one horsepower. For activities lasting a few minutes, a fit person might produce about 1,000 watts. However, for an hour-long activity, the output decreases to around 300 watts, and for activities sustained throughout the day, it reduces to about 150 watts. The human equivalent concept helps clarify energy flows in both physical and biological systems by expressing energy in relatable human terms, giving a tangible sense of energy usage.
text_ai_humanized: Energy in biology is an expression of the biosphere as an entire operating system. At the level of the individual organism it is responsible for the growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy can be stored in organisms in a variety of ways for example carbohydrates and lipids and proteins all release energy when reacted with oxygen, in a series of oxidation reactions, as part of the organism's respiration process. The human equivalent (symbol H-e) is a unit of power, for measuring the energy production rates of both machines and human beings. One human equivalent is the amount of power produced by an average human. The average human yields around 12, 500 kJ per day, which is approximately 80 watts. Therefore, in terms of human equivalence (H-e) and to draw from the average rate at which our bodies derived energy for metabolism as shown above, if we were to operate at leveled amount of 80 watts, a 100 watt light bulb would be operating at 1. 25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80), or 1. 25 H-e. For this reason the human equivalent is a reasonable measurement of both human capacity and overall effective energy production. For very short periods of time, a healthy human can produce thousands of watts more than the amount given above (746 W is 1 horsepower). However, the longer-interval values tend to average out. For example, a healthy human can produce about 1 000 W for a few minute intervals, about 300 W for an hour of vigorous exercise, and about 150 W over an 8-hour work shift. Energy flow (or flux) by itself may refer to the rate of transfer of energy... and has the unit of jules per second or watts (in SI unit). For example, bioenergetics is also defined as the study of energy flow through living systems. To clarify... energy flow (in terms of both physical and biological systems), the term human equivalent may be used, for example alongside the SI unit watt, to put the number into a more human perspective and to show the rate of change at which the system or organism itself (formal or informal), may be operating.

text_human: Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the President's Committee on Civil Rights to examine the violence and recommend appropriate federal legislation. Hearing of the incident, Truman turned to NAACP leader Walter Francis White and declared, "My God! I had no idea it was as terrible as that. We've got to do something." In 1947 the committee published its findings, To Secure These Rights. The book was widely read, influential, and considered utopian for the times: "In our land men are equal, but they are free to be different. From these very differences among our people has come the great human and national strength of America." The report discussed and demonstrated racial discrimination in basic freedoms, education, public facilities, personal safety, and employment opportunities. The committee was disturbed by the state of race relations, and included the evacuation of Americans of Japanese descent during the war "made without a trial or any sort of hearing…Fundamental to our whole system of law is the belief that guilt is personal and not a matter of heredity or association." The recommendations were radical, calling for federal policies and laws to end racial discrimination and bring about equality: "We can tolerate no restrictions upon the individual which depend upon irrelevant factors such as his race, his color, his religion, or the social position to which he is born." To Secure These Rights set the liberal legislative agenda for the next generation that eventually would be signed into law by Lyndon B. Johnson.:35–36

In 1947, the committee produced a report titled "To Secure These Rights," which gained wide readership and influence, despite being considered utopian at the time. The report affirmed, "In our land men are equal, but they are free to be different. From these very differences among our people has come the great human and national strength of America." It highlighted racial discrimination across fundamental areas such as education, public facilities, personal safety, and employment opportunities. The recommendations were bold, advocating for federal measures to eliminate racial discrimination and ensure equality: "We can tolerate no restrictions upon the individual which depend upon irrelevant factors such as his race, his color, his religion, or the social position to which he is born." "To Secure These Rights" set the groundwork for liberal legislation that later became law under Lyndon B. Johnson.

text_human: The first railways in Thuringia had been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines had been built, giving Thuringia one of the densest rail networks in the world before World War II with about 2,500 km of track. Between 1950 and 2000 most of the branch lines were abandoned, reducing Thuringia's network by half compared to 1940. On the other hand, most of the main lines were refurbished after 1990, resulting in improved speed of travel. The most important railway lines at present are the Thuringian Railway, connecting Halle and Leipzig via Weimar, Erfurt, Gotha and Eisenach with Frankfurt and Kassel and the Saal Railway from Halle/Leipzig via Jena and Saalfeld to Nuremberg. The former has an hourly ICE/IC service from Dresden to Frankfurt while the latter is served hourly by ICE trains from Berlin to Munich. In 2017, a new high speed line will be opened, diverting long-distance services from these mid-19th century lines. Both ICE routes will then use the Erfurt–Leipzig/Halle high-speed railway, and the Berlin-Munich route will continue via the Nuremberg–Erfurt high-speed railway. Only the segment west of Erfurt of the Frankfurt-Dresden line will continue to be used by ICE trains after 2017, with an increased line speed of 200 km/h (currently 160 km/h). Erfurt's central station, which was completely rebuilt for this purpose in the 2000s (decade), will be the new connection between both ICE lines. The most important regional railway lines in Thuringia are the Neudietendorf–Ritschenhausen railway from Erfurt to Würzburg and Meiningen, the Weimar–Gera railway from Erfurt to Chemnitz, the Sangerhausen–Erfurt railway from Erfurt to Magdeburg, the Gotha–Leinefelde railway from Erfurt to Göttingen, the Halle–Kassel railway from Halle via Nordhausen to Kassel and the Leipzig–Hof railway from Leipzig via Altenburg to Zwickau and Hof. Most regional and local lines have hourly service, but some run only every other hour.
text_ai_base: In the 1840s, the first railways in Thuringia were constructed, with the main line network completed around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines had been added, making Thuringia's rail system one of the densest globally before World War II, totaling about 2,500 km of track. From 1950 to 2000, most branch lines were abandoned, halving the network compared to 1940. However, after 1990, most main lines were renovated, enhancing travel speeds. Currently, the Thuringian Railway and the Saal Railway are key routes. The Thuringian Railway links Halle and Leipzig with Frankfurt and Kassel, passing through Weimar, Erfurt, Gotha, and Eisenach, and offers hourly ICE/IC service from Dresden to Frankfurt. The Saal Railway connects Halle/Leipzig to Nuremberg via Jena and Saalfeld, served by hourly ICE trains from Berlin to Munich. A new high-speed line, opening in 2017, will reroute long-distance services away from these historical lines. Both ICE routes will use the Erfurt–Leipzig/Halle high-speed railway, and the Berlin-Munich connection will proceed via the Nuremberg–Erfurt high-speed railway. After 2017, only the section west of Erfurt on the Frankfurt-Dresden line will continue with ICE trains, featuring increased speeds of 200 km/h, compared to the current 160 km/h. Erfurt’s rebuilt central station, completed in the 2000s, will serve as the new hub for these ICE lines. Significant regional lines include the Neudietendorf–Ritschenhausen railway from Erfurt to Würzburg and Meiningen; the Weimar–Gera railway from Erfurt to Chemnitz; the Sangerhausen–Erfurt railway from Erfurt to Magdeburg; the Gotha–Leinefelde railway from Erfurt to Göttingen; the Halle–Kassel railway from Halle via Nordhausen to Kassel; and the Leipzig–Hof railway from Leipzig through Altenburg to Zwickau and Hof. Most regional and local lines operate hourly, though some offer service only every other hour.

text_human: A few hard rock bands from the 1970s and 1980s managed to sustain highly successful recording careers. Bon Jovi were still able to achieve a commercial hit with "It's My Life" from their double platinum-certified album Crush (2000). and AC/DC released the platinum-certified Stiff Upper Lip (2000) Aerosmith released a number two platinum album, Just Push Play (2001), which saw the band foray further into pop with the Top 10 hit "Jaded", and a blues cover album, Honkin' on Bobo, which reached number five in 2004. Heart achieved their first Top 10 album since the early 90s with Red Velvet Car in 2010, becoming the first female-led hard rock band to earn Top 10 albums spanning five decades. There were reunions and subsequent tours from Van Halen (with Hagar in 2004 and then Roth in 2007), The Who (delayed in 2002 by the death of bassist John Entwistle until 2006) and Black Sabbath (with Osbourne 1997–2006 and Dio 2006–2010) and even a one off performance by Led Zeppelin (2007), renewing the interest in previous eras. Additionally, hard rock supergroups, such as Audioslave (with former members of Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden) and Velvet Revolver (with former members of Guns N' Roses, punk band Wasted Youth and Stone Temple Pilots singer Scott Weiland), emerged and experienced some success. However, these bands were short-lived, ending in 2007 and 2008, respectively. The long awaited Guns N' Roses album Chinese Democracy was finally released in 2008, but only went platinum and failed to come close to the success of the band's late 1980s and early 1990s material. More successfully, AC/DC released the double platinum-certified Black Ice (2008). Bon Jovi continued to enjoy success, branching into country music with "Who Says You Can't Go Home", which reached number one on the Hot Country Singles chart in 2006, and the rock/country album Lost Highway, which reached number one in 2007. In 2009, Bon Jovi released another number one album, The Circle, which marked a return to their hard rock sound.
text_ai_base: Several hard rock bands from the 1970s and 1980s managed to sustain highly successful recording careers into the new millennium. Bon Jovi scored a commercial hit with "It's My Life" from their double platinum-certified album *Crush* (2000). AC/DC also released the platinum-certified album *Stiff Upper Lip* the same year. Aerosmith reached number two on the charts with their platinum album *Just Push Play* (2001), which took a pop direction with the Top 10 hit "Jaded." They followed up with the blues cover album *Honkin' on Bobo*, reaching number five in 2004. Heart achieved a milestone with *Red Velvet Car* in 2010, their first Top 10 album since the early '90s, making them the first female-led hard rock band with Top 10 albums over five decades. Several legendary bands reunited and embarked on tours: Van Halen (with Hagar in 2004 and Roth in 2007), The Who (after a delay from bassist John Entwistle's death in 2002 until 2006), and Black Sabbath (with Osbourne from 1997 to 2006 and Dio from 2006 to 2010). Led Zeppelin also generated buzz with a one-off performance in 2007, rekindling fascination with past eras. New supergroups emerged, such as Audioslave (featuring former members of Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden) and Velvet Revolver (comprising former Guns N' Roses members, punk band Wasted Youth's Duff McKagan, and Stone Temple Pilots singer Scott Weiland). Both bands tasted success but disbanded in 2007 and 2008, respectively. Guns N' Roses finally released their long-awaited album *Chinese Democracy* in 2008, but it only achieved platinum status, not matching their earlier success. In contrast, AC/DC's album *Black Ice* (2008) went double platinum. Bon Jovi smoothly transitioned into country music with "Who Says You Can't Go Home," reaching number one on the Hot Country Singles chart in 2006. Their rock/country album *Lost Highway* hit number one in 2007. They returned to their hard rock roots with another number one album, *The Circle*, in 2009.
text_ai_humanized: A number of 1970s and 1980s hard rock bands continued to have successful recording careers through the new millennium. Bon Jovi's Crush (2000), including the number 1 single "It's My Life", was their most successful release since Keep the Faith. AC/DC's Stiff Upper Lip (2000) was a major-platinum hit. Aerosmith's Just Push Play (2001), including the Top 10 single "Jaded", went platinum and reached number 2, as did their blues cover collection, Honkin' on Bobo (2004). Heart's Jupiters Darling (2004) and Red Velvet Car (2010) gave them Top 100 albums for a group whose success had begun back in 1976, making them the first female fronted hard rock band to have Top 10 albums for five decades. Van Halen (2004, 2007), The Who (2002, though their 2002 tour was postponed owing to the death of bass guitarist John Entwistle until the following year) and Black Sabbath (under both Osbourne, 1997–2006 and Dio, 2006–10) all undertook successful reunion tours. Led Zeppelin also did an acclaimed one-off performance in 2007 in tribute to Atlantic Records founder Ahmet Ertegun, rekindling the hopes of millions for a full-fledged tour. Notable hard rock bands formed in the 2000s include supergroups Audioslave (featuring three former members of Rage Against the Machine and erstwhile Soundgarden singer Chris Cornell) and Velvet Revolver (composed of ex-members of Guns N' Roses, former Guns N' Roses guitarist Duff McKagan's punk band Loaded, Dave Kushner, and former Stone Temple Pilots singer Scott Weiland). Both bands had contemporary hit albums before disbanding in 2007 and 2008, respectively. Guns N' Roses' long-awaited Chinese Democracy was finally released in 2008, but only went platinum, a far cry from the multiplatinum status their albums held from releases earlier in their career. AC/DC's Black Ice (2008) did better, reaching 2× platinum status. In 2006, the career of Bon Jovi turned towards country with their number 1 hit "Who Says You Can't Go Home", reaching number one on the Hot Country Singles chart. Their rock/country album Lost Highway was released in 2007, reaching number 1. In 2009, Bon Jovi returned to their hard rock/crossover roots with The Circle, another number 1 album in November.

text_human: Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over more of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries. They faced a powerful rival in the Dukes of Normandy, who in 1066 under William the Conqueror (duke 1035–1087), conquered England (r. 1066–87) and created a cross-channel empire that lasted, in various forms, throughout the rest of the Middle Ages. Normans also settled in Sicily and southern Italy, when Robert Guiscard (d. 1085) landed there in 1059 and established a duchy that later became the Kingdom of Sicily. Under the Angevin dynasty of Henry II (r. 1154–89) and his son Richard I (r. 1189–99), the kings of England ruled over England and large areas of France,[W] brought to the family by Henry II's marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine (d. 1204), heiress to much of southern France.[X] Richard's younger brother John (r. 1199–1216) lost Normandy and the rest of the northern French possessions in 1204 to the French King Philip II Augustus (r. 1180–1223). This led to dissension among the English nobility, while John's financial exactions to pay for his unsuccessful attempts to regain Normandy led in 1215 to Magna Carta, a charter that confirmed the rights and privileges of free men in England. Under Henry III (r. 1216–72), John's son, further concessions were made to the nobility, and royal power was diminished. The French monarchy continued to make gains against the nobility during the late 12th and 13th centuries, bringing more territories within the kingdom under their personal rule and centralising the royal administration. Under Louis IX (r. 1226–70), royal prestige rose to new heights as Louis served as a mediator for most of Europe.[Y]
text_ai_base: During the Capetian dynasty, France gradually expanded its authority over the nobility, extending control from the Île-de-France to more regions of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries. The Dukes of Normandy posed a significant challenge, especially after William the Conqueror (duke from 1035 to 1087) invaded England in 1066, establishing a cross-channel empire that persisted in various forms throughout the medieval period. Normans also settled in Sicily and southern Italy after Robert Guiscard (died 1085) arrived in 1059 and set up a duchy that eventually evolved into the Kingdom of Sicily. Under the Angevin dynasty led by Henry II (reigned 1154–89) and his son Richard I (reigned 1189–99), the English kings governed England and large portions of France, a domain expanded by Henry II's marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine (died 1204), who was the heiress to much of southern France. In 1204, Richard's younger brother John (reigned 1199–1216) lost Normandy and other northern French regions to French King Philip II Augustus (reigned 1180–1223), sparking unrest among English nobility. John's financial demands, aimed at recapturing Normandy, contributed to the Magna Carta in 1215, a charter affirming the rights of free men in England. Under John's son, Henry III (reigned 1216–72), additional concessions reduced royal power further. Meanwhile, the French monarchy continued to strengthen during the late 12th and 13th centuries, bringing more areas under their direct rule and centralizing administrative control. Under Louis IX (reigned 1226–70), royal prestige reached new heights as he acted as a mediator for much of Europe.
text_ai_humanized: During the period 1000–1300, the Kingdom of France gradually asserted control over the lesser nobles of the kingdom itself and expanded into more territories of modern France. The most successful challengers to royal authority were the dukes of Normandy, who conquered England in 1066 and created a cross-channel empire that lasted, in various forms, throughout the medieval period. Other Norman adventurers established fiefdoms in southern Italy and Sicily, and upon the First Crusade also launched the conquest of regions of the eastern Mediterranean. In England the Anglo-Norman realm was torn by civil war before the accession of Henry II (reigned 1154–89), who inherited many territories, forming the Angevin Empire. His son Richard I (reigned 1189–99) likewise held huge parts of France until he was succeeded by his younger brother John. John lost Normandy and other northern French lands to French king Philip II Augustus (reigned 1180–1223) in 1204, along with conflicts with the English nobility that led to the signing of the Magna Carta, an agreement that established certain rights for the nobility and limited royal powers. Further concessions resulted during the reign of his son Henry III (r. 1216–72). The French monarchy also consolidated control over its more distant territories during the period 1000–1300. Assisted by continued social and economic developments, the monarchy emerged as the most important social force in France, with the royal court serving as the political centre of the kingdom. Mysticism flourished in the north of Europe, with many prominent figures, including Bernard of Clairvaux and Hildegard of Bingen. In the early 13th century, nobles led an antiheretical crusade in southern France, ruling the area as a result. Later in the century, France would gain control of parts of western France as a result of an inheritance, and in the early 14th century, French and English senators in Rome would elect rival popes, thus dividing the papacy between two rival courts. The Papacy of Avignon was thereby established, and the Kingdom of France established an alliance with the Kingdom of Navarre. In 1308, Philip IV of France ordered the arrest of the Knights Templar. Also in this period, France became the leading power in Europe, with Paris as its capital. In the 14th century, the French kingdom experienced the beginning of the Hundred Years' War. The end of this conflict marked the end of the feudal order and the rise of the House of Valois.

text_human: The men's basketball team has over 1,600 wins, one of only 12 schools who have reached that mark, and have appeared in 28 NCAA tournaments. Former player Austin Carr holds the record for most points scored in a single game of the tournament with 61. Although the team has never won the NCAA Tournament, they were named by the Helms Athletic Foundation as national champions twice. The team has orchestrated a number of upsets of number one ranked teams, the most notable of which was ending UCLA's record 88-game winning streak in 1974. The team has beaten an additional eight number-one teams, and those nine wins rank second, to UCLA's 10, all-time in wins against the top team. The team plays in newly renovated Purcell Pavilion (within the Edmund P. Joyce Center), which reopened for the beginning of the 2009–2010 season. The team is coached by Mike Brey, who, as of the 2014–15 season, his fifteenth at Notre Dame, has achieved a 332-165 record. In 2009 they were invited to the NIT, where they advanced to the semifinals but were beaten by Penn State who went on and beat Baylor in the championship. The 2010–11 team concluded its regular season ranked number seven in the country, with a record of 25–5, Brey's fifth straight 20-win season, and a second-place finish in the Big East. During the 2014-15 season, the team went 32-6 and won the ACC conference tournament, later advancing to the Elite 8, where the Fighting Irish lost on a missed buzzer-beater against then undefeated Kentucky. Led by NBA draft picks Jerian Grant and Pat Connaughton, the Fighting Irish beat the eventual national champion Duke Blue Devils twice during the season. The 32 wins were the most by the Fighting Irish team since 1908-09.

In the 2014-15 season, Brey's team went 32-6, won Notre Dame's first conference tournament in program history, and advanced to the Elite 8 where they lost on a missed buzzer beater against then undefeated Kentucky. Future NBA draft picks Jerian Grant and Pat Connaugton had 2 victories over the eventual national champion Duke Blue Devils. The 32 wins was the most ever for the Fighting Irish in the 106 years of the program (1908-09).

text_human: Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe, a continent that had dominated the world for several centuries, was in ruins, and host to the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, who now held the balance of global power. Britain was left essentially bankrupt, with insolvency only averted in 1946 after the negotiation of a $US 4.33 billion loan (US$56 billion in 2012) from the United States, the last instalment of which was repaid in 2006. At the same time, anti-colonial movements were on the rise in the colonies of European nations. The situation was complicated further by the increasing Cold War rivalry of the United States and the Soviet Union. In principle, both nations were opposed to European colonialism. In practice, however, American anti-communism prevailed over anti-imperialism, and therefore the United States supported the continued existence of the British Empire to keep Communist expansion in check. The "wind of change" ultimately meant that the British Empire's days were numbered, and on the whole, Britain adopted a policy of peaceful disengagement from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments were available to transfer power to. This was in contrast to other European powers such as France and Portugal, which waged costly and ultimately unsuccessful wars to keep their empires intact. Between 1945 and 1965, the number of people under British rule outside the UK itself fell from 700 million to five million, three million of whom were in Hong Kong.

Britain itself faced bankruptcy, narrowly avoiding it in 1946 when the United States agreed to a $4.33 billion loan (equivalent to $56 billion in 2012), with the final repayment made in 2006. Meanwhile, anti-colonial movements gained traction in European colonies, complicated further by the Cold War rivalry between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Although both superpowers were nominally against colonialism, American anti-communism overshadowed anti-imperialism, leading the U.S. to support the British Empire's continuation to counter Communist growth. Ultimately, the "wind of change" signaled the British Empire's decline, and Britain generally opted for peaceful withdrawal from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments were established to take over. Between 1945 and 1965, those under British rule outside the UK decreased from 700 million to five million, with three million in Hong Kong.

text_human: The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws. A board-only organization typically has a self-selected board, and a membership whose powers are limited to those delegated to it by the board. A board-only organization's bylaws may even state that the organization does not have any membership, although the organization's literature may refer to its donors or service recipients as "members"; examples of such organizations are Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws. The Model Nonprofit Corporation Act imposes many complexities and requirements on membership decision-making. Accordingly, many organizations, such as Wikimedia, have formed board-only structures. The National Association of Parliamentarians has generated concerns about the implications of this trend for the future of openness, accountability, and understanding of public concerns in nonprofit organizations. Specifically, they note that nonprofit organizations, unlike business corporations, are not subject to market discipline for products and shareholder discipline of their capital; therefore, without membership control of major decisions such as election of the board, there are few inherent safeguards against abuse. A rebuttal to this might be that as nonprofit organizations grow and seek larger donations, the degree of scrutiny increases, including expectations of audited financial statements. A further rebuttal might be that NPOs are constrained, by their choice of legal structure, from financial benefit as far as distribution of profit to its members/directors is concerned. Beware of board-only organizations- review the board members annual income before donating, such as the Clinton Foundation. Board members who decide what percentage of your donations will increase their personal wealth are rampant in abusing this designation of an NPO, and this is why they attempt to avoid audits and use a double bottom line for taxing.
text_ai_base: Nonprofit organizations generally fall into two categories: membership and board-only organizations. In membership organizations, the board is elected by the members, who also hold regular meetings and have the authority to amend the bylaws. In contrast, board-only organizations typically have a self-selected board with members whose powers are limited to what is delegated by the board itself. Some board-only organizations, like Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, might state in their bylaws that they do not have a formal membership, even though they may refer to donors or service recipients as "members" in their materials. Due to the complexities and requirements imposed by the Model Nonprofit Corporation Act regarding membership decision-making, many organizations, such as Wikimedia, have opted for a board-only structure. The National Association of Parliamentarians has raised concerns about the potential impact of this trend on the future transparency, accountability, and responsiveness of nonprofit organizations. Unlike business corporations, nonprofits are not governed by market discipline or shareholder oversight, thus without member involvement in critical decisions like board elections, there are few safeguards against misuse. A counterargument suggests that as nonprofits grow and seek larger donations, they face increased scrutiny, including expectations for audited financial statements. Additionally, nonprofits are legally restricted from distributing profits to members or directors, which serves as another check against financial abuse. However, it’s essential to be cautious with board-only organizations; for instance, before donating to organizations like the Clinton Foundation, review the annual income of the board members. Abuse can occur when board members direct donations to increase their personal wealth, and this can lead them to avoid audits and exploit loopholes for tax benefits.

text_human: Marshall Field & Company originated in 1852. It was the premier department store on the main shopping street in the Midwest, State Street in Chicago. Upscale shoppers came by train from throughout the region, patronizing nearby hotels. It grew to become a major chain before converting to the Macy's nameplate on 9 September 2006. Marshall Field's Served as a model for other departments stores in that it had exceptional customer service. Field's also brought with it the now famous Frango mints brand that became so closely identified with Marshall Field's and Chicago from the now defunct Frederick & Nelson Department store. Marshall Field's also had the firsts, among many innovations by Marshall Field's. Field's had the first European buying office, which was located in Manchester, England, and the first bridal registry. The company was the first to introduce the concept of the personal shopper, and that service was provided without charge in every Field's store, until the chain's last days under the Marshall Field's name. It was the first store to offer revolving credit and the first department store to use escalators. Marshall Field's book department in the State Street store was legendary; it pioneered the concept of the "book signing." Moreover, every year at Christmas, Marshall Field's downtown store windows were filled with animated displays as part of the downtown shopping district display; the "theme" window displays became famous for their ingenuity and beauty, and visiting the Marshall Field's windows at Christmas became a tradition for Chicagoans and visitors alike, as popular a local practice as visiting the Walnut Room with its equally famous Christmas tree or meeting "under the clock" on State Street.
text_ai_base: Marshall Field & Company began in 1852, quickly establishing itself as the leading department store on State Street, Chicago's main shopping avenue in the Midwest. Upscale shoppers traveled by train from across the region and often stayed at nearby hotels. Before rebranding as Macy's on September 9, 2006, Marshall Field's expanded into a major chain but was renowned for its exceptional customer service, setting the standard for other department stores. The iconic Frango mints, originally from the now-defunct Frederick & Nelson department store, became synonymous with Marshall Field's and Chicago. Throughout its history, Marshall Field’s achieved numerous firsts in retail innovation. It opened the first European buying office in Manchester, England, and pioneered the concept of the bridal registry. Field's introduced personal shoppers, a complimentary service available at every store until the chain's final days under its original name. Marshall Field's also led the way by being the first to offer revolving credit and the first to use escalators in department stores. Its book department in the State Street location was legendary, introducing the "book signing" concept. Every Christmas, the store's downtown windows featured animated displays, gaining fame for their creativity and beauty. Visiting these window displays became a cherished holiday tradition for Chicagoans and tourists, as popular as dining by the Walnut Room's famous Christmas tree or meeting "under the clock" on State Street.

text_human: In 2013, however, a study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached different conclusions, again corroborating the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. Testing was performed on the full 16,600 DNA units composing mitochondrial DNA (the 2006 Behar study had only tested 1,000 units) in all their subjects, and the study found that the four main female Ashkenazi founders had descent lines that were established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years in the past while most of the remaining minor founders also have a deep European ancestry. The study states that the great majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages were not brought from the Near East (i.e., they were non-Israelite), nor were they recruited in the Caucasus (i.e., they were non-Khazar), but instead they were assimilated within Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins. Richards summarized the findings on the female line as such: "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom that flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry comes from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent from the Near East, while the origin of the remainder is undetermined. According to the study these findings "point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities."
text_ai_base: In 2013, a study led by Martin B. Richards from the University of Huddersfield in England investigated Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA and reached conclusions supporting the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. The research analyzed the complete 16,600 DNA units of mitochondrial DNA—unlike the 2006 Behar study, which examined only 1,000 units. It revealed that the four primary female Ashkenazi founders had ancestral lines established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years ago. Most of the other minor founders also shared a deep European heritage. The study suggested that the vast majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages did not originate from the Near East (meaning they were non-Israelite) or the Caucasus (meaning they were non-Khazar). Instead, they were assimilated within Europe, mainly from Italian and Old French backgrounds. Richards summarized the findings, noting that none of the mtDNA was sourced from the North Caucasus, a region between Europe and Asia. He stated that these studies, including his own, should dispel the persistent but doubtful theory that most Ashkenazi Jews trace their roots to the Khazar Kingdom, which existed in the ninth century between the Byzantine and Persian Empires. The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal lineage is from European women, only 8 percent from the Near East, and the remainder is unknown. These findings suggest a significant role for the conversion of women in forming Ashkenazi communities.
text_ai_humanized: Studies that have primarily focused on Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA found results favoring the pre-2006 theory of origins (see above), namely that Ashkenazi were descended on the direct maternal line from non-Israelite women. A 2013 study conducted by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached the conclusion that Ashkenazi maternal line was not of Near Eastern origin (i.e., not Israelite) nor was it of the North Caucasus (i.e., not Khazar) . Instead, the paper argues for acquisition of the line in Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins. The study compared a total of complete 16,600 DNA units of mitochondrial DNA (compared to 1,000 tested in the 2006 Behar study) and concluded that the four major female Ashkenazi founders have ancestry that is both European and predates the founding of Ashkenazi Jews. Specifically, the four major female Ashkenazi founders had ancestry that had been established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years ago. The Ashkenazi Jewish population would therefore be one of the modern descendants of the earliest colonization of Europe by anatomically modern humans. "A substantial proportion of maternal ancestry of modern Ashkenazi Jews arises in prehistoric Europe." Furthermore, the study found that a large part of the remaining minor founders also have a deep European ancestry: As the founding of Ashkenazi Jewry in the first millennium CE involved well over a thousand women, it would be need be a significant number of women who converted to Judaism in Europe (a similar figure of 1,000 men was found in a study of Y chromosome). Whereas the 2006 Behar study sampled only the "control region" of the mitochondrial DNA which is supported by only 1,000 DNAunits, the 2013 study by Richards et al. samples the complete mitochondrial DNA supported by 16,600 units, giving a more comprehensive sampling. In simple terms, Richards argues that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry comes from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent originated in the Near East with the rest unknown. "None of the mtDNA was of North Caucasus (or Khazar) origin. These results point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities," Richards said. "They seem to have occurred first along the Mediterranean, with the southward movement of peoples, and then in west and central Europe as the Ashkenazi settlement belt shifted northwards. This, of course, does not mean that the paternal line is not of Israelite origin, for which see above. Richards was quoted as saying: This suggests that, even though Jewish men may indeed have migrated into Europe from Palestine around 2,000 years ago, they seem to have married European women... It seems that, at least on the maternal side, the story of the Jewish diaspora is not one of promiscuous matings, but of Jewish men who travelled to new places and settled down to lives with their new, local wives whose lineages soon became dominant. Which is to say that I hope our study will have a far-reaching cultural impact even beyond the genetic arena. Our study... should finally put to rest pseudo-scientific claims that Ashkenazi Jews are descended from the mysterious Khazars. The medieval Khazar Khaganate was a state that existed north of Georgia between the Black Sea and Caspian Sea, 9 to 11 centuries ago.

text_human: By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. For example, the cornerstone of the Maratha rule in Malwa rested on the 60 or so local tax collectors who advanced the Maratha ruler Peshwa a portion of their district revenues at interest. By 1760, the domain of the Marathas stretched across practically the entire subcontinent. The north-western expansion of the Marathas was stopped after the Third Battle of Panipat (1761). However, the Maratha authority in the north was re-established within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I. The defeat of Marathas by British in third Anglo-Maratha Wars brought end to the empire by 1820. The last peshwa, Baji Rao II, was defeated by the British in the Third Anglo-Maratha War. With the defeat of the Marathas, no native power represented any significant threat for the British afterwards.
text_ai_base: By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had evolved into the Maratha Empire under the leadership of the Peshwas, or prime ministers. In 1737, the Marathas achieved a significant victory by defeating a Mughal army in Delhi during the Battle of Delhi. Their military campaigns continued against the Mughals, the Nizam, the Nawab of Bengal, and the Durrani Empire, further expanding their territory. Historian Gordon described how the Marathas systematically seized control of new regions. Initially, they conducted annual raids, followed by demanding ransoms from villages and towns, while the weakening Mughal Empire maintained nominal control—all culminating in the eventual takeover of these areas. Gordon illustrated this with the example of the Malwa region. The Marathas developed a highly efficient system of public administration, noted for its meticulous attention to detail, and successfully increased revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids to levels comparable to those under Mughal rule. Notably, the foundation of their control in Malwa relied on approximately 60 local tax collectors who paid a portion of their district revenues as a loan to the Maratha ruler, the Peshwa. By 1760, the Maratha domain spanned almost the entire subcontinent. However, their northwestern expansion was halted after their defeat in the Third Battle of Panipat in 1761. Nonetheless, Maratha authority in northern India was restored within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I. The empire's decline was marked by its defeat in the Third Anglo-Maratha War by the British, culminating in 1820. The last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, was overthrown by the British, after which no native power posed a significant threat to British dominance in the region.
text_ai_humanized: By the early 18th century the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). After the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in Delhi in 1737 in the Battle of Delhi, they continued their expansion into Mughal, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal, and Durrani territories.[8] Gordon explained how the Marathas expanded their territory: "Seizing the opportunity presented by the ever-weakening state of Mughal power, the Marathas in the 1720s and 1730s intervened directly in northern politics to fill the power vacuum and by 1741 had driven the Sultans, now reduced to the Deccan, to accept their bids of suzerainty over the subcontinent. The Marathas even discussed abolishing the Mughal throne and placing Vishnu of the idol at Pandharpur on it. ... An annual system of raids, of tribute terms enforced pillage, of ransom pervaded villages and towns in the path of the Maratha armies, even as the time-honoured Mughal Empire continued to exist".[9] As an example he offers, "After 1737 the effective control of Malwa passed to the Pune government and the Peshwa assigned collectoriates to knights. The system of public administration to implement Chauth, the headquarters at Pune and regional agents intimately and effectively turned out, according to the evidence in the sale records ... districts that recovered from years of raids actually yielded more revenue then under the Mughals. The Marathas, as an example shows for Malwa, developed a system of public administration, so sloid and so robust that it is difficult to find faults with it. It relied on increasing degree of ingenious detail; and, the most important element factors missed by poor biographical approach, was that, in Malwa at least, the initial building block was sixty tax collectors and interested parties, all local, willing to pay the Peshwas-a loan — a share of their revenues in their districts".[9]:63–74 By 1760, the domain of the Marathas stretched across almost the entire subcontinent. The empire at its was lead by a capable administrators such as Peshwa Baji Rao I. Shortcomings of his successor Peshwa Balaji Baji Rao and the defeat of Marathas in third battle of Panipat in 1761, arrested this expansion in north-west. The Maratha authority in north India was re-established within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I. In the south, Hyderabad state was lost to the Nizam, a former Mughal governor, and Mysore was lost to Hyder Ali. The empire got permanently weakened following the assassination of Peshwa Narayan Rao. The empire is credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India[10][11] and was at the forefront of consolidating Hindu power in India.[8] After the Anglo-Maratha wars (1775-1819), the British East India Company emerged as victorious in most of India.[12] The last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, was defeated by the British. None of the other Indian kings and rulers who still remained independent, were able to pose a serious challenge to the British until the Indian rebellion of 1857.[13]

text_human: Kurita passed through San Bernardino Strait at 03:00 on 25 October and headed along the coast of Samar. The only thing standing in his path were three groups (Taffy 1, 2 and 3) of the Seventh Fleet, commanded by Admiral Thomas Kinkaid. Each group had six escort carriers, with a total of more than 500 planes, and seven or eight destroyers or destroyer escorts (DE). Kinkaid still believed that Lee's force was guarding the north, so the Japanese had the element of surprise when they attacked Taffy 3 at 06:45. Kurita mistook the Taffy carriers for large fleet carriers and thought he had the whole Third Fleet in his sights. Since escort carriers stood little chance against a battleship, Adm. Clifton Sprague directed the carriers of Taffy 3 to turn and flee eastward, hoping that bad visibility would reduce the accuracy of Japanese gunfire, and used his destroyers to divert the Japanese battleships. The destroyers made harassing torpedo attacks against the Japanese. For ten minutes Yamato was caught up in evasive action. Two U.S. destroyers and a DE were sunk, but they had bought enough time for the Taffy groups to launch planes. Taffy 3 turned and fled south, with shells scoring hits on some of its carriers and sinking one of them. The superior speed of the Japanese force allowed it to draw closer and fire on the other two Taffy groups. However, at 09:20 Kurita suddenly turned and retreated north. Signals had disabused him of the notion that he was attacking the Third Fleet, and the longer Kurita continued to engage, the greater the risk of major air strikes. Destroyer attacks had broken the Japanese formations, shattering tactical control. Three of Kurita's heavy cruisers had been sunk and another was too damaged to continue the fight. The Japanese retreated through the San Bernardino Strait, under continuous air attack. The Battle of Leyte Gulf was over; and a large part of the Japanese surface fleet destroyed.
text_ai_base: Kurita moved through the San Bernardino Strait at 03:00 on October 25 and advanced along the coast of Samar. Standing in his way were three groups—Taffy 1, 2, and 3—of the Seventh Fleet, led by Admiral Thomas Kinkaid. Each group consisted of six escort carriers, totaling over 500 aircraft, alongside seven or eight destroyers or destroyer escorts. Kinkaid assumed that Lee’s force was protecting the northern area, which allowed the Japanese to attack Taffy 3 by surprise at 06:45. Kurita mistakenly identified the Taffy carriers as large fleet carriers and believed he was confronting the entire Third Fleet. Aware that escort carriers were vulnerable against battleships, Admiral Clifton Sprague ordered Taffy 3's carriers to flee eastward, hoping poor visibility would hinder Japanese gunners, while deploying destroyers to distract the enemy battleships. The destroyers launched aggressive torpedo attacks on the Japanese, causing the Yamato to execute evasive maneuvers for ten minutes. Although two U.S. destroyers and a destroyer escort were sunk, they achieved enough disruption to allow the Taffy groups to launch their planes. Taffy 3 retreated south, enduring hits on some of its carriers and losing one. The quicker Japanese forces gained ground, attacking the other Taffy groups, but at 09:20, Kurita unexpectedly withdrew northward. He realized he wasn't facing the Third Fleet and prolonged engagement risked significant air strikes. Destroyer assaults had scattered the Japanese formations, hampering their tactical control. Three of Kurita’s heavy cruisers were sunk, and another was too damaged to keep fighting. The Japanese retreated through San Bernardino Strait under continuous aerial assault. The Battle of Leyte Gulf concluded with a significant portion of the Japanese surface fleet destroyed.

Admiral Clifton Sprague had the carriers of Taffy 3 make for nasty weather to the east to foul the aim of the Japanese gunners as he sent his destroyers to divert the advance of the Japanese battleships. The destroyers boldly charged the Japanese and managed to put the Yamato into evasive maneuvers for ten minutes. Two of the destroyers and a destroyer escort were sunk, but they caused enough disruption to allow the Taffies to get their aircraft in. He knew at this point he was not facing the Third Fleet, and staying in position was likely to result in a lot of aerial bombing. The destroyer attacks had disorganized his units and they had lost tactical cohesion. He lost three heavy cruisers in the engagement, one of which continued to float damaged in the area. The Japanese withdrew back through San Bernardino Strait while being harried by air attack. Leyte Gulf was now over and a large portion of the Japanese surface fleet had been destroyed.

text_human: The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, Cambridgeshire at −2.75 m (−9.02 ft). The Scottish Highlands in the northern part of Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis being the highest point on the islands at 1,343 m (4,406 ft). Other mountainous areas include Wales and parts of Ireland, however only seven peaks in these areas reach above 1,000 m (3,281 ft). Lakes on the islands are generally not large, although Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland is an exception, covering 150 square miles (390 km2).[citation needed] The largest freshwater body in Great Britain (by area) is Loch Lomond at 27.5 square miles (71 km2), and Loch Ness, by volume whilst Loch Morar is the deepest freshwater body in the British Isles, with a maximum depth of 310 m (1,017 ft). There are a number of major rivers within the British Isles. The longest is the Shannon in Ireland at 224 mi (360 km).[citation needed] The river Severn at 220 mi (354 km)[citation needed] is the longest in Great Britain. The isles have a temperate marine climate. The North Atlantic Drift ("Gulf Stream") which flows from the Gulf of Mexico brings with it significant moisture and raises temperatures 11 °C (20 °F) above the global average for the islands' latitudes. Winters are cool and wet, with summers mild and also wet. Most Atlantic depressions pass to the north of the islands, combined with the general westerly circulation and interactions with the landmass, this imposes an east-west variation in climate.
text_ai_base: The islands have relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain being particularly flat. The lowest point is in Holme, Cambridgeshire, at −2.75 meters (−9.02 feet). In contrast, the Scottish Highlands in northern Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis as the highest peak at 1,343 meters (4,406 feet). Other mountainous regions include Wales and parts of Ireland, though only seven peaks exceed 1,000 meters (3,281 feet) there. Lakes on these islands are generally small, except for Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland, which covers 150 square miles (390 km²). The largest freshwater body in Great Britain by area is Loch Lomond, spanning 27.5 square miles (71 km²), while Loch Ness has the largest volume, and Loch Morar is the deepest, reaching 310 meters (1,017 feet). Major rivers include the Shannon in Ireland, the longest at 224 miles (360 km), and the River Severn in Great Britain at 220 miles (354 km). The isles enjoy a temperate marine climate, influenced by the North Atlantic Drift, also known as the Gulf Stream. This current from the Gulf of Mexico brings significant moisture and raises temperatures by 11 °C (20 °F) above the global average for these latitudes. Winters are cool and wet, while summers are mild and also wet. Most Atlantic depressions pass north of the islands, and with the general westerly winds and land interactions, this creates an east-west climate variation.
text_ai_humanized: The islands are at their greatest heights near the west coast: central and southern Ireland and central and southern Great Britain are low-lying, with the lowest point on the islands being in the Fens of Cambridgeshire, at −2.75 meters (−9.02 ft). The Scottish Highlands in the north of Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis being the highest point on the British Isles at 1,343 meters (4,406 ft).[11] Other mountainous areas include Wales and parts of Ireland,[12] although only seven peaks in these areas reach above 1,000 meters (3,281 ft). Lakes on the British Isles are generally not large. The largest is Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland, at 150 square miles (390 km2). It also ranks as the 15th largest lake within the European Union.[13] The largest freshwater body in Great Britain by area is Loch Lomond at 27.5 sq mi (71 km2),[14] and by volume is Loch Ness, although several other Scottish lakes Lochs Awe, Maree, Morar, Shiel, Ness and Lomond) exceed all others in the isles by depth. Loch Morar's floor is the lowest point in the British Isles, having a maximum depth of 310 meters (1,017 ft).[15] There are a number of major rivers within the British Isles. The longest is the River Shannon in Ireland at 224 miles (360 km). The longest in Great Britain is the River Severn[16] at 220 miles (354 km). The isles are in a maritime temperate climate zone. Due to the North Atlantic Drift (an offshoot of the Gulf Stream) they are 5C warmer in winter than the global average for their latitudes, which lie between 49° and 61° N (Northern Ireland lies wholly within the 54th parallel north). Winters are cool and wet, while summers are warm and also wet. Because most Atlantic depressions pass to the north of the islands, combined with the general westerly circulation and the effect of the large landmass of Eurasia to the east, there is a distinct tendency for the west of the islands to be wetter and milder than the east, which is reflected in the differences between weather in Ireland and weather in Great Britain.

text_human: The average annual rainfall ranges from very low in the northern and southern fringes of the desert to nearly non-existent over the central and the eastern part. The thin northern fringe of the desert receives more winter cloudiness and rainfall due to the arrival of low pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea along the polar front, although very attenuated by the rain shadow effects of the mountains and the annual average rainfall ranges from 100 mm (3,93 in) to 250 mm (9,84 in). For example, Biskra, Algeria and Ouarzazate, Morocco are found in this zone. The southern fringe of the desert along the border with the Sahel receives summer cloudiness and rainfall due to the arrival of the Intertropical Convergence Zone from the south and the annual average rainfall ranges from 100 mm (3,93 in) to 250 mm (9,84 in). For example, Timbuktu, Mali and Agadez, Niger are found in this zone. The vast central hyper-arid core of the desert is virtually never affected by northerly or southerly atmospheric disturbances and permanently remains under the influence of the strongest anticyclonic weather regime and the annual average rainfall can drop to less than 1 mm (0.04 in). In fact, most of the Sahara receives less than 20 mm (0.79 in). Of the 9,000,000 km2 of desert land in the Sahara, an area of about 2,800,000 km2 (about 31% of the total area) receives an annual average rainfall amount of 10 mm (0.39 in) or less, while some 1,500,000 km2 (about 17% of the total area) receive an average of 5 mm or less. The annual average rainfall is virtually zero over a wide area of some 1,000,000 km2 in the eastern Sahara comprising deserts of Libya, Egypt and Sudan (Tazirbu, Kufra, Dakhla, Kharga, Farafra, Siwa, Asyut, Sohag, Luxor, Aswan, Abu Simbel, Wadi Halfa) where the long-term mean approximates 0.5 mm per year. The rainfall is very unreliable and erratic in the Sahara as it may vary considerably year by year. In full contrast to the negligible annual rainfall amounts, the annual rates of potential evaporation are extraordinarily high, roughly ranging from 2,500 mm/year to more than 6,000 mm/year in the whole desert. Nowhere else on Earth has air been found as dry and evaporative as in the Sahara region. With such an evaporative power, the Sahara can only be desiccated and dried out further more and the moisture deficit is tremendous.
text_ai_base: The average annual rainfall in the Sahara varies significantly, being very low on the desert's northern and southern edges and nearly nonexistent in its central and eastern regions. The northern fringe experiences more winter cloudiness and rainfall due to low-pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea along the polar front. Despite the rain shadow effects from surrounding mountains, this area receives between 100 mm (3.93 in) and 250 mm (9.84 in) annually, with cities like Biskra, Algeria, and Ouarzazate, Morocco situated here. The southern edge, near the Sahel, receives summer rainfall from the Intertropical Convergence Zone, with similar annual averages ranging from 100 mm to 250 mm. Cities like Timbuktu, Mali, and Agadez, Niger fall within this zone. In stark contrast, the central hyper-arid core of the desert remains unaffected by atmospheric disturbances from the north or south, staying under a persistent anticyclonic weather regime with less than 1 mm (0.04 in) of rainfall annually. Most of the Sahara receives under 20 mm (0.79 in) yearly. Out of the desert's 9,000,000 km², roughly 2,800,000 km² (31% of the total area) receive 10 mm (0.39 in) or less, and about 1,500,000 km² (17%) receive 5 mm or less. The eastern Sahara, encompassing parts of Libya, Egypt, and Sudan (including areas such as Tazirbu, Kufra, Dakhla, Kharga, Farafra, Siwa, Asyut, Sohag, Luxor, Aswan, Abu Simbel, and Wadi Halfa), sees virtually no rainfall with long-term averages around 0.5 mm annually. Rainfall in the Sahara is extremely unpredictable and can vary widely from year to year. In contrast to the minimal rainfall, the annual potential evaporation rates are extraordinarily high, ranging from 2,500 mm to over 6,000 mm. Nowhere else on Earth is the air as dry and evaporative as in the Sahara, leading to further desiccation and a substantial moisture deficit.
text_ai_humanized: Annual precipitation ranges from very low in the north of the Sahara to virtually non-existent in the central and the eastern parts of the desert.[13][17][18][19] The northernmost and southernmost parts of the desert have more of a semi-arid climate, and more rain falls there than in the central and eastern parts. The northern limit also receives winter rain when low-pressure systems traverse the Mediterranean Sea and are drawn south. The southern and central parts of the desert, meanwhile, are subject to disturbances, which bring rain during the ITCZ's (Intertropical Convergence Zone) northward migration that occurs from March to May, moving into the Sahara. Vegetation in the Sahara is spotty and occurs only in the northern and southern reaches and near the oases, apart from the Nile Valley. In the central, hyper-arid part of the Sahara, the situation is very different. Portions of the Sahara in Libya, Egypt and Sudan are the driest, with some regions going decades without seeing any rain at all. For example, the weather station at Kufra in Libya reported no rainfall from 1999 to 2001. Most of the Sahara receives less than 20 mm (0.79 in). However, there is a wide range in precipitation amounts across the desert since its northernmost and southernmost boundaries are semiarid with annual rainfall values between 100 mm (3.93 in) to 250 mm (9.84 in).[20] Ain Sefra, Algeria, receives 178 mm (7.01 in),[21] and Timbuktu, Mali, is in the 116 mm (4.57 in) range.[22] In Egypt, a 6,000-year-old sandstone sculpture, known as the "Cloud Shepherd", suggests that there was some rain in the Sahara 6,000 years ago.[23] The numbers are generally lower for the eastern Sahara; most of Egypt's portion of the desert receives between 0 mm (0.00 in) and 5 mm (0.20 in) of annual rainfall.[24] Some of the higher precipitation rates in the desert derive from the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), which brings moisture to the northwestern Sahara. Some proposed[…] modifications include building artificial lakes in the Sahara[23] and diverting water from the Nile into canals to irrigate the surrounding terrain.[23]

text_human: After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, seized the Macedonian throne (294) and conquered Thessaly and most of central Greece (293-291). He was defeated in 288 BC when Lysimachus of Thrace and Pyrrhus of Epirus invaded Macedon on two fronts, and quickly carved up the kingdom for themselves. Demetrius fled to central Greece with his mercenaries and began to build support there and in the northern Peloponnese. He once again laid siege to Athens after they turned on him, but then struck a treaty with the Athenians and Ptolemy, which allowed him to cross over to Asia minor and wage war on Lysimachus' holdings in Ionia, leaving his son Antigonus Gonatas in Greece. After initial successes, he was forced to surrender to Seleucus in 285 and later died in captivity. Lysimachus, who had seized Macedon and Thessaly for himself, was forced into war when Seleucus invaded his territories in Asia minor and was defeated and killed in 281 BCE at the Battle of Corupedium, near Sardis. Seleucus then attempted to conquer Lysimachus' European territories in Thrace and Macedon, but he was assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus ("the thunderbolt"), who had taken refuge at the Seleucid court and then had himself acclaimed as king of Macedon. Ptolemy was killed when Macedon was invaded by Gauls in 279, his head stuck on a spear and the country fell into anarchy. Antigonus II Gonatas invaded Thrace in the summer of 277 and defeated a large force of 18,000 Gauls. He was quickly hailed as king of Macedon and went on to rule for 35 years.
text_ai_base: Following Cassander's death in 298 BCE, Demetrius, backed by a strong army and fleet, invaded Macedon. He claimed the Macedonian throne in 294 BCE and proceeded to conquer Thessaly and most of central Greece between 293 and 291 BCE. However, in 288 BCE, Lysimachus of Thrace and Pyrrhus of Epirus attacked Macedon from two fronts, swiftly dividing the kingdom. Demetrius escaped to central Greece with his mercenaries, seeking support there and in the northern Peloponnese. Having initially laid siege to Athens after they opposed him, he negotiated a treaty with the Athenians and Ptolemy, which enabled him to move to Asia Minor and challenge Lysimachus’ control in Ionia, leaving his son Antigonus Gonatas to manage affairs in Greece. Despite some early victories, Demetrius was captured by Seleucus in 285 BCE and died in captivity. Lysimachus, who had taken control of Macedon and Thessaly, was drawn into conflict with Seleucus after his territories in Asia Minor were invaded. He was defeated and killed in 281 BCE at the Battle of Corupedium, near Sardis. Seleucus then sought to conquer Lysimachus' European lands in Thrace and Macedon but was assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus ("the thunderbolt"), who had found asylum at the Seleucid court and declared himself king of Macedon. Ptolemy was slain during a Gaul invasion in 279 BCE, leading to chaos as his head was mounted on a spear. In response, Antigonus II Gonatas advanced into Thrace in the summer of 277 BCE, vanquishing a formidable force of 18,000 Gauls. He was promptly proclaimed king of Macedon and held the throne for 35 years.
text_ai_humanized: In 298 BCE, after the death of Cassander, Demetrius invaded Macedon and captured the throne. With a large army and powerful navy, he gradually conquered most of Greece. Demetrius was eventually overthrown as King of Macedon by a coalition of neighbouring states, including Epirus, Pergamum, and Thrace, in 288 BCE. Lysimachus ruled Macedon until 281 BCE, when he was killed after attacking the kingdom of Seleucus; Seleucus briefly held Macedon, but was in turn killed by Ptolemy Ceraunos. In 277 BCE Ptolemy defeated a Gaulish invasion of Macedon, and assumed the throne. However he was himself murdered two years later by the Gauls. The Macedonian throne then passed to Antigonus II, grandson of Antigonus I.
