Demetrius was eventually overthrown as King of Macedon by a coalition of neighbouring states, including Epirus, Pergamum, and Thrace, in 288 BCE. Lysimachus ruled Macedon until 281 BCE, when he was killed after attacking the kingdom of Seleucus; Seleucus briefly held Macedon, but was in turn killed by Ptolemy Ceraunos. In 277 BCE Ptolemy defeated a Gaulish invasion of Macedon, and assumed the throne. However he was himself murdered two years later by the Gauls. The Macedonian throne then passed to Antigonus II, grandson of Antigonus I.

text_human: Constantius, ordered Liberius into exile in 356 giving him, then, three days to comply. He was ordered into banishment to Beroea, in Thrace; Beroea (Thrace). He sent expensive presents, too, if he were to accept the Arian position but were refused. He sent him, indeed, five hundred pieces of gold "to bear his charges" but Liberius refused them, saying, he might bestow them on his flatters; as he did also a like present from the empress, bidding the messenger learn to believe in Christ, and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the presents in The Church, but Liberius threw them out. Constantius hereupon sent for him under a strict guard to Milan, where, in a conference recorded by Theodoret, he boldly told Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted at Sardica, and his enemies proved calumniators (see: "calumny") and impostors, and that it was unjust to condemn a person who could not be legally convicted of any crime. The emperor was reduced to silence on every article, but being the more out of patience, ordered him into banishment. Liberius went into exile. Constantius, after two years went to Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The ladies joined in a petition to him that he would restore Liberius. He assented, upon condition that he should comply with the bishops, then, at court. He subscribed the condemnation of Athanasius, and a confession or creed which had been framed by the Arians at Sirmium. And he no sooner had recovered his see that he declared himself for the Creed of Niceae, as Theodoret testifies. (Theodoret, Hist. lib. ii. c. 17.). The Emperor knew what he wanted people to believe. So did the bishops at his court. Athanasius stuck by the orthodox creed. Constantius was an avowed Arian, became sole ruler in 350, at the death of his brother, Constans.
text_ai_base: In 356, Constantius ordered Liberius into exile, giving him just three days to comply. Liberius was banished to Beroea in Thrace. Constantius attempted to persuade him to accept the Arian position with expensive gifts, including five hundred pieces of gold "to cover his expenses," but Liberius refused, suggesting they be given to flatterers instead. He similarly rejected a gift from the empress, advising the messenger to follow Christ and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the gifts in the Church, but Liberius threw them out. As a result, Constantius had him brought to Milan under strict guard. In a conference documented by Theodoret, Liberius boldly informed Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted in Sardica, and that his accusers were proven false. He argued it was unjust to condemn someone not legally convicted of a crime. Constantius, unable to refute him, ordered his banishment again. Liberius went into exile. Two years later, Constantius visited Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The women of Rome petitioned him to restore Liberius, and Constantius consented on the condition that Liberius comply with the bishops present at court. Liberius subscribed to the condemnation of Athanasius and accepted a creed composed by the Arians at Sirmium. Upon regaining his position, he reaffirmed the Nicene Creed, as noted by Theodoret (Hist. lib. ii. c. 17). Both the Emperor and the court bishops were clear on their beliefs, while Athanasius remained steadfast to the orthodox creed. Constantius, an avowed Arian, had become the sole ruler in 350 after his brother Constans's death.
text_ai_humanized: In 356 Constantius banished Liberius, allowing him only three days to depart. The bishop was exiled to Beroea, in Thrace. Constantius tried to bribe Liberius into acquiescence with the Arian position. At first he sent him a large sum of money, five hundred pieces of gold “to defray his expenses.” The gift was refused: “Go back and tell him who sent you,” said Liberius, “to give this gold to his flatterers, for I have no need of it.” He subsequently refused a present which the empress sent him, telling Bishop Eusebius of Vercellae (Vercelli), and the messenger herself, to go and persuade Constantius “to turn to the Lord … and not to persecute the Church of God.” Constantius’s messengers tried to leave their gifts in the Church, hoping Liberius would change his mind, but Liberius “again took the pieces of gold and threw them down in the Church.” Liberius was brought to Milan, closely guarded on the longer journey. In the conference between Constantius and Liberius, recorded by Theodoret, “the zealous bishop openly told him ‘Though an Emperour, thou art but a man. Fear the Judge of all. In the day of His judgment thou too shalt stand naked before all men to render an account of all thou has done in this life. … Athanasius has been acquitted in the Court of Sardica, and his opponents have been convicted of calumny. … We decline to condemn a man whom they have not convicted of crime. … It is unjust that he who is devoured up should by his denounced, while foxes are prowling unhurt. The dispute is not concerning the Faith, but only concerning a man, to whom they assign with empty noise the honour due to him who was crucified. …’ ” Failing in argument against Liberius, Constantius reiterated his intent: “I will chastise thee, unless thou doest what the majority of bishops have decreed. Now listen, and have done with strife. I am not offending God, when I take part with the many.” Confuting the emperor, Constantius had him banished. “If the alternative be the sword or departure into exile, I shall prefer exile,” said Liberius, and so he was sent into exile. Two years later Constantius came to Rome, celebrating his vicennalia. The bishops of Rome were being changed every week, but Liberius was appointed again. The Roman women spoke with Constantius, ‘as if the Emperor said, ‘I will restore Liberius, if he will consent to comply with what the bishops came hither have decreed,’ and so unable otherwise to recall him, Liberius consented and entered Rome under the banners of Arianism, signing his agreement to the condemnation of Athanasius, and also a Creed which had been composed by the Arians at Sirmium. As soon as he was resettled he renounced the Arian position and returned to his predecessor’s Nicene Creed, which Theodoret relays as proof that, “On their own confession, both the Emperor and the writer of the letter are attached to a blasphemous creed, for that is indeed what their letter contains;” whereas Athanasius’s position was that, “If he had heard that we held the same sentiments as his Macedonia, or the Sirmian, or the disreputable Valens and Ursacius, there would be ground for suspicion, lest being deceived and listened to, we might become of the same mind as they. Now we write to assure you, that our sentiments are quit of suspicion, and that we strictly hold the creed put forth at Nicaea.” He promised to reestablish Liberius if Liberius would cooperate with the bishops at the court. Constantius was a convinced Arian, and after the death of his brother Constans in 350, became the sole ruler of the Roman Empire.

text_human: One hundred years after the fall of Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon described in his work Observations in 1553 that pissasphalto, a mixture of pitch and bitumen, was used in Dubrovnik for tarring of ships from where it was exported to a market place in Venice where it could be bought by anyone. An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France. A pamphlet dated 1621, by "a certain Monsieur d'Eyrinys, states that he had discovered the existence (of asphaltum) in large quantities in the vicinity of Neufchatel", and that he proposed to use it in a variety of ways – "principally in the construction of air-proof granaries, and in protecting, by means of the arches, the water-courses in the city of Paris from the intrusion of dirt and filth", which at that time made the water unusable. "He expatiates also on the excellence of this material for forming level and durable terraces" in palaces, "the notion of forming such terraces in the streets not one likely to cross the brain of a Parisian of that generation". But it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830. Then, in the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns, and in England, some use of it had been made of it for similar purposes". Its rise in Europe was "a sudden phenomenon", after natural deposits were found "in France at Osbann (BasRhin), the Parc (l'Ain) and the Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome)", although it could also be made artificially. One of the earliest uses in France was the laying of about 24,000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835.
text_ai_base: A century after Constantinople fell in 1453, Pierre Belon documented in his 1553 work *Observations* the use of pissasphalto—a blend of pitch and bitumen—in Dubrovnik for ship tarring. This mixture was exported to Venice, where it was available for purchase. An 1838 edition of *Mechanics Magazine* notes that asphalt was used early on in France. A pamphlet from 1621 by Monsieur d'Eyrinys describes large asphalt deposits near Neufchatel, proposing its use for various applications—particularly in constructing airtight granaries and protecting Parisian watercourses from dirt and filth, which then contaminated the water supply. He also praised asphalt's suitability for creating level, durable palace terraces, though the idea of using it for street terraces wasn't considered by Parisians of that era. Despite its promise, asphalt was largely overlooked in France until the 1830 revolution, after which interest surged. By the 1830s, asphalt was widely adopted for pavements, flat roofs, and cistern linings; similar uses were noted in England. Europe's rapid embrace of asphalt followed discoveries of natural deposits in France at Osbann (Bas-Rhin), the Parc (l'Ain), and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome), although it could also be synthesized. A notable early application in France was the laying of 24,000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835.
text_ai_humanized: In 1553, Pierre Belon published Observations in which he said of pissasphalto that "in Turkey, the pitch for pitching ships, which they call naval pitch, is made of pissasphaltos, which the citizens of Dubrovnik[Clarification needed] bring into Venice, where merchants sell it by the barrel. " Then, in 1621, "an English traveller, Fynes Moryson, stated that it was with pitch from Shetland that the Scots 'pitch and calke their ships'. "An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France. "The streets of the French capital were first paved with asphalt in 1854, on the rue Bergère. " An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine reports, "... M. Eyrini, in 1621, speaks of the vast quantities of asphaltum or bitumen found near Neufchatel, 'the use whereof is so highly valued, for being put under ground, as it quickly becomes the hardest stone that is, and is (therefore) found very useful for making of granaries, the storage of cornes, and other uses, that require to be free from water and dampness. '" But it can further be found suggested, by Dr George Christian Wittstein, that Eyrini was primarily concerned with building an underground air- and waterolar tight granary, "the idea of running it into terraces (i. e. 'Terrace-streets') in Paris, under a notion that it will prove a defence from dirt and dust, for which he particularly recommends it, never occurred to the Parisian Police of that day. " But it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830. In the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns. " Its rise coincided with the ascendance of the bagel in early 19th Century France. "In the 1830s there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used 'for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns. ' One of the first uses in France was the laying of about 24, 000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835. " Europe has since become a leader in the development of asphalt technology. Spread of the bicycle and automobiles propelled increased usage of paved roads. Asphalt largely became ubiquitous as a paving material on an international scale after the 1920s. Until the 20th century, cobblestone and granite setts were extensively used for paving roads and lanes, fig Still in 1621, it was referred to the Parliament: "Monsieur d Eyrinys, who had made great mines of it discovered near Neufchatel, presented a statement to the King and the Parliament describing means of making it suitable for many uses—particularly as an airtight storage for grain, a waterproof lining for bridges and fountains, the stoppage of leaks, a remedy for flatulence, and so on. "He proposed that the Seine and all the streets of Paris be covered with it. Observing that "the ground was covered with thick asphalte, which professors tried to drill with iron instruments, heated, as the story goes, with the residue of the oil, as cold nor sun nor dew could pierce it nor make waterproof any leaks", he gave warning against its patenting, since its "virtue is not known". He confirmed Judia' idea of its "divine gift", as "it splits into layers and gives rise to such smooth and beautiful shading that people resort to it for centuries. Despite this, it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830. In the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns". Its first widespread use occurred in France, with the first 'tarmac' being passed over or poured onto the Place de la Concorde in 1835. But the important discovery of natural asphalt deposits in France at Osbann (Bas-Rhin), the Parc (l'Ain) and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome) which could be mined, as well as manufactured, led to a more rapid development of asphalt as paving material. This material had already been in use for some years in other countries. In England and Switzerland it had more commonly been used for roofing.

text_human: As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. There were fewer invasions of the eastern section of the empire; most occurred in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, the traditional enemy of Rome, lasted throughout most of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire was marked by closer relations between the political state and Christian Church, with doctrinal matters assuming an importance in eastern politics that they did not have in Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law; the first effort—the Theodosian Code—was completed in 438. Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, under Belisarius (d. 565). The conquest of Italy was not complete, as a deadly outbreak of plague in 542 led to the rest of Justinian's reign concentrating on defensive measures rather than further conquests. At the emperor's death, the Byzantines had control of most of Italy, North Africa, and a small foothold in southern Spain. Justinian's reconquests have been criticised by historians for overextending his realm and setting the stage for the Muslim conquests, but many of the difficulties faced by Justinian's successors were due not just to over-taxation to pay for his wars but to the essentially civilian nature of the empire, which made raising troops difficult.
text_ai_base: While new kingdoms emerged in Western Europe, the Eastern Roman Empire remained largely intact and saw an economic resurgence lasting into the early 7th century. The empire faced fewer invasions, with most occurring in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, Rome's traditional adversary, persisted through much of the 5th century. In the Eastern Empire, politics intertwined closely with the Christian Church, making doctrinal issues more prominent in eastern politics than in Western Europe. Significant legal advancements included the codification of Roman law; the Theodosian Code was completed in 438. Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565) undertook another major legal compilation—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian spearheaded the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, led by his general Belisarius (d. 565). However, Italy was not fully conquered, as a devastating plague outbreak in 542 shifted Justinian's focus to defense instead of further expansion. By the end of his reign, Byzantines controlled much of Italy, North Africa, and a small portion of southern Spain. Historians have criticized Justinian’s reconquests for overextending his realm and paving the way for Muslim conquests, yet the challenges faced by his successors stemmed not only from heavy taxation to fund his wars but also from the empire's civilian nature, which made troop recruitment difficult.
text_ai_humanized: The Eastern Roman Empire remained mostly intact and its economic life became more robust again, although the empire was much less extensive than the Western Empire had been. There were fewer invasions of the eastern Roman Empire; most happened in the Balkans. Peace had been made with Persia, Rome's traditional enemy, after the Roman defeat in 363; throughout most of the 5th century, most of the Eastern Roman Empire had remained relatively peaceful compared with the Western Empire. The 5th century saw the church and the state tied closely together in the eastern half of the empire, as religious uniformity became an important part of having a unified state.[108] The beginnings of efforts to force the Eastern Roman state to conform to orthodox Christianity began during this period as well, leading to the end of the ancient institution of the games in that part of the empire.[109] Other transformations of the 5th century were the ongoing codification of Roman law; the first part—the Codex Theodosianus (Theodosian Code) – came out in 438. Another compilation—the Codex Justinianus (Justinian Code) – was completed in 529.[110] Justinian (r. 527–565) is best remembered for his reconquest of North Africa and the invasion and partial reconquest of Italy.[111] Belisarius (d. 565), the general responsible for much of these conquests, also quelled the Nika riots—caused by factions within the circus in 532—in which nearly half of Constantinople was burned.[112] Justinian presided over the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople as well the compilation of Roman law into the Corpus Juris Civilis (The Body of Civil Law). At the time of Justinian's death, Byzantine control in Italy extended northward to the southern edges of the Po Valley, although the Byzantines were still making attempts to push farther north.[111] After Justinian's death, the Byzantines had control of most of Italy, North Africa, and a small outpost in southern Spain. All these efforts to reconquer the Mediterranean west were ultimately undone by the coming of the plague, which largely stopped expansion in the reign of Justinian to focus on domestic affairs.[113] Historians have argued that Justinian's reconquests were transient and that the most important lasting legacy was the codification of Roman law that was done under the direction of Justinian.[111] Another argument is that Italy was severely affected by the fighting during Justinian's reconquest, and that the effort to reclaim the western Roman provinces[clarification needed] redirected the east's energies, providing an opportunity for other threats to the empire to materialise. Further, efforts to force the Corpus Juris Civilis on the east proved deeply divisive in terms of policy.[114] Finally, many of the problems that the eastern emperors faced were due to the essential civilian nature of the empire, which made raising troops very difficult.[citation needed][115]

text_human: American comic books have adopted the character type for stories of their own like the mutant-villain Silver Samurai of Marvel Comics. The design of this character preserves the samurai appearance; the villain is “Clad in traditional gleaming samurai armor and wielding an energy charged katana” (Buxton, 2013). Not only does the Silver Samurai make over 350 comic book appearances, the character is playable in several video games, such as Marvel Vs. Capcom 1 and 2. In 2013, the samurai villain was depicted in James Mangold’s film The Wolverine. Ten years before the Wolverine debuted, another film helped pave the way to ensure the samurai were made known to American cinema: A film released in 2003 titled The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise, is inspired by the samurai way of life. In the film, Cruise’s character finds himself deeply immersed in samurai culture. The character in the film, “Nathan Algren, is a fictional contrivance to make nineteenth-century Japanese history less foreign to American viewers”.(Ravina, 2010) After being captured by a group of samurai rebels, he becomes empathetic towards the cause they fight for. Taking place during the Meiji Period, Tom Cruise plays the role of US Army Captain Nathan Algren, who travels to Japan to train a rookie army in fighting off samurai rebel groups. Becoming a product of his environment, Algren joins the samurai clan in an attempt to rescue a captured samurai leader. “By the end of the film, he has clearly taken on many of the samurai traits, such as zen-like mastery of the sword, and a budding understanding of spirituality”. (Manion, 2006)

Released in 2003, the film, The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise draws heavily from the samurai lifestyle and culture. Cruise plays an American military advisor who embraces the samurai culture when he gets captured by samurai rebels in 19th-century Japan (Buxton, 2013). The character Nathan Algren was designed to make nineteenth-century Japanese history palatable and comprehensible to the American audience (Ravina, 2010). Captured by the samurai rebels, and under developing Stockholm Syndrome, Cruise's character begins to sympathize with his captors and befriend them. Taking place in the Meiji Period, Cruise plays US Army Captain Nathan Algren, who is hired to help an inexperienced army put down samurai rebels in Japan. Aftervintegrating into his new surroundings Algren soon becomes part of the samurai in order to help rescue a captured leader. By the end of the film, he has clearly adopted many samurai traits, such as zen-like sword mastery and a budding understanding of spirituality (Manion, 2006).

text_human: The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, the Celtic peoples living north of the Douro river during the last millennium BC, in a region largely coincidental with that of the Iron Age local Castro culture. Galicia was incorporated into the Roman Empire at the end of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, being turned into a Roman province in the 3rd century AD. In 410, the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with its capital in Braga (Portugal) which was incorporated into that of the Visigoths in 585. In 711, the Arabs invaded the Iberian Peninsula, taking the Visigoth kingdom, but soon in 740 Galicia was incorporated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias. During the Middle Ages, the kingdom of Galicia was occasionally ruled by its own kings, but most of the time it was leagued to the kingdom of Leon and later to that of Castile, while maintaining its own legal and customary practices and personality. From the 13th century on, the kings of Castile, as kings of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór, whose attributions passed to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galiza from the last years of the 15th century. The Governor also presided the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and government body. From the 16th century, the representation and voice of the kingdom was held by an assembly of deputies and representatives of the cities of the kingdom, the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, an institution which was forcibly discontinued in 1833 when the kingdom was divided into four administrative provinces with no legal mutual links. During the 19th and 20th centuries, demand grew for self-government and for the recognition of the personality of Galicia, a demand which led to the frustrated Statute of Autonomy of 1936, and to the Statute of Autonomy of 1981, currently in force.
text_ai_base: Galicia, initially settled during the Middle Paleolithic era, derives its name from the Gallaeci, a Celtic tribe that resided north of the Douro River in the last millennium BC, an area reflecting the Iron Age Castro culture. At the end of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, Galicia became part of the Roman Empire, and by the 3rd century AD, it was a Roman province. In 410, the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with Braga, Portugal, as its capital, later absorbed by the Visigoths in 585. In 711, the Arabs conquered the Iberian Peninsula, including the Visigothic kingdom. However, by 740, Galicia was integrated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias. During the Middle Ages, while sometimes having its own rulers, Galicia was often linked to the kingdom of Leon and subsequently Castile, preserving its legal customs and unique identity. From the 13th century, the Castilian kings, as rulers of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór. These duties eventually shifted to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galicia in the late 15th century. The Governor led the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and governing body. From the 16th century, Galicia's assembly of city representatives, known as the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, voiced the kingdom's interests until it was dissolved in 1833 when Galicia was split into four administrative provinces without legal ties. In the 19th and 20th centuries, there was a growing movement for self-government and recognition of Galicia's distinct identity. This led to the proposed but unrealized Statute of Autonomy in 1936 and the current Statute of Autonomy enacted in 1981.

text_human: Faced with the stripping of their powers, Wu Sangui, later joined by Geng Zhongming and by Shang Kexi's son Shang Zhixin, felt they had no choice but to revolt. The ensuing Revolt of the Three Feudatories lasted for eight years. Wu attempted, ultimately in vain, to fire the embers of south China Ming loyalty by restoring Ming customs, ordering that the resented queues be cut, and declaring himself emperor of a new dynasty. At the peak of the rebels' fortunes, they extended their control as far north as the Yangtze River, nearly establishing a divided China. Wu then hesitated to go further north, not being able to coordinate strategy with his allies, and Kangxi was able to unify his forces for a counterattack led by a new generation of Manchu generals. By 1681, the Qing government had established control over a ravaged southern China which took several decades to recover. Manchu Generals and Bannermen were initially put to shame by the better performance of the Han Chinese Green Standard Army, who fought better than them against the rebels and this was noted by Kangxi, leading him to task Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong to lead Green Standard Soldiers to crush the rebels. The Qing thought that Han Chinese were superior at battling other Han people and so used the Green Standard Army as the dominant and majority army in crushing the rebels instead of Bannermen. Similarly, in northwestern China against Wang Fuchen, the Qing used Han Chinese Green Standard Army soldiers and Han Chinese Generals such as Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong as the primary military forces. This choice was due to the rocky terrain, which favoured infantry troops over cavalry, to the desire to keep Bannermen in the reserves, and, again, to the belief that Han troops were better at fighting other Han people. These Han generals achieved victory over the rebels. Also due to the mountainous terrain, Sichuan and southern Shaanxi were also retaken by the Han Chinese Green Standard Army under Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong in 1680, with Manchus only participating in dealing with logistics and provisions. 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen served on the Qing side during the war. 213 Han Chinese Banner companies, and 527 companies of Mongol and Manchu Banners were mobilized by the Qing during the revolt. 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers were used against the Three Feudatories besides 200,000 Bannermen.
text_ai_base: Faced with the loss of their powers, Wu Sangui, later supported by Geng Zhongming and Shang Kexi's son Shang Zhixin, felt compelled to rebel. The resulting Revolt of the Three Feudatories persisted for eight years. Wu's efforts to ignite Ming loyalty in Southern China by reinstating Ming customs, abolishing the resented queues, and proclaiming himself emperor of a new dynasty ultimately failed. At the height of their power, the rebels controlled territory as far north as the Yangtze River, nearly splitting China. However, Wu hesitated to advance further north due to a lack of strategic coordination with his allies, which allowed Kangxi to consolidate his forces for a counterattack led by a new generation of Manchu generals. By 1681, the Qing government regained control over a devastated southern China, which took decades to recover. Initially, the Manchu generals and Bannermen were outperformed by the more effective Han Chinese Green Standard Army, noted by Kangxi, who then assigned Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong to lead these troops against the rebels. The Qing preferred using the Green Standard Army as the main force, believing Han Chinese were better at fighting their fellow Han and reserving Bannermen. In northwestern China, against Wang Fuchen, the Qing also deployed Han Chinese Green Standard Army soldiers and Han generals like Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong as the primary military forces, due to the terrain favoring infantry over cavalry and again favoring Han troops for their effectiveness against other Han. These generals succeeded in defeating the rebels. In the mountainous regions of Sichuan and southern Shaanxi, the Han Chinese Green Standard Army, led by Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong, recaptured territory in 1680, with Manchu involvement mainly in logistics and supplies. During the conflict, the Qing army included 400,000 Green Standard soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen. In all, 213 Han Chinese Banner companies and 527 Mongol and Manchu Banner companies were mobilized by the Qing during the revolt, with 400,000 Green Standard soldiers and 200,000 Bannermen engaged against the Three Feudatories.
text_ai_humanized: Given that their privileges and powers were being revoked, Wu Sangui, later aided by Geng Zhongming and Shang Kexi's son, Shang Zhixin, had little choice but to revolt. The ensuing civil war lasted for eight years. Wu tried to invoke anti-Manchu sentiment by restoring Ming customs, ordering that Ming-style clothing be worn, and even revoking the hated queues in the areas under his control. He also declared himself emperor of a new "Zhou dynasty", in the hope of reviving the Ming dynasty. At the peak of their strength, the three rebels were able to extend their reach as far north as the Yangtze, almost establishing a divided China. However, Wu was not able to coordinate his strategy with his other allies, and he did not press further north, allowing Kangxi to deploy his armies against the three Southern Courts one by one. After their defeat, the southern parts of China, especially Sichuan and the areas around the Yangtze River, were devastated by the war. It would take several decades for these areas to recover.[63] Initially, the Manchus and Bannermen were outmatched by Wu's forces, so the Qing government enlisted the help of the southern Chinese. Kangxi writes in his memoirs:[64] Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong were all Han Chinese. They led the Green Standard soldiers to fight the rebels. The Qing thought that Han Chinese were better at battling and defeating other Han people. Hence they let the Han Chinese lead the Green Standard Army as the primary military force and used the Bannermen as support.[65] In northwestern China against Wang Fuchen, the Qing used Han Chinese soldiers from the Green Standard Army and Han Chinese generals such as Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong to crush the rebels. The Qing put Bannermen on the sidelines since the terrain was unsuitable for cavalry, which Bannermen specialized in, and used Han Chinese as the main force. Sichuan and Southern Shaanxi were retaken by the Han Chinese Green Standard Army under Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong in 1680, with Manchus only participating in dealing with logistics and provisions.[66] 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen served on the Qing side during the war.[64] In the later part of the war, the Qing armies were composed entirely of Han Chinese soldiers and Han Chinese generals.[67] It was Green Standard Army soldiers who entered Taiwan and defeated the Ming loyalist Zheng Keshuang's grandson, receiving Zheng's surrender; the Qing did not allow Bannermen to enter Taiwan. 213 Han companies and 527 Mongol and Manchu companies were mobilized by the Qing against the Three Feudatories, while 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers were mobilized and 200,000 served in the war.[68] Only 146 Bannerman companies from the Eight Banners were mobilized by the Qing during the entire war.[69]

text_human: The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by emigration from Greece. These cities included newly founded colonies such as Antioch, the other cities of the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia (north of Babylon) and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates. These cities retained traditional Greek city state institutions such as assemblies, councils and elected magistrates, but this was a facade for they were always controlled by the royal Seleucid officials. Apart from these cities, there were also a large number of Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai) and Greek villages (komai) which the Seleucids planted throughout the empire to cement their rule. This 'Greco-Macedonian' population (which also included the sons of settlers who had married local women) could make up a phalanx of 35,000 men (out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000) during the reign of Antiochos III. The rest of the army was made up of native troops. Antiochus III the great conducted several vigorous campaigns to retake all the lost provinces of the empire since the death of Seleucus I. After being defeated by Ptolemy IV's forces at Raphia (217), Antiochus III led a long campaign to the east to subdue the far eastern breakaway provinces (212-205) including Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia and Drangiana. He was successful, bringing back most of these provinces into at least nominal vassalage and receiving tribute from their rulers. After the death of Ptolemy IV (204), Antiochus took advantage of the weakness of Egypt to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202-195). He then began expanding his influence into Pergamene territory in Asia and crossed into Europe, fortifying Lysimachia on the hellespont, but his expansion into Anatolia and Greece was abruptly halted after a decisive defeat at the Battle of Magnesia (190 BCE). In the Treaty of Apamea which ended the war, Antiochus lost all of his territories in Anatolia west of the Taurus and was forced to pay a large indemnity of 15,000 talents.
text_ai_base: The expansive Seleucid Empire, like Egypt, was largely controlled by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. This elite, predominantly composed of Greeks from the cities, was strengthened by immigrants from Greece. Such cities included new colonies like Antioch, the cities of the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia (north of Babylon), and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates. Although these cities maintained Greek city-state institutions like assemblies, councils, and elected magistrates, true power remained with the royal Seleucid officials. Beyond these cities, the empire had numerous Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai), and Greek villages (komai), established to solidify their rule. The 'Greco-Macedonian' population, including descendants of settlers who married locals, could field a phalanx of 35,000 men in Antiochos III's reign, out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000, with the remainder composed of native troops. Antiochos III embarked on several aggressive campaigns to reclaim provinces lost since Seleucus I's death. Despite a setback by Ptolemy IV's forces at Raphia in 217, Antiochos III launched a lengthy campaign from 212 to 205 to subdue the eastern provinces—Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia, and Drangiana—successfully bringing them under nominal vassalage. Following Ptolemy IV's death in 204, Antiochos capitalized on Egypt's vulnerability to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202–195). He pushed into Pergamene territory in Asia and moved into Europe, fortifying Lysimachia on the Hellespont. However, his expansion into Anatolia and Greece was abruptly stopped after his defeat at the Battle of Magnesia in 190 BCE. The resulting Treaty of Apamea stripped him of his territories in Anatolia west of the Taurus and imposed a hefty indemnity of 15,000 talents.
text_ai_humanized: The widely-dispersed Seleucid realm was far less stable than Egypt, and the Greco-Macedonian element of the population less dominant. Like Ptolemaic Egypt, the ruling Greco-Macedonian aristocracy remained a largely urban elite, although it was bolstered by influxes of immigrants from the Greek cities. Such cities were new foundations, like Antioch, and the Syrian tetrapolis, or Greek colonies such as Seleucia (to the north of Babylon) and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates, or were local towns which were refounded and settled with Greeks. The Greek cities remained independent, but such independence was on the whole reserved for the Greeks themselves. They were ruled locally by councils (boule), magistrates, and assemblies (ecclesia), but power lay with the ruling royal officials. In addition to the cities, there were also a number of Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai) and Greek villages (komai), set up for the purposes of domination. The Greco-Macedonian portion of the population (including some who had originated with intermarriage between the settlers and local women; but counted as Greek) could be considerable, but never as large as the native populations – in a military parade at Daphnae in the reign of Antiochos III, the phalanx numbered 35,000 men out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000, with the remainder consisting of native troops. Antiochos III (reigned 222–187) launched several aggressive campaigns to retake lost provinces, and to once again compete with Egypt; despite a reversal in 217 when the Seleucids were defeated at Raphia by Ptolemy IV's forces, Antiochos continued his attempts to reclaim the old Achaemenid Persian possessions of Anatolia. His most spectacular success came in the eastern provinces, which had become quite unprofitable to control since the days of Seleucus I: between 212–205 Antiochos mounted an enormous campaign by way of forced and perseverance against Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia, and Drangiana; in the process he returned the old provinces of the Persian Empire to nominal subjecthood, whilst permitting the local satraps an unprecedented degree of autonomy. After the death of Ptolemy IV in 204, Antiochos took advantage of instability in Egypt to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202–195). Despite being heralded as a liberator in several Greek cities in Asia, and having himself named "king of kings" by an assembly at Antioch, his efforts were ultimately unsuccessful. His invasion of Pergamene territory in Asia, and his movement into Europe, where he refounded the city of Lysimachia on the Hellespont, brought Roman interest. Antiochos seems to have lacked the will to oppose the Romans sufficiently, and after an unsuccessful war (the Roman–Syrian War, 192–188), the Treaty of Apamea ended Seleucid expansion in Asia Minor and Anatolia; he was forced to pay a heavy indemnity of 15,000 talents.

text_human: It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began. The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (formerly known as the RPI Glee Club), established in 1873 is perhaps the oldest known collegiate a cappella group.[citation needed] However the longest continuously-singing group is probably The Whiffenpoofs of Yale University, which was formed in 1909 and once included Cole Porter as a member. Collegiate a cappella groups grew throughout the 20th century. Some notable historical groups formed along the way include Princeton University's Tigertones (1946), Colgate University's The Colgate 13 (1942), Dartmouth College's Aires (1946), Cornell University's Cayuga's Waiters (1949) and The Hangovers (1968), the University of Maine Maine Steiners (1958), the Columbia University Kingsmen (1949), the Jabberwocks of Brown University (1949), and the University of Rochester YellowJackets (1956). All-women a cappella groups followed shortly, frequently as a parody of the men's groups: the Smiffenpoofs of Smith College (1936), The Shwiffs of Connecticut College (The She-Whiffenpoofs, 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (1951). A cappella groups exploded in popularity beginning in the 1990s, fueled in part by a change in style popularized by the Tufts University Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys. The new style used voices to emulate modern rock instruments, including vocal percussion/"beatboxing". Some larger universities now have multiple groups. Groups often join one another in on-campus concerts, such as the Georgetown Chimes' Cherry Tree Massacre, a 3-weekend a cappella festival held each February since 1975, where over a hundred collegiate groups have appeared, as well as International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and the contemporary commercial a cappella group Rockapella. Co-ed groups have produced many up-and-coming and major artists, including John Legend, an alumnus of the Counterparts at the University of Pennsylvania, and Sara Bareilles, an alumna of Awaken A Cappella at University of California, Los Angeles. Mira Sorvino is an alumna of the Harvard-Radcliffe Veritones of Harvard College where she had the solo on Only You by Yaz.
text_ai_base: The origins of collegiate a cappella are somewhat unclear, but one of the oldest known groups is the Rensselyrics from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, founded in 1873 as the RPI Glee Club.[citation needed] Meanwhile, Yale University's Whiffenpoofs, formed in 1909 and once boasting Cole Porter among its members, are likely the longest continuously-performing ensemble. Collegiate a cappella steadily expanded throughout the 20th century, giving rise to historic groups such as Princeton University's Tigertones (1946), Colgate University's The Colgate 13 (1942), Dartmouth College's Aires (1946), Cornell University's Cayuga's Waiters (1949) and The Hangovers (1968), the University of Maine Steiners (1958), the Columbia University Kingsmen (1949), the Jabberwocks of Brown University (1949), and the University of Rochester YellowJackets (1956). All-women groups emerged soon after, often humorously riffing on the men's groups with formations like the Smiffenpoofs of Smith College (1936), The Shwiffs of Connecticut College (The She-Whiffenpoofs, 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (1951). Interest in a cappella surged in the 1990s, thanks in part to stylistic innovations from the Tufts University Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys, who incorporated vocals simulating rock instruments and vocal percussion or "beatboxing." Many larger universities now host multiple groups, and these ensembles frequently participate in on-campus collaborations, such as the Georgetown Chimes’ Cherry Tree Massacre, a three-weekend a cappella festival each February since 1975 featuring over a hundred collegiate groups and highlights like International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and the commercial act Rockapella. Co-ed ensembles have nurtured a range of notable artists, including John Legend from Penn's Counterparts and Sara Bareilles from UCLA's Awaken A Cappella. Mira Sorvino also performed in Harvard's Veritones, showcasing her talent with a solo on "Only You" by Yaz.
text_ai_humanized: The history of modern collegiate a cappella is murky, but organized a cappella groups have been around for over a century. The longest continuously-operating group is probably The Rensselyrics [1] of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, which was founded in 1873 as the RPI Glee Club.[citation needed] The Yale Whiffenpoofs were formed in 1909 and are arguably the best-known group, having been featured on the long-running television show The Sing-Off. Cole Porter was a member of the Whiffenpoofs, and they have retained their ties with the dominant musical theater tradition over the years. Throughout the 20th century a cappella developed a presence on numerous college campuses, with many groups once again having their roots in the traditional college glee club. The Princeton Nassoons date back to 1941, the Colgate 13 to 1942, the Dartmouth Aires to 1946, the MIT Chorallaries to 1946, the Harvard Krokodiloes to 1946, the Cornell University Cayuga's Waiters to 1949, The Madison Project of James Madison University to 1952, the University of Maine Steiners to 1957, the Yale Spizzwinks(?) to 1914, Jabberwocks of Brown University to 1949, the University of Rochester YellowJackets to 1956, and the Georgetown Chimes to 1946. Shortly after their all-male counterparts emerged in their respective schools, all-female ensembles were formed in response, often parodying the names of the original male ensembles. Examples include the Smiffenpoofs (founded in 1936 at Smith College), The Shwiffs (The “She-Whiffenpoofs”) of Connecticut College (founded in 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (founded in 1951). The Aires and Brovertones merged to become the Dartmouth Cords. The exponential growth of a cappella in the 1990s has been attributed to two factors: the contemporaneous emergence of groups that embraced a new style, with vocals imitating electric guitar, trumpet, bass, and even vocal percussion or “beatboxing,” and the publication and access to recorded a cappella music through the website CASA.org run by the Contemporary A Cappella Society. The Tufts Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys (named after the advice columnists) were two of the earliest groups to integrate these new stylistic changes into their repertoires. Most collegiate groups are either all-male or all-female, although some feature both male and female singers. Many combine a light-hearted atmosphere and the styles and music of their times with more traditional and classical pieces that showcase their technical skills. There are numerous longstanding traditions, including many groups that “call-out” new members when they are tapped to the group, a smaller sub-group that persists in many a cappella groups as documented by Mickey Rapkin in his book, Pitched Perfect: The Pursuit of Collegiate A Cappella Glory.[2] There are several recognized historical categories for collegiate a cappella groups, including Christian (such as Carolina Harmony, the oldest Christian group in existence), Jewish, fraternity and sorority (Sweetheart Singers, Hearttohearts, and Acafellas), barbershop (such as Ball in the House), and international (Caius College Cambridge and the Oxford Alternotives). Most of these groups are not collegiate in nature and are more likely to be identified as part of the broader a cappella scene and movement. Many are semi-professional and tour extensively, often performing at private gigs in concert halls and at large a cappella festivals. The Georgetown Chimes, for example, have hosted an annual Cherry Tree Massacre concert for over 100 collegiate a cappella groups over three weekends in February since 1975, with notable performances by International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and commercial a cappella group Rockapella.[3][4] Mainstream pop and rock groups associated with collegiate a cappella include The Whiffenpoofs, the Tufts Beelzebubs, the Yale Spizzwinks(?), the University of Virginia Gentlemen of the College, the Penn University Counterparts, the Harvard Veritones, the Stanford Fleet Street Singers, the Yale Redhot & Blue, the Bowdoin Longfellows, the Tufts University Amalgamates, the Tufts University Turkeys, the Columbia Kingston Kingsmen, the Phillips Academy Brovertones, and the Dartmouth Aires.[citation needed] There are records of notable co-ed groups as well, such as the University of Pennsylvania Cup of Cold Water (founded in 1972 by Mac Silver, Jamie Borja, and Lynne Cohen), the Dartmouth Cords (a co-ed group founded in 1977), and the Harvard Veritones (a co-ed group founded in 1985). Many a cappella groups are associated with notable musicians, including John Legend,[5] Dr. Ramani,[6] Renée Fleming,[7] and many others. For example, Mira Sorvino (an accomplished actress) was a member of the Harvard Veritones and performed a plaintive solo on "Only You" by Yaz.[8] Sara Bareilles, the popular recording artist with a hit 2007 song “Love Song,” started in the UCLA-based co-ed group Awaken A Cappella.[9]

text_human: After a three-year hiatus, a fifth Digimon series began airing on April 2, 2006. Like Frontier, Savers has no connection with the previous installments, and also marks a new start for the Digimon franchise, with a drastic change in character designs and story-line, in order to reach a broader audience. The story focuses on the challenges faced by the members of D.A.T.S. ("Digital Accident Tactics Squad"), an organization created to conceal the existence of the Digital World and Digimon from the rest of mankind, and secretly solve any Digimon-related incidents occurring on Earth. Later the D.A.T.S. is dragged into a massive conflict between Earth and the Digital World, triggered by an ambitious human scientist named Akihiro Kurata, determined to make use of the Digimon for his own personal gains. The English version was dubbed by Studiopolis and it premiered on the Jetix block on Toon Disney on October 1, 2007. Digivolution in Data Squad requires the human partner's DNA ("Digital Natural Ability" in the English version and "Digisoul" in the Japanese version) to activate, a strong empathy with their Digimon and a will to succeed. 'Digimon Savers' also introduces a new form of digivolving called Burst Mode which is essentially the level above Mega (previously the strongest form a digimon could take). Like previously in Tamers, this plot takes on a dark tone throughout the story and the anime was aimed, originally in Japan, at an older audience consisting of late teens and people in their early twenties from ages 16 to 21. Because of that, along with the designs, the anime being heavily edited and localized for western US audiences like past series, and the English dub being aimed mostly toward younger audiences of children aged 6 to 10 and having a lower TV-Y7-FV rating just like past dubs, Studiopolis dubbed the anime on Jetix with far more edits, changes, censorship, and cut footage. This included giving the Japanese characters full Americanized names and American surnames as well as applying far more Americanization (Marcus Damon as opposed to the Japanese Daimon Masaru), cultural streamlining and more edits to their version similar to the changes 4Kids often made (such as removal of Japanese text for the purpose of cultural streamlining). Despite all that, the setting of the country was still in Japan and the characters were Japanese in the dub. This series was the first to show any Japanese cultural concepts that were unfamiliar with American audiences (such as the manju), which were left unedited and used in the English dub. Also despite the heavy censorship and the English dub aimed at young children, some of the Digimon's attacks named after real weapons such as RizeGreymon's Trident Revolver are not edited and used in the English dub. Well Go USA released it on DVD instead of Disney. The North American English dub was televised on Jetix in the U.S. and on the Family Channel in Canada.

text_human: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. Males within Palaeognathae (with the exception of the kiwis), the Anseriformes (with the exception of screamers), and in rudimentary forms in Galliformes (but fully developed in Cracidae) possess a penis, which is never present in Neoaves. The length is thought to be related to sperm competition. When not copulating, it is hidden within the proctodeum compartment within the cloaca, just inside the vent. The digestive system of birds is unique, with a crop for storage and a gizzard that contains swallowed stones for grinding food to compensate for the lack of teeth. Most birds are highly adapted for rapid digestion to aid with flight. Some migratory birds have adapted to use protein from many parts of their bodies, including protein from the intestines, as additional energy during migration.

However, birds like hummingbirds can switch to being ammonotelic, releasing most nitrogenous waste as ammonia. Birds excrete creatine, as opposed to mammals, which excrete creatinine. All waste materials exit through the cloaca, a versatile opening used for expelling waste, mating, and egg-laying. Additionally, many bird species regurgitate food pellets. Certain male birds, including those in Palaeognathae (except kiwis), Anseriformes (except screamers), in rudimentary form in Galliformes, and fully developed in Cracidae, have a penis—absent in Neoaves—which stays hidden inside the proctodeum part of the cloaca when not in use. The bird digestive system is unique, featuring a crop for storage and a gizzard with ingested stones to grind food, compensating for the absence of teeth. Birds are usually adapted for fast digestion to enhance flight efficiency, and some migratory birds even utilize protein from various body parts, including the intestines, as extra energy for migration.

text_human: An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the more privileged upbringing people have, the more successfully they develop their identity. The forming of an adolescent's identity is a crucial time in their life. It has been recently found that demographic patterns suggest that the transition to adulthood is now occurring over a longer span of years than was the case during the middle of the 20th century. Accordingly, youth, a period that spans late adolescence and early adulthood, has become a more prominent stage of the life course. This therefore has caused various factors to become important during this development. So many factors contribute to the developing social identity of an adolescent from commitment, to coping devices, to social media. All of these factors are affected by the environment an adolescent grows up in. A child from a more privileged upbringing is exposed to more opportunities and better situations in general. An adolescent from an inner city or a crime-driven neighborhood is more likely to be exposed to an environment that can be detrimental to their development. Adolescence is a sensitive period in the development process, and exposure to the wrong things at that time can have a major effect on future decisions. While children that grow up in nice suburban communities are not exposed to bad environments they are more likely to participate in activities that can benefit their identity and contribute to a more successful identity development.

Adolescence is a delicate time in the growth process, and negative exposure during this period can impact future choices significantly. While children in suburban communities avoid harmful environments, they are more likely to engage in activities that enhance identity development, leading to more successful outcomes.

text_human: The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", they were not just military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into the empire. Such movements were aided by the refusal of the western Roman elites to support the army or pay the taxes that would have allowed the military to suppress the migration. The emperors of the 5th century were often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho (d. 408), Aspar (d. 471), Ricimer (d. 472), or Gundobad (d. 516), who were partly or fully of non-Roman background. When the line of western emperors ceased, many of the kings who replaced them were from the same background. Intermarriage between the new kings and the Roman elites was common. This led to a fusion of Roman culture with the customs of the invading tribes, including the popular assemblies that allowed free male tribal members more say in political matters than was common in the Roman state. Material artefacts left by the Romans and the invaders are often similar, and tribal items were often modelled on Roman objects. Much of the scholarly and written culture of the new kingdoms was also based on Roman intellectual traditions. An important difference was the gradual loss of tax revenue by the new polities. Many of the new political entities no longer supported their armies through taxes, instead relying on granting them land or rents. This meant there was less need for large tax revenues and so the taxation systems decayed. Warfare was common between and within the kingdoms. Slavery declined as the supply weakened, and society became more rural.[F]
text_ai_base: With the fall of the Roman Empire, Western Europe's political landscape transformed significantly. While the movements of peoples during this era are often termed "invasions," they were not merely military campaigns but involved entire populations migrating into the empire. These migrations were facilitated by western Roman elites' refusal to back the military or pay taxes that would have enabled the army to hinder these movements. In the 5th century, emperors were frequently under the sway of military leaders like Stilicho, Aspar, Ricimer, and Gundobad—figures who were wholly or partly of non-Roman descent. When the line of western emperors ended, many kings who took their place shared these backgrounds. Intermarriage between these new kings and Roman elites became common, leading to a blending of Roman culture with the customs of the tribes, such as popular assemblies that provided free male tribal members with more political voice than typical in the Roman state. The material culture left behind by Romans and invaders shows similarities, with tribal artifacts often modeled after Roman ones. Additionally, the intellectual culture of the new kingdoms drew heavily from Roman traditions. However, a notable change was the gradual decline in tax revenue for these new political entities. Many stopped funding their armies through taxes, instead granting them land or rents, reducing the need for large-scale taxation systems, which subsequently deteriorated. Warfare was rampant both between and within these kingdoms. As the supply diminished, slavery decreased, and life grew more rural.
text_ai_humanized: During this period, the political structure of western Europe changed. While the peoples who moved into the Empire during this period are often described as "invaders", they were not simply military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into the empire. These movements were aided by the refusal of the western ruling classes to support the army or pay the taxes that would have allowed the military to suppress the migrations. The emperors of the 5th century were often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho , Aspar , Ricimer , and Gundobad , who were at least partially from the non-Roman peoples and after the deposition of the last western emperor, a series of kings took over in the western provinces. There was a high degree of contact between the kings and the Roman elites, as well as the two cultures blending together, rather than a sudden replacement of one culture with another. Synthesis was a longstanding tradition in the Roman state, due to the widespread dissimilarity of the cultures within the empire . Many of the new kings and rulers had been or were Roman military officers already, and there were many cases of intermarriage between Roman and non-Roman families. This led to a blending of cultures, which included the popular assemblies that allowed free male members of the tribe more say in political matters than had been usual in the Roman state. Artefacts left by the Romans and the invaders are often similar, with tribal items often being obviously modelled on Roman objects. Likewise, much of the intellectual culture of the new kingdoms was also based on Roman intellectual traditions. An important difference was the gradually declining tax revenue available to the new rulers. Many of the new polities no longer provided their armies with tax revenues, instead allocating land or rents as the means of supporting troops, thus causing the soldiery to become an increasingly land-owning class, doing away with the need for large taxes. This also, of course, reduced the need for a large slave-owning class supporting intricate taxation systems. Warfare was common between and within the kingdoms. Slavery declined as the supply waned .

text_human: On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for new Arab and Jewish states and also specified an area of Jerusalem and its environs which was to be administered by the UN under an international regime. The end of the British Mandate for Palestine was set for midnight on 14 May 1948. That day, David Ben-Gurion, the executive head of the Zionist Organization and president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared "the establishment of a Jewish state in Eretz Israel, to be known as the State of Israel," which would start to function from the termination of the mandate. The borders of the new state were not specified in the declaration. Neighboring Arab armies invaded the former Palestinian mandate on the next day and fought the Israeli forces. Israel has since fought several wars with neighboring Arab states, in the course of which it has occupied the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (1956–57, 1967–82), part of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), Gaza Strip (1967–2005; still considered occupied after 2005 disengagement) and the Golan Heights. It extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank. Efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict have not resulted in peace. However, peace treaties between Israel and both Egypt and Jordan have successfully been signed. Israel's occupation of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem is the world's longest military occupation in modern times.[note 2]
text_ai_base: On November 29, 1947, the United Nations General Assembly proposed the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This plan outlined borders for separate Arab and Jewish states and designated Jerusalem and its surrounding area to be governed by the UN under an international regime. The British Mandate for Palestine was scheduled to end at midnight on May 14, 1948. On that very day, David Ben-Gurion, head of the Zionist Organization and president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, proclaimed the creation of a Jewish state in Eretz Israel, named the State of Israel, to become effective at the mandate's end. The declaration did not detail the new state's borders. The following day, neighboring Arab armies invaded the former mandate, engaging Israeli forces. Since then, Israel has fought multiple wars with neighboring Arab countries and has occupied areas including the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (1956–57, 1967–82), parts of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), the Gaza Strip (1967–2005, still considered occupied post-2005 disengagement), and the Golan Heights. Israel extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not to the West Bank. Attempts to solve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict have yet to achieve peace, although Israel has signed successful peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan. Israel's control over Gaza, the West Bank, and East Jerusalem is the longest ongoing military occupation in modern history.
text_ai_humanized: The United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan (Resolution 181) as a Plan of Partition with Economic Union for Mandatory Palestine. On 29 November 1947, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Plan of Partition (Resolution 181) regarding the future government of Palestine, which recommended the creation of independent Arab and Jewish States and a Special International Regime in the city of Jerusalem placed under the sovereignty of no state, which would be administered by the United Nations.[69][70] The British mandate was set to expire on 1 August 1948, but the British Government announced on 14 May 1948: "His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom will cease to be responsible for the administration of Palestine from midnight 14 May 1948." 12 minutes after the cessation of the British Mandate for Palestine at midnight on 14 May 1948, the leader of the Zionist Organization in Palestine (the Jewish Agency), and later first prime minister of Israel[71][72] David Ben-Gurion proclaimed the State of Israel.[73][74] The borders of the new state were not specified in the declaration.[75] Neighboring Arab states invaded the former Palestinian mandate on the next day and fought the Israeli forces.[76] Since then Israel has fought several wars with neighbouring Arab states,[77] in the course of which it has occupied the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (from 1956 to 1957 and 1967 to 1982), part of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), Gaza Strip (1967–2005, still considered occupied after 2005 disengagement) and the Golan Heights. It extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank.[78][79] Israel's occupation of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem is the longest military occupation in modern times.[80] Efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict have not resulted in peace. However, peace treaties between Israel and both Egypt and Jordan have been signed.[81][82][83]

text_human: Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming a Seventh Coalition, which ultimately defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in June. The Royal Navy then thwarted his planned escape to the United States in July, so he surrendered to the British after running out of other options. The British exiled him to the remote island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic. His death in 1821 at the age of 51 was received with shock and grief throughout Europe. In 1840, a million people witnessed his remains returning to Paris, where they still reside at Les Invalides.

text_human: Since annelids are soft-bodied, their fossils are rare. Polychaetes' fossil record consists mainly of the jaws that some species had and the mineralized tubes that some secreted. Some Ediacaran fossils such as Dickinsonia in some ways resemble polychaetes, but the similarities are too vague for these fossils to be classified with confidence. The small shelly fossil Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago, has been classified by some authors as an annelid, but by others as a cnidarian (i.e. in the phylum to which jellyfish and sea anemones belong). Until 2008 the earliest fossils widely accepted as annelids were the polychaetes Canadia and Burgessochaeta, both from Canada's Burgess Shale, formed about 505 million years ago in the early Cambrian. Myoscolex, found in Australia and a little older than the Burgess Shale, was possibly an annelid. However, it lacks some typical annelid features and has features which are not usually found in annelids and some of which are associated with other phyla. Then Simon Conway Morris and John Peel reported Phragmochaeta from Sirius Passet, about 518 million years old, and concluded that it was the oldest annelid known to date. There has been vigorous debate about whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusc or an annelid. Polychaetes diversified in the early Ordovician, about 488 to 474 million years ago. It is not until the early Ordovician that the first annelid jaws are found, thus the crown-group cannot have appeared before this date and probably appeared somewhat later. By the end of the Carboniferous, about 299 million years ago, fossils of most of the modern mobile polychaete groups had appeared. Many fossil tubes look like those made by modern sessile polychaetes , but the first tubes clearly produced by polychaetes date from the Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago.
text_ai_base: Annelids have soft bodies, making their fossil record sparse. Polychaetes' fossils primarily consist of the mineralized tubes some species secreted and the jaws they possessed. Some Ediacaran fossils, such as Dickinsonia, resemble polychaetes in certain aspects, but the similarities are too ambiguous to confidently classify them as annelids. The small shelly fossil Cloudina, dating from 549 to 542 million years ago, has been variably classified as an annelid or a cnidarian (the phylum including jellyfish and sea anemones). Until 2008, the earliest widely accepted annelid fossils were the polychaetes Canadia and Burgessochaeta from Canada's Burgess Shale, formed roughly 505 million years ago during the early Cambrian. Myoscolex, found in Australia and slightly older than the Burgess Shale, may also be an annelid but lacks certain typical annelid features while exhibiting traits linked to other phyla. Later, Simon Conway Morris and John Peel reported Phragmochaeta from Sirius Passet, about 518 million years old, concluding it was the oldest known annelid. Debates have persisted over whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusk or an annelid. Polychaetes underwent diversification in the early Ordovician, approximately 488 to 474 million years ago, marking when the first annelid jaws appeared. This suggests the crown group emerged post-Ordovician. By the end of the Carboniferous, around 299 million years ago, fossils of most modern mobile polychaete groups had emerged. Though many fossil tubes resemble those produced by contemporary sessile polychaetes, the first unequivocal polychaete tubes date from the Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago.
text_ai_humanized: Since annelids are soft-bodied, their fossils are rare. Polychaetes' fossil record consists chiefly of the calcareous tubes that some of the species secreted and the jaws that some had.[20] Some Ediacaran fossils such as Dickinsonia appear to some eyes rather like polychaetes,[22] but these similarities are not sufficiently precise to support a close relationship.[20] The small shelly fossil Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago at the end of the Ediacaran, has been classified by some authors as an annelid and by others as a cnidarian (jellyfish, sea anemones, etc.).[23] Until 2008, the oldest widely accepted annelid fossils were polychaetes from the early Cambrian, about 518 million years ago. There were several good specimens from the Burgess Shale, about 505 million years ago in the middle Cambrian.[20] There have been reports of annelid fossils from the Sirius Passet, which is about 518 million years old; however, these fossils are poorly preserved, and it is difficult to tell whether they are really annelids.[22] Myoscolex, from Australia's Emu Bay Shale, about 515 million years old, appears on close examination to share some features with modern annelids but lacks others and has features not found in any living annelid. Simon Conway Morris described over 1,130 fossil specimens of polychaetes in the Burgess Shale and another 49 species in the Early Ordovician (about 488 to 474 million years ago) Soom Shale.[22] Later, Conway Morris and John Peel described Phragmochaeta from the early Cambrian Sirius Passet as the oldest known annelid.[24] Cotton and Lewis[25] reported a probably polychaete from Australia two or three million years older than Phragmochaeta. In 2008, a new polychaete fossil with biomineralised plates was reported in Australia, named as Canadia spinosa, from the same type as the Burgess Shale Canadia worms. There is continuing debate about whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusc or annelid.[21][26] Polychaetes diversified in the early Ordovician period, 488 to 474 million years ago, when the first jawed forms appeared.[20] On the other hand, fossils of most of the groups that formed the crown group of modern annelids, including both mobile and tube-forming polychaetes and the earliest oligochaetes (in freshwater in this period), all appeared by the end of the Carboniferous, about 299 million years ago. Many fossil tubes look like those of modern tube-dwelling polychaetes:[20] the earliest such fossils are Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago, and there is a gap after them until the appearance of Serpula in the Early Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago. However, it is difficult to tell whether tube fossils were produced by annelids, since similar tubes were produced in the Cambrian period by some pogonophorans.[21]

text_human: Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served the function of an Islamic centre for spiritual learning. "The goal of all knowledge and in particular, of the spiritual sciences is knowledge of God." Religion, for the most part, determines the significance and importance of each science. As İnalcık mentions: "Those which aid religion are good and sciences like astrology are bad." However, even though mathematics, or studies in logic were part of the madrasa's curriculum, they were all centred around religion. Even mathematics had a religious impulse behind its teachings. "The Ulema of the Ottoman medreses held the view that hostility to logic and mathematics was futile since these accustomed the mind to correct thinking and thus helped to reveal divine truths" – key word being "divine". İnalcık also mentions that even philosophy was only allowed to be studied so that it helped to confirm the doctrines of Islam." Hence, madaris – schools were basically religious centres for religious teachings and learning in the Ottoman world. Although scholars such as Goffman have argued that the Ottomans were highly tolerant and lived in a pluralistic society, it seems that schools that were the main centres for learning were in fact heftily religious and were not religiously pluralistic, but centred around Islam. Similarly, in Europe "Jewish children learned the Hebrew letters and texts of basic prayers at home, and then attended a school organised by the synagogue to study the Torah." Wiesner-Hanks also says that Protestants also wanted to teach "proper religious values." This shows that in the early modern period, Ottomans and Europeans were similar in their ideas about how schools should be managed and what they should be primarily focused on. Thus, Ottoman madaris were very similar to present day schools in the sense that they offered a wide range of studies; however, these studies, in their ultimate objective, aimed to further solidify and consolidate Islamic practices and theories.
