The ultimate aim was the knowledge of God, with religion dictating the importance of each science. İnalcık notes: "Those which aid religion are good, and sciences like astrology are bad." Although logic and mathematics were part of the curriculum, they were taught with a religious focus, as understanding them was seen as a way to uncover divine truths. İnalcık also observes that even philosophy was studied to affirm Islamic doctrines. Thus, madaris were essentially religious centers for Islamic teachings in the Ottoman era. While scholars like Goffman suggest that the Ottomans were tolerant and lived in a diverse society, the schools were firmly rooted in Islam, not religious pluralism. Similarly, in Europe, Jewish children learned Hebrew prayers at home and studied the Torah at synagogue-organized schools. Wiesner-Hanks notes that Protestants also emphasized teaching "proper religious values." This reflects a commonality between Ottoman and European approaches to education in the early modern period, focusing on religious foundations. Ottoman madaris offered diverse studies, much like contemporary schools, but aimed to reinforce Islamic beliefs and practices.

Protestant Catholicism also transmitted proper religious values according to Wiesner-Hanks. text_human: The second Digimon series is direct continuation of the first one, and began airing on April 2, 2000. Three years later, with most of the original DigiDestined now in high school at age fourteen, the Digital World was supposedly secure and peaceful. However, a new evil has appeared in the form of the Digimon Emperor (Digimon Kaiser) who as opposed to previous enemies is a human just like the DigiDestined. The Digimon Emperor has been enslaving Digimon with Dark Rings and Control Spires and has somehow made regular Digivolution impossible. However, five set Digi-Eggs with engraved emblems had been appointed to three new DigiDestined along with T.K. and Kari, two of the DigiDestined from the previous series. This new evolutionary process, dubbed Armor Digivolution helps the new DigiDestined to defeat evil lurking in the Digital World. Eventually, the DigiDestined defeat the Digimon Emperor, more commonly known as Ken Ichijouji on Earth, only with the great sacrifice of Ken's own Digimon, Wormmon. Just when things were thought to be settled, new Digimon enemies made from the deactivated Control Spires start to appear and cause trouble in the Digital World. To atone for his past mistakes, Ken joins the DigiDestined, being a DigiDestined himself, with his Partner Wormmon revived to fight against them. They soon save countries including France and Australia from control spires and defeat MaloMyotismon (BelialVamdemon), the digivolved form of Myotismon (Vamdemon) from the previous series. They stop the evil from destroying the two worlds, and at the end, every person on Earth gains their own Digimon partner.

This new evolutionary process, called Armor Digivolution, helps the DigiDestined combat the evil in the Digital World. The team eventually defeats the Digimon Emperor, who is actually Ken Ichijouji on Earth, but this victory comes at the cost of Ken's Digimon partner, Wormmon. Once things seem calm, new Digimon enemies formed from the deactivated Control Spires start causing chaos in the Digital World. Ken, seeking redemption, joins the DigiDestined with his revived partner Wormmon to fight these new threats. Together, they save countries like France and Australia from the influence of Control Spires and defeat MaloMyotismon (BelialVamdemon), Myotismon’s digivolved form from the previous series. Ultimately, they prevent destruction in both worlds, and by the end, everyone on Earth gains their own Digimon partner.
text_ai_humanized: As the second Digimon series, it moved forward one generation from the previous Digimon games. The series began airing in Japan on April 2, 2000. It features a new team of DigiDestined who join a few returning characters (T.K. and Kari) from the first series, travelling back and forth between the Human and Digital Worlds to save both from evil. Much like the first season, several changes to the appearance of the Digital World and to the general programme format would be made, though on a heavier scale. Season Two occupies the same continuity as Adventure. Season Three and onwards takes place in an alternate universe. In Digi Destined Go to School, it has been three years since the original DigiDestined battled Apocalymon and most of the kids are now fourteen and attending high school. They believe the Digital World to be safe and contain only good Digimon, until evil returns in the form of the Digimon Emperor (Digimon Kaiser in the Japanese version) who enslaves most of the world. Unlike past foes, the Digimon Emperor is a human like the DigiDestined, and uses Dark Rings and Control Spires to digivolve his captive Digimon and force them to obey his every command. Normal digivolution being impossible, the Digimon bestow five Digi-Eggs with engraved emblems of power on three new DigiDestined, as well as T.K. and Kari from the previous series. These Digi-Eggs allow their chosen DigiDestined to perform a new type of evolution called Armor Digivolution to combat the evil in the Digital World. After destroying the Control Spires, the DigiDestined defeat the Digimon Emperor whose real name is Ken Ichijouji on Earth. However, Ken's Digimon partner Wormmon is killed in the process. Shortly after that, new Digimon enemies created from the deactivated Control Spires by another evil force begin to play havoc on the Digital World. By now Ken has come to regret his actions and joins the DigiDestined with his revived Wormmon to make amends. Together, they save countries like France and Australia among others from the evil power of the Control Spires and defeat Myotismon's digivolved form from the previous series, MaloMyotismon (BelialVamdemon in the Japanese version), fascinating viewers and saving both worlds from destruction. In the final episodes, everyone on Earth has a Digimon partner of their own.

text_human: Critics labelled Gaddafi "despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain and stupid", with western governments and press presenting him as the "vicious dictator of an oppressed people". During the Reagan administration, the United States regarded him as "Public Enemy No. 1" and Reagan famously dubbed him the "mad dog of the Middle East". According to critics, the Libyan people lived in a climate of fear under Gaddafi's administration, due to his government's pervasive surveillance of civilians. Gaddafi's Libya was typically described by western commentators as "a police state". Opponents were critical of Libya's human rights abuses; according to Human Rights Watch (HRW) and others, hundreds of arrested political opponents often failed to receive a fair trial, and were sometimes subjected to torture or extrajudicial execution, most notably in the Abu Salim prison, including an alleged massacre on 29 June 1996 in which HRW estimated that 1,270 prisoners were massacred. Dissidents abroad or "stray dogs" were also publicly threatened with death and sometimes killed by government hit squads. His government's treatment of non-Arab Libyans has also came in for criticism from human rights activists, with native Berbers, Italians, Jews, refugees, and foreign workers all facing persecution in Gaddafist Libya. According to journalist Annick Cojean and psychologist Seham Sergewa, Gaddafi and senior officials raped and imprisoned hundreds or thousands of young women and reportedly raped several of his female bodyguards. Gaddafi's government was frequently criticized for not being democratic, with Freedom House consistently giving Libya under Gaddafi the "Not Free" ranking for civil liberties and political rights.
text_ai_base: Critics described Gaddafi as "despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain, and stupid," with Western governments and media portraying him as the "vicious dictator of an oppressed people." During Reagan's presidency, the United States labeled him "Public Enemy No. 1," and Reagan famously called him the "mad dog of the Middle East." Critics argued that Libyans lived in fear under Gaddafi due to his government's widespread surveillance of civilians. Gaddafi's Libya was often characterized by Western commentators as a "police state." Opponents condemned Libya's human rights abuses; according to Human Rights Watch (HRW) and other organizations, hundreds of political opponents were arrested without guarantee of a fair trial and sometimes faced torture or extrajudicial execution, notably in the Abu Salim prison. HRW reported an alleged massacre there on June 29, 1996, estimating 1,270 prisoners were killed. Dissidents abroad, derogatorily called "stray dogs," were also publicly threatened and sometimes assassinated by government hit squads. Human rights activists criticized the government's treatment of non-Arab Libyans, including native Berbers, Italians, Jews, refugees, and foreign workers, who suffered persecution. Journalist Annick Cojean and psychologist Seham Sergewa reported that Gaddafi and senior officials raped and imprisoned hundreds or thousands of young women and allegedly raped several female bodyguards. Gaddafi's regime faced consistent criticism for lacking democracy, with Freedom House continually rating Libya under Gaddafi as "Not Free" in terms of civil liberties and political rights.
text_ai_humanized: Critics charged that Gaddafi was "despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain, and stupid," and that while claiming to be a man of the people he actually ruled in an authoritarian manner. Western governments and media presented him as the "vicious dictator of an oppressed people." During the Reagan administration, the United States regarded Gaddafi as "public enemy No. 1", and Reagan dubbed him the "mad dog of the Middle East". Critics believed that Gaddafi was prevented from leaving office by his government-imposed fear over dissenters through intimidation, although Gaddafi claimed that he would have retired long ago but for his obligation to liberate the Palestinian people. According to critics, Libyans living under Gaddafi feared the government's pervasive abuse of human rights. Gaddafi's Libya was typically described by western commentators as a "police state". Opponents accused Gaddafi's administration of enacting a number of egregious human rights abuses. According to Human Rights Watch (HRW) and others, hundreds of Libyans were incarcerated for political reasons, with some having been tortured, forced to confess, and sentenced in unfair trials. HRW also criticized laws that criminalized "insulting public officials" or the Libyan state. Some Libyans were arrested and executed for alleged participation in the 1980s attempted anti-Gaddafist coup. Of these, many had gone abroad into exile, but not all of those targeted in this manner were dissidents; Libya's Berber minority faced harsh persecution. Many of those arrested faced torture and other inhumane treatment in the country's jails, while hundreds were executed in extrajudicial killings. Most killings occurred in the notorious Abu Salim prison, including an alleged massacre in June 1996, when, according to HRW, 1,270 prisoners were killed. Dissidents abroad were labelled "stray dogs"; they were publicly threatened with death and sometimes killed by government hit squads. Gaddafi was also condemned for his government's treatment of non-Arab Libyans, in particular native Berbers, but also Italians and Jews, as well as black immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa. Journalist Annick Cojean and psychologist Seham Sergewa reported that Gaddafi and some senior officials raped and illegally imprisoned hundreds or thousands of young women, as well as allegedly several of his female bodyguards. Gaddafi's administration was also criticised for the many basic civil liberties it denied to the Libyan people. Freedom House consistently rated Libya as "Not Free" in its annual Freedom in the World index.

text_human: In surveys made in Europe and the United States, green is the color most commonly associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope and envy. In Europe and the U.S. green is sometimes associated with death (green has several seemingly contrary associations), sickness, or the devil, but in China its associations are very positive, as the symbol of fertility and happiness. In the Middle Ages and Renaissance, when the color of clothing showed the owner's social status, green was worn by merchants, bankers and the gentry, while red was the color of the nobility. The Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci wears green, showing she is not from a noble family; the benches in the British House of Commons are green, while those in the House of Lords are red. Green is also the traditional color of safety and permission; a green light means go ahead, a green card permits permanent residence in the United States. It is the most important color in Islam. It was the color of the banner of Muhammad, and is found in the flags of nearly all Islamic countries, and represents the lush vegetation of Paradise. It is also often associated with the culture of Gaelic Ireland, and is a color of the flag of Ireland. Because of its association with nature, it is the color of the environmental movement. Political groups advocating environmental protection and social justice describe themselves as part of the Green movement, some naming themselves Green parties. This has led to similar campaigns in advertising, as companies have sold green, or environmentally friendly, products.

During the Middle Ages and Renaissance, clothing color indicated social status—green was worn by merchants, bankers, and the gentry, while red signified nobility. The Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci wears green, indicating she is not of noble descent; similarly, benches in the British House of Commons are green, contrasting with the red benches of the House of Lords. Green traditionally signifies safety and permission; a green light means "go," and a green card enables permanent residence in the United States. Political groups advocating for environmental protection and social justice often identify as part of the Green movement, some even calling themselves Green parties. This association has prompted similar themes in advertising, with companies promoting green, environmentally friendly products.

text_human: The novel is cited as a factor in the success of the civil rights movement in the 1960s, however, in that it "arrived at the right moment to help the South and the nation grapple with the racial tensions (of) the accelerating civil rights movement". Its publication is so closely associated with the Civil Rights Movement that many studies of the book and biographies of Harper Lee include descriptions of important moments in the movement, despite the fact that she had no direct involvement in any of them. Civil Rights leader Andrew Young comments that part of the book's effectiveness is that it "inspires hope in the midst of chaos and confusion" and by using racial epithets portrays the reality of the times in which it was set. Young views the novel as "an act of humanity" in showing the possibility of people rising above their prejudices. Alabama author Mark Childress compares it to the impact of Uncle Tom's Cabin, a book that is popularly implicated in starting the U.S. Civil War. Childress states the novel "gives white Southerners a way to understand the racism that they've been brought up with and to find another way. And most white people in the South were good people. Most white people in the South were not throwing bombs and causing havoc ... I think the book really helped them come to understand what was wrong with the system in the way that any number of treatises could never do, because it was popular art, because it was told from a child's point of view."
text_ai_base: The novel is often credited with contributing to the success of the civil rights movement in the 1960s, as it "arrived at the right moment to assist the South and the nation in grappling with the racial tensions" during the rapidly progressing movement. Its publication is so closely tied to the Civil Rights Movement that many analyses of the book and biographies of Harper Lee highlight significant moments in the movement, even though Lee herself was not directly involved. Civil Rights leader Andrew Young remarks that part of the book's impact lies in its ability to "inspire hope amidst chaos and confusion," and its use of racial epithets reflects the realities of the time in which it is set. Young considers the novel "an act of humanity" for illustrating the potential for people to overcome their prejudices. Alabama author Mark Childress compares its influence to that of Uncle Tom's Cabin, a work often credited with igniting the U.S. Civil War. Childress argues that the novel "offers white Southerners a means to understand the racism they grew up with and to seek alternatives. Many white people in the South were good individuals who did not engage in violence or unrest. The book helped them perceive the faults in the system in ways that numerous treatises could not achieve, because it was popular art, narrated from a child's perspective."
text_ai_humanized: The novel has been noted for its poignancy in terms of the era in which it was written. Texts and documentaries on the history of the era often mention Lee's novel only in passing, associating it with the civil rights movement that was gaining momentum at the same time; the novel has been cited as a factor in the movement's success. "To Kill a Mockingbird in some ways set the agenda for the civil rights movement in the 1960s," said Bob Moses, a civil rights leader who worked with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. William T. Going believes the novel, while holding merit, "arrived at the right time to help the South and the nation realize some of the problems that had arisen with the quickening of the civil rights movement." The publication of the novel is considered by many to be intimately connected with the beginnings of the Civil Rights Movement in the U.S., with more written on the book's connections to the movement than on the book itself. Many social, literary, and personal accounts, essays, and books have been written since its publication on the people and events in the book. Biographies of Lee, analyses of the novel, and materials created for the classroom explore many of the lessons that can be taught with the novel, its influence on the movement, and the connection of the Civil Rights Movement to the story; e.g., as in "Critical Insights: To Kill a Mockingbird" (2010) and "Scout, Atticus & Boo: A Celebration of Fifty Years of To Kill a Mockingbird" (2010), which provide extensive commentary and analyses focusing on the book's messages and how they are conveyed. In addition, many authors and readers have commented that the book gives true, memorable, and noteworthy examples and representations to the personal, political, and social issues at play at the time in the U.S. Civil Rights Movement. Civil Rights leader Andrew Young states the book's message is, for many, "the inspiration that pulled us all together. This is history as we need to understand it in America: an inspiration to think differently about everything that went on and continues to go on in the world. The book and its history are understandably an inspiration to anyone who wants to understand the racial injustice of this country." Young said that the book brings out the "best exemplars of the old South," and it represents "not that the Jim Crow system worked for black people but the people best worked it." He also states that the book can teach "hope" to civil rights groups and others of system changes centered on communities "not by chaotic and kicking-in-the-door activities, but by the subject matter of education in self-discipline." He highlights that the book "inspires hope out of the madness and confusion" and its racial slurs are not offensive in the context of the book but rather utilized to loosely represent the era in which the book is set. Young states the novel is "an act of humanity" in showing the possibility of people rising above their prejudices. Alabama-born author Mark Childress said, "To Kill a Mockingbird gives white Southerners a way to understand our history and our racism. It is a novel that is so deeply influential that a prominent librarian recently said 'the book is our conscience; the movie was our black-and-white Bible.' Our Bible as a metaphor seems suitable because, like the Good Book, the story told in Harper Lee’s classic novel changed the world. Nobody could argue with the dark inspiration of Uncle Tom’s Cabin, which is widely believed by historians to have ignited the U.S. Civil War. But To Kill a Mockingbird was about white people. Many whites in the South were good people; they didn’t riot or tweet or dynamite churches. The novel showed them where the holes were in their own system in a way that thousands of treatises and tracts couldn’t do, because it was popular art in which they were the children, not the adults.

text_human: Three and a quarter years after the end of the fifth series, a new sixth series was confirmed by Bandai for the Digimon anime, its official name of the series revealed in the June issue of Shueisha's V Jump magazine being Digimon Xros Wars. It began airing in Japan on TV Asahi from July 6, 2010 onwards. Reverting to the design style of the first four series as well as the plot taking on the younger, lighter tone present in series one, two and four throughout the story. The story follows a boy named Mikey Kudō (Taiki Kudo in Japan) who, along with his friends, ends up in the Digital World where they meet Shoutmon and his Digimon friends. Wielding a digivice known as a Fusion Loader (Xros Loader in Japan), Mikey is able to combine multiple Digimon onto one to enhance his power, Shoutmon being the usual core of the combination, using a technique known as 'DigiFuse' (Digi-Xros in Japan). Forming Team Fusion Fighters (Team Xros Heart in Japan), Mikey, Shoutmon and their friends travel through the Digital World to liberate it from the evil Bagra Army, led by Bagramon(Lord Bagra in English), and Midnight, a shady group led by AxeKnightmon with Nene as a figurehead before joining the Fusion Fighters. The Fusion Fighters also finds themselves at odds with Blue Flare, led by Christopher Aonuma (Kiriha Anouma in Japan). The second arc of Xros Wars was subtitled The Evil Death Generals and the Seven Kingdoms. It saw the main cast reshuffled with a new wardrobe while Angie (Akari in Japan) and Jeremy (Zenjiro in Japan) stay behind in the Human World; thus making Mikey, Christopher and Nene the lead protagonists as they set off to face the Seven Death Generals of the Bagra Army and AxeKnightmon's new pawn: Nene's brother Ewan (Yuu in Japan). A new evolution known as Super Digivolution was introduced at the end of the first arc. The English dub of the series began airing on Nickelodeon on September 7, 2013, which is produced by Saban Brands.
text_ai_base: Over three years after the fifth series ended, Bandai confirmed a new sixth series for the Digimon anime. It was officially named "Digimon Xros Wars" in the June issue of Shueisha's V Jump magazine and began airing on TV Asahi in Japan on July 6, 2010. The series returns to the design style of the first four series and adopts a younger, lighter tone similar to series one, two, and four. The plot revolves around a boy named Mikey Kudō (known as Taiki Kudo in Japan) and his friends, who find themselves in the Digital World where they encounter Shoutmon and other Digimon. Mikey uses a digivice called the Fusion Loader (Xros Loader in Japan) to combine multiple Digimon into one, enhancing his power. Shoutmon usually forms the core of these combinations using a technique called 'DigiFuse' (Digi-Xros in Japan). Mikey, Shoutmon, and their team, known as Team Fusion Fighters (Team Xros Heart in Japan), journey through the Digital World to liberate it from the Bagra Army, led by Bagramon (Lord Bagra in English) and Midnight (an enigmatic group led by AxeKnightmon with Nene as a figurehead before she joins the Fusion Fighters). The team also faces competition from Blue Flare, led by Christopher Aonuma (Kiriha Anouma in Japan). In the second arc titled "The Evil Death Generals and the Seven Kingdoms," the main cast changes outfits while Angie (Akari in Japan) and Jeremy (Zenjiro in Japan) stay in the Human World. This elevates Mikey, Christopher, and Nene to lead protagonists as they confront the Seven Death Generals of the Bagra Army alongside AxeKnightmon's new ally, Nene's brother Ewan (Yuu in Japan). A new evolution, Super Digivolution, is introduced at the end of the first arc. The English dub of the series, produced by Saban Brands, started airing on Nickelodeon on September 7, 2013.
text_ai_humanized: More than three years after the end of the fifth series, Toei Animation announced that there were plans to make a sixth series.[13] In the June issue of Shueisha's V Jump magazine, it was officially named "Digimon Xros Wars" and began streaming in Japan on July 6, 2010 on TV Asahi. Digimon Xros Wars features a return to the art style from the first four series. The story centers on a boy named Mikey Kudō (Taiki Kudo in Japan) who is transported to the Digital World along with his friends, where they meet Shoutmon and other creatures known as Digimon. With the use of a digivice known as a Fusion Loader (Xros Loader in Japan), Mikey can combine multiple Digimon into one, significantly increasing his strength and power, with Shoutmon normally as the center of the DigiFuse process (Digi-Xros in Japan). Mikey, Shoutmon, and their army, Team Fusion Fighters (Team Xros Heart in Japan), travel throughout the Digital World in order to free it from the evil Bagra Army (Bagra Empire in Japan), along with other enigmatic evil organizations like Midnight (an underground evil organization led by AxeKnightmon with Nene as the figurehead until she joins the Fusion Fighters) and the blue army, whose leader is rival Christopher Aonuma (Kiriha Anouma in Japan). In the second arc of the story, "The Evil Death Generals and the Seven Kingdoms" (The Evil Death Generals of the Seven Kingdoms in Japan), the main cast don badges with new attire while Angie (Akari in Japan) and Jeremy (Zenjiro in Japan) remain in the Human World, and Mikey, Christopher, and Nene are the main heroes as they battle over the seven Death Generals of the Bagra Army along with AxeKnightmon's new partner, Nene's younger brother Ewan (Yuu in Japan). While the series' lighter tone resembles that of the first, second, and fourth series, Super Digivolution is introduced at the end of the first arc. The official English dub of the series began on September 7, 2013, on Nickelodeon under the title Digimon Fusion, produced by Saban Brands.[14][15] Lord Bagra is known as Bagramon in the original Japanese version.

text_human: The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools were subscription schools that typically held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students were Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes were taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students were charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and didn't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman who had traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust to obtain a teaching certificate. With the help of an assistant teacher, Mrs. Farley, Raymond was responsible for teaching 50 to 60 students each day out of the 81 students enrolled at the school. Sarah Raymond was paid at a rate of $125 per month, and Mrs. Farley was paid $75 per month. There were no textbooks used in the school. In their place was an assortment of books brought in by various emigrants. Sarah quit teaching the following year, but would later become the Madison County superintendent of schools.
text_ai_base: The Montana Territory was established on April 26, 1864, following the passage of the Organic Act by the U.S. Even before it was officially designated as a territory, families settling in the area began forming schools. Initially, these were subscription schools, often held in the teacher's home. The first formal school recorded was in 1862 at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley, where classes included children of Fort Owen employees and Indian children. The school term began in early winter and ended by February 28, with Mr. Robinson as the instructor. In 1863, Thomas Dimsdale started another subscription school in Virginia City, charging students $1.75 per week. In 1864, the inaugural session of the Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly took place. The first legislature allowed counties to levy taxes for schools, laying the groundwork for public education. Madison County was the first to utilize these taxes, establishing the first public school in Virginia City in 1886. Though scheduled to open in January 1866, severe weather delayed its start until March. The school year continued through summer, ending on August 17. Among the first teachers was 25-year-old Sarah Raymond, who had arrived in Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. She became a certified teacher after passing a test at home and paying a $6 fee in gold dust for her teaching certificate. Assisted by Mrs. Farley, Raymond taught 50 to 60 students daily from an enrollment of 81, receiving a salary of $125 per month, whereas Mrs. Farley earned $75. Without textbooks, classes relied on diverse books brought by various emigrants. Sarah Raymond left teaching the next year but went on to become superintendent of schools for Madison County.
text_ai_humanized: The Organic Act establishing the Montana Territory was passed by the U.S. on April 26, 1864. Even before Montana was officially a territory, schools were being formed by the families that settled there. The first schools began as subscription schools, usually taught in their home by the schoolmistress. The first such school was taught in 1862 by Mr. Robinson in Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley. Classes were for children of the men employed at Fort Owen and the Indian children. The school started in the early winter and finished on February 28. In 1863, Thomas Dimsdale opened a subscription school in Virginia City. He charged his students $1.75 per week. In 1864, the first session of the Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly was held. The first legislature enacted that counties would use taxes for schools. This set up the basis for public schools in Montana. Madison County was the first county to benefit from the school taxes. The first public schools were established in Virginia City in 1886. The county set aside $500 for building maintenance. The schools were set to open on January 1, 1866, but blizzards and storms prevented the teachers from starting until March of the same year. The weather prompted the school to remain open during the whole summer. The session ended on August 17, 1866. One of the first schoolmistresses was Sarah Raymond. She was 25 years old and had come by wagon train in 1865. Both Raymond and a Mrs. Farley held classes. They had 81 enrolled, averaging 50 to 60 students daily. Raymond's salary was $125 while Mrs. Farley earned $75. Raymond passed the test to become a teacher at her home and paid $6 in gold dust for a certificate to teach. The ladies did not have textbooks. Instead the students used books the emigrants had brought with them. Raymond discontinued teaching the following year but later became superintendent of schools for Madison County.

text_human: There were several protests along the torch relay route. Members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, including pro-democracy activist Szeto Wah, waved novelty inflatable plastic Olympic flames, which they said symbolised democracy. They wanted accountability for the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989 and the implementation of democracy in Hong Kong. Political activist and Legislative Council member Leung Kwok-hung (Longhair) also joined the protest, saying "I'm very proud that in Hong Kong we still have people brave enough to speak out." Pro-democracy activists were overwhelmed by a crowd of torch supporters with insults like "running dog," "traitor," "get out!," and "I love the Communist Party." At the same time, about 10 members of the Civil Human Rights Front had orange banners calling for human rights improvements and universal suffrage. Onlookers were saying "Aren't you Chinese?" in Mandarin putonghua as they tried to cover the orange banners with a large Chinese national flag. One woman had an orange sign that said, "Olympic flame for democracy", while a man carried a poster with a tank and the slogan "One world, two dreams". A university student and former RDHK radio host Christina Chan wrapped the Tibetan snow lion flag around her body and later began waving it. Several onlookers heckled Chan, shouting "What kind of Chinese are you?" and "What a shame!" In the end, she and some of the protesters were taken away against their will by the authorities via a police vehicle "for their own protection." Chan is currently[when?] suing the Hong Kong government, claiming her human rights were breached. (case number HCAL139/08)
text_ai_base: Protests occurred along the torch relay route, led by members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, including pro-democracy activist Szeto Wah. They waved novelty inflatable plastic Olympic flames, claiming these symbolized democracy and called for accountability for the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989 and democracy in Hong Kong. Political activist and Legislative Council member Leung Kwok-hung, known as Longhair, also participated, stating, "I'm very proud that in Hong Kong we still have people brave enough to speak out." However, pro-democracy activists faced hostility from torch supporters, who hurled insults like "running dog," "traitor," "get out!," and "I love the Communist Party." Meanwhile, about 10 members of the Civil Human Rights Front unfurled orange banners advocating for human rights improvements and universal suffrage. Some onlookers, speaking Mandarin, confronted them by asking, "Aren't you Chinese?" while attempting to obscure the orange banners with a large Chinese national flag. One woman held an orange sign reading, "Olympic flame for democracy," and a man carried a poster featuring a tank and the slogan "One world, two dreams." Former RDHK radio host and university student Christina Chan wrapped herself in the Tibetan snow lion flag and waved it. She was heckled by several onlookers, who shouted, "What kind of Chinese are you?" and "What a shame!" Ultimately, Chan and some other protesters were taken away by the authorities in a police vehicle, reportedly "for their own protection." Chan is currently suing the Hong Kong government, alleging her human rights were violated (case number HCAL139/08).
text_ai_humanized: Members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, including pro-democracy activist Szeto Wah, shouted their support with novelty inflatable plastic Olympic flames on the relay route, saying they represented democracy and redress of the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989, and for the democracy in Hong Kong. Pro-democracy activist and Legislative Councilor Leung Kwok-hung Longhair participated,[16] saying, "I'm very proud that in Hong Kong we still have people brave enough to speak out."[17] Pro-democracy protestors were taunted and insulted by torch supporters with slogans such as "running dog", "traitor", "get out!", and "I love the Communist Party".[18] Around 10 Civil Human Rights Front unfurled orange banners calling for greater respect of human rights and implementation of universal suffrage – only to have bystanders shout at them in Mandarin, "Aren't you Chinese?" before shielding the orange banner with a large Chinese national flag.[19] A woman held up an orange placard saying "Olympic flame for democracy" and a man held up a poster showing a tank and saying "One world, two dreams".[20] Former RDHK radio host university student Christina Chan draped the Tibetan snow lion flag around her shoulders and waved it. Several bystanders jeered her yelled: "What kind of Chinese are you?" and "What a shame!" Chan and several other demonstrators were bundled into police van for protection.[21][22] Chan is suing the Hong Kong government for violation of her human rights (HCAL139/08).
